HEADLINE: After 43 Fun Years, Ford Takes the T-Bird Away

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 17

 BODY:
With even the Beach Boys going bald and turning gray, perhaps it had to happen: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it will end production this year of its legendary Thunderbird after 43 years of building the car that found a beloved spot in America's cultural history.
Introduced in Detroit's postwar glory period, the Thunderbird went on to win the affection of generations of Americans for its supporting role during their years of young love and adventure. 
 When the Beach Boys crooned about the good times, the Thunderbird was their chosen symbol. "She'll have fun, fun, fun till her daddy takes the T-Bird away," they sang, and America's crush on the Thunderbird deepened as it seemed to capture the melody of the times.
Even as Ford announced that it would stop making the Thunderbird, it held out hope to longtime fans that it might resurrect the model as a small two-seater a few years from now. But a T-Bird return was presented as an if, not a when. For now, Thunderbird devotees could only mourn.
Ford announced the move as part of a broader plan to cut costs, and, in the process, up to 2,500 jobs.
The company also said today that it would discontinue three of the Thunderbird's slow-selling siblings later this year -- the Aerostar van, Probe and the Mercury Cougar, itself a legend to many baby boomers.
The Thunderbird dates to the early 1950's, when a group of Ford engineers drafted plans for a powerful new roadster only to be discouraged from building it by Ford's senior management, which was more interested in family cars. But that attitude among top executives changed completely when General Motors displayed the first Chevrolet Corvette in January, 1953, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York. Moving with a speed that would be unusual today and was extraordinary then, Ford was able to start selling two-seat Thunderbirds in September 1954.
The Thunderbird also had one feature that the Corvette did not: It was the first mass-produced American convertible offered with two roofs, said Eugene M. Nelson, a Ford engineer who is treasurer of the Detroit chapter of the American Road Thunderbird Club. A young couple out on a summer date under cloudless skies could leave the removable hard top behind in the garage. If a storm suddenly blew up, the couple could then pull up the collapsible soft top.
For all its glamour, the two-seat Thunderbird moved slowly out of the showrooms at first, with just 14,190 cars sold in the first year. Ford responded in 1958 by installing a rear seat. Sales climbed to 91,000 in 1960 and hit a peak of 322,517 in 1977. By last year, Thunderbird sales had shrunk to just 80,000.
But the classic Thunderbirds live on. Mr. Nelson said that just two years ago, he was out driving one of his two 1957 Thunderbirds on a sunny Saturday when clouds appeared and it suddenly began to rain. "I'd had the top off, but I had the soft top," Mr. Nelson recalled. "So no problem, I put up the soft top and away we went."
While a press release issued by the company said, "The Thunderbird nameplate will return in a different form in the future," a Ford executive said he was less sure it would be resurrected. "If we do bring it back, it would need to make good business sense," said Jacques A. Nasser, the president of Ford's Automotive Operations.
"We haven't made a decision," Mr. Nasser said, but in several years, Ford might sell a smaller, sporty car carrying the Thunderbird name, one that recalls the T-Bird's roots. "It would be very limited production levels," Mr. Nasser said.
The T-Bird came on the scene in what seemed like a more expansive era, when downsizing was foreign to the national vocabulary and to a mighty United States auto industry.
These days, all of Detroit's grand old names -- and roomy, soft-riding cars -- are struggling. Buick, Mercury, Oldsmobile and even mighty Cadillac have watched their sales slow for years as younger buyers shied away from the gas-hogging road barges driven by their parents -- most recently in favor of enormous, gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles and mini-vans. Even a grand name like Thunderbird no longer seems to be enough of a lifeline.
"What we're really seeing is the continuing trend to more trucklike products," Mr. Nasser said. Discontinuing the Thunderbird and the other models "is really responding to changing consumer tastes."
Discontinuing the Thunderbird and Cougar will shutter part of the Ford factory in Lorain, Ohio, at the cost of about 1,800 jobs. Because 20 other factories nationwide build parts for the vehicles being discontinued, the moves could result in an additional 700 layoffs.
Wall Street's initial reaction was to cheer, not to mourn, the passing of the Thunderbird and other models. Ford stock rose 12.5 cents, to $32.25 in trading yesterday.
"It is an encouraging development," said David M. Garrity, an auto analyst at Smith Barney. "The reason they are doing this is that these products didn't sell."
Ford is likely to take a charge against earnings in the second quarter of up to $150 million to pay for the moves announced today, Mr. Nasser said. Workers who are laid off will receive long-term pay and benefits under their union contracts. For the first 36 weeks of joblessness, workers will receive unemployment benefits and other payments amounting to about 95 percent of their pay. After that, they will receive 100 percent of their pay and report for duty, where they will be assigned community service or job training. When other Ford factories nationwide have openings, the Ohio workers would be high on the list to get those jobs.
Of the models being discontinued, only Thunderbird and Cougar are built in Ohio and will result in layoffs. The Probe, a sports car, is built at a factory in Flat Rock, Mich., that Ford and the Mazda Motor Corporation jointly operate, and workers who built the Probe will instead build additional Mazdas. The Aerostar is built in the same St. Louis factory that builds the popular Ford Explorer, and workers there will switch from building vans to assembling sport utility vehicles.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Production of the Thunderbird will end with the 1997 model line because of slumping sales in recent years. (Ford Motor Company)

HEADLINE: Credit Card Default Rate Is Climbing

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Over the last three years, Americans have received in the mail more than eight billion offers for credit cards. The good news, for the credit card companies, is that millions of people have taken the cards and borrowed more than ever before. The bad news is that a growing number cannot pay their bills, and in recent months the problem has been getting worse.
Many credit card companies recently tightened their lending standards in hopes of avoiding a plague of defaults and late payments. But instead of improving the situation, the latest moves by the credit card companies appear to be rippling negatively through the industry. 
 Yesterday, the Advanta Corporation, one of the fastest-growing credit card issuers, said it would lose money in the first quarter because as much as 7.5 percent of its loans outstanding had gone bad. Advanta, long proud of its independence, has hired an investment banker to consider, among other options, selling the company outright.
Advanta's woes reflect a wider trend. Last week, the American Bankers Association said 3.72 percent of credit card borrowers were behind on their payments in the fourth quarter of last year, up from 3.48 percent in the third quarter. By comparison, 3.34 percent of borrowers were behind on payments in the fourth quarter of 1995. And the problems are likely to get worse before they get better, because credit card borrowing has jumped sharply recently as Americans stretched to finance their Christmas and post-Christmas shopping.
Advanta, while perhaps worse off than many of its competitors, is certainly not alone. Earlier this month, the Banc One Corporation became the latest card issuer forced to bail out bonds backed by its credit card loans, because losses were higher than investors in the bonds had expected.
So now the card companies are preparing to get even tougher on customers, imposing higher interest rates and more fees on card users and providing them with fewer goodies. Advanta and others are starting to raise interest rates on riskier customers. They are increasing "nuisance" fees -- for being late on payments or going over a credit limit. And new credit card offers will have less attractive terms, such as shortened periods in which low introductory "teaser" interest rates apply.
Other credit card companies have been raising fees and cutting back on such giveaways as discounts on new-car purchases or, simply, cash back.
"There is more risk in the system today than a year ago," said Alex W. Hart, Advanta's chief executive. The result, he said, is that lenders will try to make card borrowing more expensive in an attempt to maintain their lucrative profit margins.
For the economy, tighter standards for credit cards may well slow spending by hard-pressed consumers, who have relied heavily on cards in recent years to help maintain their living standards. But if consumers cut back and weaken the economy, then credit card losses are likely to go nowhere but up.
While banks have started to tighten their lending standards, the moves have not yet had any effect on overall borrowing, which has continued to climb at a rapid clip. The Federal Reserve said last week that consumer borrowing in January jumped $8.4 billion, to $1.203 trillion, the largest rise in two years, after increasing $3.8 billion in December.
"It's not going to look pretty for a while," Moshe Orenbuch, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said of the industry's situation. "The streets are littered with companies that have 7 percent loss rates." Mr. Orenbuch said that Advanta, long seen as one of the more sophisticated issuers, seemed to have slipped behind the industry leaders.
In contrast to lenders who have run into trouble by lending to people with past credit problems, Advanta was known for seeking out more affluent customers, mainly offering gold cards with greater credit limits. The company had developed complex computer models intended to sift millions of tidbits of information about prospective customers to find those it believed would run up big balances while still being able to repay them.
But Advanta's experience shows that lending to the affluent can be just as precarious as providing credit cards to low-income customers.
For a few years, Advanta's strategy paid big dividends as it racked up one of the industry's best records. But by the middle of last year, it was hit by rising losses and it slowed its marketing virtually to a halt.
The company had once told analysts that its revenue would rise sharply this quarter as the low introductory rates on its accounts, generally 5.9 percent, increased to almost 15 percent. But Advanta found that too many of its customers simply moved their balances to other cards as soon as the rate increased. So the company did not have as much income as it would have liked to cover the surging losses nor did it employ enough bill collectors to bring in revenue from delinquent accounts.
While Advanta focused on generic cards with low teaser rates, the competition moved to attract customers in other ways, forging links with organizations like alumni associations and creating tie-ins with airline frequent-flier accounts.
The shakeout in credit cards has been going on for several years. Two years ago, several regional banks, like the Mellon Bank Corporation and the Mercantile Bancorporation, had unexpected losses from their card operations. But now even the leading lenders, including Dean Witter, Discover, Banc One and First Chicago NBD are experiencing escalating losses. And yesterday, the Administrative Office of the United States Courts said that a record 1.125 million households had filed for personal bankruptcy last year.
"This is not a typical economic cycle," said Tanya S. Azarchs, a bank analyst with the Standard & Poor's Corporation. "We are in a good economy but consumers have become overleveraged."
As a result of its losses, Advanta said yesterday that it expected to lose $20 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $41 million in the 1996 quarter. It said it expected to be profitable in the second quarter. The shares of Advanta fell $8.50 each, to $31.875, in Nasdaq trading.
The company, based in Horsham, Pa., also said that David A. Brooks, a former Visa executive it had hired two months ago as its chief operating officer, had resigned. Several other top Advanta executives have left in recent months.
Advanta said it had hired BT Wolfensohn, a division of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, to look at "strategic alternatives" for the company. These include a sale or merger, the sale of some divisions, or some sort of joint venture.
Analysts said the current uncertainties would make it difficult for Advanta to sell itself.
"With such a great amount of other assets for sale in the financial services industry, the price Advanta will get would not be to its liking," said Thomas Facciola, an analyst with Lehman Brothers.

HEADLINE: New U.N. Chief Proposes Plans To Slash Waste

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 17

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan today outlined the first detailed, concrete plans for streamlining the United Nations in the hope of polishing its image, solving its financial problems and persuading Congress to authorize spending for about $1 billion in unpaid American dues.
The proposals, the first part of a reform program that Mr. Annan, of Ghana, promised when he took over the job in January, deal mainly with management and organizational matters that fall under the Secretary General's personal authority. They involve shifting some $200 million in bureaucratic spending to development aid, reducing budget and staff levels and reorganizing parts of the New York-based Secretariat. 
 The response was favorable, both from the Clinton Administration and from the most powerful critic of the United Nations in Congress, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Annan called Mr. Helms today to brief him on the proposals.
Mr. Helms's spokesman, Mark Thiessen, called the Secretary General's announcement "a good first step in the right direction." But he said the Senator wants to insure that the staff cuts are real. "We don't want any shell games here," he said.
He added that Mr. Helms would press for conditions to be written into legislation authorizing payment of Washington's arrears to insure that certain goals are met before any money is paid.
Mr. Annan was chosen for the position after Washington vetoed a second term for his predecessor, Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt, saying he had not done enough to promote change at the United Nations.
While the Secretary General defended the changes he announced as "a powerful tool for strengthening the organization," he also made clear his other objectives.
"Congress said it will pay if it gets reform," Mr. Annan said at a news conference here. "We are giving them reform. I hope they will deliver on their part of the bargain."
Washington's chief delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, called the proposals "a significant step toward the kind of structural reform that will help the United Nations do more, better and for less."
Mr. Annan said he would present a more sweeping package of suggestions in July for the organization's long-term future, for which he would seek member states' approval.
Diplomats say any improvement in the United Nations' financial prospects -- the organization says it is owed $1.3 billion by the United States in unpaid budget and peacekeeping dues and a further $840 million by other members -- is likely to be tied to the fate of the second package.
Among the changes that the United States is hoping to negotiate is a cut in its share of the total United Nations budget. The Administration wants Congress to appropriate $1.2 billion to pay back dues to the United Nations and other international organizations but favors withholding most of the money until 1999, when the outcome of the latest spending cuts should be clear.
Under the plan, the United Nations will cut by a third the portion of its $1.2 billion in annual spending, now 38 percent, that now goes for administration. The roughly $200 million that reduction should save will be transferred to aid programs run by Unicef, the United Nations Development Program, which provides technical help to poor countries, and other development agencies.
The United Nations' budget for 1998 and 1999 is set at $123 million less than the current two-year budget of $2.48 billion. Under the new budget, 1,000 staff posts, most of them vacant, will remain unfilled. Other plans include the merging of the Secretariat's three separate departments dealing with economic and social issues into one and taking steps to coordinate aid agencies' field operations more tightly. Plans also call for consolidating the separate administrative, personnel and procurement services that those agencies maintain at their New York headquarters.
The Secretary General also plans to overhaul the United Nations' information department and draw up a code of conduct for its staff.
While Mr. Annan can make most of the changes on his own authority, much more difficult issues are likely to be raised by the second package of proposals he will put forward this summer. One is Washington's insistence that its share of the regular budget be cut from the current 25 percent to around 20 percent and that its peacekeeping assessment be trimmed from just over 30 percent to about 25 percent of the peacekeeping budget. But diplomats acknowledge that negotiations on those matters may be hard to separate from parallel efforts to enlarge the Security Council by giving permanent seats to Germany, Japan and some large developing nations.
Only if Germany and Japan get permanent Council seats are they likely to be generous in helping fill the budget gap created by the cuts the United States is seeking.

HEADLINE: Striking a Balance Between Deer and Residents in the Florida Keys

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: BIG PINE KEY, Fla.

 BODY:
For two years, the endangered Key deer have died in record numbers. That, some residents of the Florida Keys say, may be good news.
The herd, estimated at about 300 deer here and on a few other islands of the Keys, lost 104 deer last year and 94 in 1995, said officials at the Federal National Key Deer Refuge here. Two-thirds of those that died were killed by cars on U.S. 1 and residential paved roads, they said. Before 1995, about 70 deer were killed each year. 
 But while Federal officials say the mounting number of deaths underscores the need to further control traffic and development, many residents question whether the deer population was as small as reported. If about 100 deer were dying a year, as one developer put it, it might mean there were "more deer jumping around" in the islands' vegetation.
The question is more than academic. With Florida's explosive population growth, developments have been invading the habitats of many species of animals and plants, and environmentalists, government officials and residents have clashed over how far to go to protect them.
In Big Pine Key, an island two miles wide and eight miles long, where most of the deer live, protecting the Key deer has meant severe restrictions on construction of new homes, schools and roads. Speed limits of 30 to 35 miles an hour have slowed traffic to a crawl.
Many of the island's 5,000 permanent residents say they feel like second-class citizens, compared with Bambi.
"I love the animals. I don't want to see them hurt," said Don Pollock, 51, the owner of Jig's Bait and Tackle. "But it's gotten to the point where you don't have any personal rights anymore. Maybe I should go to Cuba."
Key deer, a subspecies and the smallest of the North American white-tailed deer, less than three feet high at the shoulder, were placed on the Federal endangered species list in 1967. Nevertheless, development was allowed to flourish here through the 1980's, before state and county officials began clamping down on growth through ordinances and by buying land. A patchwork of about half of the land on Big Pine Key is now under some form of protection by environmental groups or the government, officials said.
One of the most controversial growth management policies has been the one that severely restricts new construction, denying owners of vacant lots the right to build on them.
"These were their dream lots, since they had planned to retire here, and now they can't build here and it's very distressing for them," said Timothy McGarry, director of planning for Monroe County. "But it's a question of who was here first. The deer were."
Most residents say they love the animals, which are the size of big dogs and often behave like pets. Visible throughout the island and comfortable around encroachers, they munch on hibiscus in backyards, graze among homes and cars and do not hesitate to approach people.
But hand-feeding is punishable by a $250 fine because it makes the deer fearless and more likely to be killed by cars or dogs, said officials at the refuge, which covers 8,000 acres. Thirty people have been fined since enforcement was tightened last summer. Biologists said that in the last 10 years, the deer population, attracted by handouts and garbage, has grown in developed areas while declining in wild ones. This is a concern because when the herd is concentrated, a disease outbreak or catastrophe could wipe out the deer.
"Why go chew on a mangrove leaf if you can have a potato chip?" said Michael J. McMinn, assistant refuge manager for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
Fines are just one of the many restrictions on humans who co-exist with the Key deer in the Florida islands that are the deer's only home. Dianne Stevens, 34, a waitress with two sons, said she was not allowed to erect a fence around her corner property to protect her children, because it would have prevented the deer from roaming freely.
In addition, Ms. Stevens said, the children must commute to schools on other islands, too far away for her to volunteer or attend functions, because construction of new schools would take away more habitat.
"I don't blame the deer," she said. "I blame the politicians."
Indeed, residents like Ms. Stevens say the deer are so plentiful and "street-smart" that many of the measures to protect them are unnecessary. The most skeptical suspect a land grab by government officials whose goal is to hold on to their preservation jobs.
The Lower Keys Chamber of Commerce is urging Federal and state officials to conduct a new deer census. A study in the 1970's estimated that there were 200 to 250 deer on Big Pine Key and as many as 150 more on 22 other islands.
But while some hope a new count would bolster their argument that the deer are thriving alongside humans and can survive more development, others said that disaster evacuation constraints and sewage needs may limit growth anyway.
Conservationists say numbers are meaningless.
"There could be 1,000 and they'd still be endangered and unique," said Harold Nugent, 63, a retired English professor who lives here and belongs to the Key Deer Protection Alliance, a volunteer group. "You can go through 1,000 very quickly if something happens, like a hurricane."
For now, the most immediate danger is traffic, although refuge officials said most deer killed last year were less than two years old, indicating that the does were bearing well.
Long-term solutions being considered include transplanting some of the herd to less populated islands nearby and establishing an undeveloped corridor the length of Big Pine Key to connect the patchwork of publicly owned lands and help minimize the deer's interaction with people, Mr. McMinn said.
What is clear, he said, is that the time is past for compromise between the needs of people and the deer.
"We've messed up," he said. "We allowed all these subdivisions to be put in. There's no way politically or economically to buy that land. The deer are going to have to survive on what's left."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Key deer, left, are endangered in the Florida Keys. More are dying because they are so tame and because of development. Officials are considering tighter protection. (Photographs by Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Canada Says U.S. Falls Short With Proposal to Bolster Air Quality

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
In an unusual formal criticism of another country's domestic policies, the Government of Canada maintains that proposals in the United States to toughen air quality standards -- denounced by industry as too demanding -- do not go far enough.
Canada said that the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed rules "will continue to result in health damages and death," and it bluntly recommended that the rules be made more stringent. 
 Canada's comments, filed with the environmental agency, are unusual not only because they came from abroad, but also because they unequivocally call for even tougher measures than the agency has proposed and are based on a detailed scientific examination of the issues by Canada's own pollution control authorities.
Because residents of some border cities in Canada breathe air that is sometimes contaminated by soot and smog blown in from the United States, tightening air pollution rules in this country could benefit Canadian citizens as well as Americans.
The E.P.A. seems unlikely to toughen its proposals in response to the Canadian criticism.
Rather, the agency is likely to use the independent scientific assessment by Canada as evidence that the United States is moving in the right direction.
Canada's rebuke is just one among thousands of documents, ranging from brief electronic mail messages and petitions to hefty crates of legal, economic and scientific arguments, that were filed with the E.P.A. before the March 12 deadline for public comments on proposals to set new health-based limits on pollution by soot and smog.
A United States group, the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, which represents the health agencies of each state, also filed comments warning that the E.P.A.'s proposal "will not fully protect the public."
The group praised the E.P.A.'s scientific review, saying that "a wealth of evidence" supported tougher smog goals and that "sufficient evidence" supported tougher soot goals.
But major industry groups filed voluminous comments deriding the science behind the rules and saying they would cost far more than they are worth in terms of health protection.
The American Petroleum Institute, for example, filed documents measuring about a foot high. The group said that tighter rules on smog "would not provide any significant improvement in protection of public health." And it said there was "no credible evidence" that the fine sooty particles that the E.P.A. wants to control more tightly were causing health problems.
The industry argument was expressly contradicted by Canada.
"Canada wishes to congratulate and encourage the E.P.A. for moving forward with tougher clean air requirements," its Government said in a 15-page unsigned document delivered on March 11, the day before the comment period closed. "At the same time, Canada is convinced that the proposals being made, if implemented, will not provide adequate protection for human health."
After considering public comments, the E.P.A. is to issue final rules this summer. The rules will define what levels of fine chemical particles and of ozone, a gas that is the main ingredient of smog, can be tolerated in the air without unduly jeopardizing public health.
Once the standards are set, states must devise plans for meeting them, subject to Federal approval.
The Clean Air Act requires the E.P.A. to review air quality standards periodically for six major pollutants and to set goals at levels that protect the public's health with a margin of safety that considers especially vulnerable people, like children with asthma or people who work and exercise outdoors. Under the law, the standards must be set without consideration of how much it might cost to meet them.
The Canadian Government and the provincial governments have already determined that pollution standards should be tightened in Canada, which would make them tougher than those that the E.P.A. is proposing for the United States.
A few other industrial countries have assessed studies of air pollution and health in their nations and come to conclusions similar to Canada's.
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ahmanson Sweetens Bid For Great Western Financial
H. F. Ahmanson & Company, battling to acquire Great Western Financial, a rival California savings and loan, sweetened its all-stock hostile bid for the company, to $6.6 billion, or about $50 a share.
The value of the revised deal would change with the price of Ahmanson stock, but it appears to top the friendly $6.25 billion offer that Great Western accepted on March 6 from Washington Mutual. [Page D6.]
 
Dow Rises as Nasdaq Falls
Blue chips staged a late rebound, with the Dow Jones industrials closing up 20.02 points at 6,955.48. But losers exceeded winners by almost 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq index lost 13.54 points, closing at 1,279.43. [D10.] 

Prices of Treasury securities slipped, as investors worried about a possible Fed rate increase and were wary ahead of the week's economic data. The yield on the 30-year bond edged up to 6.95 percent. [D20.]
 
S.E.C. Considers Shift on Funds
The S.E.C. is considering dropping its requirement that mutual funds disclose to shareholders all the securities they hold. Rather, it might require a list of the top 25 to 50 holdings. Industry analysts were critical. [D2.]
 
Thyssen Sees Hostile Krupp Bid
Thyssen A.G., Germany's largest steel producer, said that the Krupp-Hoesch group was planning to attempt a rare hostile takeover, and that Thyssen would fight it. Krupp refused to comment. [D2.]
 
For Time Warner, Delay Could Pay
Time Warner may be able to avoid hundreds of millions of dollars in capital gains tax if it keeps its troubled partnership with U S West intact through late June. Market Place. [D10.]
 
News Corp. to Acquire Heritage
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said that it would acquire Heritage Media, a direct-marketing and broadcasting company, in a tax-free stock deal worth $754 million. [D4.]
 
Rockwell to Shed Auto Operations
Rockwell International, continuing to reposition itself as an electronics and communications company, said that it would spin off its automotive parts operations as an independent, publicly traded company. [D2.]
 
A New Approach at Pearson P.L.C.
Pearson P.L.C., the British media and entertainment company, announced it would invest $160 million in The Financial Times over the next five years in the United States and Asia. Marjorie M. Scardino, the chief executive, also said she had put a new management team in place and begun a system to raise profits and cut costs. [D4.]
 
H.M.O.'s Found To Limit Elderly
Elderly people in health maintenance organizations often find that they cannot obtain the medical services they need because H.M.O.'s limit their ability to appeal adverse decisions on treatment, Federal investigators said. More than half the H.M.O.'s examined by Federal auditors did not fully comply with Federal rules for handling appeals and grievances. [A1.]
 
Canada Criticizes U.S. Plan on Air
The Government of Canada criticized proposals in the United States to toughen air quality standards -- denounced by industry as too demanding -- saying they "will continue to result in health damages and death." [A17.]
 
Former Chief Returns to Luby's
Luby's Cafeterias, whose chief executive, John Edward Curtis Jr., died last week in what the police have ruled a suicide, said that its chairman, Ralph Erben, had quit. A former chairman of the chain, John Lahourcade, will return as chairman and chief executive. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Albanians Must Foster Stability From Within;
Modest Comforts

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re your March 17 news article "As Unrest Swells in Albania, Eerie Calm Falls on Capital": 
 During a monthlong visit to Albania last August, my husband and I lived with many families who had been our hosts during earlier trips. Except for a few improved roads near major cities, the infrastructure seemed not to have improved at all, but most of our friends' lives had become a little easier.
Their greatest pride was their new bathrooms, equipped with modern showers and toilets and water storage tanks. It was hopes of modest comforts like these, not dreams of quick riches, that persuaded many people that the pyramid schemes in which they were ultimately swindled were worth the risk.
A lasting solution of the crisis must defuse the powderkeg by dismantling the remaining "investment" companies and transforming their assets into legal and productive economic enterprises.
A national infrastructure -- water, electricity, communications and roads -- to support modern investment is an urgent priority. Albania's latest tragedy is the culmination of five years of social, economic and political dreams gone sour; we can only hope that somehow these dark times will bring forth wise leaders.
 
MARJORIE SENECHAL
Northampton, Mass., March 17, 1997

HEADLINE: Gingrich Suggests Party Leaders May Drop Push for Big Tax Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
House Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the Republican Party should consider shelving its demand for a big tax cut to advance the prospects of balancing the budget.
Mr. Gingrich's statement was the latest indication of a growing split among Republicans over whether to surrender, at least temporarily, their long-running debate with the Democrats and the Clinton Administration over sweeping tax reductions. 
 Other influential Republicans, including Senator William V. Roth, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, have insisted in recent days that the party would press ahead with its tax-cutting proposals, which have been the centerpiece of the Republican agenda for the last two years.
In impromptu comments to reporters, Mr. Gingrich said, "We've said all along we think it's very, very important to balance the budget and get as large a tax cut as possible while balancing the budget."
He added, "But we think that the moral imperative is to balance the budget."
Leaders of both parties in Congress said earlier today that they would try to get the budget process restarted through legislative give-and-take rather than through direct negotiations with the Clinton Administration.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said the chances of using President Clinton's budget proposals as the basis for negotiating a deal to eliminate the deficit by 2002 were waning. But Mr. Lott said Republicans and moderate Democrats in Congress might be able to reach their own compromise, including an agreement on reducing cost-of-living increases for recipients of benefit programs, like Social Security, through an adjustment to the Consumer Price Index, which most economists believe overstates inflation.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, said Congress should develop a budget resolution -- the framework for more detailed spending and tax bills -- without holding the process hostage to negotiations with the Administration.
"I don't know why we feel that there has to be a negotiated settlement prior to the time we seriously consider budgetary questions," Mr. Daschle said. "I think the best approach is to start the budget process, to allow amendments, to work through the budget in the Budget Committee."
After initial expressions of optimism from both sides that they could strike a budget deal quickly, both parties agreed last week that their initial negotiations were going nowhere, particularly after Mr. Clinton backed away from a politically explosive proposal to save billions of dollars by addressing the apparent overstatement of cost-of-living increases.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee, said last week that the chances of negotiating a deal with the White House were "finished." But Mr. Domenici and other Republicans have since softened that stand, looking for potential compromises on an issue that both sides say is their overriding goal this year.

HEADLINE: At Rental Counters, Are All Drivers Created Equal?;
Avis Finds Itself at the Center Of Discrimination Complaints

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: TULSA, Okla., March 14

 BODY:
"The rental of an automobile is not an inalienable right granted in the Constitution," Richard Aronow, president of the New York Rental Vehicle Association, observes. Yet the scope of those rights has provoked a growing, national brawl, with Avis, the No. 2 rental agency, at its center.
The company faces a lawsuit over complaints that several outlets in North and South Carolina have refused to rent cars to blacks and that the top executives of Avis have hesitated to step in. In New York, the lawsuit by the state Attorney General to keep Avis and others from rejecting younger drivers has reached the state's highest court. The state Assembly plans to investigate whether some rental companies systematically turned down blacks and Hasidic Jews, as well. 
 Most recently, two former employees have accused Avis supervisors and telephone representatives at the company's global reservations center in Tulsa of rejecting corporate accounts for those who appeared to be Jewish, especially Hasidic Jews, in what the employees described as the "yeshiva" policy. Two other rental companies that charge higher rates to Brooklyn, Queens and Bronx drivers are the targets of Federal legislation to be introduced on Tuesday that would outlaw basing rates on where a renter lives.
All these complaints bear on industry practices that rental companies consider necessary to making money in a business built on putting valuable, potentially lethal assets into strangers' hands. An 1866 Federal law that bars discrimination because of race or religion has been interpreted by the courts as applying to a broad range of businesses and services, including schools, restaurants and rental agencies. The companies say they still must be choosy about whom they will rent to and at what prices. The young, the accident-prone, the Brooklyn resident all threaten, experience shows, to cost the car rental companies more than they pay.
"The rental of an auto combines the exposure of an insurance company and a bank rolled into one," Mr. Aronow, whose group leads the defense against threatened state legislation, said.
Banking and insurance, however, are two industries prominently accused of letting business judgment sometimes slide into bias. Some neighborhoods, however prosperous, with high concentrations of members of racial minorities have found that red-lining makes mortgages or insurance coverage scarce.
Challenges to such practices have increasingly succeeded. Federal agencies have forced many banks to step up their lending in neighborhoods they had shunned. Pressed by protests and lawsuits, many big insurers have begun writing homeowners policies in inner-city neighborhoods -- and are finding it profitable.
In the restaurant business, Denny's, a unit of the Flagstar Companies, agreed in 1994 to pay $54 million to settle accusations that some of its outlets had refused to serve black customers. The lead lawyer in that suit, John P. Relman of the Washington Lawyers Committee for Civil Rights and Urban Affairs, is also handling the Federal lawsuit in Wilmington, N.C., that accuses Avis and its local franchisee of bias against blacks.
Avis, pointing out that more than 42 percent of its employees are members of racial minorities, says that any discrimination was the fault of a franchisee over whom it had little control -- John B. Dalton 3d, who operates Avis lots in Wilmington and four other cities in the Carolinas.
"Avis did not discriminate against blacks, against Jews or against any other majorities or minorities," said Henry R. Silverman, chief executive of HFS Inc., the Parsippany, N.J., franchising operation that bought Avis last October.
Mr. Silverman acknowledged that Mr. Dalton might have shown bias. Avis, based in Garden City, L.I., tried to take over his locations in December, but a Federal court in North Carolina blocked any immediate action. Mr. Silverman called the new complaints of discrimination against Jews false -- prompted, he said, by lawyers who were trying to manipulate the media and embarrass Avis into settling the Wilmington case.
"This is a new way -- I'm trying to use a nicer word than extortion -- that lawyers for plaintiffs try to extract money from corporations," Mr. Silverman said in a phone interview.
Mr. Dalton and his lawyers refused to comment beyond issuing a statement in which he denied refusing anyone on the basis of race.
The North Carolina case has gotten wide exposure, but the details of what happened in Tulsa are still emerging.
In about 1990, the company says, underage drivers falsely claiming to work for yeshivas -- Jewish day schools, usually high schools -- began renting cars under the schools' corporate accounts. Some used the cars as taxis, trash haulers and, in one case, a hearse, then returned them in sad shape. The company says it alerted its reservation center in Tulsa to avoid establishing corporate accounts that were likely to be abused, checking customers from the Northeast most closely.
According to two former employees, however, managers of the division that sets up small-business accounts responded with a broader pattern of discrimination. In a sworn statement he provided, William B. Ward said that supervisors had coached him and other telephone representatives to watch for "Jewish-sounding names," look for locations like New York and New Jersey and listen for "Jewish accents," and then deny applications for corporate accounts from what were broadly termed "yeshivas."
Mr. Ward recalled that a supervisor blamed an agent for granting a corporate account to a New Jersey fish market that the supervisor said was a yeshiva. Another supervisor put a caller on a speaker phone to demonstrate the screening process, Mr. Ward said in the sworn statement. "We don't want your business," the supervisor said. He hung up, then looked at Mr. Ward and explained, "That was a yeshiva."
Usually, Mr. Ward said, the slight was more subtle. Customers were given accounts that yielded discounts no better than those available to auto club members. True corporate accounts offered larger discounts, ample insurance coverage and a free day's rental for every 15 paid, he explained. Over about a year and a half, Mr. Ward said, he denied hundreds of such accounts.
In Tulsa, a metropolitan area of 743,000 where there are no yeshivas and the Jewish population is estimated at 3,000, Mr. Ward said that employees were befuddled. "The term 'yeshiva' was so derogatory, I believed it was some kind of Yiddish cuss word," Mr. Ward said in an interview.
In January, Mr. Ward was dismissed after being accused of cheating on an incentive program, a charge he is challenging in an unemployment compensation proceeding.
Another former telephone agent, Elaine M. Rodgers, said in a court filing in the Wilmington case that she was instructed to spot "yeshivas" by customers' accents and addresses, though she said agents used the word to mean Hasidic Jews in particular.
Avis said that no customers had complained about prejudice against Jews and that it did not screen customers by accent or name. "The suggestion that there was any anti-Semitic motive to it is preposterous," John H. Carley, the Avis general counsel, said. Agents may have applied the term "yeshiva" more generally to customers who tried to deceive the company, he said. "Ultimately, it may have been used to denote in some minds a problem, not an ethnic group," he added.
Far larger numbers of former employees -- about 15 in the Carolinas and several more in Tulsa -- have described discrimination by Mr. Dalton and his five franchises, with some instances dating back two decades. Mr. Dalton, several said, instructed them to find any pretext for turning down blacks, whom he often referred to in derogatory terms, and also shunned members of the military. His business rationale was that blacks were more likely to return cars dirty or damaged or use them to deal in drugs.
According to a statement that an Avis complaint handler in Tulsa filed in the Wilmington case, Mr. Dalton said, "I own these cars, and I can rent to whomever I want."
That policy, according to the three black women who filed the class action lawsuit, humilated them -- spoiling vacations, family reunions and other long-held plans. One of the plaintiffs, Lerline E. Wilson, made a telephone reservation to drive a rental car about 300 miles from Mr. Dalton's Florence, S.C., lot to visit a mother-in-law dying of cancer in Kentucky. When she showed up at the counter, according to the lawsuit, Ms. Wilson -- then 54 -- was told she was too old to drive so far.
Several employees of the Dalton franchises said they had forwarded complaints to the Avis service center in Tulsa. Here, employees said they had alerted their bosses, including those at company headquarters.
"You can imagine the disgust," said Dixie Dean Bailey, a former Avis employee in Tulsa who recalled having more than 100 conversations with Mr. Dalton about the complaints. "In order to get your paycheck, you had to file reports, but nothing was ever done."
Sue P. Parker, third in command at Tulsa from 1985 to 1994, said in a court filing that the complaints came up at meetings attended by all the top Avis executives. Mr. Silverman, however, said that until former employees made sworn statements late last year, the company lacked enough evidence to take action. Most top Avis executives have left since the acquisition by HFS.
[On Monday, HFS named R. Craig Hoenshell, a former American Express executive and Wall Street consultant, as the new chairman and chief executive of Avis.]
The accusations of bias against Avis and other rental companies have prompted the New York State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, to schedule a hearing on March 31.
On Tuesday, Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, plans to introduce a bill in Congress to keep car rental companies from charging higher rates based on where customers live -- as Hertz and Budget do for residents of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, no matter where they rent in New York City.
"The kind of discrimination we're talking about is broad-brushed and callous," Mr. Schumer said. "Once they say anyone from Queens pays a higher rate, maybe it's a short step to saying anyone who's a black or Jew deserves a higher rate as well."
Budget charged Bronx drivers $127.99 a day -- $54 more than the regular rate -- for picking up a car in Manhattan, according to a report by Mr. Schumer's office in February. The company's chairman, Jack A. Frazee, said in a letter to Mr. Schumer on March 5 that Budget was seeking to limit its losses in New York City -- $8 million last year, he said -- by charging more to those most likely to steal their cars or have accidents, including residents of some boroughs.
"It is a fairness in pricing concept," Mr. Frazee said, similar to the geographical rating systems used by insurance companies.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
WAGNER, SHERLE

 BODY:
WAGNER-Sherle, died on March 14th at the age of 79. Husband for 54 years of Rose (Lichtstein), father of Linda Geoffroy, Paul and Amy, father-in-law of Vincent Geoffroy and Melanie Wagner, grandfather of Rennie, Evan, Jeremy, Chloe, Marissa and Colin. He is also survived by his sister Sylvia Feinstein and his brother, Laurence Wagner. He was predeceased by his sister, Francis Kroll. Sherle Wagner revolutionized the luxury bathroom and decorative hardware industry. For more than 50 years his creative vision has made his name synonomous with elegance. In 1995, he and his wife established The Rose and Sherle Wagner Foundation. By providing support for small, communitybased organization, the foundation embodies the Wagners' life-long commitment to social and economic justice. Contributions may be sent to The Rose and Sherle Wagner Fund for Humanistic Medicine, c/o Dr Jerome Lowenstein, 550 1st Avenue, New York, New York 10016. A memorial service will be held at a future date.
WAGNER-Sherle. The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) notes the passing of Sherle Wagner. Mr. Wagner was a member of the IMF for many years. His patronage supported the IMF's many programs including research and education. The IMF, its Board of Directors and members express their deepest sympathy to the Wagner family. He will be sorely missed.
WAGNER-Sherle. The North Star Fund mourns the passing of Sherle Wagner. We honor his strong committment to social and economic justice. He will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and support to his family during this difficult time. Betty Kapetanakis, Exec Director North Star Fund, New York, NY
WAGNER-Sherle. Creator, teacher, advisor, friend. A man with great love for his family and great pride in his work. He was special. Leonard Sacks

HEADLINE: Study of Ocean Currents Offers Clues to Global Climate Shifts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
As scientists struggle to understand how and why the earth's climate is changing, they are increasingly looking deep into the oceans, where oscillations in water temperature that travel on stately currents from one continent to another may cause weather trends to change from decade to decade.
These flip-flops in climate, which scientists suspect owe their slow decadal pacing to the sluggish movement of ocean currents and the sea's prodigious ability to retain heat and move it around, determine whether winter in Northern Europe, Asia and parts of North America will be generally mild or severe -- for 20 to 30 years at a time. They control long-term rainfall patterns over wide areas. They help determine where ocean fish can thrive and where they cannot. 
 And now, scientists are studying them for clues to whether the earth's climate will be warmer in the future than it is now, and to why the ancient civilizations of Mesopotamia vanished thousands of years ago.
One of the major oscillations, in the North Atlantic, may be in the process of switching to a new state, one with far-reaching implications for the study of global warming.
Since the 1970's, scientists say, the North Atlantic oscillation and a similar oscillation in the Pacific have made the continents of the Northern Hemisphere unusually warm, on the average, in winter and spring. This natural heating is believed to be a major reason for an especially sharp rise in the average global surface temperature from the 1970's to the 1990's. Mainstream scientists say emissions of heat-trapping waste industrial gases like carbon dioxide are also partly responsible, but they do not know which effect is more important.
The change in the North Atlantic oscillation may tell them. Last year it made its sharpest reversal on record, cooling off Eurasia and casting Northern Europe into two harsh winters in a row. North America cooled as well, though the mechanism is less clear. If the overall rise in global temperatures continues in the face of continental cooling, it would offer strong support to the theory that human activity -- particularly the emission of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere -- is disrupting the global climate system.
Just as important, climatologists would have a better idea of the magnitude of any human impact. The last cool period linked to ocean oscillations, in the 1950's and 1960's, interrupted a century-long global warming trend that resumed only when the oscillation switched again in the 1970's. This time, though, average global temperature remained at a near-record level last year despite the cooler continents. But two winters' data do not establish a trend, so scientists will be watching intently to see what happens in the years just ahead.
"If we decide the system has flipped, and if then the global warming were to continue, that would be kind of disconcerting," said Dr. Michael S. McCartney, a physical oceanographer at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution at Woods Hole, Mass.
Climate oscillates on seasonal, annual, decadal and century-long time scales, with smaller swings imposed on larger ones. But it is the decade-to-century scale that is most relevant to the question of human-induced climate change, since that is the shortest span over which it can be reliably detected.
On this scale, the oceans provide the heartbeat of climate: their inertia determines the pace of natural change. Climatic oscillations in the atmosphere, many scientists believe, would play out rapidly if they were stripped of their contact with the seas. But because the ocean and the atmosphere are linked by the mutual transfer of heat, moisture and motion, the atmosphere to a great extent must dance to the tempo of the seas.
So far, scientists studying oscillations on the decade-to-century scale have concentrated on the Northern Hemisphere, where both the Pacific and Atlantic climatic seesaws affect mainly the winter and spring seasons. In one phase of the Pacific oscillation, sea-surface temperatures in the western three-quarters of the North Pacific are cooler than normal, while the tropics are warmer. In this state, the tropical sea warmth extends northward along the North American coast to west of the Gulf of Alaska. This creates an atmospheric pattern in which winters tend to be milder and drier in Alaska, Canada and the Pacific Northwest, cooler in the Southeastern United States and wetter in the Southwest.
This pattern has been entrenched since the mid-1970's; before that, starting about 1945, sea-surface temperature relationships were reversed, and so were the atmospheric consequences. Temperature patterns recorded by tree rings show that these flip-flops have come every 20 to 30 years for the last 200 years, suggesting that a new flip might now be due. But it is too soon to tell whether that is happening, said Dr. John M. Wallace, an atmospheric scientist at the University of Washington in Seattle. "It's very difficult to know where you are in real time," he said. "It's easy with hindsight to go back and see when it flipped."
A number of ideas have been proposed about what drives the Pacific oscillation. One says that subsurface ocean machinations outside the tropics are responsible. Another holds that interactions between the tropical and mid-latitude oceans are the cause. Some scientists suggest that El Nino, the vast pool of unusually warm surface water that comes and goes every few years in the eastern tropical Pacific, may in some fashion trip the trigger for decade-to-decade oscillations.
Strikingly different forces appear to be at work in the Atlantic. There, Dr. McCartney and other scientists are focusing on a huge, powerful current that carries warm water from the vicinity of Florida to the coast of Ireland before turning westward, cooling, sinking and curling back south near Labrador. The existence of this oceanic pipeline, which begins as the Gulf Stream and becomes the North Atlantic Current as it heads east across the ocean, has long been known. But Dr. McCartney believes, based on observations at sea, that it is linked with the atmosphere to produce the North Atlantic oscillation's interdecadal rhythm.
His analysis and that of others has found that deep-lying parcels of unusually warm water move continually through the pipeline, alternating with cooler ones. Each parcel takes about 20 years to travel from the tropics, around the North Atlantic circuit to Labrador. Observations indicate that sea-surface temperatures rise and fall in concert with the movement of these parcels and with the speed of the pipeline current -- and atmospheric pressure above the sea appears to rise and fall in concert with all the other factors.
When these factors are in one phase of the oscillation, characterized by lower sea-surface temperatures, powerful west-to-east winds across the Atlantic are on average stronger. This carries more oceanic warmth to Northern Europe and Asia, making for milder winters there (though cooler, the ocean is still warmer than the land). An analysis by Dr. James Hurrell of the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., has shown that in this phase, Northern Europe has more precipitation than normal, while Southern Europe and the Middle East have less.
When the system flips, the opposite is true: the westerlies weaken and shift southward, making Northern Europe much colder and drier but bringing more warmth and precipitation to Mediterranean Europe, Africa and the Middle East. Eastern Canada and Greenland are warmer.
While the system's elements do indeed appear to work in concert as Dr. McCartney says, not all aspects of his explanation of the oscillation's workings are nailed down, said Dr. Hugo Bezdek, director of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory in Miami. "I wouldn't call it an airtight case yet," he said. For one thing, he said, the origin of the warm-water parcels that move through the pipeline is unknown; for another, evidence of the ocean's connection to the atmosphere "is suggestive, but I wouldn't call it robust."
Nor has anyone yet figured out exactly how the oscillation functions. Some still say the atmosphere may be driving the system, but others say that given the oscillation's stately pace, it is more likely that either the ocean is driving the atmosphere or that the two are locked in a perpetual feedback loop.
"If Mike's right, this is a dynamite idea," Dr. Bezdek said. "Then you have a scheme to make some predictions," something of enormous economic value. It would be possible, for instance, to forecast rainfall trends in Europe and probably the Middle East and North Africa years ahead.
It might also be possible to predict the abundance of oceanic fish like cod, which depend ultimately on tiny marine animals for their subsistence. A recent study has found that the abundance of one such animal, a copepod called Calanus finmarchicus, rises and falls in close concert with the North Atlantic oscillation. Other studies have found that populations of Alaskan salmon and Japanese sardines similarly vary with the North Pacific oscillation.
New evidence is also emerging that implicates the North Atlantic oscillation as the cause of a long drought that archeologists believe caused the collapse, starting about 4,200 years ago, of the ancient Akkadian civilization of Mesopotamia.
Two paleoclimatologists at the Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Heidi Cullen and Dr. Peter deMenocal, extracted a sediment core from the bottom of the Persian Gulf that, they say, shows that huge amounts of dust blew off the Mesopotamian landscape about 4,200 years ago, just as the Akkadian drought was beginning. Another Lamont researcher, Dr. Gerard Bond, produced evidence from ice cores of a North Atlantic cooling at the same time.
Building on Dr. Hurrell's work showing that precipitation in Istanbul, near the headwaters of the life-giving Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, has varied in phase with the North Atlantic oscillation, Ms. Cullen analyzed Turkish precipitation records in detail and concluded that when the North Atlantic was cold, the headwaters region was cooler and drier and water flows dropped in the streams that supplied Mesopotamia's water.
Whether the North Atlantic oscillation could operate over time scales of a century or more, where even larger climate swings have taken place in the last few thousand years, is unclear. "There's no evidence that it couldn't happen, and no evidence that it did," Dr. Bond said. Even so, he said, the ocean could well play some major role in the large, centuries-long climatic fluctuations; variations in the sun's output are another possible cause.
The two biggest of these fluctuations in recent millenniums were the Medieval warm period, when northern climes were so balmy that the Vikings colonized Greenland and vineyards grew in Britain; and the Little Ice Age, when much of Europe starved in the cold. An especially clear record of these swings, as well as shorter recent ones, has emerged from ocean sediments on the Bermuda Rise, a hump in the ocean floor on which Bermuda sits.
There, Dr. Lloyd D. Keigwin, a paleoclimatologist at the Woods Hole institution, has tracked the swings for the last 3,000 years by analyzing the fossilized carbonate shells of tiny animals called foraminifera, in this case a species named Globigerinoides ruber, which lives year-round on the surface of the Sargasso Sea. The shells' chemical content changes according to how cold the climate was at a given time, and Dr. Keigwin has found in them evidence of the larger swings. The shells clearly reflect, for instance, two periods of Medieval warmth, 500 and 1,000 years ago, as well as an even more pronounced warming about 2,500 years ago. The shells show the depths of the Little Ice Age about 300 years ago.
"The evidence of natural oscillations is clear," Dr. Keigwin said. "They have been going on as long as we can look back in time." According to the shells, a recovery from the Little Ice Age is still going on. The big message from the Bermuda Rise, Dr. Keigwin says, is that to whatever extent humans are warming the climate, that warming is coming on top of a natural post-Little Ice Age warming. "It could be," he said, "that whatever is driving these oscillations in the ocean may overwhelm what we're doing to the atmosphere -- or it could be that we're making a bad situation worse."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 25, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Science Times last Tuesday with an article about the effects of ocean currents on the global climate misstated deviations from the average high air temperatures at the Kodiak, King Salmon and Cold Bay weather stations in Alaska since 1900. A corrected chart appears today on page C7.

GRAPHIC: Diagrams: "Currents Carry Climate Change"
Scientists studying ocean currents are gathering increasingly detailed data on how variations in ocean temperature influence climate. Among other things, they have discovered decades-long cycles in water temperature in the North Atlantic current running from the Gulf of Mexico to northern Europe and back again.
 
Seemingly minor temperature changes can cause long-term population shifts among copepods like this one and other microscopic plankton. Now researchers are tracking how plankton levels are linked to scarcity or abundance of larger creatures.
 
"Gyres, Currents and Weather"
Water in the Gulf Stream/North Atlantic Current, which courses between two vast gyres, or ocean-wide eddies, alternately runs warmer and cooler for periods of about 20 years years each, scientists say. They suspect that this sets off an atmospheric chain reaction that alters the strength and position of the westerly winds, making Northern Europe and Asia either generally colder or warmer in winter and spring.
 
Researchers working near Bermuda tracked changes in ocean temperature over thousand of years by measuring changes sediments bearing the fossil shells of microscopic creatures that live in the Sargasso Sea.
 
"A New Oscillation Begins?"
Starting in the 1970's, oscillations in the northern Atlantic and Pacific oceans brought generally warm winter and spring weather to Northern Europe, Asia and parts of North America. Now scientists say the Atlantic pattern may be changing to colder weather, and they wonder whether global temperatures will continue to rise.

HEADLINE: The Job Engine Sputters

BYLINE: By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris, a business and financial consultant, is the author of "The Cost of Good Intentions: New York City and the Liberal Experiment."

 BODY:
Joe L. Roby, president of the securities firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, took home $33 million last year. Perhaps shareholders did not mind, because the company, like most of Wall Street, had a very good year. But Mr. Roby apparently did not spend much of his wealth in New York's bodegas, for the city's unemployment rate rose last year to 9.9 percent, one of the nation's highest big-city rates. And therein lies a historical disjuncture.
In 1968, when Wall Street was enjoying a similarly long-running market boom, the unemployment rate in New York fell to 3.1 percent, much lower than the national average and lower than in any other big city except Dallas. The unemployment rate among blacks was only 4 percent, about half the level in the rest of the nation. 
Even in the 1980's, the recovery on Wall Street created hundreds of thousands of jobs, not even counting spinoff employment for building maintenance people and limo drivers. These were the glory days when midlevel clerical workers were pocketing $75,000 to $80,000 in salary and bonuses, and secretaries who worked past 6:30 got overtime, dinner money and a driver to take them home.
During the 1996 market boom, by contrast, the city's financial sector created only 12,500 new jobs, and those include jobs generated by all the stepped-up activity among printers, law firms and accountants. By the end of the year, Wall Street was actually cutting employment.
Since its 1989-91 recession, Wall Street has been automating with a vengeance. Until the 1980's, most trading and securities transfers were paper-based. It took an army of worker-ants to deliver, register and keep custody over millions of bond and stock certificates, and to make sure that dividends and interest were collected on schedule and properly accounted for. But the big market players have long since switched from paper to computerized registries, and the worker-ants are obsolete.
New York City has managed to retain its share of the financial services business in the 1990's, but only by keeping a rough parity with the cost-efficiency of a host of new competitors -- off-hours exchanges, computerized trading systems and discount brokers. The shareholders and top executives of the big corporations can continue to pocket big profits and bonuses only if they keep rigid control over operating costs. Even with its recent streamlining, Wall Street is still far from a model of efficiency, and the downsizing that is likely to follow the next market downturn may be cataclysmic.
The old Wall Street job engine was the last vestige of New York as Empire City, when its position as the world's business, financial, entertainment and media center cushioned the economic ups and downs. But New York can no longer defy the economic laws of gravity. Most of the recent business revolutions, like those in computer technology and biotechnology, have simply passed it by. That the city has derived little benefit from the biotechnology boom is especially disturbing, because there is an exceptional academic and research base here, and most of the big pharmaceutical companies are just across the river in New Jersey.
With the aging of the baby boomers, health care could be a real growth industry in the city. Despite its bad reputation, health care is a rapidly growing, technology-intensive and, believe it or not, high-productivity industry. (Just compare the cost and success rate of, say, knee cartilage surgery 15 years ago with the mostly outpatient procedures done today.) But in New York, the health care industry is burdened with the huge overhead of big teaching institutions. High costs could chase away insurers and push more business to suburban hospitals and outpatient centers.
Like the old Soviet Union, New York has acquired its own nomenklatura, a privileged elite who feed off the regulations and high costs that make the city such a mine field for everyone else. Take the rent laws that benefit the well-to-do on the Upper West Side and create artificial scarcities and exorbitant prices in the "free market." Or the featherbedding entertainment unions that almost succeeded in driving serious theater out of the city. Or the blackbird flock of inspectors, "environmental consultants," lawyers and mortgage brokers who collect a toll from routine daily transactions.
Only in New York, and places like Beijing, does one hire "expediters" to obtain routine government approvals. In a city of small businesses, we levy punitive taxes on small proprietors -- a flat 4 percent on anyone making more than $20,000, in addition to a uniquely high municipal income tax.
City government can help, but not by trying to create biotechnology venture capital funds, as some have suggested. It should simply do well what it is supposed to do, like run decent schools and keep the streets safe.
The Giuliani administration has made some promising starts. The recent reductions in crime -- assuming the administration deserves even half the credit it claims -- must count as the most important economic development program in years. But promising starts are just promising starts. Rolling back the bureaucratic encrustations will be the work of decades.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Tuning In to Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
"One of the strangest consequences of the Second World War," Aaron Copland wrote in 1967, "has been the belated discovery that there is music to the south of us." This was, of course, a rhetorical flourish: Copland, of all people, knew listeners were still getting used to the idea that music was composed on the Western side of the Atlantic, and it cannot have surprised him that audiences were slow to recognize Latin American concert music. He crusaded for it, using its rhythms and melodic turns in works like "El Salon Mexico" and "Danzon Cubano," and forging professional links between North, Central and South American composers. Yet for all that, the "music to the south of us" remains largely uncharted territory in the United States and Europe.
Now Dennis Russell Davies, the music director of the American Composers Orchestra, has taken up the cause. With Tania Leon, the composer, as his Latin American music adviser, Mr. Davies has devoted part of every season to a Sonidos de las Americas festival, a methodical exploration of the region's music. Puerto Rico was the focus of the fourth installment, a week of concerts, symposiums and master classes that ended with an orchestral performance on Sunday at Carnegie Hall. 
 The concerts included everything from quaint chamber music and advanced orchestral scores to vibrant pop amalgams showing influences of African drumming, Spanish folk melody and North American jazz and rock. Listeners intent on looking beyond the standard canon can only admire Mr. Davies's efforts, which in past seasons have brought Mexican, Venezuelan and Brazilian music into the spotlight.
But festivals of this sort inevitably raise questions. One is whether they have any lasting effect, and so far the answer seems to be no. Brazilian and Mexican concert works have long had a marginal presence in New York concert halls; the festivals have not noticeably increased it, nor has there been a lingering curiosity about Venezuelan music among musicians and programmers.
Related is the question of whether this music is so compelling that it demands a place in the concert repertory. Several of the chamber works offered early in the week were not: The Chopinesque "Danzas" of the 19th-century composer Juan Morel Campos and a more recent set of piano duets, "De Barrio Obrero a la Quince," by William Ortiz, had a charming salon quality, but a single hearing was sufficient.
Hector Campos Parsi's Sonatina No. 2, on the other hand, has gritty energy that catches a listener's imagination. Henry Hutchinson, a violinist, and Jose Ramos-Santana, a pianist, gave it a stately reading on Monday at Weill Recital Hall, but it sounded more vigorous two nights later at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, where Mr. Ramos-Santana had to make do with a funky upright piano.
There were also several keepers among the orchestral works Mr. Davies conducted on Sunday. Mr. Campos Parsi's "Divertimento" is a charming, sunny 1950's-vintage Neo-Classical suite. Loyda Camacho's "Ensayo" had an alluring eeriness and a strong profile, but the most powerful work offered all week was Roberto Sierra's "Glosas Para Piano y Orquesta," an edgy, chromatic score that Mr. Ramos-Santana played with virtuosity and precision.
There was, however, little in these works that seemed identifably Puerto Rican, and that raised a question that pervaded the festival and its literature: what is Puerto Rican music? And in truth, the most vital music presented all week, and the most uninhibitedly Puerto Rican, was not from the classical tradition at all. Los Planeros de la 21, at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday, and William Cepeda's Boricua Ensemble, at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, on Wednesday, played amplified, heavily percussive music buoyed by its rhythmic complexities and its bursts of bright-edged brass playing.
Those qualities, and questions of identity, also came together in William Ortiz's "Rican," a pop opera presented at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening. Mr. Ortiz's protagonist, Louie Goya Beans, is disillusioned with life on New York's economic periphery and moves to Puerto Rico, only to find that he has no real connection to the country's culture. Returning to New York, he comes to terms with his place in the hybrid Nuyorican culture. Mr. Ortiz's score is fetchingly melodic and full of energy, yet Louie's journey is more clearly captured in the libretto than in the music: the New York scene is in English, the Puerto Rican episode is in Spanish, and the conclusion is in Spanglish.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls and Mark Surges On Warning of Delay for Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply and the mark surged yesterday after a senior Bundesbank official offered one of the strongest warnings yet that Germany might not qualify for Europe's planned single currency.
The remarks by the official, Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, amplified concerns that the January 1999 debut of the single currency, the Euro, would have to be delayed because even the most economically powerful country in Europe might not be able to meet its strict entry criteria. That would still leave the mark as the pre-eminent European currency. 
 "Fear of delay in European monetary union is finding roots in the market, and people are jumping right back into the mark," said Stephen Flanagan, a senior foreign exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York.
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6727 marks, down from 1.6894 marks on Monday and the lowest level in three weeks. The dollar fell to 122.43 yen from 123.66 yen. The pound rose to $1.5901 from $1.5888.
Mr. Kuhbacher, a member of the Bundesbank's central council, told the German magazine Borse Online that it was highly doubtful that Germany could limit its 1997 government deficit to 3 percent of gross domestic product as required for monetary union participation, and for that reason "a delay of the Euro's introduction is inevitable."
His comments followed similar anxieties over monetary union on Monday, when the German Finance Minister and other Bundesbank officials suggested a delay was preferable to softening the stringent criteria.
The Bundesbank's monthly report for February released yesterday also helped intensify doubts about Germany's chances of meeting the budget deficit criterion, saying that depended on whether "extra burdens can be offset," a reference to increased public spending costs as a result of Germany's welfare burdens and high unemployment.
The dollar weakened against the yen in early Asian dealings after the Japanese Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said the Government would announce measures by March 31 to help improve Japan's distressed real estate market and help Japanese banks reduce their enormous burden of bad loans.
