HEADLINE: Thomas Fichandler, Washington Theater's Executive Director, 81

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Thomas C. Fichandler, a founder of the Arena Stage in Washington and the theater's executive director until his retirement in 1986, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 81.
The cause was a heart attack, said his wife, Zelda Fichandler. 
 The Arena Stage, created in 1950 by Mr. and Mrs. Fichandler and Edward Mangum, was from the first a principal force in the regional theater movement, and it remains one of the leading theater companies in the United States. During most of the Arena's existence, Mr. Fichandler ran the business side of the operation while Mrs. Fichandler was the artistic director.
As a creative team, they won many honors, including the first Tony award given to a regional theater. The Fichandlers continued their professional partnership after they were separated in 1975.
Mr. Fichandler was born in New York City. He graduated from Brooklyn College and later from George Washington University. Trained as an economist, he went to Washington in 1936 and worked for the Treasury Department. Then he became chief of the Actuarial Division for the Social Security Administration's unemployment insurance program.
His office was in the building that also housed the National Theater, which was closed after a dispute over its policy of not allowing blacks to sit in the audience with whites. Mr. Fichandler joined the pickets outside the National, and when he and his wife opened the Arena Stage, it was the first integrated theater in Washington.
The original home of the Arena was in a boat on the Potomac River, after which it moved to an abandoned movie theater and later a former brewery. In 1961, the company occupied a new, modern building near the Potomac. Mr. Fichandler was primarily responsible for planning the construction of the Arena and for raising the money to support it.
Under the leadership of the Fichandlers, the Arena built a reputation for venturesome theater. It made its national reputation with such plays as "The Great White Hope" by Howard Sackler (which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama after it moved to Broadway) and "Moonchildren" by Michael Weller. The Arena was also known for the professionalism of its acting company. At the same time, the theater achieved financial stability, largely through Mr. Fichandler's efforts.
Mr. Fichandler was active in the regional theater movement, as president of the League of Resident Theaters for six years and as a consultant to the Ford Foundation.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Hal, of Philadelphia and Mark, of New York City, and a grandson.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas C. Fichandler (The New York Times, 1985)

HEADLINE: Ralph S. Abascal, 62, Dies; Leading Lawyer for the Poor

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

 BODY:
Ralph S. Abascal, a pioneering legal-services lawyer in California who won landmark decisions on behalf of farm workers, welfare recipients and undocumented immigrants, died on Monday at his home in Berkeley. He was 62 and had been suffering from cancer.
Mr. Abascal, a rumpled, soft-spoken man whose manner sometimes belied a disciplined legal mind, was for more than 20 years the general counsel and guiding spirit of California Rural Legal Assistance, one of the largest of the 280-odd programs endowed by the Federally financed Legal Services Corporation. 
 He was among the first and most vigorous combatants in environmental law, winning cases that forced an end to the agricultural use of DDT and other pesticides. He also fought successfully to block state efforts to cut welfare benefits in the 1970's, becoming a particular nemesis of the administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan. Soon after becoming President in 1981, Mr. Reagan tried to halt all Federal financing for the legal services program.
To Mr. Abascal's conservative critics in the California capital and in Washington, he epitomized what was wrong with the legal services organization: He viewed himself more as a civil rights activist than a social worker. He worked closely with liberal politicians. And he offered no apology for his focus on sweeping class actions that sought to change the lives of thousands of people, some of whom were only dimly aware of what he was doing.
Mr. Abascal also inspired a generation of young law-school graduates, many of whom forsook the promise of more lucrative careers so they could serve poor clients in farm towns in the Central Valley of California.
"He was the quintessential public-interest lawyer," said Al Meyerhoff, a senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council who frequently worked with Mr. Abascal. "If you look at how the Legal Services Corporation has been under siege for all these years, it has been because of lawyers like Ralph Abascal."
The grandson of a stonemason from the Spanish seaport of Santander, Mr. Abascal said he had inherited some of his liberalism from his father, Manuel, who lost three brothers in the Republican cause in the Spanish Civil War. As a young man, Manuel Abascal traveled to Cuba, helped build a railroad in northwestern Mexico and then walked across the border to San Diego. He settled in San Francisco, where his son Ralph Santiago was born on May 31, 1934.
Mr. Abascal, whose mother came from a family of immigrant fruit-pickers, did not start learning English until he was almost 5. He once said he had spent much of his youth haunting pool halls, but he became serious enough about his studies to earn a master's degree in business and pursue a doctorate in economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
Then, he recalled in an interview last year, he saw the 1960 film "Inherit the Wind," which depicted the debate over evolutionary theory waged by Clarence Darrow and William Jennings Bryan in the 1925 Scopes trial. That helped shift the focus of Mr. Abascal's studies, first toward the Progressive Era in American history, then to the law. He quit economics for the Hastings College of Law at the University of California, graduating in 1968.
Mr. Abascal went to work immediately as a staff lawyer for California Rural Legal Assistance, one of the many legal-services programs born of the War on Poverty. He started out in Salinas, quickly joining forces with the leaders of California's nascent farm workers' union, Cesar Chavez and Dolores Huerta.
Their collaboration resulted in several groundbreaking cases. One led to a ban on the use of the short-handled hoe, a symbol of harshness in the lettuce fields that allowed foremen to assume that their laborers were slacking off if they were not hunched over. In another, more contentious case, 19 farm workers represented by Mr. Abascal challenged the right of the University of California to conduct publicly financed research intended to develop labor-saving farm machinery.
Branded by his adversaries as a Luddite, Mr. Abascal responded that Congress had never meant to save money for big agribusiness enterprises. Rather, he said, it had intended to support "the little person, the person most in need."
Mr. Abascal's defense of that constituency led him into frequent battles with California's biggest farmers. A suit filed in 1969 on behalf of six nursing mothers who were working in the fields eventually led to the banning of DDT. Two decades later, two other cases in the Federal courts led to limits on dozens of pesticides thought to cause cancer.
In 1970, Mr. Abascal moved to the San Francisco Neighborhood Legal Assistance Foundation, where he filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of welfare recipients whose benefits were threatened by Governor Reagan's early efforts to cut the welfare rolls.
Years later, he described those efforts to fight poverty by preserving entitlements as fundamentally misguided.
"We should have been strong advocates of getting people into work," he said after President Clinton signed the welfare legislation last year. "Had we done that then, we would not have had this welfare bill now."
Mr. Abascal served on the boards of many legal and public-interest organizations and received many awards for his work, including the American Bar Association's Thurgood Marshall Award in 1995 and the Kutak-Dodds Prize of the National Legal Aid and Defender Association and the Robert Kutak Foundation.
The latter prize came with a $10,000 check, which Mr. Abascal put toward a small Chrysler convertible. Mr. Abascal, who once shared a single pair of wingtip "court" shoes with another lawyer whose feet were roughly the same size, had to stop himself in the interview from apologizing for the luxury.
Mr. Abascal is survived by his wife, Beatrice A. Moulton, a law professor at Hastings; their daughter, Pilar C., of Berkeley; two brothers, Manuel, of Santa Fe, N.M., and Richard, of Fremont, Calif., and a sister, Mary Jo, of San Diego.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Prices Fall Sharply As Worries on Rates Grow
Stock prices tumbled after a report showed a jump in housing starts in February, as investors feared a strong economy could prompt the Fed to raise rates. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged to a loss of nearly 101 points with about a half-hour remaining before recovering to 6,896.56, down 58.92. 
 Broader indexes also fell. The S.& P. 500 fell 6.05 points, to 789.66, and the Nasdaq composite fell 10.09, to 1,269.34. [Page D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed. The 30-year bond slipped 2/32, to 95 27/32 to yield 6.96 percent. [D18.]
 
Goldman, Sachs Profit Up 60%
Goldman, Sachs reported a 60 percent rise in pretax profit to $905 million in its fiscal first quarter, in a sign of continued huge earnings by Wall Street securities firms. [D7.]
 
News Corp. Seeking Pointcast
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is said to have offered $400 million for the Internet information distributor Pointcast Inc., but Pointcast executives want far more. [D2.]
 
Dangers as Big-Vehicle Sales Boom
With American drivers buying increasing numbers of light trucks -- which include sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans -- the consequences can be deadly. More Americans die in crashes involving a car and a light truck than in crashes involving two cars, even though the trucks make up only a third of the vehicles on the road. [ A1.]
 
Housing Starts Jump 12.2%
Housing starts jumped 12.2 percent in February to the highest level in almost three years, the latest evidence the economy is growing strongly. [D4.]
 
Price Fixing Charges Allowed
Criminal charges of price fixing can be brought against foreign companies even if the wrongdoing took place outside the United States, a Federal appeals court ruled in a case involving Nippon Paper Industries. [D2.]
 
Krupp Confirms Plan for Thyssen
Krupp-Hoesch, the German steelmaker, confirmed it would seek to buy Thyssen A.G., its largest competitor, for $8.1 billion. Thyssen vowed to fight but said it needed help. [D20.]
 
Incentives Swell I.B.M. Chief's Pay
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chief executive of I.B.M., took a $5,000 cut in his salary and bonus of nearly $5 million last year, the company's proxy statement showed. However, Graef S. Crystal, an executive compensation consultant, calculated that, thanks to growth of Mr. Gerstner's incentive pay package, his total pay rose 29.4 percent to $20.2 million. [D4.]
 
A Boeing Deal, Quandary for Gore
When Vice President Gore lands in Beijing next week, Chinese officials have suggested, he could preside over a billion-dollar deal for China to buy a fleet of Boeing 777 aircraft. But a deal puts Mr. Gore in a quandary, given the turmoil over campaign finances. [B9.]
 
N.A.S.D. Investigates 9 Brokerages
The N.A.S.D. is investigating nine brokerage firms and trading in 19 small companies for possible links to organized crime and other securities violations. [D8.]
 
Japan to Repackage Bad Loans
Stock prices rose in Japan after the Government took a long-awaited step to help banks clear their books of bad loans. [D18.]
 
Jacor Is Buying EFM Media
Jacor Communications is acquiring EFM Media Management, which is best known for distributing Rush Limbaugh's syndicated talk show, for undisclosed terms. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Gore in a Quandary Over the Chance to Seal Boeing Deal in China Trip

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The Chinese Government quietly approached the Clinton Administration recently with a deal it thought Washington could not refuse: When Vice President Gore lands in Beijing next week, Chinese officials suggested, he could preside over the signing of a billion-dollar deal for China to buy a small fleet of Boeing 777 aircraft.
But what looked like a plum opportunity -- a chance to beat out Europe's Airbus Industrie and protect hundreds of jobs at Boeing's plant in Seattle -- has turned into a foreign policy quandary. At a time when the White House is caught in the middle of campaign finance charges that make any deal with the Chinese the subject of intense scrutiny, some of Mr. Gore's aides say he should steer clear of events that sniff of deal-making. 
 And it does not help, officials familiar with the deal say, that China would send to the signing its hard-line Prime Minister, Li Peng, who presided over the 1989 crackdown on student demonstrators at Tiananmen Square.
"I can't tell you how many meetings there have been on this problem," one exasperated Administration official said earlier this week. "It's the kind of thing that paralyzes the White House these days."
Boeing, which has consistently complained that its huge orders are held hostage to the political atmosphere between China and Washington, has a clear position on this issue: It wants the Vice President to seal the deal.
"I don't think we know yet if we really have an order," said Thomas Tripp, the director of public affairs for the company. "These are the kinds of deals that are highly politicized to begin with. If the Vice President's schedule permits, and there is an order, we think it is entirely appropriate that he attend."
Mr. Gore's national security adviser, Leon Fuerth, was noncommittal today, saying, "We will consider any development that may arise if it is a normal transaction, appropriate and good for American business and labor, and in the commercial interests of the United States."
Mr. Fuerth noted that Mr. Gore was already scheduled to meet Mr. Li, in connection with the Vice President's main agenda: the environmental impact of China's industrialization.
Mr. Gore, Administration officials say, clearly does not want to appear to be snubbing the Chinese during his most important venture abroad. Nor does he want to jeopardize a deal that Boeing, which dominates China's air market, appears to have nearly in the bag.
But given the political environment in Washington, Mr. Gore's aides have worked hard in recent weeks to steer clear of potentially controversial economic issues. They have begged off detailed discussions of China's entry into the World Trade Organization, the biggest ongoing negotiation right now between the two capitals. No business executives are traveling with him, though in the first term they often accompanied Cabinet members on tours of the world's greatest emerging market.
Other world leaders have not been so shy. Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, has led several missions to China. So has France's President, Jacques Chirac. During his first term, President Clinton often put his weight behind major deals, including a Boeing sale to Saudi Arabia.
In recent months, though, there is evidence that the White House has been playing down that role. The new Commerce Secretary, William Daley, has issued strict regulations governing how companies are selected for participation in trade missions to pre-empt critics on Capitol Hill who charge that the Administration has favored big contributors. (Boeing donated $118,250 to the Democrats last year, but Federal Election Commission records show that it gave even more to Republicans.)
When pressed, Administration officials say they are no less committed to fighting a daily battle with Japan and Europe to win major contracts around the world, particularly those decided by foreign governments.
But no one is certain how to involve the President and the Vice President in those deals without appearing to make mercantilism seem a centerpiece of American foreign policy. It is a sign of the shift that one of the phrases that the late Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, used incessantly as he traveled around the world -- "commercial diplomacy" -- is all but banned in the White House today.
That may be more a matter of semantics than a shift in policy.
"It would be understandable if the Vice President was gun-shy about being identified with a big commercial deal in light of the alleged campaign scandals," said Jeffrey Garten, who was Undersecretary of Commerce for international trade during the first term and has written a book, soon to be published, about what the Commerce Department called "the big emerging markets."
"But it could be wrong to jump to the conclusion that commercial diplomacy is dead," Mr. Garten added. "We are in an intense struggle to win major projects abroad, and Government support will still be necessary. Whatever happens on this trip will not be determinative."

HEADLINE: 4,000 Hearts Full of Hope Line Up for 700 Jobs

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
Gayle Blanding pulled on her best dress, the navy one with the gold buttons, painted her lips cranberry and repeated her mantra: "I have great confidence. I have great skills." But the 38-year-old unemployed woman still trembled as she rode the A train from Harlem to midtown Manhattan yesterday.
"Don't worry, Mommy," whispered her 19-year-old daughter, who accompanied her part of the way. "You're going to get that job." 
Lasidy Honoret, a 33-year-old cook from the Dominican Republic, took an unpaid day's leave from his $5-an-hour job at a Boston Market and practiced his English during the subway ride from Woodhaven, Queens. "A job with benefits," he said.
And Elizabeth Gatling, 55, stuffed her black canvas bag with dozens of multi-colored resumes and certificates from every training program she had ever completed. And as she rode to Manhattan from Crown Heights in Brooklyn, she envisioned a whole new world where she could pay her electric bills on time and permanently erase the stigma of public assistance.
"I'm not asking for no pity," she said. "I just want to get off welfare."
What drew them from their homes before dawn yesterday was a tiny classified advertisement in the local newspapers: the possibility of getting one of the 700 jobs at the soon-to-reopen Roosevelt Hotel in midtown Manhattan. By noon, 4,000 job seekers had formed a a twisting, turning human chain that extended two square blocks and reflected the city's dreams and frustrations.
While Wall Street booms and stock brokers rake in big bonuses, ordinary workers are finding it harder and harder to find jobs, some economists say. Earlier this month, the state announced that unemployment in January had reached its highest level in three years, climbing to 9.9 percent. And some economists fear that in coming years the city may no longer produce the kinds of entry-level jobs upon which so many have historically depended.
"They're making money on Wall Street, but that money and those jobs are not making it down to us, the people," Mr. Honoret said.
There were teen-agers wearing diamond studs in their noses and baseball caps on their heads, bouncing in time to the rhythms of their radios as they waited on line. There were middle-aged men wearing business suits and clutching leather portfolios. There were welfare recipients afraid of losing their benefits, and immigrants still searching for the golden streets of America.
Many job seekers waited as long as eight hours to fill out an application. But they said it was worth it. Behind the hotel's grand doors, which were still covered with plywood, they could imagine a world of steady work, of tuxedo-wearing waiters juggling plates, of uniformed maids making beds, of smartly dressed front-desk clerks welcoming guests and tapping on computers.
"I got a 3-month-old daughter to support, so I'll do anything for a real job," said Martiza Rivera, 23, who lost her job as a supermarket cashier six months ago and arrived at the hotel at 7 A.M. "I just want her to have the things I've never had. A bank account. A college education. It's hard waiting out here for so long. But when I get tired I just think of her, smiling at me."
The 1,033-room Roosevelt Hotel, which sits on the corner of 45th Street and Madison Avenue, is scheduled to reopen in late April after 18 months of renovation. And the classified advertisements, which appeared on two consecutive Sundays, called on housekeepers, managers, maintenance workers and security guards to apply during a four-day job fair, which began yesterday.
The hotel's manager said his staff had expected to interview 1,000 people a day and to pay those hired anywhere from $6 to $15 an hour. But no one anticipated the thousands thatshowed up, some as early as 3 A.M.
"I've never seen anything quite like it," said Ted Knighton, who is opening the hotel for Interstate Hotels, a management company.
Police officers set up barricades to control the surging crowd, which snaked around 46th Street, down Vanderbilt Avenue, back across 45th Street, up Madison Avenue, and back to the entrance on 46th. There were so many people that the officers even started another line on the opposite side of 46th Street, which snaked around another city block, creating the effect of a boxy figure eight of human bodies.
Disillusioned by the deluge of applicants, some job seekers went home. Others waited for hours in the chilly weather, sipping coffee, conducting mock interviews, and shouting down those who dared to cut into the line.
"My brain is frozen," said Ms. Blanding, who waited for eight hours, biding her time by flipping through the book her daughter had borrowed from the library, "Naked at the Interview: Tips and Quizzes to Prepare for Your First Real Job."
"But I'm not leaving until I get seen," she said firmly.
She would not say what caused her to lose her job a year ago. But others were more forthcoming, describing how the restaurants they worked in had failed, how they fell onto welfare, or how they desperately needed the security that their current jobs cannot provide.
"I have work, but I don't have benefits," explained Mr. Honoret, who said he was a lawyer in his own country but had worked in factories and supermarkets since he arrived in the United States five years ago.
At first, he dreamed of saving enough money to attend Harvard University, of sending money regularly to his 70-year-old mother, and of working as a professional. He has not given up on that dream, but sometimes as he mashes potatoes and roasts chicken at Boston Market, he wonders why he ever left home.
"I'm just a cook now," said Mr. Honoret, who wore jeans and a St. Louis Cardinals baseball cap. "Sometimes, I think I'm just too scared to admit that I can't make it here."
Farther down the line, Mrs. Gatling reminisced about the last real job she had, four years ago. She worked in an office, dumping trash, cleaning bathrooms and sweeping floors, and earned $300 a week. She had a credit card then and bought a brand-new bedroom set from Seaman's. "That was the best I ever had," she said.
When she got laid off, she went on welfare and has been on it ever since. But the classified advertisement gave her new hope.
She started to dream about paying off her bills, buying new boots and maybe even treating herself to a pair of fancy stockings.
"I'm gonna try and sell myself," Mrs. Gatling said as the line inched forward. "I'm gonna look the person in the eye and tell them the truth: I'm honest and reliable and I'm desperate for work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thousands of people lined up at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan early yesterday in response to a want ad. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton Hopes to Jump-Start Bipartisan Talks on Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
President Clinton sought today to re-energize the stalled effort to balance the Federal budget, laying out steps to get the two sides talking again.
Mr. Clinton said that in particular he was heartened by comments from Republicans suggesting they might delay their demands for sweeping tax cuts and had softened their opposition to the economic assumptions used in his budget plan. 
 Saying the nation is "closer than ever to the point where we can reach an agreement on a balanced budget," Mr. Clinton appealed for a restoration of the bipartisan spirit that marked the early weeks of the budget process this year, and said both sides would need to make politically painful sacrifices to reach a deal.
"No one will achieve everything he or she wants," the President said at a news conference. "Everyone must be prepared to compromise if we're going to break the gridlock and finally balance the budget."
Mr. Clinton said he would meet at the White House on Wednesday with the leaders of the Congressional budget committees to discuss the prospects of forging an agreement that would eliminate the Federal deficit by 2002.
The President said he would follow up on the meeting by instructing his aides to continue discussions with the Republicans during the two-week Congressional recess that begins Friday. And he said he wanted both his own team and the Congressional budget chairmen to report back to him and to the Republican leadership early next month "on the progress they have made and the best means for reaching the bipartisan agreement we all seek."
There has been little substantive contact between the White House and Republican leaders since the President submitted his budget plan to Congress last month. Republicans have criticized the Administration's plan without offering an alternative, and the impasse grew worst last week when the White House abandoned an effort to save tens of billions of dollars by reducing cost-of-living increases for people receiving Social Security benefits.
Republicans said tonight that they were skeptical that Mr. Clinton's initiative would yield any significant progress unless he made some specific concessions.
The President did not specify what compromises he might be willing to make, and it was unclear whether what he called the Republicans' "new flexibility on tax cuts and economic assumptions" would live up to the billing he gave it.
Indeed, Republicans spent much of the day trying to dispel the notion that they were backing off from the party's demands that a big tax cut be part of any budget agreement.
On Monday, Speaker Newt Gingrich said he might be willing to fashion a plan that eliminated the deficit but did not include sweeping tax cuts. Mr. Gingrich said the question of tax cuts could be considered separately after Congress and the Administration locked in the spending cuts necessary to balance the budget.
Today, Mr. Gingrich welcomed Mr. Clinton's efforts. "I am encouraged by the movement on the White House's part toward reopening the budget negotiations," he said in a statement. "I hope the President's words indicate that the Administration is now ready to move beyond partisan politics and work with the Congress in a flexible and positive manner to reach a balanced budget."
Although it was Mr. Gingrich's statement that led the White House to make its effort to get negotiations going again, a number of influential Republicans said that the Speaker was alluding only to a procedural question of when to consider tax proposals, and that neither he nor other Republican leaders were backing away from their demand for a broad-based tax reduction.
Mr. Gingrich's suggestion that balancing the budget should come first further deepened a rift among Republicans over tax cuts, an issue at the heart of the party's agenda for the last two years.
Representative David M. McIntosh of Indiana, who was elected to the House in the Republican sweep of 1994 and is one of those most emphatic about using tax cuts as a means to shrink the size of the Federal Government, sent a letter to Mr. Gingrich today urging him to insist that tax cuts be part of any budget deal.
"It's one thing to give the leadership wide berth to develop a strategy for a budget agreement, but it's something else entirely when the leadership's chief strategy is to capitulate on a fundamental Republican principle," Mr. McIntosh said.
But some Republicans admitted they were in a quandary over their tax cut proposals, which range up to $200 billion over five years. Unless they want to push for deep and politically suicidal spending cuts, there is no way for them to enact their tax cuts while continuing to insist that the budget be built on the conservative economic assumptions developed by the Congressional Budget Office.
In a telling example of what it would take to enact the complete Republican tax plan, Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and a leading advocate of deep tax cuts, made a compromise proposal. His plan would require using the more optimistic economic assumptions developed by the White House and would assume billions of dollars in savings from a change in the formula for cost-of-living payments for Social Security, an idea so sensitive that the White House backed away from it last week.
Even with those assumptions, Senator Roth's plan would still require delaying by a year the enactment of the Republicans' main tax cut, an increased credit for families with children.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, has said several time in the last few weeks that he would consider a compromise on the economic assumptions employed by the two sides, which could substantially narrow the gap.
But more than anything, it was the White House's decision last week not to pursue reducing cost-of-living increases for benefit recipients that left Republicans scrambling for ways to keep their sometimes conflicting budget goals intact.
The meeting on Wednesday at the White House will include the Republican chairmen of the Senate and House Budget Committees, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, as well as the ranking Democrats on those committees, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina.
In addition to Mr. Clinton, the White House team will include Erskine B. Bowles, the chief of staff; Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary; Franklin D. Raines, the budget chief; John Hilley, the liaison to Congress, and Gene Sperling, head of the National Economic Council.

HEADLINE: NASA Plans to Study Forests and Global Gravity

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The space agency announced today that it would sponsor two low-cost satellite projects to study the distribution of Earth's forests and provide a detailed map of the planet's gravity field.
National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials said the new economical projects, part of the agency's Mission to Planet Earth program, were intended to complement more expensive space missions to study the planet's environment. 
 William Townsend, the NASA official in charge of the program, said the new missions were part of the agency's renewed focus on quickly developing and flying smaller, less expensive spacecraft that have limited objectives rather than concentrating on billion-dollar missions.
After a competition, NASA selected 2 of 12 semifinalist projects to finance and a third project to be sponsored as a backup.
The first to fly is expected to be the Vegetation Canopy Lidar mission, a satellite that would orbit 250 miles above Earth, firing energy pulses from five lasers to the ground. The mission would spend two years accumulating three-dimensional details of 98 percent of the world's forests. The satellite is scheduled for launching in January 2000 on a Pegasus rocket, said Dr. Ralph Dubayah of the University of Maryland, the chief mission scientist.
Dr. Dubayah said the safe, low-power laser beams would scan strips of forests more than 80 feet wide to determine the height of foliage. That would allow more precise measurements of tree heights, the cataloging of information about forest canopies and greatly improved estimates of global biomass, or the number or mass of living organisms in a particular area, he said.
The forest survey mission has a budget of $59.8 million, which includes the price of launchings, as well as data gathering and analysis, NASA said.
The second mission selected is the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment, which plans to use two satellites, to be launched by a Russian rocket in 2001, to measure gravity fluctuations while flying in formation 280 miles above Earth. A team headed by Dr. Byron D. Tapley of the University of Texas in Austin plans to work with a German group led by Dr. Christoph Reigher of GeoFor schungsZentrum in Potsdam to launch and operate the satellites for up to five years.
NASA plans to spend $85.9 million on this mission for the United States investigators to build the satellites and instruments. The Germans agreed to contribute an additional $40 million to buy a Russian Cosmos launching rocket and to control mission operations, officials said.
The satellites, expected to fly 60 to 250 miles apart in the same orbit around Earth's poles, would be linked by microwave signals to calibrate their distance from each other and changes in movement caused by the gravitational pull of masses like large metal deposits on Earth.
If one of these missions is canceled, NASA said, it will invest up to $500,000 over two years for preliminary work on a backup project to map the movement of 30 types of gases, particles and pollutants in the atmosphere.

HEADLINE: Pact Reported For New York Lilco Takeover

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki plans to announce an agreement today on a multibillion dollar state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, including billions of dollars in debt from the defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, participants in the negotiations said last night.
The move is expected to result in rate reductions of 20 percent or more for customers who pay the highest energy rates in the nation. 
 Under the long-sought-after agreement, the state's Long Island Power Authority would purchase transmission and distribution lines and retail service operations including billing, installation and repairs from Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas, which has a pending merger agreement with Lilco. The deal also includes an option for the power authority to later purchase Lilco's power generation plants.
But most importantly, the state would assume the billions in debt from the Shoreham nuclear plant, which the state would pay for with a tax-free bond issue at a rate much smaller than what Lilco is currently paying.
The Power Authority can pay off the debt more cheaply than Lilco because it can borrow money at lower interest rates. That translates to lower rates for consumers.
The deal must still clear several hurdles, which include obtaining the approval of State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the state's Public Service Commission and obtaining a waiver of capital gains taxes for Lilco shareholders from the Internal Revenue Service.
Lilco, which has a merger with the Brooklyn Union Gas Company pending, and state officials have petitioned the Internal Revenue Service to forgive the capital gains tax liability, or at least postpone it for many years, and the I.R.S. has not ruled on the matter.
The deal would allow Mr. Pataki to claim victory after two years of promising rate relief to a region that will be key to his re-election hopes, and to take credit for the resolution of the Shoreham quagmire, which long eluded his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo.
Long Island's electric rates -- nearly double the national average, with the average household paying about $100 a month -- are a perennial source of fury from residents and businesses and, officials say, a damper on the local economy.
Also included in the deal is a settlement of a lawsuit in which Lilco was awarded a judgment worth as much as $1.1 billion against Suffolk County, the Town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham Wading River School district. The lawsuit alleged that Lilco was overcharged on property taxes since the early 1980's and the judgment threatened to bankrupt the local governments.
Under the agreement reached last night, that case will be settled for $625 million. Electricity customers in Suffolk County will pay a surcharge to cover the cost of the settlement.
Because of this surcharge, Nassau utility customers stand to gain the most from the deal: a 22 percent rate reduction.
Under the agreement, the Long Island Power Authority will hire Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas to run the electrical operations. In addition, the companies would continue to provide natural gas service for Long Island as well as for Brooklyn Union's current customers in New York City.

HEADLINE: As Rents Move Up, Roommates Move In

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
AT age 35, Antonio Da Motta thought he was too old for one particular rite of passage. But in October, pressed by a 30 percent jump in his rent, Mr. Da Motta, a designer and showroom manager, decided to take in a roommate so he could stay in his home of four years, a 700-square-foot loft in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. It was not an option many people would relish, and for a designer it was doubly scary: "The prospect of living with a stranger terrified me," he said, "not just because I wouldn't know how they would act, but because I couldn't be sure of what kind of taste they'd have."
With a new set of duplicate keys, Mr. Da Motta has joined a significant if largely untracked subset of New Yorkers who are coping with the steep rise in rents, especially in Manhattan, by making space for strangers to share their refrigerators, their bathrooms and their lives. 
 These midlife roommates are different from the young college graduates who have always split the rent two, three or more ways until they could establish themselves. Long-term home sharers are "career renters," real estate agents say. For many, sharing is the only way they can stay in New York. Others welcome another presence in the apartment to counter "the only sounds I hear are the high heels upstairs" isolation of city life.
While no one charts exact numbers of roommates, Nancy Packes, the president of Feathered Nest, a real estate agency that regularly surveys trends in Manhattan's rental market, said she suspected that as many as 30 percent of the tenants whose rents are under $2,500 are sharing.
"Starting in 1994, we started seeing the most dramatic increase in rents since the crazy 80's," Ms. Packes said. "There's a tightening of the economy for all but the high rollers. And along with the high rents, budgets are staying the same or dropping, so it's no surprise that the share phenomenon is very, very big right now."
Traditionally, the rule of thumb dictated that monthly rent should not exceed 25 percent of one's gross income. In Manhattan, that can easily go as high as 35 percent, real estate agents say. (Many landlords use a different formula in an effort to assure that prospective tenants can afford their apartments. The formula, which increasingly shows up in leases, requires that gross annual income be 40 to 50 times the monthly rent.)
When the rent starts to creep higher than 35 percent of income, that's when people start to think roommate, said Michael Beltrami, a vice president of the Stribling Wells & Gay agency.
He said that the typical roommate has grown older and better educated in the last 15 years and that the threat of changes in the city's rent stabilization and rent control laws has helped fuel the change. In Mr. Da Motta's case, the 30 percent increase, to $1,940, occurred when his landlord informed him that he was ending a discount in his lease in anticipation of rent deregulation.
Indeed, for Roommate Finders, at 18 one of the oldest agencies in the business, 1996 was a very good year, with business up 22 percent over 1995. The founder, Michael Santomauro, says his typical client is getting older and is as likely to be 40 as 20.
Lisa Wisely, an owner of Roommates N.Y.C., a three-year-old company created to tap into the booming shares market, added: "I've seen people from every walk of life, with every need. People always think that when they're done with their 20's they won't be doing this anymore. That's no longer the case."
Carol Sommers, 59, a travel agent, saw her income drop precipitously two years ago after a business failure and faced the possibility of losing the one-bedroom Gramercy Park apartment where she had brought up two children. Determined to stay, Ms. Sommers installed louvered doors on the 11-by-12-foot room that had served over the years as dining room, nursery and home office. She listed the room at what she calls the "preposterously high rent" of $500, and the phone rang off the wall.
"I saw 17 people in the first week," she recalled. "There were doctors, lawyers, Indian chiefs. I never thought there would be so many people out there looking to share such a little space. I had my pick of the best." She chose a young man from Canada who was training to become an architect.
As with more than a dozen other sharers interviewed, coexisting in a small apartment has turned out to be less complicated than she expected, especially as it applies to sharing a single bathroom. The tacit understanding among roommates seems to be, Wait till the bathroom lights are out, and then proceed. Likewise, roommates with similar kitchen habits seem to gravitate to each other, and many prefer tenants who eat out, order in, or otherwise can limit their cooking to the microwave oven.
(Not Ms. Sommers: she always keeps plenty of food on hand. "It's my Jewish upbringing," she said. "I've got to be able to feed 40 people at all times, even if they never show up." She says her roommates are welcome to all the food they want, as long as they replace it with the same brands.)
 FOR many who share their apartments, what began as a financial necessity has evolved into a desirable way of life.
"I like having a kid back in the house without the emotional involvement," Ms. Sommers said. "They can do things that would have made my hair stand on end if they were my children, but I can sit back and enjoy it."
There are even those who don't depend on the additional rent but have become accustomed to the little luxuries that the extra money affords them. A 45-year-old computer graphics manager in TriBeCa said she uses the $700 a month she gets for sharing her four-bedroom loft as mad money for manicures, massages and weekend getaways.
Karen Gerber's motives for sharing are part economic, part esthetic: she loves her two-bedroom apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn. It is roomy, the sun pours in all day and the long views of Brooklyn brownstones are humble but charming. "It's big enough here for two to have privacy," said Ms. Gerber, an instructor at the Fashion Institute of Technology. "There's no comparison with the quality of life that having a roommate makes possible for me. I couldn't stand living in a little box of a studio, which is all I could afford on my own."
Andy Velez, 58, a writer, has a rent-stabilized apartment but has watched his rent gradually double in the last 15 years. Three years ago, he wanted to freelance full time and realized the only way he could do it was to share his two-bedroom Greenwich Village apartment. After four roommates that he termed "learning experiences," Mr. Velez now shares his home with an actor who is often away, most recently on tour in "The Phantom of the Opera."
"Ideally, I would rather not have a roommate, and I anticipate the day that I won't need to," Mr. Velez said. But meanwhile, he added, "it's very pleasant to have a friendly face around the house."
"Our lives are complementary but not deeply intermingled, which suits both of us," he said.
Mr. Da Motta, the designer, turned the arrival of his roommate, Web Tysver, 25, into a design opportunity.
He got out the masking tape and outlined a new angled wall near the front door of his long, thin, one-bedroom apartment. With a designer's sense of proportion, he placed the wall to give an improved sense of flow from the entrance into the living room, allowing people to feel enclosed on entering and then, a few steps later, to be treated to a sweeping view of the far end of the apartment and the view through the three eight-foot windows toward a warehouse tiled in terra cotta.
He found Mr. Tysver by canvassing friends. Mr. Tysver filled the bill admirably: he was an acquaintance, and a designer himself.
Mr. Tysver's rent deposit of $800 went toward building the new angled wall. The cocoon-shaped space carved out of the entrance hall had an inoperable window, so Mr. Tysver suggested inserting a small window in the interior wall. It has fluted, hammered glass for privacy, but when opened, it admits a neat shaft of light into the interior of the apartment. The new 12-foot-high wall, made of dry wall on a frame of metal studs, even allows for more storage space tucked into the top three feet.
The new living arrangement has proven a mutual success. After four years of living alone in New York, Mr. Da Motta was surprised to discover that perhaps he had needed a roommate all along. "I was born in a crowd," he said of his large family in Brazil. "I should have known that living alone was not for me. Looking back, I realize that some of the emotional difficulties of those first years here may have had to do with the basic lack of companionship."
Like many others who share apartments, Mr. Da Motta and Mr. Tysver have found that some expected flash points turn out not to be so fraught with tension. Sharing a bathroom, for instance, has never been an issue. Nor have kitchen privileges: "We don't share food generally," Mr. Da Motta said, "but we don't label everything either. The only hard and fast rule is, Don't leave dirty dishes in the sink."
He added that in his view there are two essential amenities to easing the roommate way of life: separate phone lines, and a cleaning service. To that, the design-savvy Mr. Da Motta adds one more sine qua non: a soundproof bedroom. To achieve that, he lined his walls with fabrics: hanging velvets hide the closets, and a large tapestry fills another wall. On the floors, a Japanese sea grass rug is bordered in linen and rubberized on the back to further insulate against noise. For the ceilings, Mr. Da Motta designed an ingenious tentlike web of theatrical muslin affixed with eye hooks connecting to a wood valance running around the walls.
Unlike many other roommates who guard their privacy zealously, Mr. Da Motta and Mr. Tysver have found that they enjoy socializing with each other's friends. "When Web is entertaining, I'm an instant guest," Mr. Da Motta said.
"It's nice to have someone there to help with little emergencies," Mr. Tysver said, adding: "Even if the money weren't a factor, I would consider it. It's much better than having a pet."
 
Deregulation: Ins and Outs
 
THE laws that govern rent regulation in New York will expire on June 15 unless the Legislature in Albany takes action to renew them. Speculation is running high about what might happen to the tenants of rent-regulated apartments if the law is changed or allowed to expire.
Currently, rent regulations can be removed from an occupied apartment if the rent exceeds $2,000 a month and if the occupants make $250,000 a year for two consecutive years.
While real estate watchers acknowledge that no one knows for certain what is going to happen, among the most discussed possibilities is lowering the income threshold for this "luxury decontrol," perhaps to $150,000.
An even more likely possibility, said Ann Snee, a managing director of the Corcoran Group, the Manhattan real estate company, is "decontrol by attrition," meaning that apartments would be deregulated as they became vacant. Current laws allow deregulation only for vacant apartments where rents will be $2,000 or more.
For people considering a roommate, an important caution: The combined incomes of the prime tenant plus the incomes of all roommates will be the figure used in determining whether an apartment is eligible for deregulation. So taking in an investment banker could mean that the rent for your stabilized apartment would be repegged at market value.

(Some agents average the figure to 45.) The total is what you should be earning annually. If you're not, maybe it's time to get a roommate.

HEADLINE: The Pop Life

BYLINE: By Neil Strauss 

 BODY:

Aerosmith's 'Nine Lives'
The fact that Aerosmith is still a major force in the music world is one of pop culture's great unsolved mysteries. By all rights, Aerosmith should be nostalgia by now. Since the late 70's, this hard-rock band has been buffeted by drug abuse, in-fighting, musical stasis and all kinds of business problems. It has let its record labels make its creative decisions for it, and it has managed to ally itself with everything that marketing surveys deem cutting-edge -- rap music, the Internet, CD-ROM's -- while hardly changing its boy's-night-out sound (except for maybe increasing the ratio of power ballads to rockers).
The story behind its current album, "Nine Lives," released on Columbia on Tuesday, would seem fantastic even to a soap-opera script-writer: the band laid off its longtime manager, dismissed its record producer, temporarily lost a member to depression, weathered accusations of straying from sobriety (which it denies), underwent group therapy, made a controversial decision to release a promotional album solely to Wal-Mart and remade the entirety of "Nine Lives" because Columbia didn't like it. 
 For Aerosmith, every album is a fight to stay relevant. And at Tuesday night's release party for "Nine Lives" at the newly renovated Hammerstein Ballroom in Manhattan Center, the band fought hard. It sought to throw the most elaborate and extravagant record-release party of the year, and like most events staged by arena-rock bands of the Aerosmith type, it was a grand but empty gesture.
That's not to say that the party was bad. It was a great spectacle. For the first half of the night, the hall was divided into nine rooms, each representing a different song on "Nine Lives." There was an aquarium room, with a woman dressed in a mermaid outfit and waitresses serving sea breeze cocktails and oyster shots. There was a petting zoo, with women dressed up like animals and a cellist playing Aerosmith songs. There was a pole-dance room, a devil's room and a doctor's office. What tied them together was that each had a different cocktail and a different scantily clad woman wearing fetish apparel.
After a couple of hours, the partitions that separated the rooms were raised to the ceiling to reveal a large stage. There was a trite display of subversive entertainment -- a combination freak show and fetish ball with a sword swallower, an escape artist and many rubber-clad women (perhaps in honor of the new album's couplet, "I want to be your lover/I want to wrap you in rubber"). And then Aerosmith performed the first concert in the remodeled hall, which is to open to the public in May.
The band played mostly new, innuendo-drenched songs, occasionally looking back to the 70's for hits like "Sweet Emotion" and "Walk This Way." Oddly, the band's new album rocks (and rocking is Aerosmith's renewed priority) a lot more than the half-hour show did. Nonetheless, Aerosmith succeeded in disproving one lyric on "Nine Lives": the one where the 48-year-old Steven Tyler sings "I'm no Peter Pan."
 
 
Bruce Odland and Sam Auinger
 In recent years, the sound artists Bruce Odland and Sam Auinger have used as their acoustic canvas a castle in Linz, Austria, ancient ruins in Rome and the entire town of Salzburg in Austria. Last week, they labored on their latest: Manhattan's warehouse district. From the Kitchen performance space, the pair turned the sounds of the city into eerily beautiful music.
Approaching the Kitchen, one could see a long white tube hanging down the side of the building, a parabolic dish spinning on the roof and, on top of the Roxy club, a white tube like a Cyclops gazing across the West Side Highway. The sights of the city were captured on camera by the parabolic dishes while the sounds traveled through the long white tubes (each tuned to a different note) into the second floor of the Kitchen, where they were sent through a battery of digital effects. After this journey, the impatient hum of the West Side Highway filled the Kitchen like ominous music from a horror film while 10th Avenue buzzed like a musical swarm of bees.
"After we first did this installation," Mr. Odland said, "I dreamt all night that I was a bee and couldn't get the honey off my wings. The sounds are from an industrial soundscape generated by the economy of the city that our brains can't decode. It's like a human hive. But instead of being about honey, it's about money."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Against the Mark On Rate Bets in the 2 Nations

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the mark yesterday for the first time in four days after a report on Germany's money supply reinforced expectations that the Bundesbank would not soon raise German interest rates.
The central bank said that its key inflation gauge, the M-3 money supply, grew at a 9.1 percent annual rate in February from the fourth quarter of 1996, slowing from January. 
 "The M-3 number shows inflation is still low," said Ivar Bjornstad, foreign-exchange chief at Den Norske Bank. "That has people thinking the Bundesbank is on hold, and helped the dollar against the mark."
The dollar was also bolstered by reports on February consumer prices and wages in the United States, which lent themselves to the notion that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates. The Fed's key committee meets next week.
"The U.S. economy is stronger than Germany's, rates are higher, and I think the Fed may tighten in March and May," said Hans Boman, a currency trader at Swedbank.
The premium of American interest rates over German rates makes dollar investments attractive. Foreigners' purchase of dollars has helped push the currency up 9 percent against the mark this year. German 10-year bonds yield 5.91 percent, compared with 6.73 percent for United States 10-year bonds.
"I don't see in the next 12 months how interest-rate differentials could turn against the dollar," said Laura Zimmerman, senior portfolio strategist at Payden & Rygel of Los Angeles, which manages $23 billion.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.6816 marks, up from a three-week low of 1.6727 marks on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 122.82 Japanese yen from 122.43 yen. But it fell against the British pound, which traded at $1.5982 compared with $1.5901 late Tuesday.
A report showing rising business confidence in Germany tempered enthusiasm for the dollar. The Ifo economic institute said its index of western German business confidence rose to 93.6 in February from 93.3 in January. The February reading is the highest since June 1995.
"That takes some of the gloom and doom out of the German economy," said Stephen Flanagan, a currency trader with Credit Agricole.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The New Iron Curtain

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If you have any doubts that the cold war is over, I suggest you watch CNN's coverage of Albania.
The CNN reports usually begin by showing a map of the sea off Albania. On this map are little ships, each representing one of the U.S. and other foreign naval vessels that have rushed to Albania's shores. In the cold war, the ships on that map would have been U.S. and Soviet warships competing over who would get into Albania first, fill the vacuum there and thus gain an edge in the worldwide superpower competition. In the new era, an era defined not by the cold war but by globalization, the game is different: The winner is the country whose navy gets its citizens out of Albania first and gets away the fastest. Today, the loser occupies Albania; the winner evacuates Albania. 
 And that's why conflicts like Albania, Zaire, Liberia and Algeria don't spread quite the way they used to. In the cold war, these internal conflicts had a built-in reason to spread. The world was divided into zones of influence, and if pro-Soviet forces rose in Albania or Zaire, the U.S. supported pro-American forces next door. And thus not only did the two superpowers help conflicts to spread, by backing different factions, they funded these factions to carry on the war.
Now flash forward to the new world of globalization -- a world in which the integration of financial networks, information and trade is binding the globe together and shifting power from governments to markets. In the world of globalization there is only one superpower: the U.S. There is no worldwide competition with the Soviets, so there is no automatic impulse for the U.S. to take sides in Albania or Zaire. There's no "our guys" because there's no "their guys."
And no one even pretends today that the war in Albania is Karl Marx vs. Thomas Jefferson. It's more Thomas Hobbes vs. Thomas Hobbes -- the state mafia vs. the street mafia. The Financial Times quoted a woman in Albania dragging away her front door for firewood as describing the political choices like this: "I don't care about the royal family or the President. They are all scum."
In the cold war, all that a third-world government like Albania's needed to do to get funds was to align with a superpower. But today the U.S. is low on cash and Moscow's broke. It is the supermarkets -- the Tokyo, Hong Kong, Singapore, London, Paris, Frankfurt and Wall Street stock markets -- that pass out the cash now. And the supermarkets don't finance civil wars. Rather, they punish countries for war-making by withholding any investment capital for them to grow. In the world of globalization, the only way Albania or Zaire get financed is if they have a real government, and it's precisely because they didn't that they melted down. Now they get the new Iron Curtain -- the one the supermarkets build around the Zaires and Albanias, to seal them off, so the world can do business around them.
Still, globalization doesn't mean the end of geopolitics. All you have to do is look at China vs. Taiwan or Arabs vs. Israelis to know that competition for territory, resources and identity have not gone away in a market-dominated world. But globalization definitely changes the costs and benefits that countries have to calculate as they play out their geopolitics. The conflicts in Albania or Zaire could spread, but it will be more like a cancer spilling over the border, not something driven from outside.
All of this has become rather confusing for U.S. diplomats, suckled on the cold war. Who are the good guys in Zaire, besides the innocent civilians, and how do we help them? One U.S. diplomat I know who served in Moscow and is now in Africa said to me: "When I joined the Foreign Service, you knew where the goalposts were, and you knew all the plays. But now it's like you're in the huddle and everyone is asking everyone else, 'Which way is the goal line?'
"The more I'm here," my friend added, "the more I feel like I'm in that scene of 'The Grapes of Wrath,' when the banker comes to take away the tenant farmer's home and the farmer threatens to shoot the banker, but the banker says it's not his fault, he's just working for the Big Corporation. The farmer asks, but where does it all stop? Who can we shoot? And the banker says, 'I don't know, maybe there's nobody to shoot.' "

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Price Index Rose by 0.3% In February

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February, led by higher costs for fresh vegetables and natural gas, the Labor Department said today.
Still, prices not including food and energy remained tame. The closely watched core rate, which excludes those two categories, increased only two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Analysts had expected today's report to show gains of two-tenths of 1 percent in both the rate over all and in the core rate. During January, consumer prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent, the smallest increase since June 1996, and the core rate grew by the same amount.
Technological improvements, competition and an unusual absence of wage inflation -- at least until last month -- have helped contain prices in many industries. Nevertheless, evidence of economic strength -- a rebound in industrial production, relatively robust retail sales and rapid employment growth -- suggests to many analysts that Federal Reserve policy makers will consider raising interest rates to cool the economy and guard against accelerating inflation. They meet next Tuesday.
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, "made it clear that trends in the core rate may not be favorable in 1997," said Scott Brown, an economist at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla., before today's report. "That is, if the Fed doesn't act preventively."
Another report issued today could influence the policy makers. The Labor Department said that Americans' weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, increased 2.4 percent in February from January -- the largest increase on record.
Earnings had fallen in January; the decline was revised today to 1.7 percent from 2.1 percent.
Economists are concerned about the potential for accelerating labor costs stemming from the low unemployment rate, which has forced many employers to offer higher wages to attract job applicants. Labor costs, including wages and benefits, account for about two-thirds of consumer prices.
February's report on consumer prices said food prices, which account for about one-sixth of the Consumer Price Index, increased three-tenths of 1 percent as the cost of fresh vegetables rose by the largest amount in almost two years. Beef, poultry and dairy costs were lower.
Energy prices, which account for about one-tenth of the index, rose three-tenths of 1 percent. Natural gas prices surged for a second month while gasoline prices showed little change and fuel oil prices dropped. Natural gas prices have been running about 14 percent above their levels a year ago.
In other categories, housing costs climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, while costs of clothing, medical treatment and entertainment each rose two-tenths of 1 percent. Transportation costs dropped one-tenth of 1 percent as airline fares continued to fall.
Last week, the Labor Department said producer prices unexpectedly fell four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the largest decline in more than two years.

HEADLINE: Court Opens Species Act To Wider List Of Challenges

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that people can sue the Federal Government not only for doing too little to protect endangered species, but also for doing too much.
The unanimous decision opens the door to lawsuits under the Endangered Species Act by people whose economic interests are affected by restrictions placed on land and water use for the purpose of protecting endangered species. A Federal appeals court had ruled, in a 1995 decision the Court overturned today, that those complaining about overregulation lacked legal standing to sue because they did not fall within the "zone of interests" the Endangered Species Act was enacted to protect. 
 The decision today, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, reinstated a lawsuit brought against the Fish and Wildlife Service by a group of Oregon ranchers and irrigation districts seeking to block proposed limitations on the release of water from the Klamath Irrigation Project near the Oregon-California border.
The wildlife service had issued a report concluding that higher water levels should be maintained in two of the project's reservoirs to protect the habitat of two endangered species of fish, the Lost River sucker and the shortnose sucker.
The ranchers' suit alleged that there was no evidence that the population of the fish was declining in the reservoirs or that higher water levels would help them. The Federal District Court in Eugene, Ore., dismissed the lawsuit in a ruling that the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, affirmed.
In reinstating the lawsuit, the Court said today that there was no basis in the Endangered Species Act for concluding that the right to challenge the way the Government enforces the law "applies to environmentalists alone."
Justice Scalia noted that Congress wrote no limitation into a provision of the law authorizing "any person" to bring a suit challenging the way the Secretary of the Interior is carrying out the law. He said there was no reason to interpret the provision as applying only to "underenforcement" but not to "overenforcement."
Most other Federal environmental laws, including the Clean Water Act, the Clean Air Act, the Safe Drinking Water Act, and others, also include similarly worded "citizen suit" provisions that will presumably now be available to those seeking to challenge regulatory actions under those laws.
The case, Bennett v. Spear, No. 95-813, attracted considerable attention from business and property-rights groups, which argued in briefs filed with the Supreme Court that the Ninth Circuit's decision had turned the Endangered Species Act into an unfairly one-sided law.
W. Henson Moore, president of the American Forest and Paper Association, praised the Supreme Court's ruling in an interview today as restoring balance to the law.
Given the expense of litigation, industry groups would not rush to bring "a rash of cases," Mr. Moore said, "but when it's a question of poor science or regulation gone overbroad, you'll find the law now being used to correct it."
The Clinton Administration defended the Ninth Circuit's decision to dismiss the lawsuit, although the Administration's brief did not adopt the appeals court's reasoning. Environmental groups filed no briefs in the case, because they have most often been on the side of urging the Court to take a more expansive view of the right to sue and so did not want to be on record as urging a more restrictive view of legal standing even for their opponents.
"Citizens ought to have access to the courthouse to make sure the Government doesn't run amok in either direction," William Snape 3d, legal director of Defenders of Wildlife, said in an interview today.
Mr. Snape said the decision would have the positive effect, from the environmentalists' point of view, of removing an irritant that had prompted calls in Congress to overturn the Ninth Circuit's decision legislatively.
Patrick Parenteau, a professor at the Vermont Law School and director of its Environmental Law Center, said the decision could prove to be "a tool for creative environmental litigation" rather than a setback.
In an interview, Mr. Parenteau said the "logic of the decision" would support new kinds of environmental-based legal challenges to Government actions involving energy use, transportation planning, and even tax policy.
"This is the first time in years that the Court has broadened standing in environmental cases," he said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price Report Sets Off Fall In Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities slid yesterday, after a report of a bigger-than-expected increase in consumer prices raised investors' concern that inflation will accelerate and that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates to cool down the economy.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 10/32, to 95 17/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.98 percent, from 6.96 percent on Tuesday. 
 The consumer price report did not appear to change bond traders' expectations -- now roughly equally divided -- of whether there will be an increase in interest rates when the Federal Open Market Committee meets next week. But investors were bracing themselves in case Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, provides any hint of the Fed's intentions in Congressional testimony today.
The three-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer prices in February was a bit higher than the two-tenths of 1 percent rise that was expected, though the core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, was up two-tenths of 1 percent, as expected. The core rate was held in check by a 2.6 percent decline in air fares, which analysts expect will be reversed in the spring.
Traders said concerns over coming supply also became a factor in trading, as there was some worry about how the sale of two-year and five-year notes next week would be received.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.24 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.57 percent.
Some analysts said that dealers would have to lower prices and raise yields to more attractive levels if they expected people to buy the securities whent the Fed is deciding monetary policy and the course of interest rates for the next few months.
"Next Tuesday's F.O.M.C. outcome is a tough call, but we still come down on the side of a steady policy stance," said Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco. "The C.P.I. data did not provide a strong signal one way or another, and we're in the same boat we've been in over the last six F.O.M.C. meetings of strong growth with mixed inflation. It is not obvious that the risks to the price outlook are significantly greater now, mandating a tightening at the March meeting. We still expect a tightening at the May meeting."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, also said he did not think that the report made an increase in interest rates necessary.
"Once again we have an economic report that confirms the complete lack of inflationary pressure in the economy," he said. But Mr. McCarthy said that because Mr. Greenspan had talked in the past about having to counter inflation before it got started, an increase in rates could not be ruled out, even if inflation data showed few signs of increases.
Still, "we think this report should keep monetary policy on hold at next week's F.O.M.C. meeting," Mr. McCarthy said.
But Allen Sinai, chief global economist of Primark Decision Economics Inc., an economic advisory firm, in recent market comments said the Fed could not simply sit by and take pride in the strong performance of the economy and the relative lack of inflation. "If no tightening action is taken and the exuberance continues, the Federal Reserve will be taking a big risk that price inflation 6 to 12 months hence will accelerate from current levels," Mr. Sinai said. "If some action is taken, then there is still time, given the lags between monetary policy, the economy and inflation, to prevent a rise in price inflation and with little risk of big damage to the economy."
He said Primark was predicting an increase of one-quarter of a percentage point in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, with further increases later this year.
But even if there is an increase, and despite the strength in the economy and the risk of higher inflation, he said, the yield on the 30-year bond is expected to trade in the range of 7 percent to 7.25 percent in the near term, not much higher than current levels.

HEADLINE: Messinger Proposes 50 Fares For City Children on M.T.A.

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, a Democratic candidate for mayor, urged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to permit children between 5 and 11 to ride New York City subways and buses for 50 cents during off-peak hours.
Children can now ride the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and Long Island Rail Road for 50 cents during off hours. Ms. Messinger said the M.T.A. was discriminating against New York City transit riders by not offering the same deal to them. 
 Children 44 inches tall or less -- generally speaking, 5 years old and younger -- are permitted to ride free on the city transit system at any time. About 500,000 children are given passes that allow them to ride free or half price to school.
Ms. Messinger has been looking for issues with which to distinguish herself from the three other Democratic candidates seeking to run against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Her advisers said yesterday that this would be one of them. Ms. Messinger issued a press release and wrote a letter to Mr. Giuliani urging the change in policy.
"The M.T.A. calls this 'good marketing,' " Ms. Messinger said in her letter to Mr. Giuliani. "I call this a double standard. A kid is a kid is a kid, after all, whether they live in Stamford or Stuyvesant Town."
Ms. Messinger was unable to offer an estimate yesterday of how many children her policy might affect, how much it might cost the M.T.A. in lost revenues, or whether the policy should apply to children riding alone or only when accompanied by parents. She said she decided to seize on this policy -- which has existed for rail lines outside the city since April 1990 -- after hearing it promoted in a public service advertisement on a local radio station.
Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, Colleen A. Roche, said the Mayor had no comment on Ms. Messinger's proposals. "We'll take a look at the plan," she said. M.T.A. officials also declined to comment.
But M.T.A. officials defended the policy yesterday, saying it had promoted economic activity in the city. "We will review her letter," Tom Kelly, the M.T.A. press secretary, said. "But the program was instituted seven years ago so that people outside of the five boroughs could take advantage of all that the city has to offer, in addition to producing additional economic activity in the city."
"If you're asking why it took so long for her to notice it," Mr. Kelly said, "my response to that is, it's an election year."

HEADLINE: Play It Again, Boris

 BODY:
After comparing surgical histories in Helsinki, Bill Clinton and Boris Yeltsin will slip some coins into the diplomatic jukebox and play a few top hits from the cold war. Among the old favorites will be nuclear arms reductions, the balance of power in Europe and the future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The agenda of the convalescing Presidents reflects both the enduring importance of the nuclear weapons issue and the misplaced emphasis the Clinton Administration has given to NATO expansion.
The most threatening legacy of the cold war is the nuclear arsenals still maintained by the United States and Russia. Though the number of nuclear warheads is falling, and the two countries no longer target their missiles at one another, the remaining firepower exceeds any reasonable limit. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin need to devote much time to renewing the efforts of both countries to retire and dismantle nuclear warheads and missiles. 
 To that end, Mr. Clinton has sensibly offered to explore the outlines of a future arms reduction treaty to encourage the Russian Parliament to ratify the last accord, which was signed during the Bush Administration. Mr. Yeltsin ought to welcome this offer and work with Mr. Clinton to cut warhead levels in each country to the 3,000-to-3,500 range specified in the last treaty and to set lower limits in a future agreement.
But these vital matters may not get sufficient attention in Helsinki. The reason is that Mr. Clinton has loaded the agenda with European security questions revolving around his determination to expand NATO eastward into Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic by 1999. At a time when American and Russian officials should be talking about ways to consolidate democracy and free markets in Russia, they have been arguing over the number of tanks that can be stationed in Poland.
Under pressure from Washington, Moscow has at least temporarily given up hopes of stopping this expansion into Central Europe and is instead trying to negotiate the best terms it can before NATO officially issues invitations for new memberships this summer. Washington, in turn, has offered a variety of inducements to Moscow, including a pledge not to place nuclear weapons on the territory of new members and a proposal to cut the number of conventional weapons in Western Europe while freezing the number in Central Europe.
Washington has also promised a modest increase in financial assistance to Russia and an enhanced role for Moscow in international economic institutions.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin will no doubt spend considerable time haggling over the terms of a proposed charter that would spell out a new relationship between Russia and NATO. The idea is to make Russia a partner in many NATO activities, including peacekeeping missions like the current one in Bosnia where Russian soldiers are participating. But Russia, at least for now, would not be invited to become a full NATO member.
The rush to enlarge NATO is not justified by any Russian military threat today. Russian conventional forces are weak, and even a government with imperial ambitions would require years of draining expense before it could threaten Europe again. Nor will NATO growth do anything to bolster the economies of Central European countries, which face a substantial cost to modernize and integrate their military forces into the alliance.
The future stability of Europe depends more than anything on stability in Russia. Rather than taking actions that may isolate Russia and encourage a resurgence of Russian nationalism, the United States ought to concentrate on trying to help Russia rebuild its faltering economy, establish a fair and effective tax system and make democracy irreversible. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin cannot advance those interests by debating the balance of power in Europe.
