HEADLINE: Jacques Foccart Dies at 83; Secret Mastermind in Africa

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 19

 BODY:
Jacques Foccart, who masterminded clandestine military coups in French-speaking Africa for Charles de Gaulle and three French presidents after him, died at his home this morning. He was 83.
Mr. Foccart's secrecy and preference for operating in the shadows were legendary. He was trusted by France's friends in Africa and remained a powerful influence on his country's African policy almost to his death, serving as an honorary adviser to President Jacques Chirac after his election in 1995. 
 Mr. Foccart's Machiavellian hand was seen in many a coup and manipulation in French-speaking Africa over the years, and lately in Mr. Chirac's policy of indirect support for President Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire, despite the crumbling of support for Mr. Mobutu at home.
Gaullist politicians paid effusive tribute to him today. "A great servant of our country has died," said Economic Cooperation Minister Jacques Godfrain.
Mr. Foccart was born in Ambrieres near Mayenne in west-central France on Aug. 31, 1913. He spent his first six years in Guadeloupe, where his family had property. Drafted into the French Army at the start of World War II, he avoided capture when France fell and, according to his biographer, Pierre Pean, joined the Resistance only after the German occupiers brought a criminal complaint against him for construction work he was doing for them to build fortifications on the Atlantic coast.
For his Resistance work he won an award from the United States Army and friendships in the inner circle of the leadership around General de Gaulle, the leader of the French government in exile.
After the war he started an import-export company called Safiex that did business in many of the French colonies in Africa, although Mr. Foccart said most of its activities were centered on the West Indies.
The company did so well that Mr. Foccart, almost single-handedly, was able to finance the Rally of the French People, the party that de Gaulle, who had served briefly as President after returning to France in 1944, organized to support his political agenda.
Mr. Foccart also became one of the founders of a powerful private police force the movement organized to do battle against the Communists -- the Service d'Action Civique, the "Action Service."
Its school in Cercottes, outside of Orleans, became a gathering place for the keepers of the Gaullist flame in the 1950s. Mr. Foccart forged lasting connections there with a network of army officers and secret service operatives that survived long after de Gaulle's movement disbanded in 1955.
Support for the General did not die with it. With a colonial war raging in Algeria, the men fighting to keep it a French colony thought politicians in Paris were selling them out, and many came to believe de Gaulle could keep Algeria French.
Under the code name "Mathurin," Mr. Foccart masterminded the strategy that brought the General back to power in 1958, using the secret intelligence networks he had forged to create popular fears of a coming coup d'etat led by angry paratroopers from Algeria and to make sure that when the Fourth Republic fell, de Gaulle, not the diehards in Algeria, would get power.
As first President of the Fifth Republic, de Gaulle made the bald, bespectacled Mr. Foccart, who was rarely seen in public, one of his closest aides. He became Secretary-General of the French Community, the vehicle de Gaulle created in 1960 after giving France's colonies in Africa nominal independence. There, Mr. Foccart put his clandestine operating skills to use over the next nine years.
"Foccart was assigned the task of orchestrating an arrangement whereby French interests could maintain the upper hand in her former colonies, for whom she had done virtually nothing to prepare for independence," Douglas Porch, an American expert, wrote in "The French Secret Services," published by Farrar, Straus & Giroux in 1995.
In 1964, Mr. Foccart sent French troops to oil-rich Gabon to keep Leon Mba, a close ally, in power against an American-supported rival, and incidentally to protect the local interests of the French petroleum group Elf, led by another close friend.
Asked by Philippe Gaillard in his first volume of memoirs, "Foccart Speaks," published in France two years ago, who had run Gabon, Mr. Foccart said, "Without question, it was Mba. But I was available, and he consulted me a lot."
There were six military coups in French-speaking Africa at the end of 1965 and the beginning of 1966, but, Mr. Foccart said, France did nothing to foment any of those, including one that brought Jean-Bedel Bokassa to power as President of the Central African Republic.
The threat of calling off a visit by Mr. Bokassa to Paris in 1969 was enough, he recalled, to get the African leader to halt an economic boycott of Chad, another country where France had, and still has, important military interests.
He was a lifelong friend of Felix Houphouet-Boigny , who served in French governments in colonial times and later became President of the Ivory Coast.
"He never caused blood to flow, and he let fewer of his opponents rot in prison than others did," Mr. Foccart later wrote.
De Gaulle left power after a year of tumult in France in 1969, but Mr. Foccart stayed on, first for President Georges Pompidou and later, despite some interruptions, for President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who finally authorized French support for an uprising against Mr. Bokassa after the African leader proclaimed himself Emperor.
"There were chiefs of state who had sent their ambassadors demands for French assistance in case of a coup d'etat," Mr. Foccart told the daily Le Figaro, without revealing details. He wrote a second volume of memoirs to fill in some of the gaps in the first, but delayed its publication. A spokeswoman for the publisher, Fayard/Jeune Afrique, said it would come out on April 9.

HEADLINE: Brokerage Houses Come Out Winners in State Takeover of Lilco

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Analysts on Wall Street expressed some reservations yesterday about the attractiveness of the $7 billion bond issue -- the largest municipal bond issue in history -- that is the central element of the partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.
But there was widespread enthusiasm among brokerage houses about the chance to sell the bonds. 
 The total fees associated with the sale could reach $40 million for the firms that sell the bonds. And Bear Stearns, which served as an adviser to the Long Island Power Authority, will be competing for some of the business, said Bob Foran, a senior managing director at the firm.
In bidding for the consulting work for the power authority, Mr. Foran said, the firm had made clear it would want to resign at some point to compete for the underwriting.
"We are looking forward to competing," he said. "After all, we are in the bond business."
Selling the bonds is expected to begin after all the necessary regulatory approvals are obtained, which is expected to take about 18 months. The first sale will total $4.2 billion, which is larger than the total of municipal bonds New York State has outstanding.
It will be followed by two smaller issues.
Mr. Foran said he expected the sale to go well, but acknowledged that the interest rate LIPA will have to pay will be a little higher than that on other issues with the same credit rating and outlook, mostly because of the enormousness of the issue.
But one veteran of the municipal bond market who grew up in Brooklyn and worked on Long Island will need convincing. "I will have to see a lot of analysis and data," said Austin Tobin, president of Delphis Hanover Corporation in Southbury, Conn. "And so will everybody else."
Analysts said it was not clear how easy it would be over the long term for the authority to meet the principal and interest costs.
"The strength of cash flow over time will be one of the key ratings' hot buttons," said Julia Doetsch, the senior analyst for Lilco at Moody's Investors Service, a rating agency. She said she could not make a judgment now because all the data was not available.
Standard & Poor's, another major credit rating agency, said that it had changed its rating on Lilco to account for the uncertainty that surrounds the deal. The rating went from BBB minus on credit watch with a positive outlook to BBB minus with a developing outlook, which means the rating could go up or down.
S&P said its "initial credit concerns" were that despite the reduction in electric rates, they would still be relatively high and "could politically limit LIPA's rate flexibility." In addition, S&P said a move by municipalities to take over the distribution of electricity locally could "dilute LIPA's ability to raise revenues and repay its debt."
Bill Tilles, a senior analyst at Smith Barney, suggested there was one long-term issue potential buyers of the municipal bonds, which will have a maturity of 30 years, should think about. That is the possibility that Brooklyn Union Gas might eventually decide to go into the electricity business on Long Island, making it a LIPA rival.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
New York Created 44,500 Jobs in 1996

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City had its best year in 1996 since the 1980's in creating new private sector jobs, according to revised figures from the city and the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The city said that 44,500 new jobs were added, an upward revision of 7,500 from its preliminary count. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, using a slightly different calculating method, said the year-to-year increase in new jobs was 50,000, up 15,000 from its earlier number. 
 By both measures, it was the best one-year total for new jobs since the city began recovering from the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's.
The last year that came close was 1994, early in the economic recovery, when the city added 47,000 jobs. The growth rate fell in 1995, when only 27,000 new jobs were added.
The new job total for January was also very strong, up 16,900 jobs from last January, though economists caution that the monthly number is very volatile and does not necessarily suggest a newly accelerated pattern.
The city added 24,000 jobs in one month last year, for example, as people returned to work after the economic disruption of the winter's blizzards.
And the city's unemployment rate was also up in January, to 9.5 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis, its highest level since March 1994.
 KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: Bell Atlantic, Nynex Merger Set to Advance

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
New York State regulators are expected to give qualified approval today to the $22 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. And in a victory for Nynex, the chairman of the Public Service Commission indicated that the regulators were reluctant to demand cuts in local telephone rates as a condition for endorsing the deal, according to people who attended the meeting.
Executives at Nynex had expected the commission to rule on the merger yesterday. But after an uncharacteristically freewheeling discussion among the three commissioners, the chairman, John F. O'Mara, put off a final ruling until a special session scheduled for this morning. 
 People who attended yesterday's meeting said the commissioners were likely to attach several strings to their approval, including a commitment by Nynex to improve its customer service and to invest in its aging telephone network. But on the key issue of a rate cut, Mr. O'Mara favored letting Nynex off the hook for at least three years.
That prompted a last-minute blast of criticism from consumer advocates and competitors of Nynex and Bell Atlantic, who contended that New York State was not extracting enough concessions from Nynex.
"Every Nynex customer has a right to immediate rate relief," said Robert Ceisler, the executive director of the Citizens Utility Board, a consumer lobbying group, "I am quite concerned that the economic benefits to consumers will be put off until the year 2000."
If the Public Service Commission approves the deal today, it would be an odd reversal of expectations in what has been a two-track regulatory process. Nynex and Bell Atlantic had regarded the commission as the biggest hurdle to their merger ever since they announced it last April, because of Nynex's troubled customer service record in the state and because of the commission's aggressive reputation.
Yet just as New York seems to be falling into line, the second track of the process is now posing a problem for Bell Atlantic and Nynex. The Justice Department, which has approved other telecommunications mergers, is stepping up its antitrust scrutiny of the deal. Lawyers for the companies met with officials in Washington last evening to discuss whether the merger would eliminate potential competition in the phone business.
Bell Atlantic and Nynex must also receive the blessing of the Federal Communications Commission, but the companies said that would not be a problem if the Justice Department approved the deal.
Executives at both companies declined to discuss either the Federal investigation or the New York proceeding. But one senior executive at Nynex said that an endorsement in New York would increase the pressure on the Justice Department to go along with the deal.
Still, in a similar merger between SBC Communications and the Pacific Telesis Group, California regulators have not dropped their demands in the wake of the Justice Department's approval of that deal.
Fears about the regulatory delays dragged down Nynex's stock yesterday by $1.75 a share, to $47.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Bell Atlantic's shares also fell $1.75, to $68.375. Analysts noted that the shares of other regional Bell telephone companies declined as well.
In New York, the debate over the merger has been linked to more general concerns about Nynex's poor customer service. Last November, the staff of the Public Service Commission harshly criticized Nynex's service record and recommended that Nynex be forced to return some of the savings it would realize from the deal in the form of lower rates.
The staff did not stipulate the size of the reduction, but consumer advocates have argued that Nynex should reduce rates for its 7.5 million residential customers by $1.25 billion over five years. They said that number reflected both the internal savings from by the merger and a calculation the amount of savings customers would have to forgo by not having Bell Atlantic as a competitor to Nynex.
People who attended the meeting, however, said Mr. O'Mara argued that Nynex's rates should be left alone until 2000, when the state could better assess the savings of the merger. That would be the fifth year of a seven-year rate agreement between Nynex and New York State.
In the meantime, Nynex would pledge to upgrade its network, which has deteriorated badly in some New York City neighborhoods. The company would also adhere to more stringent customer service standards. Among the proposals being considered by the commission: a pledge that Nynex would raise its service standards in New York to be in line with the service record of Bell Atlantic in its mid-Atlantic region.
Critics of the merger noted that the commission had planned to review Nynex's rate agreement in three years anyway. So the critics contend that the commission is effectively not asking Nynex to do anything more than honor the deal it already has with the state.
Moreover, they said the commissioners did not address the loss in potential competition that would result when two huge phone companies join forces to dominate a region. "Not a word was mentioned about the anticompetitive issues," said Donna Sorgi, the regional executive for public policy at MCI Communications Corporation.
New York's Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, has opposed the deal because he believes it would be anti-competitive. The loss of potential competition is also a central focus of officials at the Justice Department, who have pored over internal documents at Bell Atlantic that lay out plans for competing for long-distance customers in Nynex's region.
People who attended the meeting said the commissioners noted that the Justice Department was conducting its own investigation -- a gesture some observers interpreted to mean that if the Federal Government were to challenge the deal, New York might reconsider its approval.
On the plus side for Nynex, Mr. O'Mara reiterated his earlier statement that New York's economy would benefit by having the headquarters of the combined company in Manhattan, rather than in Philadelphia, where Bell Atlantic is based. People at the meeting said the commissioners discussed ways to guarantee that the new company would not move its headquarters out of New York later.
In addition to Mr. O'Mara, who was appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, the other commissioners are Thomas Dunleavy and Eugene Zeltman, both of whom were also appointed by Mr. Pataki.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Congressional Leaders Lay Out Differences on Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
President Clinton and Congressional budget leaders met today to lay out their differences over how to eliminate the Federal deficit, with both sides having powerful motivations to get a deal but facing intense opposition to possible compromises from within their own constituencies.
"We agree on the goal, we've agreed on a schedule to start discussion," Mr. Clinton told reporters after the meeting. "Now comes the hard work of writing the agreement dollar by dollar, program by program, issue by issue." 
 There were no breakthroughs at the 1-hour, 20-minute meeting in the White House, but both sides said they would continue to talk in the coming weeks in the hopes of bringing Republican leaders into serious negotiations with the Administration during the spring.
"They understand our pain, and we understand theirs," said Representative John R. Kasich, Ohio Republican who heads the House Budget Committee.
Republican pain was particularly acute today, as their latest budget initiative came under intense criticism from one of the most influential allies of their party's conservative wing, Ralph Reed, the executive director of the Christian Coalition.
At issue was the suggestion by Speaker Newt Gingrich earlier this week that Republicans should consider temporarily setting aside their demands for a sweeping tax cut in order to concentrate on getting a balanced budget deal.
In what Republican aides said was an effort to deprive Democrats of an excuse not to agree to a balanced-budget plan, Mr. Gingrich said the Republicans should get Mr. Clinton to agree to lock in deep spending reductions first, and then return to taxes later.
But while Mr. Gingrich's proposal was seen by the White House as an olive branch, and while it holds some appeal to those in the party who put deficit reduction first, it has infuriated his own right wing, where tax cutting is an article of faith that comes behind no other priority. Several dozen Republicans who were first elected to the House in 1994 supporting the tax-cutting pledge in the Contract With America have put their names to a letter telling Mr. Gingrich to "count on our steadfast opposition to any reconciliation bill that turns it back on our promises to cut taxes for American families."
On Tuesday night, Mr. Reed sent members of Congress a letter warning that his group "could be forced to oppose a Republican budget resolution if it does not provide for significant and broad tax relief for American families."
In an interview today, Mr. Reed said his organization could easily produce enough Republican votes to doom any budget plan that does not include the party's proposed $500-per-child family tax credit. And he dismissed Mr. Gingrich's contention that it would be possible to push through tax cuts after securing a budget deal.
"Given the slim margin separating the parties in both houses, saying that we will get to you later is a sure-fire recipe for saying we will get to you never," Mr. Reed said.
Mr. Gingrich's proposal won backing today from moderate Republicans and conservative Democrats.
"We believe that considering tax cut legislation separately from the budget significantly improves the chances for an agreement to balance the Federal budget by 2002," said a letter signed by 40 members of the House, led by two Republicans, Representatives Michael N. Castle of Delaware and Fred Upton of Michigan, and two Democrats, Representatives Charles W. Stenholm of Texas and John Tanner of Tennessee.
But it was unclear whether Mr. Gingrich would be able to withstand the pressure from the right any better than Mr. Clinton was able to deal with the intense opposition from his party's left wing when he backed away earlier this month from another promising but politically explosive compromise, the proposal to save tens of billions of dollars in the next five years by reducing the cost of living increases received by Social Security recipients.
Balancing the budget is the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's second term agenda and is arguably the only issue sweeping enough to distract attention from his partisan woes over campaign financing.
For Congressional Republicans, reaching a budget deal is a chance to eradicate the shadow of extremism that Democrats hung on them in the last election, and to make good, at least partially, on their promises of the last several years to shrink the size of the Government and restore fiscal order to Washington.
The question now is whether it is possible to fashion a plan to balance the Federal budget by 2002 that will appeal to majorities of both parties without so incensing hard-liners on either side that a deal would be impossible.
The one area in which a compromise now seems likely is on the technical but extremely important issue of the economic assumptions that underpin any budget. Republicans over the last several years have insisted that any budget use assumptions generated by the Congressional Budget Office, which tends to use very cautious projections of growth, tax revenues, unemployment and other statistics that determine the gap between government receipts and expenditures. The White House uses more optimistic projections.

HEADLINE: Sowing Preservation;
Towns Are Slowing Invasion of Farms by Bulldozers

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Mark Greene's family has been farming in Pittsford, N.Y., since 1812, but until recently the prospects that his 400-acre farm would be in business for another generation looked dim. A local ordinance requires developers to set aside 50 percent of any new project for farming or open space, but even that did not knock land prices down enough to slow the relentless sprawl of Rochester, 10 miles to the northwest.
Last year, though, Pittsford issued $10 million in bonds so it could pay Mr. Greene and six other farmers for promises not to sell their 1,200 acres -- about 60 percent of the tillable land remaining in the town -- to developers. 
 "If we didn't do this," Mr. Greene said, "it would only be a matter of time."
It has long been an iron law of the real estate market that if farmland stands in the path of urban expansion, no crop is valuable enough to keep it out of developers' hands.
As Pittsford's bond issue highlights, though, that iron law can be bent a bit. By arguing that farms provide more than food and fiber -- the list includes environmental benefits, soul-soothing scenery, diversity for the local economy and especially tax savings -- advocates of farmland preservation are forging the political ties and financial tools to steer developers' backhoes away from farmland.
"You are going to see some very interesting alliances evolve," said Ralph Grossi, president of the American Farmland Trust, a lobbying group based in Washington that for nearly two decades has been charting both farmland losses and the efforts to halt them. He cited a coalition formed last year to channel new growth toward already-developed areas in and around Fresno, Calif., an alliance that includes the local Chamber of Commerce and the regional building industry association in addition to farm groups.
Despite America's unparalleled agricultural abundance, concern about disappearing farmland is clearly on the rise. Numerous states and communities have in recent years experimented with tax and zoning policies to encourage farmers at the urban edge to hang on. And both private and public programs to buy development rights are spreading.
At the Federal level, the Government in 1995 finally began applying a 1981 law that required it to look for alternatives to proposed highways, airports and other public projects that consume prime farmland. And in last year's farm bill, Congress authorized spending $35 million over six years to bolster state and local programs that pay farmers not to sell to developers, the first such Federal payments ever.
Federal officials say saving prime farmland not only has local benefits but also helps the nation's balance of trade and protects against volatility in food prices. "Land is the bank supporting 15 percent to 20 percent of our economy," Dan Glickman, the Secretary of Agriculture, said. "Keeping it in agriculture is extremely important."
So far, though, such talk and the measures backing it up have been too restricted and modestly financed to have much effect. In the 20 years since Suffolk County, L.I., began the first program to buy development rights from farmers, such buyouts have preserved 450,000 acres in 18 states.
But that is a drop in the bucket. In a report to be issued today, the American Farmland Trust says that urban sprawl eats up two acres a minute -- a million acres a year, including 400,000 acres uniquely suited to certain crops.
Some of the best farmland being lost is around heartland cities like Indianapolis and Des Moines that tend to be overlooked because there is so much high-quality farmland in the Midwest.
"We lose a little bit every year," said Anthony Hession, who farms 3,000 acres just west of Indianapolis, most of it rented. Mr. Hession said he had won a statewide corn-growing contest in 1995 on a 160-acre field being torn up this month for a subdivision.
Still, Mr. Grossi said, conditions might be better than ever for slowing the loss of farmland, especially in 20 hot spots highlighted by the Farmland Trust report, like California's Central Valley, the northern Piedmont stretching from Virginia to New Jersey, the region bordering the Florida Everglades and the prairie land around the Illinois-Wisconsin border. The report focuses not just on soil quality but on areas where soil and climate together are uniquely suited for certain crops.
"We have a much better understanding of the cost of losing this land than even five years ago, a lot more examples of good local programs, and the Federal action legitimizes this effort," Mr. Grossi said.
Farmland preservation would be a much easier sell, of course, if the nation seemed in even remote danger of ever being hungry. At current development rates, the worst-case scenarios suggest that the nation's surplus food for export would not dry up until the middle of the next century, when 13 percent of the prime land being farmed would be gone. Some products now produced domestically would become imports, food prices could climb substantially, and other food-short regions of the world would be politically and economically less stable.
But blessed as it is with more than 300 million acres of prime agricultural land, the United States has paid about as much attention to such pessimistic visions as a billionaire to fliers suggesting it's time to open a savings account.
After all, decades of paving over farmland has not stopped farmers from producing such huge surpluses that Americans pay less of their income for food than anyone else in the world. And agricultural goods are the nation's largest export. The Federal Government has spent hundreds of billions of dollars on price-support programs intended to prevent the farm economy from drowning in its own abundance.
"We are losing good farmland needlessly, but we don't need it to feed ourselves," said Dennis Avery, an agriculture specialist at the Hudson Institute, a conservative research group. Ending excessive losses of American farmland to development might help feed other nations and slow the destruction of rain forests, Mr. Avery said, but not as much as increased spending on agricultural research or efforts to halt urban sprawl in developing countries.
Others note that each acre lost simply increases farmers' incentives to improve output on the remaining land. And biotechnology is very likely to provide previously unimagined opportunities, such as more drought-resistant strains of key crops like wheat and corn that would make marginal land far from cities more productive.
"Our concept of what is prime land has changed dramatically over time," said Philip Raup, a land economist at the University of Minnesota, who noted that pioneer farmers wanted land with exposed salt deposits for livestock nutrition. "Genetic engineering will change it again in the next 30 or 40 years."
Regardless of their long-range accuracy, such assessments encourage political leaders and voters to vastly underrate how much the nation might gain now from paying more attention to farmland, the Farmland Trust and its allies say. In the Central Valley of California alone, where the population is expected to triple by 2040 and today's sprawling development averages three homes an acre, a million acres of farmland will be lost and 2.6 million more will become harder to farm efficiently, according to a 1995 study.
Given the same population growth, the study projected, new laws forcing "compact growth" at an average of six homes an acre would save more than 500,000 acres of farmland, protect a million acres from encroachment, add nearly $70 billion to the agricultural economy and save taxpayers $29 billion that would be spent extending sewers and other services to newly developed areas.
Farmland losses are easy to dramatize. Farmers on the urban edge are often featured in news reports showing how the approach of suburbia can be more disruptive and nerve-racking than the eventual outright loss of the land, which, after all, can make millionaires of them if they are lucky enough to own it.
New homeowners often push local officials to halt normal farm practices, like noisy nighttime harvesting or planting, spreading manure to fertilize fields, importing swarms of bees to pollinate fruit trees and spraying pesticides. Subdivisions can cause crop losses by altering drainage patterns in nearby fields. Dogs chase cattle and other livestock. And vandalism of machinery and crops becomes commonplace.
"There was one kid who drove around in my alfalfa one night, got stuck in a creek and had the gall to come ask me to get my tractor to pull him out," said Jim Lehrer, a dairy farmer in Kaukauna, Wis. "He said he was just having fun."
Mr. Lehrer said he pulled the vehicle out after first demanding the teen-ager's address, then drove his tractor to the offender's home and rode around on the lawn until the teen-ager's father burst out furiously demanding to know what he was doing. Mr. Lehrer said he told him he was "just having fun like your son," and then took a spin through the backyard before going home.
Most farmers never catch the vandals, though, and in many cases, they say, there are burdens even well-intentioned suburbanites do not perceive. Sayre Miller, co-owner of 300 acres of almond groves outside Clovis, Calif., said that suburban horse riders and the cross-country team from a new school to the west had worn enough of a trail through the groves to disrupt the path of her unmanned harvesting machines.
Such problems give a human dimension to issues of urban sprawl. But cataloguing such conflicts provides no rationale for treating farms differently from any other business. That leaves it to groups like the Farmland Trust and various national agriculture and environmental groups to assemble the larger arguments for zoning and tax changes that could limit the farmland losses.
Often the actual quality of the farmland is not decisive. In Pittsford, the cost of development was what impressed voters most. Pittsford planners calculated that providing services and schools to subdivisions on the 1,200 acres would have a net cost of $200 a taxpayer indefinitely, compared with $67 a year for 20 years to pay off the bonds.

HEADLINE: Enron Wins Pact to Supply Power From Wind Turbines

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, March 19

 BODY:
The search for cheap, renewable sources of en ergy although slowed by the pressures of electricity generation -- advanced significantly today as the Enron Corporation announced the world's largest project to generate power from wind.
Enron's wind-power subsidiary agreed to build 150 propellered wind turbines to supply the MidAmerican Energy Company, Iowa's largest electric utility, with a peak of 112.5 megawatts of electricity, enough for about 50,000 homes. Standing on masts about 15 stories tall, the turbines' 25-ton fiberglass and epoxy rotors will have about the same wing span as a Boeing 747. 
 The Iowa project, in the northwestern part of the state, will cost about $100 million and is expected to go into operation by the end of 1998. Because the winds do not always blow strongly, MidAmerican, which serves 642,000 electric customers, anticipates receiving an average of about 45 megawatts, under a 20-year contract.
Enron, which is based in Houston and is the nation's largest independent natural gas company, said that this project and others would provide power at rates competitive with fossil fuels. "Enron believes that renewables are going to play a more significant part in the United States' and the world's energy picture," said Kenneth C. Karas, chief executive of the Zond Corporation, the wind-power subsidiary of Enron.
"The cost of some of the renewables, wind in particular but also solar, has declined and will continue to decline."
In a deregulating, cost-cutting industry, some companies have pruned their renewable energy programs. But Enron, an advocate of deregulation, says that as renewable power becomes more economical, providing it will be a competitive advantage. Some smog-bound regions want nonpolluting energy, and some customers have said that they would pay a premium for it.
"As customer choice arrives, that will be good for renewables," said Randall Swisher, executive director of the American Wind Energy Association.
MidAmerican Energy, he said, has spent 14 years fighting a 1983 state law requiring the state's utilities to generate a portion of their power from alternative sources. But having persuaded Federal regulators that the state could not mandate the purchase at relatively high costs, the company was still left with an obligation to seek new sources. Enron's bid was selected from the 18 bids MidAmerican received late last year.
The cost of generating wind power has fallen sharply from about 12 cents a kilowatt-hour a decade ago. The new project will provide power for 4 cents to 4.5 cents a kilowatt- hour, Mr. Karas said, before tax benefits worth about a penny a kilowatt-hour over the long run.
The wind turbines will therefore be more efficient than most nuclear, coal and oil-fired plants, but not as efficient as the latest, which use natural gas. The largest operating wind project currently is owned by Zond and is near Bakersfield, Calif. It was completed in 1991 and uses 342 turbines to generate 77 megawatts, Mr. Karas said. His company expects to break ground on a 107-megawatt project in Minnesota in May.
Enron is rapidly moving into the electricity business, with a $2.1 billion acquisition of the Portland General Corporation pending.
Daniel Barcelo, an analyst at Paine Webber, said that although renewables, including solar power, accounted for only a small portion of Enron's revenues, the company's investments helped secure its future in case the markets for these energy sources became larger.
"They have mastered electricity; they have mastered natural gas, and this is another arrow in their quiver," Mr. Barcelo said.
Providing alternative energy can be risky. Technology and management problems, analysts have said, have forced one of Zond's major competitors, the wind subsidiary of the Kenetech Corporation, to seek bankruptcy protection. Mr. Karas said, however, that slightly smaller versions of Zond's new wind turbines are operating in Vermont, Texas, Northern Ireland and China.

HEADLINE: Hard to Say No

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 19

 BODY:
In announcing a deal today that promises to lower Long Island's high electric rates, Gov. George E. Pataki may have found a way to cut the Gordian knot of Island politics, a problem with important political and economic implications, and one that the Governor has invested heavily in solving.
But as with so many of Mr. Pataki's initiatives, he needs the cooperation of his nemesis, Speaker Sheldon Silver of the Assembly, and that could mean trouble for both men. 
 Mr. Pataki, whose 1998 re-election chances rest heavily on retaining the high level of support he got from Long Islanders in 1994, has staked his credibility on lowering the Island's electric rates, which are more than double the national average.
As a candidate, he criticized Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for pursuing, to no avail, a state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, including its crushing debt from the never-used Shoreham nuclear plant. In the end, Mr. Pataki has resorted to much the same mechanism, a reversal that will no doubt be forgiven if the promised rate savings take effect.
Now, the Republican Governor has positioned himself as the hero of the hour, his administration having negotiated a deal with Lilco that he said would reduce rates by more than 20 percent, but Mr. Silver can take that victory away from him. The Speaker, a Democrat from Manhattan, sits on the state's Public Facilities Control Board, whose unanimous approval is required for Mr. Pataki's plan to proceed.
And Mr. Silver, whose relations with Mr. Pataki are notoriously uneasy, is not about to rubber-stamp anything the Governor wants. In addition, the Assembly will hold hearings on the plan before the control board acts.
"I don't intend to stand in the way of a deal that produces all the things this deal is supposed to produce," Mr. Silver said. "I just want to make sure it's as advertised."
But Mr. Silver can ill afford having Democrats seen as the bogeymen who robbed Long Islanders of their chance at cheaper electricity.
"It becomes very difficult for him to turn this down, and not have his Long Island members bear the brunt of that," said Martin Connor of Brooklyn, the leader of the Senate's Democratic minority. "The politics of Long Island are such that you can't afford to turn your back on this issue of electric rates."
Mr. Silver insisted that he was untroubled by such concerns. "If the deal doesn't do what it's supposed to do, the public will know it," he said. He remained cautiously neutral on the pact, turning down an invitation from the Governor's office to join Mr. Pataki in announcing it.
The administration has assembled a deal that could be hard to oppose, offering something to please all the parties directly involved. Lilco, once and for all, sheds the burden of the Shoreham debacle, making it more attractive to its merger partner, Brooklyn Union Gas.
Suffolk County and some local governments escape a billion-dollar tax rebate judgment against them in a suit brought by Lilco, which threatened them with bankruptcy. Nassau County gets greater rate reductions and rebates than Suffolk, just to even the scales between the two. And customers, of course, get lower rates.
If the agreement holds firm, it could be of great political benefit to Mr. Pataki, who could be seen as the politician who succeeded where a generation of others had failed. If, as Democrats and Republicans alike have predicted, lower rates mean more businesses and more jobs on Long Island, Mr. Pataki will be in a position to take credit.
New York's political geography magnifies the importance of the deal. With rural upstate regions solidly Republican and New York City solidly Democratic, the downstate suburbs -- particularly Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties -- are the state's true battleground. And Mr. Pataki's slim margin of victory over Mr. Cuomo came largely from a better-than-expected showing in Suffolk.
Some Democrats in the Legislature, including Mr. Connor, are already taking shots at the deal, saying that it shows the administration favoring Long Island over the rest of the state, and that it does not force Lilco to swallow a large enough share of the Shoreham debt.
Under the agreement, the utility would be responsible for about $900 million, or 20 percent of that debt. The remaining $3.6 billion would be paid off with bonds issued by the Long Island Power Authority, a state agency, to be repaid by electric customers over the next 30 years.
Mr. Pataki's plans for the state's six other regional power companies also include heavy borrowing to pay off debts and reduce rates, but the savings would be far smaller than those for Lilco, for two reasons. First, the debt would be incurred by the utilities, not by a tax-exempt state agency, so the interest rates would be significantly higher. Second, no other utility has a debt load nearly as large as Lilco's.
Assemblyman Paul D. Tonko, a Democrat from Schenectady County, assailed the Lilco agreement today, calling Suffolk and Nassau "affluent New York City suburbs singled out to receive the benefits of lower electric rates."
Such remarks do not bode well for the accord. It is Mr. Tonko, the chairman of the Energy Committee, who will head the Assembly's hearings on the deal.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Praising the Wonders of Workfare, Giuliani Finds a Campaign Theme

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
For all of the traditionally Democratic programs Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed in this election year, there is one subject that can instantly bring out the old-fashioned Republican in him: the value of work.
Whenever his critics suggest that he is demeaning or intimidating welfare recipients by putting them to work sweeping streets or cleaning parks, the Mayor breaks into an exasperated speech about how any kind of work can restore a sense of dignity to those receiving public assistance. In what is becoming one of his signature campaign themes, repeated before a variety of audiences, he regularly invokes his father's New Deal-era advice to him: that there is no such thing as a menial job if it supports one's family. 
 But in doing so, Mr. Giuliani has stepped squarely into an intense national debate over education and work, and in a series of remarks last week, his positions on the issue seemed to go a bit beyond the national political mainstream now supporting workfare programs. In Mr. Giuliani's view, the experience gained by those in workfare is actually more valuable than education in leaving public assistance.
He has repeatedly cited the rise of Sanitation Commissioner John J. Doherty -- a former street sweeper who was never on welfare -- as proof of how far one can go from humble beginnings.
"What Martin Luther King said about sweeping streets was, if you do it better than anybody else, then you're doing God's work, which is the way I look at it," he told a group of applauding small-business owners at a meeting of the Sunnyside Chamber of Commerce in Queens. "So I think buying into this philosophy that work is demeaning is very, very damaging. And it has a lot to do with what was wrong with our city."
The Mayor said that he had "turned around welfare" in New York City even more than he had reduced crime, but that he did not get credit for it because of a rigid, "politically correct" thinking in the city that prefers government programs -- including the city's community colleges, with their low graduation rates -- to hard work.
Mr. Giuliani's repeated discourses on the subject run contrary to much of the social research on welfare, which experts in the field say continues to show that a good education remains the best way out of a life of dead-end jobs and dependency. Researchers say that in a global, post-industrial economy, the advice of Mr. Giuliani's father is no longer as valid as it was in the 1940's and 50's.
"The Mayor's views are contrary to the research findings," said Dr. Mary Ann Quaranta, dean of the Graduate School of Social Service at Fordham University, who is now working with the Giuliani administration to develop better child welfare procedures.
"There is compelling research that welfare recipients who go to college, even if they don't finish, tend to be more likely to get a job and keep a job than their counterparts without that education," she said. "These jobs sweeping streets are dead-end jobs, not stimulating, not interesting and with no upward mobility or security. And they're certainly not good role models for kids."
Mr. Doherty's personal history shows how much the economy has changed and how different his experience was from that of the people now sweeping streets for their welfare benefits in a climate of downsizing. When Mr. Doherty joined the Sanitation Department in 1960, he said in an interview this week, he did so after taking the civil service test, having been advised by his father that civil service jobs were among the best paying and most secure.
Although he did sweep streets when asked, he said, his job duties also included hauling garbage, operating a mechanical broom and doing clerical tasks. After nine years of steady work, he said, he took the civil service test again and was promoted to assistant foreman.
By contrast, participants in the city's workfare program technically do not even have jobs, let alone the security and potential for advancement that come with a civil service position. Mr. Doherty said he had yet to hire a single workfare participant in the Sanitation Department, because the department had no openings and about 15,000 people were on the waiting list.
"I still think there's opportunity in the department," said Mr. Doherty, who never received a college education. "Back then, nobody pushed us to get an educational background, but now I tell all the guys to get some more education, some computer training, because the job is more demanding than it used to be."
Gordon L. Berlin, senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a national nonprofit group that evaluates welfare experiments, said welfare programs that offered useful vocational training had the greatest success in moving recipients to better jobs. Programs that offer high school equivalency education have not led to substantial increases in employment, he said, and neither have pure workfare programs like New York's.
The Mayor's own workfare program, the largest in the country, has yet to show a proven record of finding permanent jobs for those who leave the rolls. According to city records, fewer than one-tenth of the 125,000 people who have passed through the program have reported finding permanent jobs; nearly two-thirds have left the program and given up their benefits without any indication of employment, and the city has made no effort to track their progress after leaving welfare.
In combination with a tough screening procedure, workfare has, however, reduced the city's welfare rolls by 240,000 people in the last 24 months; that is the figure which Mr. Giuliani cited often in his remarks last week and will be taking with him on the campaign trail later this year.
The Mayor's remarks on the subject came in response to an article in The New York Times of March 10, the first in a series about how a neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has reacted to the overhaul of welfare at the national and local levels. Mr. Giuliani has cited quotations from the article that he says show how people in the neighborhood believe workfare to be beneath them. That attitude, he says, flies in the face of what made this country great.
But in the last two years, many of the criticisms of the city's workfare program have centered not on the nature of its work, but on its operation. Many of those who have participated in the program have criticized the working conditions, the quick imposition of sanctions for those who are late or absent, and the inability to get training that might lead to a more productive, fulfilling life.
The Mayor has compared the program to the Works Progress Administration jobs program of the 1930's and 40's. But the voters he must convince are entering the economy of a new century.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Sea Change in Policy by the Trustbusters

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Observers were quick to note the irony of the brouhaha over the proposed merger of Staples and Office Depot. This union, like the blocked merger of the Rite-Aid and Revco drugstore chains last year, would never have been contested by the Federal Trade Commission if the two companies did not offer rock-bottom prices and superior service.
But there is more to the tale than the clash between hard-driving superstores and Federal bureaucrats suspicious of their success. Both cases are evidence of a long-brewing sea change in antitrust, one in which the focus of merger policy has shifted to the nitty-gritty of what's in a deal for consumers. 
 Where once the antitrust watchdogs would measure market shares and -- if they were Democrats -- rumble about the rising tide of corporate power, they now measure what will happen to prices. "The economists have triumphed over the lawyers," concludes Joe Sims, a lawyer at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, who was a deputy assistant attorney general in the Carter Administration.
This is not unalloyed good news, however, even to those with no patience for the Naderesque view that big is inherently bad. The abandonment of relatively simple rules for weighing the merits of mergers in favor of sophisticated economic analysis has increased the trustbusters' discretion in deciding where to intervene. That makes it harder for businesses to know what to expect from Washington when they propose a deal. And paradoxically, it invites bureaucrats to meddle in the name of maintaining free markets.
Legal theorists have been gnawing on the issue of what makes a merger good or bad since the first great wave of industrial consolidation late in the 19th century. Initially, bigness itself was presumed evil. In 1955 the Supreme Court backed the Justice Department in opposing the merger of Brown Shoe, the country's third-largest shoe maker, with Kinney, a shoe retailer with just 2 percent of the nation's sales. And in 1966, Washington shot down the merger of two Los Angeles supermarkets that shared just 8 percent of the market.
But since the mid-1970's the Supreme Court has been following the lead of the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission, which have been increasingly inclined to give business the benefit of the doubt. William Baxter, the Reagan Administration's free-market-minded antitrust chief, codified the idea in guidelines that transformed merger policy into a numbers game, one that green-lighted all mergers that did not concentrate the market beyond a predetermined limit. The result was a virtual free-for-all.
By the 1990's, trustbusters were busily refining the still-crude effort to link antitrust to modern economics. And now, Robert Pitofsky, the current chairman of the F.T.C. and a one-time believer in the big-is-bad doctrine, has eliminated the intellectual disconnect. For Mr. Pitofsky and his staff, the key question is identical to those that concern economists: How will a merger affect costs? And how will it affect prices?
The only practical way to answer the latter question is product by product and market by regional market. Hence the F.T.C.'s staff now estimates whether increased concentration will allow the combined companies to raise prices.
More often than not, this makes it as easy to obtain antitrust blessing in the Clinton 90's as it was in the Reagan 80's. Washington no longer blocks links where efficiency gains are likely to overwhelm anticompetitive effects -- for example, the merger of Chase Manhattan and the Chemical Bank. Indeed, the Clinton Administration is encouraging consolidation among military contractors. Nor will it block mergers between companies specializing in different segments of the same market -- for example, Dean Witter and Morgan Stanley.
But the rise of economist-think does imply more micromanagement of mergers in new industries created by technology and marketing.
Take the Staples-Office Depot deal. Together, the two chains sell only 4 percent of the $170 billion worth of office supplies in America -- less than Wal-Mart. Even in regions where they are strongest, their combined market share would hardly make a traditional trustbuster blink.
The F.T.C.'s staff argues, however, that the office superstores have created a new market, offering service and pricing previously unavailable to small-business purchasers. As a consequence, the F.T.C. estimates, most of their customers would have nowhere better to turn if the merged chains took advantage of their new position and raised prices by as much as 15 percent.
It was by the same token that the F.T.C. voted to block the merger of Rite-Aid and Revco. While that combination would not have controlled a very high proportion of the total market for prescription drugs, the commission worried that it would reduce the bargaining power of insurance plans that negotiate retail markups on behalf of millions of individuals.
So what's the problem? For one thing it leads to messy disputes over details in which dueling economists fight for the technical high ground. In the Staples-Office Depot case, Jerry Hausman, an economist at M.I.T. and a consultant to Staples, contends that the F.T.C. misread the evidence by comparing prices in markets where the chains currently compete with markets where they don't. Those with just one superstore today may well have higher prices for office supplies, he argues, but only because retailing costs are higher in those markets.
The subtler qualm here is that the new approach is transforming trustbusters from policemen to regulators -- a perverse consequence for a policy driven by the idea that markets can make decisions more efficiently than people. Rather than give a simple thumbs-up or thumbs-down to proposed mergers, the Justice Department and the F.T.C. are inclined to identify the anticompetitive aspects, then negotiate spinoffs, pricing rules or reporting requirements that offset their concerns. In the Staples-Office Depot case, for example, it seems likely that the commission will settle for the sale of some choice stores to a competitor, Officemax.
Note, too, that the bargaining power of corporations is very limited. If the Government contests a merger, the resulting delay and uncertainty typically K.O. the deal. As a consequence, "we've entered the 'fix-it' era of merger policy, with lots of negotiated settlements and few court cases," says Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution who was a senior adviser to the Clinton Justice Department.
Is micromanagement the inevitable price of a merger policy based on sophisticated economics?
There are ways to reduce the arbitrariness of enforcement without eviscerating it. Mr. Sims would streamline review procedures to give thwarted merger partners a practical way to challenge the Government in court. Mr. Hausman would like to set formal thresholds for Government intervention: If a merger would raise prices by less, say, than 5 percent, he would substitute the presumption that the social virtue of efficiency gains outweighed the vices. But nobody sees a way to eliminate the inherent tension. "There is simply no substitute for hands-on antitrust vigilance," says Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business.

HEADLINE: Sleeker Design for Staten Island Ferry Terminal Is Unveiled

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
The gigantic clock is out. The electronic message board, no more. Instead, the city's Economic Development Corporation has proposed that the new Staten Island Ferry terminal in lower Manhattan be a sleek, simple glass-walled building.
The new design calls for a 19,000-square-foot structure to replace the existing building, which in turn replaced the terminal destroyed in a 1991 fire. The waiting room would be about 50 percent larger than the current one. With a 90-foot-high entry hall, the $81 million terminal would have views of New York Harbor, the Statue of Liberty and lower Manhattan. 
 The project is still in the preliminary stages: before the construction contract can be awarded, additional design work still needs to be done, public hearings held and approvals from various city agencies obtained. All told, the project may not be finished until 2003.
But if approved, the design will cap a project that has been plagued by years of false starts, including rejected proposals to affix a big clock and an electronic message board to the facade. The design would also be a modern touch for an old-fashioned institution: the chugging boat which, at 50 cents a round trip, means cheap commuting for 60,000 Staten Islanders, and an inexpensive nighttime cruise.
"We're very enthusiastic about the project," said Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, "and we're glad that the community seems to be, too."
The original terminal, called the Whitehall Street Ferry Terminal, was a squat, washed-out green hulk in which function vanquished form; the American Institute of Architects once called it "the world's most banal portal of joy." A fire destroyed the old terminal in 1991, forcing the construction of a temporary station.
In 1992, the Economic Development Corporation selected a design for a new terminal from a team led by the architectural firm of Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates. But that design, with its clock, and another one, with an electronic message board, were torpedoed by public criticism and budget constraints.
Last October, Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates bowed out of the project, leaving Anderson/ Schwartz Architects to work on it. Last week, Anderson Schwartz unveiled the newest design at a meeting in Staten Island Borough Hall.
Under the plans, the terminal would include 8,000 square feet of concessions, including cafes and newsstands. It would redesign the outdoor Peter Minuit Plaza, currently a group of traffic islands, to accommodate pedestrians, markets and cultural performances, as well as vehicles.
It would also offer improved mass transit links. The entry hall would include an entrance to the No. 1 and 9 subway lines at the South Ferry Station. There would also be a covered walkway to the Whitehall Street Station and the N and R lines.
The city has already earmarked $31 million and the Federal Government $12.35 million to the project, according to the Economic Development Corporation. And the city and Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island are lobbying the Federal Government to dedicate an additional $37.65 million in Federal transportation funds.
The new design follows last month's announcement of a plan by Staten Island officials to replace the aging St. George Ferry Terminal with a $100 million building.
"Clearly, we need a new terminal badly, and I think the net impact of what will happen is that you'll have more people using the ferries," said Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island Borough President. "But frankly, almost anything would be an improvement over what was there before the fire."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Unlike previous, rejected designs, the new plan for the facade of the $81 million Staten Island Ferry terminal, left, has no giant clock and no electronic message board. HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Tentative Deal Reached In American Airlines Talks
American Airlines and negotiators from its pilots' union reached an agreement in principle on terms of a new contract, making another strike by the pilots somewhat less likely.
But two significant hurdles remain to reaching a final agreement, and those uncertainties may give pause to travelers making plans to fly on American in late April, when a strike can still occur. The agreement remains subject to votes by the board of the union and then by its members. [Page A1.]
 
Plan for Cut in Power Rates
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York announced details of a plan to cut Long Island's high electric rates by as much as 23 percent through a partial state takeover of Long Island Lighting. Wall Street applauded the deal, which would entail the largest municipal bond issue in history. [A1.] 

Price Index Rises 0.3%
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent last month, led by higher costs for fresh vegetables and natural gas. [D4.]
 
Treasury prices fell because of concern about inflation, with the yield on the 30-year bond climbing to 6.98 percent from 6.96. [D18.]
 
With Technology Weak, Stocks Fall
The Nasdaq index fell 20.05 points, closing at 1,249.29, hurt by a sharp selloff in computer stocks. The Dow industrials fell less, slipping 18.88 points, to 6,877.68. [D8.]
 
2 Views of the Internet
The Supreme Court heard starkly different descriptions of the Internet from supporters and opponents of the Communications Decency Act of 1996. At stake is the Government's effort to regulate sexually explicit material on the global computer network. [A1.]
 
New Phones' Security Is Breached
A group of computer security experts has cracked the electronic code meant to protect the privacy of calls made with the new digital generation of cellular telephones. That means that the new cellular telephones may in practice be little more secure from eavesdropping than the analog cellular phones in use for the last 15 years. [A1.]
 
Report of Bid for Sprint Is Denied
Sprint and France Telecom denied a report that Cable and Wireless was considering a takeover bid for Sprint. But France Telecom said that talks were under way for Cable and Wireless to become the British arm of the French company's joint venture with Sprint and Deutsche Telekom. [D7.]
 
Liggett Settlement Said to Be Near
State attorneys general are close to a settlement with Liggett that could include the company's handing over documents potentially damaging to the tobacco industry, negotiators said. [B10.]
 
Krupp Shifts Tack on Thyssen
The German steelmaker Krupp said that it would drop its unsolicited takeover bid for Thyssen if they could reach an agreement to combine their steel operations. [D4.]
 
Regulators Chastise Merrill
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission criticized Merrill Lynch, saying it had failed to exercise proper supervision over a broker who defrauded customers of millions of dollars. But the commission said it would not bring any enforcement action against the firm. [D19.]
 
Pepsi to Sponsor Baseball
Pepsi-Cola signed up as a sponsor with Major League Baseball, hoping to link its youth-oriented marketing to baseball's young stars like Ken Griffey Jr. and Derek Jeter. The deal is valued at an estimated $50 million over five years. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Pataki Outlines Accord to Cut Electric Rates for Long Island

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 19

 BODY:
A jubilant Gov. George E. Pataki flew to Long Island today and announced details of an agreement to cut the Island's electric rates up to 23 percent through a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.
Flanked by enthusiastic politicians of both major parties, the Republican Governor said the plan would bring a new era of prosperity to an area that now pays the highest electric rates in North America. As part of the deal, homeowners, who for more than a decade have had their rates inflated by the cost of building and abandoning the $6.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant, would receive rebate checks averaging $100 to $232. 
 If the deal is completed on the current schedule, those checks will be mailed out in the fall of 1998 while Mr. Pataki is campaigning for a second term.
"By dramatically cutting electric rates," Mr. Pataki said, "we will allow the economy to grow and create new jobs for years to come."
The deal would entail the largest municipal bond issue in history -- $7 billion -- to be sold by the state's Long Island Power Authority. In the stock market, investors pushed up the closing price of stock today in both Lilco, which climbed to 24 1/2, up 1 1/8, and its merger partner, Brooklyn Union Gas, whose shares rose to 29 3/4, up 5/8.
The deal still faces several regulatory and political hurdles, and final approval is expected to take 18 months.
Still, the plan is a major political achievement for Governor Pataki, fulfilling a promise that he made more than a year ago to reduce Long Island's electric rates by at least 10 percent.
In his 1994 election campaign, Mr. Pataki attacked a state takeover plan proposed by his Democratic opponent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. But he soon learned that few issues are more important to Long Island's residents -- and its Republican politicians -- than Lilco's burdensome rates. Many of the Governor's strongest allies, including United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, are Long Islanders and pushed for the deal to cut rates.
After last week's announcement of a state plan to overhaul utility service in Consolidated Edison's territory, the Lilco plan would further revamp the New York region's electric service in an era of energy deregulation and increased competition.
The state's agreement with Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas would create a potentially powerful new entity. The new company would continue to run Long Island's electric system under a contract with the Long Island Power Authority, which would own Lilco's former transmission and distribution lines and customer service. Company executives also have their eyes on expansion to other parts of the state.
But the deal faces at least two potential pitfalls.
First, it needs the approval of the Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, who has veto power with one of the three votes on the state's Public Authorities Control Board. While Mr. Pataki said the Speaker's initial reactions were positive, Mr. Silver said he had not made up his mind.
"I don't intend to stand in the way of a deal that produces all the things this deal is supposed to produce," he said. "I just want to make sure it's as advertised."
Second, the plan needs a waiver from the Internal Revenue Service to avoid about $2 billion in capital-gains taxes on the state's payments to Lilco. The Long Island Power Authority's chairman, Frank G. Zarb, said that "an adverse ruling from the I.R.S. would cripple this solution" and force officials to try other strategies. But he said he felt strongly that the proposal would meet I.R.S. standards.
The plan is also subject to review by the State Public Service Commission, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition, the Lilco-Brooklyn Union Gas merger is subject to approval by the companies' stockholders.
Longtime critics of Lilco expressed skepticism about the plan.
Larry Shapiro, a senior attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group said, "It looks like a bailout of Lilco and a deal to send a check to every ratepayer in an election year, then worry about it the next 29 years."
But the plan's political appeal was evident as local officials jockeyed for position today next to the Governor and competed to outdo each other in praise for one another and the agreement.
"Governor, today, you have lit up the lives of Long Islanders -- and at less cost," said Bruce Blakeman, presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature. His Democratic counterpart, Bruce Nyman, the minority leader, said: "When Democrats thank a Republican governor, you know there's a story here. It's the greatest day for Long Island I can remember."
Mr. Pataki lauded Richard M. Kessel, a Democrat and minority member of the Long Island Power Authority, who worked closely with the authority's chairman, Mr. Zarb. For his part, Mr. Kessel praised Mr. Pataki and another Republican adversary, Senator D'Amato. "Behind the scenes, Al D'Amato brought this together," Mr. Kessel said.
Under the agreement, the power authority would buy Lilco's transmission and distribution lines and customer services like billing, installation and repairs, and would reserve the right to buy Lilco's power generating plants after three years. The authority would also assume $3.6 billion of the remaining $4.5 billion Shoreham debt and Lilco's share in the troubled Nine Mile Point 2 Plant.
The holding company for the merged Lilco and Brooklyn Union Gas would absorb the remaining $900 million in Shoreham debt.
The Long Island Power Authority bond issue would pay for the purchase, and the authority's tax-exempt status would allow for lower interest rates. The authority would also save money because it would not pay Federal corporate income taxes or stock dividends.
The merged Lilco-Brooklyn Union company would run the operation, under a contract with incentives and penalties based on performance. After the fifth year, the authority would require competitive bidding for the contract to run the electricity operation.
Although the authority would buy power from Lilco's generating plants, it would be free to buy cheaper power elsewhere as demand grows, and would gradually be allowed to switch to other suppliers for all the electrical power.
Because of the high cost of power produced on the Island, the authority would work with Suffolk County on a project to install a new transmission line under Long Island Sound to enable the importing of cheaper power. It would also work with Nassau and Suffolk Counties to distribute cheaper power.
The authority would gradually give customers the right to choose their source of power as the industry becomes deregulated.
Another key issue in the agreement was the potentially devastating $1.1 billion refund owed to Lilco by Suffolk County, Brookhaven Town and the Shoreham-Wading River School District for excessive property taxes. In the negotiations, that amount was reduced to $625 million. The payment will be financed by the bond issue, and repaid by a surcharge to Suffolk electric customers. As a result, they would receive less of a rate reduction than Nassau customers.
The initial rate reductions under the plan would be 18.2 percent in Nassau and 16.4 percent in Suffolk. After five years, the reduction would reach 23.2 percent in Nassau and 20.5 percent in Suffolk.
Critics accused Mr. Pataki of failing to provide in the plan as much competition as he originally promised, but he said the agreement represented a practical compromise.
Much stronger praise came from the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, who was delighted to have the property tax refund resolved.
"This is as close to a perfect solution as I have seen in my years of government," he said.

HEADLINE: Trade Group Backs Effort To Ship Bananas to Europe

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
After spending years trying to get leaders of both political parties to pay attention to his trade problems around the world, Carl H. Lindner, who controls Chiquita Brands International, has finally won a victory: The World Trade Organization has backed his right to ship bananas to Europe.
Mr. Lindner, a Cincinnati businessman, is well-known in Washington. Since 1993, he and his American Financial Corporation have contributed more than $1 million to the two major political parties. Bob Dole, the former Republican Presidential candidate, used a jet belonging to the Lindner family empire during the 1996 campaign, and Mr. Lindner, sharing in what has become a perquisite for Democratic donors during the Clinton Administration, spent a night in the Lincoln Bedroom. Bananas became one of Mr. Dole's most intense trade interests, and the Administration, while declining to impose unilateral sanctions against Europe, pressed his case with the World Trade Organization in Geneva. 
 But until Tuesday, when a preliminary decision was handed down in that case, he had yet to win a single round of his banana battles with Europe. Now, said diplomats familiar with a still-confidential opinion written by a three-judge panel of the trade organization, Europe's regulations have been found to unfairly favor fruit from African, Caribbean and Pacific states, chiefly former European colonies.
The European Union said that those rules were designed to support the Caribbean economies that depend heavily on their banana crops, and that those economies would be destroyed if they had to compete with lower-cost producers in Latin America who sell huge volumes of bananas through Chiquita and other brands. Chiquita contends that the European policy has cost the company more than $400 million over the last five years.
European officials said yesterday that they intended to appeal.
"Many of the conclusions of the report appear to be unfavorable but we need to analyze this further," said Peter Guilford, spokesman for the European Union's trade commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan. Appeals are common in World Trade Organization rulings, but rarely successful.
It is unclear, however, whether Mr. Lindner will be entirely satisfied with his victory. When the ruling is completed, the European Union will have the chance to rewrite its rules, or to pay compensation to the United States, Mexico and the other countries that challenged the banana import restrictions.
"There are ways for the Europeans to blunt the effect of this," one American official said today.
For that reason, Mr. Lindner had sought stronger action from Washington. On his behalf, then-Senator Dole introduced amendments to budget bills in Congress that would have imposed sharp sanctions on Costa Rica and Colombia for going along with the European banana-trade system. Those amendments failed.
Mr. Lindner also pressed the White House, seeking unilateral sanctions against Europe. The Administration balked at that request, but agreed to take his case to what Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative, called an "impartial review" by the trade organization.

HEADLINE: In Helsinki, U.S. Wants Yeltsin Nod On NATO

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, March 19

 BODY:
The summit meeting that begins here on Thursday caps a month of intensive bargaining and diplomatic courtship that American officials hope will lead to grudging Russian tolerance of a plan to expand the NATO alliance eastward.
As advance parties awaited the arrival on Thursday of Presidents Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin for two days of talks, Americans today described a campaign of military reassurances and economic inducements that they predict will allow Mr. Yeltsin to leave Helsinki declaring that he has fully defended Russian honor. [President Clinton left Washington shortly after 9 P.M. Wednesday.] 
 Most of the Western sweeteners have been presented to the Russians over the last month. They include promises not to station nuclear weapons or foreign troops in new members at Russia's edge as long as there is no clear threat.
The Americans do not expect Mr. Yeltsin to make any final decisions on NATO when he meets Mr. Clinton for the first time in 11 months. But they hope for signals that the Russian leader is prepared to live with the new military arrangement in exchange for a closer political and economic integration with the West.
The Americans hope Mr. Yeltsin is setting up Helsinki as a great battle from which he will emerge declaring ultimately that he had protected Russian security, drawn the sting from NATO expansion and made the new Europe safe for a Russia that will take its place once again as a great nation.
American officials said that Mr. Yeltsin would be able to highlight NATO's pledge, "in the current or foreseeable security environment," not to station nuclear weapons or alliance troops on the soil of new members, which are expected to include Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and possibly Slovenia.
He could also point to NATO's offer to slash the limits on the size of conventional forces in Western Europe and to freeze them in Central Europe.
And he could cite NATO's offer of a permanent council for consultation with Russia, providing it special status, as well as special access to military planning and exercises.
As a measure of American good will, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Defense Secretary William Cohen gave Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov a two-and-a-half-hour briefing last Sunday at the Pentagon.
In Helsinki, Mr. Clinton will also offer Mr. Yeltsin guidelines for a new strategic arms reduction treaty, Start 3, which would save Moscow the expense of building up to Start 2 limits and still preserve its cherished "nuclear parity" with Washington.
American officials are also hoping that increased economic aid will appeal to Mr. Yeltsin, particularly now that he has placed young market reformers like Anatoly B. Chubais and Boris Y. Nemtsov in charge of the economy. Mr. Clinton will ask Congress for increased economic aid of $242 million, up from $95 million last year. While relatively small -- and Congress could cut the amount -- the aid will promote Russian goals of economic growth, improved taxation and more foreign investment.
To meet Russia's desire to be welcomed into the larger club of important countries, Mr. Clinton will also promise Washington's support for Russian membership in several major organizations. These include permanent membership in the political sessions of the Group of seven major industrial countries; in the World Trade Organization, and in the Paris Club, which renegotiates the terms of government-to-government debt.
Russia does not now qualify for full membership in the G-7, but Mr. Clinton will pledge to support its membership once its economy and legal systems improve.
While hoping that Mr. Yeltsin will "take yes for an answer," the Americans acknowledge that Russia may be trying to make the process so painful that the West will not try to expand NATO further after the first round.
The Russians are working to limit NATO's expansion and insure that former Soviet republics like Ukraine, Belarus and especially the Baltic nations never join. April 2 is the anniversary of Russia's agreement with Belarus to create some form of union, and some Americans think those talks may accelerate, putting more pressure on Ukraine and the Baltic nations not to join NATO.
Mr. Primakov did manage last weekend to irk some American officials, part of a time-tested Moscow strategy when playing a weak hand. But today's Russia is not the mighty Soviet Union.
As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright insists, Russia's consent to NATO expansion is unnecessary. But she says Russia should understand its own interest in cooperation and stability.
"We know it will take time," she said, "for the progress of trust to catch up with the process of change."
