HEADLINE: Mexican Drugs: A Semi-Censure Reported Near

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and Senate negotiators agreed tonight to a resolution that criticizes Mexican anti-drug efforts but does not bar the President from certifying Mexico as an ally in the war on drugs.
Administration and Senate aides said they had found a way to defuse a confrontation that has been building all month over how to chastise Mexico but avoid the embarrassment of declaring a close trading partner to be delinquent in fighting drugs. 
 The resolution gives President Clinton until Sept. 1 to report to Congress on what progress has been made in a number of specific areas, including extradition of drug merchants, efforts to curb money laundering and measures to protect United States drug agents in Mexico.
Complicating the prospects for such a report are persistent assertions that Mexico is allowing drug traffickers to accumulate millions in local accounts. [Page A10.]
Even some senior Administration officials agree that drug corruption is so endemic throughout Mexican law enforcement that cooperation is difficult if not impossible. The President must notify Congress every year which countries are cooperating in fighting drugs. Those that are not face economic sanctions.
Senator Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who has led the effort to overturn President Clinton's declaration on Feb. 28 that Mexico had "cooperated fully" in efforts to halt the drug trade, said she was satisfied with the language. "This is a definitive statement by the Senate that the status quo is not acceptable and that both countries need to redouble our efforts," she said.
An Administration official agreed, saying, "Rather than a confrontational approach, this amplifies our ongoing joint efforts and holds the promise of even greater results on the war on drugs."
The resolution, which is likely to come to a Senate vote on Thursday, does not provide for any further automatic action. If Congress is dissatisfied with Mr. Clinton's report and wants to take action against Mexico, it would have to start from scratch legislatively.
Mr. Clinton's declaration that Mexico had cooperated fully was necessary to avert formal "decertification," a step that would have required reductions in aid to Mexico.
Mrs. Feinstein and other legislators had attacked that declaration, but Administration officials warned that decertification could erode confidence in the Mexican economy and would almost surely reduce -- not increase -- Mexican efforts to combat the drug trade.
Then last week the House approved a resolution that would extend certfication for only 90 days unless the President reported specific progress by Mexico.
The Administration official said the new resolution, unlike previous versions in both the House and Senate, was less focused on blame and more on what needed to be done.
The language is indeed gentler toward Mexico. For example, its references to safeguarding United States agents are less speciifc than the earlier demand that they be allowed to carry firearms in Mexico, a demand Mexican officials publicly rejected last week. It also acknowledges, at least in passing, Mexican anti-corruption efforts.

HEADLINE: Auckland Journal;
The Betrayed Maori Are Calling for a Reckoning

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 19

 BODY:
Solid as an anvil in a well-worn buff jacket, granite-eyed behind bristles of beard, Mike Smith is one of the urban Maori called "nga tamatoa," or "young warriors."
A high-school dropout, he is at home in the city's jails, quotes Noam Chomsky and the American Indian advocate Russell Means, rails against privatization, economic cutbacks and foreign investors and for 16 years has been at the sharp edge of the movement to redress the wrongs of the British colonizers of New Zealand. 
 Although the Government is now trying to address claims by the Maoris, who were cast into second-class status after confiscation of their lands in the last century, he warns that too little is coming too late.
Asserting that "younger people really feel betrayed," he said: "The mood is no longer to tug at the forelock and say, 'I'll be a good nigger, master,' which was very much the attitude of our parents and grandparents. They had the boot physically on their necks. It's now ratcheting up. Expect more and more acts of destruction."
Not all Maori share the radicalism of Mr. Smith, 38, who last tangled with the authorities 17 months ago when he hacked at a symbolic ponderosa pine planted by white colonizers in a place known as One Tree Hill and was jailed overnight.
The sledgehammer attack that badly damaged the America's Cup last week, carried out by a 27-year-old Maori protester whose name has not been disclosed, horrified not only the yachting world but also many other Maori, some of whom apologized to an American visitor.
"Smashing things is not the answer," said Keri Neilson, 23, a teacher and member of the Nga Puhi tribe north of here. "We need more educated Maori people and a wide range of jobs."
"I don't know whether we're ever going to find an equitable balance with the Pakeha," she said, using the Maori term for whites.
Tuariki John Delamere, 45, one of 15 Maori in the 120-seat Parliament in Wellington and one of three Maori ministers in the Government, said, "All the educational attainment in the world will not change the fact that when a Maori attends a job interview, as things now stand, he or she will most likely be judged by a person from the majority culture who will see them first as a Maori -- with all the negative connotations that may include."
Archeological remains suggest that Maori ancestors emigrated here by canoe from Eastern Polynesia more than 1,000 years ago. Today the Maori represent 15 percent of the 3.5 million New Zealanders.
Until the first quarter of this century they lived almost exclusively in rural areas. Four out of five Maori today are in the bigger cities and towns.
Poverty, worsened by severe cutbacks in Government services after years of fiscal retrenchment, has generated what scholars here call a rootless and alienated Maori underclass subject to unemployment at rates above 50 percent in some urban pockets and high consumption of alcohol and drugs.
But with so much intermarriage between the Maori and whites, few here fear racial clashes. "I don't know a single Maori who doesn't have Pakeha cousins," Mr. Delamere said.
While denouncing acts of violence, even the more conservative and better-off Maori share with the radicals a deep sense of grievance over what the New Zealand Government has finally recognized are a series of broken promises by whites.
Ranginui Walker, 65, is the head of the Maori Studies Department at Auckland University and the author of books including "Years of Anger" and "Struggle Without End." A member of the Whakatohea tribe, he sees the history of the last 150 years "in an extremely personal way."
"Our tribe had all its land confiscated in 1864-65, 35,000 acres of prime farming land, and our people were pushed up into a reservation, up against the hills.
"So that's got to be a pretty definitive experience when you're living in poverty, no employment, and when you go into town you see white people, descendants of military settlers, control all the businesses and you see a beautiful golf course and you know that is confiscated land, and so the insult is there for your whole lifetime."
Mr. Walker succeeded academically, became upwardly mobile, then jumped into the cauldron of cultural politics and was considered extremist back in the 1970's as he railed "openly and vehemently," as he put it, "against monocultural Pakeha dominance and Maori subjection."
He calls the chopping down of trees, earlier defacement of British statues and now the battering of the America's Cup "quixotic acts" of a new generation of radicals, expressing "an anger and frustration that has to be taken into account -- rather than eliciting a knee-jerk reaction to them."
He adjusts thick glasses as he sits at a cluttered desk in his book-stuffed office. Towering Maori totem poles dominate spaces of the atrium outside.
"White people regard me as an elder statesman," he said. "They come up to me and say, 'You've mellowed in your old age.' 'Oh, is that right?' I say. 'I'm still the same old person. Perhaps it's your perceptions that have changed.' "
While the Maori always insisted that the Government had in effect stolen their land, the Government's acknowledgment of responsibility has come about in recent years after a series of protests and court rulings. Negotiations have been under way since 1991 over specific claims.
The story of Maori disaffection goes back to a charter signed in 1840 by representatives of the British Crown and 500 Maori chiefs, the so-called Treaty of Waitangi. It guaranteed that the Maori would retain their lands and other material and cultural treasures and enjoy equal rights of citizenship.
"A big rip-off occurred," Justice Minister Douglas Graham conceded in an interview. Mr. Graham, who is also Minister for Treaty of Waitangi Negotiations, forecast that at least the major Maori claims would be settled by the year 2000. More than 400 claims have come from 37 tribes and hundreds of subtribes and even individual families. Not everyone wants money. Some families simply want burial grounds protected.
But for most it is a question of getting assets back. So far the Government has agreed to return the equivalent of $450 million, and is hoping to cap total outlays at $750 million.
"We have to be realistic," Mr. Graham said. "The rest of the country and the tax base won't allow us to do more." But he emphasized, "We are committed to working with the Maori to achieve their full and active participation in New Zealand society."

INTERNATIONAL A3-13

Senate and White House Agree on Faulting Mexico
The Senate and the White House reached agreement on language to criticize Mexico for what legislators see as its failure to fight drug trafficking diligently, without taking any steps that might undermine the Mexican economy. A1
 
A new dispute between Washington and Mexico erupted over Mexico's failure to seize $160 million the United States asserts was deposited in Mexican banks by a drug suspect. Mexican officials contended that the amount was misunderstood. A10

President Clinton departed for Helsinki, Finland, and a meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. United States officials hope Mr. Yeltsin will find the political cover he needs to accept a plan to expand the NATO alliance eastward. A6
 
Egypt Warns Against Har Homa
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt warned that Israel's decision to build Har Homa, a Jewish housing project in East Jerusalem, could set off a new cycle of violence in the Middle East. In Jordan, King Hussein made a surprise move, choosing a Prime Minister seen as committed to warmer ties with Israel. A11
 
Israeli Proposal Elicits No Trust
Israeli officials said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had revived a proposal to bypass interim steps of the Mideast peace accords and go straight to talks on a final settlement. They said that since Mr. Netanyahu had to extend so much political capital to get his right-wing supporters to accept each step, he might as well go all the way at once. The Palestinians rejected the notion as a "media trick." A12
 
New Tuberculosis Treatment
Millions of lives could be saved through a tuberculosis treatment that has been used successfully from New York City to Tanzania, the World Health Organization said. The treatment hinges on insuring that patients continue to take four inexpensive drugs for a full course lasting six to eight months. A5
 
Protests Over Polish Shipyard
Hundreds of laid-off workers in Poland chanted anti-Communist slogans in protesting the closure of the bankrupt shipyard in Gdansk where the Solidarity movement was born. The Government, whose refusal to guarantee loans to keep the shipyard afloat was seen by workers as politically motivated, blamed the Solidarity-led management for overemployment and excessive benefits. A7
Italy Calls Refugee Emergency
Italy declared a national state of emergency that allows the immediate expulsion of Albanian refugees whom the Government deems undesirable. The decree was Italy's first comprehensive response to a crisis that has brought more than 10,600 Albanian refugees to its shores in the past week. The decree also called for at-sea inspections of boats carrying refugees and the seizure of any vessels that arrive in Italy. (AP)

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
A Fair That Travels Through Centuries Of Asian Creativity

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
THE debut of the International Asian Art Fair in Manhattan last spring was an undisputed hit. Top-flight dealers were on board; the art was spectacular. The swell of foot traffic from Park Avenue surpassed even the most optimistic expectations: New York had clearly discovered Asian art in a major way.
This year's fair gives every indication of repeating that success, even without an extravaganza like the Met's 1996 "Splendors of Imperial China" fanning the flames. Many of the dealers are back; a few new ones have been added. (Europeans outnumber Americans this time around.) And one would have to travel far indeed to encompass the sheer range of material -- Indian bronzes, Chinese funerary figures, Japanese screens, Persian carpets -- filling the Seventh Regiment Armory from tonight through Wednesday. 
 Why the interest in Asian art now? Politics and economics play their part. The uncertain future of Hong Kong with its crucial art market and the increased attention to art poaching internationally seem to have inspired a buy-while-you-can urgency. And in the West, where a nothing Picasso can fetch millions, great Asian objects are a comparative steal.
But does the interest go beyond the practical? One can only speculate, of course. But maybe an art with a reputation for being infused with spiritual traditions sustained over centuries has come to have a talismanic presence at this jittery, fragmented, millennial moment.
All these factors -- commerce and connoisseurship, scholarship and poetry -- are in the air at the Asian Art Fair, and their undisguised, often unholy alliance helps explain the show's magnetism.
As was the case last year, Chinese art is predominant. In fact, it is so plentiful and varied that, with a little legwork, a rough chronological survey of the field can be worked out. The Gisele Croes Gallery is a place to start, with its great bronze vessels from the Shang period (circa 1600-1027 B.C.) and a svelte female dancer, meant to enliven a tomb of the Han dynasty (202 B.C-A.D. 220).
A leap to an exquisite swatch of floral patterned silk from the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618-907) at Francesca Galloway could be next. (The same design in hushed blues and beiges ornaments the Buddhist caves of Dunhuang.) And this can be followed by a visit to the imposing set of 13th-to-14th- century polychromed stucco temple sculptures, near life-size, at A. & J. Speelman.
From here one might make a nod to the recent craze for Ming furniture (M. D. Flacks shows almost nothing else) and take a quick but bracing dip into ceramics (Spink & Son has a pair of jars from the late 17th century, in Dufy yellows and reds).
Finally, the booths of L. J. Wender and Michael Goedhuis make logical end points, the one with a painting by a Buddhist-pacifist artist, Feng Ze Kai (1898-1975), which includes a cartoonlike image of Mao Zedong as a child's doll; the other with stainlike ink and pigment paintings of flowers by Yang Yanping, a Chinese-trained artist who lives on Long Island.
Devotees of Korean art will want to sample the wares at Kang Collection and Lea Sneider. Ariane Dandois again offers an entrancing display of Japanese screens: in one, deer gambol through a landscape composed of dusted gold. Islamic art shines at Oliver Hoare's booth, with a pocket-size 14th-century Moroccan astrolabe and a piece of 16th-century Ottoman silk whose rippling, surreal-looking organic forms are woven in metal thread.
In terms of both quality and rarity, however, the art of India is the star attraction this year, and it finds a stunning showcase at John Eskenazi. The lineup here includes the streamlined figure of a nude Jain saint and the gorgeous head of a bodhisattva, his eyes half closed, his flowing hair caught up into an elegant chignon.
But the centerpiece is a relief panel, carved around the second century A.D., from the fabled Buddhist stupa at Amaravati. The stupa itself -- an immense, solid reliquary mound covered with carvings -- was destroyed long ago, but this sculpture, worn smooth with time, touch and weather, pulses with peculiar devotional energy that distinguishes the Amaravati style.
Such dynamism is the hallmark of Indian art throughout its history. It is there in two stone female figures, as grave as Roman matrons, at Rossi & Rossi; in the gorgeous sixth-century stone figure of Sarasvati, goddess of music, surrounded by her celestial court at R. H. Ellsworth; and in the ravishing South Indian bronze dream team of Krishna and his consorts at the Chinese Porcelain Company, with their rapt, confident faces and hands like flowers.
There is no greater art than the art of India, though it has never found a wide audience in the West, and perhaps never will. Its apparently contradictory blend of spiritual enthusiasm and repose, its reluctance to draw firm lines between the natural and the supernatural, its preference for gods who dance, for joy over tragedy, may always stand as a distant challenge to Western taste.
But it is a challenge well worth considering. And the Asian Art Fair, with its exotic versions of the familiar (ceramic pillows, a chic little tunic painted with gold) and its eye-opening embodiments of the transcendent, is, this year again, an ideal place to do so.
The International Asian Art Fair is at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, through Wednesday. There is a benefit preview tonight at 6 for the Asia Society; tickets: (212) 288-6400, extension 235 or 360. Fair hours: 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday; 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Sunday and Wednesday. Admission: $15. Information: (212) 642-8572.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A sixth-century buff sandstone figure of the Indian goddess Sarasvati is in the R. H. Ellsworth booth at the Asian Art Fair. (R.H. Ellsworth Inc.)

HEADLINE: MUSIC REVIEW;
How to Go to Extremes To Tart Up 'Rigoletto'

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
Tito Capobianco's 1988 staging of Verdi's "Rigoletto" returned to the New York City Opera for the first time this season on Wednesday evening with its broad, magnifying strokes intact. For Mr. Capobianco, the Duke was not merely decadent; he and his courtiers, dressed in gold, red and black, cavort in a chamber that looks more like a brothel than a ducal court. Cushions are conveniently strewn in every corner, even though the bedroom is just through the double doors, and half-naked dancers weave among the revelers.
Nothing is left to suggestion in this production, which is now directed by Cynthia Edwards. The Duke sings "Questa o quella" with women draped around him, and he rolls on the cushions with several women while Monterone delivers his stinging lament. Esperanza Galan was clearly given a free hand to choreograph: nothing occurs without elaborate movement. And Carl Toms, the stage and costume designer, seemed intent on showing the economic hierarchy. The wasteful opulence of the court gives way to Sparafucile's lair, a lattice of rotted timber that looks as if it might crumble at any moment. Between those extremes, Rigoletto's home seems comfortably bourgeois. 
 Of the singers who inhabited this world, only Mark Delavan, in the title role, successfully climbed into his character's skin. He was consistently commanding, not a quality normally associated with the hunchbacked jester but one that worked in Mr. Delavan's portrayal. And if his timbre was slightly boxy at times, he sang with power and clarity. He also proved a fine actor who captured the full range of Rigoletto's complex, twisted emotional world.
Good acting was at a premium on Wednesday. After Mr. Delavan, one had to move well down the cast list -- to Brian Matthews's finely etched Sparafucile, Angela Horn's energetic Maddalena and George Cordes's dignified Monterone -- to find singers whose vocal and dramatic abilities were fully in sync.
Vocally, Vladimir Grishko was a better than passable Duke. His light tenor was uneven at first but grew in power and warmth though not in subtlety as the evening progressed. Yet his quintessentially Russian body language, including grand hand and arm gestures, were not for the world of "Rigoletto."
Olga Makarina has the timbre and range for Gilda, and she produced lovely sounds throughout the evening. But her "Caro nome" was unduly cautious, and even by operatic standards, her acting was awkward and stiff. At key moments -- when Rigoletto leads her away at the end of the second act and when she walks into Sparafucile's dagger in the finale -- Ms. Makarina seemed not to have a clue what to do with herself.
Joseph Colaneri led a brisk but by no means rushed performance. He made the most of key moments, like the sudden change of mood when Monterone pronounces his fateful curse, and drew a rich, nicely balanced sound from the orchestra.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes With Surge After an Up-and-Down Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar surged yesterday after Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly hinted that the central bank would raise interest rates next week.
The dollar overcame early weakness caused by the release of data showing that the United States trade deficit rose to a record in January. 
 In an appearance on Capitol Hill, Mr. Greenspan's repeated references to the need for preventive efforts to thwart inflationary pressure in the economy were interpreted by currency traders as the most persuasive evidence yet that the Fed's policy-making committee would increase rates at its meeting on Tuesday.
Rising rates tend to bolster the value of a currency because they increase the returns of securities denominated in that currency.
The dollar settled at its high point of the day in New York at 1.6935 German marks and 123.75 Japanese yen, up from 1.6816 marks and 122.82 yen on Wednesday. The British pound weakened to $1.5881 from $1.5982.
Many traders said they expected the Fed to raise the Federal funds short-term lending rate next week by at least a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent.
Even before Mr. Greenspan spoke, the dollar was beginning to rebound as traders reassessed the selloff caused by the Commerce Department report in the morning that showed the United States trade deficit rising 21.1 percent in January, to a record $12.7 billion.
The report suggested that the dollar's recovery from postwar lows against the yen and mark two years ago was hurting United States exporters by making their goods more expensive overseas.
But a closer look at the trade report showed that the dollar's strength against the yen and the mark played only a minor role in the increased deficit. Most of the shortfall came from a surge of imports from China.
"People sold the headline and then looked at the details, and everyone started scrambling to buy the dollar back," Ben Strauss, a senior currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York, said.
"Then," he added, "Greenspan added fuel to the fire."

HEADLINE: A.C.L.U. Is on Wrong Side of Campaign Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Having enthusiastically paid dues to the American Civil Liberties Union since the age of 17, 50 years ago, I never expected to resign from the organization in disgust. But the A.C.L.U.'s opposition to limits on huge campaign contributions did it (news article, March 15).
To continue to support an organization that is on the wrong side of the most fundamental issue facing our country -- the swamping of American political life by increasing, highly motivated millions of dollars -- should be abhorrent to any "small-d" democrat. 
 The Jeffersonian principle of decentralization of economic and political power is as vital to the future of democracy as the First Amendment principle of free speech. To claim that the right of a few to throw millions of dollars onto the scales of political decision-making should take precedence over the rights of all to an equal voice in those decisions is a tragic error.
Thousands of members of the A.C.L.U. know better, even if its paid lobbyists in their myopia do not.
 
DOUGLAS C. KELLEY
San Bernardino, Calif., March 17, 1997

HEADLINE: Bond Act Spending Is Legislature's Purview

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A March 16 editorial argues correctly that the proceeds of New York's Clean Air-Clean Water Bond Act must be spent fairly and wisely. But your conclusion that Gov. George E. Pataki should have final authority over the spending is inconsistent with this objective and with the essence of representative democracy.
Virtually every state constitution, including New York's, has language that closely resembles the power-of-the-purse provision the Founders included in the Federal Constitution: "No Money shall be drawn from the Treasury, but in Consequence of Appropriations made by Law." 
 A 1927 amendment to the State Constitution gives a governor the power to propose appropriations bills, but the power to adopt them still rests with the Legislature. This was made clear by the state's highest court in 1981 when it ruled that the governor could not avoid this requirement by claiming that certain funds (in that case, Federal grants) were not part of the state treasury.
If the Legislature isn't working as well as it should, the solution is to make it work better, not to abrogate the concept of majority rule by ceding essential legislative powers to the executive.
 
FRANK J. MAURO
Niskayuna, N.Y., March 16, 1997
 
The writer is executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Condominium Offering Plan on Upper West Side

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
One of the West Side's largest landlords has begun the process, rare in recent years, of converting a 48-unit prewar rental apartment building on the Upper West Side into condominium apartments.
The sponsor of the 12-story, rent-regulated building at 650 West End Avenue, at 92d Street, filed a condominium offering plan with the State Attorney General's office in January. The proposal's sponsor is a partnership in which the general managing partner is Henry Moskowitz, the chairman of the family-owned Argo Corporation, which manages 6,300 apartments in the city, including rentals, co-ops and condominiums. 
 This company's inventory includes 2,300 apartments in rental buildings owned as well as managed by Argo. Almost half of these rentals, 1,020 apartments, are in 14 Manhattan buildings, 10 on the Upper West Side.
Under the conversion plan, the per-square-foot asking price for tenants to buy their units, as is, will be $170, but the bargaining that typically goes on between renters and sponsors has not yet started. For outsiders, the asking price will be $360.
At those prices, a 1,576-square-foot two-bedroom would cost current residents $259,000; those living elsewhere would pay $575,500. The projected monthly charges, including real estate taxes, range from $308 to $1,730.
Mark Fessel and his wife, Sherry, seven-year tenants of the building, are taking a wait-and-see attitude.
"If the price is right for us and our neighbors, and the matters relating to the building are addressed, we would consider purchasing our apartment," Mr. Fessel said.
If the Attorney General's office decides the conversion plan complies with all applicable laws and regulations, sales of the units could begin by summer. The apartments, from studios to five-bedroom units, are from 309 to 2,594 square feet.
The sponsor would have 15 months after state acceptance of the plan to sell at least 15 percent of the units for the conversion to be approved. Tenants who did not buy could stay in their apartments and remain under rent regulations.
In recent years, such conversions have become increasingly rare in Manhattan. There were 278 building conversions at the peak in 1986. Last year, five condominium and co-operative conversion plans were submitted to the state, according to the Attorney General's office.
Most conversions in recent years have been buildings that had been built as condominiums, but, after failing to sell in the lackluster market early this decade, were operated as rentals and are now being offered for sale again.
Real estate professionals say the planned conversion of 650 West End Avenue shows that the trickle of conversions will continue, given the robust market for co-ops and condominiums in the city. But it does not signal a trend, they said, pointing to contradicting market forces.
"Even in today's up real estate cycle I just don't see a strong rush to convert," said Richard Siegler, a partner at Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, a law firm that specializes in real estate.
Mr. Siegler cited the prospect that rent regulations might be substantially weakened, particularly on luxury apartments. That possibility encourages landlords to hold on to rental units, since rents might increase.
But the uncertainty surrounding rent regulations has also made co-ops and condominiums more attractive, as some renters decide to buy. That encourages building owners to convert their properties to sell them.
"Conversions are not dead, but they depend on the specific finances of the deal," said Adam R. Rose, executive vice president of Rose Associates Inc., which is controlled by one of the city's large real estate families. "Owners have choices."
Last summer, a partnership led by Rose had its condominium conversion plan approved for the Allegro, a 121-unit tower at 62 West 62d Street, built as a condominium, that opened as a rental in 1989 when the market was sputtering. Mr. Rose said 93 units have been or are under contract to be sold, 44 to tenants.
Mark Moskowitz, Henry Moskowitz's son and the president of Argo, said he has not "contemplated long-term plans to convert other buildings," but said he would "consider the situation in particular buildings on a case-by case basis."
Argo converted 14 properties to 2,048 cooperative units from the 1970's through 1990, but 650 West End Avenue would be the company's first condominium conversion.
"Condos are more marketable," said Karen A. Berman, vice president and director of sales at Argo. Whether the rent regulation laws change or not, "this building makes more economic sense as a condo," she said, and would generate more profits. Rents for the units, most with two bedrooms, are $1,000 to $2,000 a month, but six lease for more than $2,000.
There is a demand for and a limited supply of two- and three-bedroom prewar condos on the Upper West Side, she said, adding, "The hope is that many tenants will buy."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Moves Higher, but 2-Year Treasury Is Lower

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities outperforming the short end of the market, where the Fed would have the most impact should it increase rates to slow economic growth.
The yield on the Treasury's benchmark 30-year issue briefly moved above the 7 percent level that analysts consider psychologically important early in the session after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, testified before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. He again touched on the possibility of a pre-emptive policy move to keep inflation low. Analysts said the tone and content of his testimony were no different than his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony a fews weeks ago, but the markets are becoming believers. 
 The price of the 30-year bond gained 12/32, to 95 29/32, sending its yield down to 6.95 percent, from 6.98 percent on Wednesday. On the short end of the market the two-year was down 2/32, to a price of 99 11/32 to yield 6.24 percent.
Dave Shabelman, a market analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, said, "The F.O.M.C. will weigh the benefits of an appropriate policy action against the costs of being wrong." He added that it looked as though Mr. Greenspan had become more concerned about inflation and the risk of not tightening at this point.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research for Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said he, too, had reluctantly joined those who expect a 25-basis- point, or quarter of a percentage point, rise in the Federal funds rate to 5.50 percent on Tuesday when the F.O.M.C. meets, "although we certainly concur with those who argue that such an increase is not really warranted at this time."
"But given Mr. Greenspan's desire to avoid another stock market debacle like the one which ushered him into his job in 1987," he continued, "we believe he will successfully generate enough political-economic cover to persuade his F.O.M.C. colleagues that a 25-basis-point hike is in everyone's best interest." Furthermore, he said, Mr. Greenspan's "credibility will suffer immeasurably this time, if we get yet another no-action verdict, in which case the market's reaction would certainly cause substantially more damage to the long end."
Assuming the quarter-point increase, Mr. Delaney foresees Treasury yields something like this: a one-year maturity around 6 percent; two-year, 6.35 to 6.40 percent; three-year, between 6.50 and 6.55 percent; five-year, 6.70 to 6.75 percent; 10-year, between 6.85 and 6.90 percent, and the 30-year bond between 7.05 percent and 7.10 percent.
"The tendency may be for the yield curve to attempt further flattening, that is, the yield spread between a two- and 30-year maturity," Mr. Delaney said, "but we believe that the formidable historical resistance at between 68-70 basis points will hold without serious indications of additional Fed tightening down the road." He further suggested that those who bought on that premise would be unprofitably premature.
Mr. Shabelman of MMS International called yesterday's rebound in the longer maturities on no fresh news impressive. "After busting through 7 percent on the long bond yield, many traders felt that level would now represent resistance and were eager to set up short positions," he said. "Those shorts had to cover when the bond market rebounded and stayed below 7 percent. There also was a feeling among traders that all of the bad news was priced in."
Also weighing on bond prices yesterday was the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's monthly manufacturing index, which climbed to 21.1 this month from 17.4 in February. Economists had predicted that the index would register 15.6 this month.
And while the supply of new Treasury issues is not yet a factor, it is likely to be next week when the Treasury plans to sell $29.7 billion of new two-year and five-year notes, as well as the $23 billion of new three-month and six-month bills at the regular weekly auction.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.28 percent, up four basis points from Wednesday, while the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.60 percent, up three basis points.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Banc One uses promotional tie-ins to a movie about Selena to reach out to the Hispanic market.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A BANKING powerhouse is proclaiming "Hooray for Hollywood" with a Spanish accent.
The Banc One Corporation, the country's 10th-largest bank, has become the financial services sponsor of "Selena," a biographical film about Selena Quintanilla Perez, the South Texan singer who died in March 1995. Banc One is spending more than $1 million on a series of extensive marketing tie-ins with the movie, which is being released nationally today by the Warner Brothers unit of Time Warner Inc. 
 The bank's efforts to link with "Selena" are its first in the realm of entertainment marketing. They include the placement of Banc One logos in scenes featuring the actress Jennifer Lopez, who portrays Selena; kiosks in bank branches promoting a sweepstakes giving away tickets to screenings of the film; screening parties in local markets with high concentrations of Spanish-speaking consumers, and donations to the Selena Foundation.
There are even plans for Banc One check cards and imprinted checks to bear the image of the singer, who specialized in a style known as Tejano that mixes elements of country, polka and pop music with tunes popular in Colombia and Mexico.
"We think of ourselves as being in the retailing business, with our products being financial services," said Kenneth T. Stevens, chairman and chief executive of the Banc One Retail Group in Columbus, Ohio, a former executive of Taco Bell and General Mills who is responsible for Banc One businesses like consumer banking and loans.
"Like any good marketer, we want to generate interest in what we have," he added. "And the story of Selena's life has universal appeal."
At first glance, it seems incongruous for a financial institution to latch onto a singer whose success came in a niche segment of the music industry and whose life ended at the age of 23 when she was shot to death by a disgruntled fan. But because of the increasing appeal of sales pitches pegged to the glitz and glamour of the movies -- and of addressing fast-growing ethnic markets like the Hispanic one -- popular culture is spurring the Ohioans of Banc One to look South and West.
"People think of banks as staid and traditional and as interesting as watching paint dry," said Victor Ornelas, president and chief executive at Ornelas & Associates in Dallas, which handles Banc One's advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. "So banks are saying, 'Hey, we've got to shake it up a little bit.' "
"Banc One is all about building their brand," he added, "and they're a trailblazer in marketing to the Latino community. So when this came up, they jumped all over it."
Nanci McMenamy, relationship manager at the John Ryan Company in Minneapolis, a retail marketing agency responsible for aspects of the "Selena" campaign that include the kiosks and sweepstakes, said: "Banc One is showing its empathy, reaching out by saying, 'We understand that Selena is an icon in the community and important to Hispanic culture.' "
Selena is joining the ranks of dead celebrities like James Dean, Elvis Presley, Marilyn Monroe and Babe Ruth as the focus of advertising and promotional campaigns. Like them, she has also become the subject of a book -- "Selena's Secret: The Revealing Story Behind Her Tragic Death" (Simon & Schuster) -- that paints a portrait at odds with the flattering, reverential tales told by their families and films.
"That is a risk you always run when you affiliate with a personality," Mr. Stevens said. "You just have to live with it."
As for the violent end to Selena's life, echoing the finale of "La Bamba" -- a decade-old biopic about another Hispanic singer, Ritchie Valens -- Mr. Stevens said: "We all know what the story is. Obviously, she dies. But it's really a celebration of her life."
Mr. Ornelas agreed.
"Selena means so much to us," he said, "because she's a great symbol of someone who has a dream and is not going to be stopped by barriers like her youth and ethnicity."
Indeed, the Warner Brothers campaign for "Selena" is imbued with upbeat, uplifting language meant to capitalize on a belief that Selena was, as Yxta Maya Murray writes in the April issue of Buzz magazine, "the Great Brown Hope" who was "poised to grab the brass ring of crossover success."
Print ads, for instance, call the film "the story of a girl who had the spirit to believe in a dream and the courage to make it come true." In other words, the goal is to glorify her life, though her greatest fame came after her death.
Banc One, which developed its tie-ins through the efforts of Judy Chapa, its director for Hispanic marketing, is one of several mainstream marketers involved with "Selena." The American Honda Motor Company and the J. C. Penney Company sponsored 13 benefit screenings in cities including Chicago; Corpus Christi, Tex., Selena's hometown; Dallas; Los Angeles, and San Antonio. Latina, a magazine for Hispanic women owned by Latina Publications L.L.C. -- a joint venture of Alegre Enterprises Inc. and Essence Communications Inc. -- also sponsored those screenings.

HEADLINE: A Summit That Blurs Strength and Weakness

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, March 20

 BODY:
The 66-year-old Russian President strode down the gangway of his shiny new $50 million Ilyushin 96-300 presidential jet with the relish of a man back from the dead.
The 50-year-old American President, in a wheelchair after a brush with his own vulnerability, was lowered from Air Force One on a food catering truck. 
 Milking the irony, the Deputy Speaker of the Russian Parliament, Aleksandr Shokhin, coyly suggested that in return for America's generosity in sending heart surgeons to help President Boris N. Yeltsin during his operation, "we would be happy to lend him the services of the Kremlin doctor, Sergei Mironov."
All summit meetings begin with tactical feints and psychological game-playing. But once the doors to the meeting room close, the real state of mind of each leader inevitably rears up to color the negotiations.
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, alluded to President Clinton's psychic burden when he told reporters today that Mr. Clinton was "adjusting to the reality of holding a summit in a wheelchair."
Out of the hospital and on his first foreign trip since he underwent quintuple bypass surgery, Mr. Yeltsin has presented himself as a man reborn and ready to take bold, new risks.
What that new confidence means for the future of NATO expansion depends on the eye of the beholder. Americans hope it is a signal that Mr. Yeltsin will have the political courage to accept the inevitability of NATO expansion and agree to move the process forward. Russians read it as a sign that their President may be prepared to hang tough and defy the West.
Mr. Yeltsin has blurred his true feelings, talking belligerently at home for a purely domestic audience, and sounding statesmanlike as he addressed a Western audience from the airport tarmac today in Helsinki.
He told awaiting journalists, "I do not want to lose the partnership we have built up over the past few years." He left it to "Bill Clinton and his team" to find a suitable "compromise."
Public statements, moreover, are clouded by a fierce war of nerves and public relations as the two sides maneuver before the talks begin in earnest on Friday.
While American officials in Washington and Helsinki have quietly laid out the set of inducements and compromises they believe should allow Mr. Yeltsin to agree to in order to move the process forward, Russian officials have been hotly voicing their outrage over the threat to Russian security and European security that they say NATO expansion will inevitably bring.
American officials say they trust that much of the heated language is a bluff, a tactic to force the Americans into greater flexibility, and a few Russian officials privately agree.
"We have to holler first," a Foreign Ministry official said, "then we'll take what we can." But there are also signs that many Russian officials -- and perhaps even Mr. Yeltsin -- are beginning to persuade themselves with their own rhetoric.
"The ordinary Russian public doesn't understand or care about NATO," said Boris A. Beresovsky, a tycoon who is now deputy chairman of the National Security Council and part of the Kremlin lobbying team that followed Mr. Yeltsin to Helsinki.
"But public opinion in Russia flows from the top down. There has been an amazing consolidation of the political elite -- reformers, Communists, bureaucrats, businessmen, everybody -- that this is wrong and that our national security interests cannot be bought at any price."
There are advisers to Mr. Yeltsin who fear that his recent decision to appoint a new Cabinet filled with young reform-minded economists looks too much like a concession to the West. Preoccupied with the domestic agenda, they openly hope he can combat that image by confounding American expectations and refusing to compromise.
"Of course he can work for the best deal he can get and try to present that back home as a victory," a top adviser said. "But it would be a lot easier to say no and tell the Russian people he refused to give in to the Americans."
Psychology -- or at least Russian insecurity -- is a card that Mr. Clinton hopes he can turn in his favor. American officials in Helsinki say that if Mr. Clinton can offer enough inducements on arms control and bilateral aid to appease some of Mr. Yeltsin's security and economic concerns, the pomp and ceremony of the summit meeting itself could pump up the Russian President's image enough to ease his anxieties about his standing back home.
"He likes being seen by the world on an equal par with Bill Clinton," said an American official who helped prepare the trip. "He wants to show his people that he is taken seriously as a world leader."
But Russian advisers say Russians have tired of the "Bill and Boris" show and are expecting him to stand up to the American President, not renew their friendship.
Before he left Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin gave a trial display of toughness by telling Russian newspaper editors that Mr. Clinton had called him up and offered him $4 billion in bilateral aid, and that he had sharply turned it down as a "bribe." His version of the conversation went over very well.
At the Russian press center, located by the docks of the Gulf of Finland and far from the American and Finnish press centers, the Russian delegation has been holding a series of news conferences that are actually seminars on Russian opposition to NATO expansion.
A discussion of freedom of the press on Wednesday that featured prominent Russian newspaper editors and a television executive turned into a full-throttle assault on the perils of isolating Russia.
Otto Latsis, editor of the daily Izvestia, noted the irony of talking about the independence of Russian journalists "when we are here at the request and expense of the Kremlin." But he too argued against NATO expansion.
The Americans have taken the Russian propaganda blitz in stride, hopeful that it will at least help Mr. Yeltsin appease his domestic opposition.
But in the war of imagery, the Americans were not prepared to roll over completely.
When the two Presidents sat for photographers in the presidential palace before dinner, the American advance team insisted that they both be seated in chairs, to minimize Mr. Clinton's injury. They ushered photographers out before they could film him being lifted by three aides out of his armchair and into his wheelchair.
On the substantive issues, the United States, which can proceed with NATO expansion without Russia's assent, is dealing from a position of strength.
Russia, weak, isolated and ornery, is seeking whatever psychological advantage it can find.
Advance teams were able to agree on many fine points of protocol -- from placement of chairs to flower arrangements -- but as the summit meeting began today, they remained blocked over a seemingly minor point: who, in the final news conference, would speak first.
The Americans argued that since Mr. Clinton is technically the host of the summit meeting -- the site was moved from the United States to Finland last January to accommodate Mr. Yeltsin's poor health -- protocol required Mr. Clinton to begin.
The Russians vehemently disagreed, insisting that Mr. Yeltsin, who has been in office longer, should take precedence.
Unable to resolve it, the advance teams left that detail to Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton to work out themselves.

HEADLINE: With Aid, Staten Island to Get a Banana Warehouse

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
To prevent the area's last banana importer from leaving, the New York City Economic Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey each promised yesterday to contribute $2 million to help build a new warehouse on Staten Island for the company that distributes Bonita bananas.
That $4 million, coupled with an earlier $1 million pledge from Staten Island Borough President Guy V. Molinari's office, will allow the importer, Ecuadorian Line, to move from its outmoded warehouse in Port Newark to a new building with temperature and humidity controls in Howland Hook -- and not to Gloucester, N.J., near Camden, as it had threatened to do a few months ago. The company had said that moving would be cheaper than renovating its existing warehouse. 
 "I'm very happy with the results of the two board meetings," said Chuck Schwarz, vice president for operations of Ecuadorian Line, which is based in Miami. "We will be staying in New York."
A decade ago, the Dole, Chiquita and Turbana companies shipped their goods into New York Harbor. But they later moved their operations, citing rising costs.
By November, when the Bonita warehouse is to be completed, at least 150 jobs are expected to move to Staten Island. The 64,000-square-foot building will hold bananas, mangoes and other fruit.
"We create jobs in New York City and we continue the Mayor's effort to revitalize the waterfront," Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation, said. He added, "Yes, we will have bananas."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

First Bank Agrees to Buy
U.S. Bancorp for $9 Billion
First Bank of Minneapolis agreed to buy U.S Bancorp of Portland, Ore., for $9 billion in stock, in a deal that will create the nation's 14th-largest banking company, with $70 billion in assets. 
 First Bank, which will assume the U.S. Bancorp name, is paying a significant premium for the company, though it said it expected the deal to quickly lift its earnings. But 4,000 employees are expected to lose their jobs because of cost cuts. [Page D2.]
 
Liggett to Settle Tobacco Cases
In a first for the tobacco industry, Liggett Group, the maker of Chesterfield cigarettes, acknowledged that smoking is addictive and causes cancer, and disclosed that tobacco companies have for decades consciously marketed their products to children as young as 14. Liggett agreed to settle lawsuits filed by 22 states accusing the industry of hiding its knowledge of the adverse health effects of tobacco and seeking compensation for health care costs tied to smoking. [A1.]
 
U.S. Trade Deficit Soars
America's trade deficit soared to $12.7 billion in January, the largest since a new method of measuring international trade was adopted in 1992. The deficit with China rose 36 percent, complicating the politics of Vice President Al Gore's trip to Beijing next week. [A1.]
 
The dollar overcame early weakness caused by the release of the trade report, surging against the German mark and the Japanese yen after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly hinted that the central bank would raise interest rates at its meeting next week. [D8.]
 
Nynex-Bell Atlantic Deal Advances
New York State regulators approved the $22 billion merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic, clearing a significant hurdle for the deal. But as a condition, Nynex was ordered to spend $500 million and hire additional employees to improve its customer service. [B1.]
 
Dow Falls 57.40 to 6-Week Low
The Dow industrials fell to their lowest level in six weeks, losing 57.40 points to close at 6,820.28, as traders worried that higher interest rates and a stronger dollar could weaken earnings. But technology stocks rallied, sending the Nasdaq up 9.97, to 1,259.26, its first gain in eight sessions. [D10.]
 
Despite those results, the trend has been for investors to flee small stocks in favor of big ones like those in the Dow, which are perceived as less risky. One measure of the relative value of big stocks compared with the broader market has reached levels not seen since 1973 -- right before the last big bear market.
Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 6.95 percent from 6.98. [D17.]
 
2d Strike by Pilots Seems Unlikely
Pilots at American Airlines have shown an unpredictable streak before. But for reasons that have as much to do with image and perception as with the terms of their tentative agreement with the airline, another strike seems unlikely. News Analysis. [D2.]

Delta to Order Only Boeing Jets
Delta Air Lines said that it would buy only Boeing jets, like the 767, for the next 20 years, ruffling Boeing's rival, Airbus. Delta announced an initial order for 106 aircraft, worth $6.7 billion, and options to buy an additional 124 jets, worth $8.3 billion. [D2.]
A Ruling for Dow Chemical
A judge in Michigan ruled that Dow Chemical, which owns half of Dow Corning, a maker of breast implants, was not liable for medical problems that hundreds of women in the state said arose from the devices. [D2.]
 
Faster Plan for High-Definition TV
Some 43 percent of the nation's households would be able to receive digital, high-definition TV in the next 18 to 24 months under a more aggressive timetable that leaders of the broadcast industry gave regulators. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Democrats Propose Spending On Police Instead of Jail Cells

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20

 BODY:
Rebuffing Gov. George E. Pataki's prison construction proposals, the Assembly's Democratic leaders today proposed making large investments instead in hiring new police officers, expanding drug treatment programs and providing shelter for domestic violence victims.
Taking a cue from New York City's hugely popular -- and, by most accounts, successful -- police force expansion of recent years, the Democrats proposed a 2,500-officer increase in the size of local police departments outside the city, with three-quarters of the cost to be paid by the state. 
 They also called for 6,000 new residential drug treatment slots, a 46 percent increase, and new shelter space for 1,100 victims of domestic violence, a 69 percent increase.
Over all, the Democrats' program would spend $650 million a year when fully in effect, in five years.
"I'd much rather deal with prevention than lock someone up after they've committed a crime," said Assemblywoman Helene E. Weinstein, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairwoman of the Judiciary Committee.
The Governor has proposed building prison space for 7,000 inmates, at a cost of $635 million, to relieve overcrowding in a prison system that has nearly 70,000 inmates. The Democrats proposed building 400 new cells and contracting with counties to use up to 1,000 vacant beds in their jails to house state inmates.
"The Assembly's failure to support Governor Pataki's initiatives would be a major step backward," said Patrick McCarthy, a spokesman for the Governor. But he added that "there are positive aspects to the Assembly's plan."
Today's proposal may just be the Assembly Democrats' opening gambit in a long bout of wrangling with Mr. Pataki and the Republican leaders of the Senate. Many Republican senators represent small upstate towns where prisons are the foundations of the local economies and might be willing to horse-trade for new construction.
Some Democratic lawmakers would like to see mandatory sentences for drug offenders eased, but will not propose it for fear of being tarred as soft on crime. Mr. Pataki himself has talked about relaxing those laws.
"The fact is that 61 percent of our prison population today is nonviolent," Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, said today. "The question is, with the crime rate dropping, do we have to go out and spend a lot of money to build more prisons?"
The Correctional Association of New York, a private group that studies prison issues, lauded the plan, but said it did not go far enough. "Six thousand drug treatment beds is good," said Robert Gangi, executive director of the group, "but there are 860,000 drug addicts."

HEADLINE: Zaire Rebels Try to Find Way to People's Hearts

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: KISANGANI, Zaire, March 20

 BODY:
The meeting hall was packed with civil servants and small-time politicians, the leftovers from President Mobutu Sese Seko's Government. On a dais above sat three civilian officials from the rebel alliance that captured this city last weekend. The heat was unbearable as a local lawyer got up and gave voice to what was on many minds.
"I'm afraid of what happened in 1960 after we got independence," he said. "We were promised democracy, but we got dictatorship. Is it going to be the same thing now?" 
 The rebels' political affairs minister, Deogratias Bugera, listened intently.
"President Mobutu didn't ask the people to vote for their leaders," he said. "We are. A few days ago there was a curfew in this town. Now you can go wherever you like without problems. Government soldiers used to rob everyone. Our soldiers go shopping and pay their own way. Now we are giving you the power to elect your representatives."
A murmur of approval coursed through the crowd.
Having won the battle last weekend for this strategic city on the Congo River, the rebels set about today to win the hearts and minds of the people here, holding meetings with political officials and promising elections at once to choose a local government.
With the Zairian Army retreating and looting on every front, it is looking more and more as if the success of the rebellion depends less on military strength than on the ability of its civilian ministers to capitalize on their political gains, reform the civil service, weed out corruption and jump-start the nation's moribund economy.
That effort started here today in a sweaty meeting hall with the kind of grass-roots, town-hall-style politicking any mayor or governor in the United States would recognize. Three ministers from the inchoate rebel government, which has headquarters in the city of Goma, spent two hours fielding sharp questions from the civil servants, many of whom have not seen a paycheck in years.
The questions came fast and furious. When would the rebels start paying civil servants? What would be done about higher education with the country split in half? How would the local elections for the provisional government be held? Would former Mobutu supporters be allowed to stand as candidates? How could they hold elections with so many illiterate voters? When would a legislature be formed?
While alliance officials insist that the elections will be free, it is not clear precisely how delegates will be chosen. In at least one other town where the rebels have assumed control, members of Mr. Mobutu's ruling party were excluded from the elections.
At the meeting, one professional bureaucrat said he was afraid open elections would bring uneducated and unqualified people to power.
"The people who are elected should be the people who understand administration," he said. "I'm afraid to see someone who hasn't studied to be an administrator being elected."
The finance minister, Mwana Nanga Mawampanga, pounced on the question with the skill of an American spin-doctor.
"To have a university degree does not guarantee you are qualified to be elected as a representative," he said. "The former governor of this province was a professor of the university, but you know what he did." The crowd burst into long applause.
Besides holding meetings with bureaucrats, the civilian arm of the rebels, who are known as the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo, flew in 117 young converts to their cause today to begin spreading their message of the rebellion among the citizens in the city's six boroughs.
These civilian supporters of the rebel government have all attended a series of seminars indoctrinating them in the new philosophy of Laurent Kabila, the 63-year-old former Marxist and longtime Mobutu foe who is leading the rebellion.
Mr. Kabila has changed his tune since the Lumumbist rebellion of the 1960's, when he styled himself a leftist on the Maoist or Che Guevara model. The ideology of the alliance now reads more like an American civics course: free and fair elections, basic civil rights, freedom of speech, a free press, lower taxes, clean government and a military under civilian control.
To prove they are serious about democracy, rebel officials are planning to hold elections of a sort this weekend to chose a governor and a mayor. The plan is to have local political and community leaders choose delegates from their neighborhoods, as well as candidates for borough leader, mayor and governor, who will serve in a provisional government that would hold office until after the war is finished. A randomly chosen group of delegates will then vote on the candidates.
"It's not perfect," Mr. Mawampanga said. "But it's the best we can do with the time and money we have."
Moving quickly to install a local civilian government appears to be a strategy to avoid appearing like a conquering army rather than liberators. The rebel soldiers are widely perceived here as being outsiders. The core of the force are Tutsi men of Rwandan ancestry from the eastern edge of the country. Some of the other front-line units are made up mostly of soldiers from tribes in the Kasai and Shaba provinces, which have always been hotbeds of anti-Mobutu sentiment, but are a long way from Kisangani in the province of Haut Zaire. On the streets of Kisangani, people point out that the Government army has been dominated by people from Mr. Mobutu's tribe, as well as by foreigners, and was so undisciplined and underpaid that soldiers spent most of their time robbing citizens. Most people here say they are willing to give rebel soldiers from other regions the benefit of the doubt.
"That's not a problem," said Musa Kombo, a 34-year-old unemployed graduate student. "They are liberators. It doesn't matter if they are Tutsi, people of Rwandan ancestry or Ugandan background. They came to liberate us and we will treat them as friends."
But many people also say that no government would gain popular support in Kisangani without local ethnic groups being heavily represented. Of course, this is an axiom of politics everywhere.
"We are not going to accept the Tutsi because the Tutsi are not local Zairians," Bernard Afata Botikotiko, a evangelical pastor, said. "When Kabila comes, we will see. It must be a native of Haut Zaire who becomes the governor. It must be a native who becomes the head of each zone."
There are more than 200 ethnic groups in Zaire, with the largest in Kisangani being the Lokele.
The issues driving many to support the rebellion are closer to the pocketbook and hearth. These potential voters say any government that brings peace and prosperity would be welcome, whatever its ethnic balance.
Alliance officials are trying to build on that sentiment, arguing that an expanding economy and a responsible government will erase much of the tribalism that has infected this country's politics for the last 32 years of Mr. Mobutu's stewardship.
"Tribalism was used by Mobutu to consolidate his power by dividing people," the finance minister said. "What we need to do is develop this country. Then there won't be any Nande, or Hunde, or Tutsi. People will just look for economic opportunity."
Perhaps to avoid the accusation of being a Tutsi-dominated rebellion, Mr. Kabila has chosen a ethnically diverse group of civilian ministers. Mr. Kabila is a Luba from Kasai, not a Tutsi, and of the seven top civilian officials in the alliance, only Mr. Bugera comes from a Tutsi background.
But for many of the political professionals in Kisangani, the proof will be in the government Mr. Kabila assembles. For years, they lived with the hegemony of Mr. Mobutu's Ngandi tribe from the north. Now, some wonder if they will face a government dominated by Tutsi from the east.
"Right now, people are just observing Mr. Kabila," said Momoty Lemand'Azuato, a news writer for the state-run television network. "We are watching carefully to see what will happen. We don't want to trade St. Paul for St. Peter. What we really want is real change. We lived a long time with a dictatorial system."

Map of Zaire showing the location of Kinshasa: The rebel alliance that captured Kisangani is promising elections.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Home-Grown Pension Alternative to Social Security

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: OXFORD, Ohio

 BODY:
For 28 years Bill McKinstry taught economics at Miami University here, including a course on Social Security in which he warned that the system faced an inevitable crisis.
Now retired, Professor McKinstry considers himself fortunate that most of his pension money comes from the Ohio Teachers' Retirement System, one of the few pension plans in the country that operate apart from Social Security. 
 You don't have to go as far away as Chile to find alternatives to Social Security. Nearly two million state and local government employees are exempt from paying Social Security taxes. Along with several hundred thousand retirees, they are eligible for benefits that -- while more costly -- almost always provide a better deal than the Federal system.
"There is a general conception that everyone in the United States pays Social Security taxes," said Richard Thau, executive director of Third Millennium, a nonprofit advocacy organization for people under 35 that is about to release a study extolling plans that exempt employees from Social Security. "But several million people have managed to escape the Social Security tax. They are all government employees and we think their experience is an interesting model for considering alternatives to Social Security."
The Advisory Council on Social Security, which issued three separate proposals early this year to overcome the retirement system's financing problems, agreed on at least one thing: All 1.9 million workers currently in exempt plans should be brought into Social Security, providing a shot-in-the-arm to Social Security revenues.
But Mr. Thau disagrees. "Folding these plans into Social Security," he said, "is akin to chopping down a rain forest without determining first the prospects that within the forest is the cure for cancer."
The study, which looked at seven plans outside Social Security covering 1.3 million government employees, was conducted by William Even, an economist at Miami University, and David A. MacPherson, an economist at Florida State University. It concluded that the vast majority of people now paying Social Security taxes would receive less in retirement benefits than they and their employer paid, while those outside it could expect to earn annual returns, after inflation, of 1.6 to 3 percent.
Only one-income couples who make less than $40,000 will receive more from Social Security than was paid in, the study says.
But supporters of Social Security, which is tilted to help low-wage workers more than those with higher incomes, say that is exactly why it is so important to preserve the system.
Karen C. Burke, a legal scholar at the University of Minnesota, said that redistributing income "is an explicit and important goal" of Social Security, while in contrast, private pension plans "are distinctly skewed in favor of high earners."
Professor Even agreed that providing a more generous payoff to lower-wage workers made sense, but complained that Social Security's rules, largely written when the vast majority of wage earners were men, created all kinds of anomalies. "Two-earner couples subsidize one-earner couples with the same income," he said. "Now what sense is there in that?"
Even for those with modest earnings, the government pensions are often a better deal. The study looked at what would happen to people who start their careers at age 25, retire at 62, and enjoy real wage gains averaging 1 percent a year better than the inflation rate. A worker who retired with an income of $20,000 would get $7,468 from Social Security, but the average benefit from the seven alternative systems would be $18,951, or 2.5 times as much.
But they are even better for more affluent workers. Those earning $100,000 under an exempt system would retire with 7.5 times more than Social Security alone would pay.
The most significant difference is in how the systems are funded. Social Security is primarily a pay-as-you-go system, in which today's workers pay the benefits for today's retirees. Only a small portion of Social Security revenues are invested -- in Treasury bonds; the plans rely largely on money set aside by the workers earlier in their careers.
The state and local government pension systems then invest a large portion of that money in the stock market.
Still, the local alternatives, since they are intended to serve as a full pension, cost more. Compared with the combined 10.5 percent of wages, up to $64,500 this year, that are designated for retirement benefits under Social Security, the plans range from 18.6 percent of payroll for one covering Colorado state workers, to 24 percent for civil servants in Los Angeles. Taxpayers pick up all or most of those costs. Government workers in Los Angeles, for example, paid only 4.7 percent of their paycheck directly.
Mr. McKinstry, the retired professor, likes his pension just fine, but is worried that those citing arrangements like his as a justification for abandoning Social Security are going too far in advocating a system where workers would mostly rely on their own retirement accounts.
"I certainly hope we are not going to turn people loose with their retirement savings," he said, "so they can lose it with some broker who has a hot stock tip."

HEADLINE: How Chile Farms Out Nest Eggs;
Can Its Private Pension Plan Offer Lessons to the U.S.?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
"It's such a difference," bubbled Isabel Margarita Perez Moore, a 45-year-old secretary in Santiago. "I love my pension plan."
So apparently do most Chileans, who have enjoyed spectacular returns on their nest eggs since the country dumped the national pension system in 1981 for a savings plan that makes individuals responsible for financing their own retirement. And so do the Governments of Argentina, Mexico and Peru, which are all following Chile's lead, switching to private -- though heavily regulated -- pension accounts. 
 Indeed, what began as a model for born-again free marketers in stagnant Latin American economies is inspiring policy makers in the high churches of capitalism. Earlier this month, Prime Minister John Major announced plans to privatize Britain's pension system. And here in America, where many younger people doubt that Social Security will provide even a modest pension when they retire unless it is overhauled, a variety of similar proposals have been floated as the answer to low savings rates and high Social Security payroll taxes.
Over the years, "the gains from privatization would be worth $10 trillion to $20 trillion," argues Martin S. Feldstein, an economist at Harvard who was the chairman of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers.
For all its apparent success in Chile, though, the question remains whether what works for a poor but rapidly developing economy would work in America and Europe -- which cannot hope to pay for the retirement of aging populations with the dividends from growth.
Advocates of privatization in rich countries do not see it as a miracle cure. But, like Mr. Feldstein, they do say it is a way to spur growth and a means of distancing the national pension system from the rough and tumble of entitlement politics.
For their part, skeptics focus on the drawbacks to privatization -- the relatively high costs of operation and its potential for unraveling support for a social safety net. They also caution that in the event investment returns go south in a privatized system, the government may still be on the hook -- a debacle that could shake an economy unprepared for it.
Given such concerns, the skeptics see no compelling case for leaping into the unknown. "Chile couldn't fix the system they had," argues Peter Diamond, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Ours ain't broke."
Chile's pension reform was driven by a mix of ideology and necessity. In 1973, after he brought down the elected Socialist Government in a bloody coup, Gen. Augusto Pinochet was left to cope with a moribund economy. He turned to a group of economists later known as the "Chicago boys," American-trained Chileans who shared a commitment to the libertarian ideas of the University of Chicago's Milton Friedman. One of them, Jose Pinera (who earned his Ph.D. at Harvard), pushed tirelessly to change Chile's pay-as-you-go national pensions to a system of privately funded individual retirement accounts.
Mr. Pinera, then minister of labor and social security, was pushing on an open door. The existing hodge-podge of industry-based social insurance plans was unpopular, in no small part because it exacted payroll taxes in excess of 25 percent.
Today, workers deposit 13 percent of their wages in the retirement accounts. The accounts, which move from job to job with their owners, are managed by some 20 private mutual fund groups, known as Administradora de Fondos Pensiones, or simply A.F.P.'s.
To achieve what Mr. Pinera, who is now associated with the libertarian Cato Institute in Washington, calls "radical reform with a conservative execution," the Government strictly limited the A.F.P.'s discretion to take investment risks. At the end of last month, the A.F.P.'s held 40 percent of their assets in Government-backed debt, 24 percent in interest-bearing bank deposits and 35 percent in Chilean stocks.
Buoyed by high interest rates and phenomenal gains on Chilean stocks, the A.F.P.'s have delivered a stunning 13 percent average annual return after inflation over the last 15 years. Equally important, Mr. Pinera argues, the switch to "defined contribution" accounts has ended the Government's discretion to raise pensions at the expense of future generations of taxpayers. But what intrigues observers most is the way the pension reform has meshed with Chile's goal of moving the economy to the fast growth track.
The economist's prescription for growth these days invariably includes prudent fiscal policies, high savings rates, tax reform and the development of liquid financial markets. Chile's pension makeover, Mr. Pinera argues, helped to accomplish each.
For starters, he notes, privatization made it impossible to paper over Government budget deficits with current cash flow from the pension system. The resulting fiscal austerity (combined with increased confidence that personal savings would not be taxed or inflated away) raised the savings rate from 16 percent in 1980 to an astonishing 28 percent. Mr. Pinera also argues that the substitution of mandatory pension savings for the 25 percent social security tax on wages sharply increased incentives to work.
Last but hardly least, the reform guaranteed a flow of savings to jump-start the small domestic capital market. The assets in A.F.P.'s now exceed $30 billion.
Mr. Diamond suggests that Mr. Pinera confuses cause and effect. The political will to contain Government spending, control inflation, reduce tax distortions and put out a welcome mat for private enterprise made pension privatization work, he suggests -- not the other way round. Mr. Pinera meets him halfway: "Pension privatization was part of a virtuous circle of economic reforms," in which successes built on successes, he argues.
A closer look at the Chilean system does disclose some weaknesses. With regulation effectively forcing the A.F.P.'s to pursue me-too investment policies, competition is driven in wasteful directions. Just as American banks used to give away toasters to attract new accounts, A.F.P.'s employ armies of salesmen and pour on extraneous services. Provida, the largest A.F.P., with some 1.7 million accounts, "never forgets my birthday or Christmas," said Ms. Perez Moore, the secretary from Santiago.
And while the resulting costs are not absurdly high -- about 1 percent -- customers are paying for annual turnover exceeding 30 percent.
More important, there is an inherent tension between the private pension approach and the Government's guarantee of a minimum pension. Since their contributions will not increase the size of their retirement checks, Chileans with low wages have strong incentives to hide income.
Finally, the jury is out on how the Chilean system would fare in hard times. If returns on pension assets fell to disappointing levels, there would surely be pressure on the Government to subsidize pensions from other sources.
Back in the United States, the debate over Social Security continues. Earlier this year, a sharply divided advisory commission recommended that the system needed an injection of funds to restore its balance and a majority favored allowing investments in the stock market. For now, though, little action is expected from lawmakers.
The question preoccupying American pension specialists is what lessons they should draw from the Chilean experience. One of the benefits of Chile's privatization -- the nurturing of nascent capital markets -- obviously does not apply. But as in Chile, private accounts might inhibit politicians from using the cash surpluses of Social Security to balance the budget.
"Might" is the operative word, Mr. Diamond counters. Congress might not dare to use private assets to offset budget deficits. But it might deny Government benefits -- unemployment payments, food stamps, Medicare, Medicaid -- to those with substantial pension accounts.
Another question is the relevance of Chile's relatively painless transition from an underfunded public system to a fully funded private one. The unfunded liability of Chile's system in 1980 was roughly the same percentage of national income as Social Security's unfunded liability in 1997, Mr. Pinera says. But Chile had one giant advantage: the potential to pay off the liability very rapidly since undeveloped economies have the potential to grow so fast.
The biggest issue is whether privatization would distance the national pension system from interest-group politics in Washington, as it has in Chile. On the one hand, Washington would lose the discretion to set benefits. On the other, there is nothing to stop retirees from turning to Congress for help if the return on their savings was disappointing.
"One thing you don't want," cautions Carolyn Weaver, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, is to replace the unfunded Government liabilities of Social Security with ill-defined liabilities to pensioners who, deep-down, believe the Government owes them a comfortable retirement. She sees less political risk in a two-tier approach that layers a private account on top of a modest basic benefit funded from tax revenues.
For his part, Mr. Feldstein estimates that the most likely consequences of privatization -- higher national savings rates and lower payroll taxes -- would ultimately raise national income by 5 percent, or about $350 billion a year.
In the end, suggests Olivia Mitchell of the Wharton School, Social Security privatization fits neatly into the parable of the three blind men and the elephant.
"Each touches a different part of the elephant," she says, "and feels something different."
