Charts: "CHILEAN PENSION FUND SYSTEM"
A "DEFINED CONTRIBUTION" SYSTEM in which mandatory deductions from each worker's salary go into individual, privately managed accounts, with the assets invested in stocks and bonds. At retirement, a Chilean can draw down the savings or use them to purchase an annuity. The Government guarantees a minimum pension to those who fail to accumulate sufficient savings to cover subsistence after retirement.
 
"U.S. SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM"
A PAY-AS-YOU-GO "DEFINED BENEFIT" SYSTEM in which payroll taxes are used to pay pensions of current retirees. While the system is supposed to be self-supporting, there is no relationship between revenues collected from individuals and how much is paid out in benefits. Current revenues far exceed outlays, but the system is expected to go bankrupt by 2030 when it will be paying out huge benefits from the baby boom generation. (pg. D1)

HEADLINE: Interest Rate Rise Hinted By Greenspan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Faced with an economy that by all rights should be generating inflation but is not, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted today that he would raise interest rates next week as a precautionary measure to keep the nation's six-year expansion on track.
Mr. Greenspan was, as always, equivocal about his intentions, and he stressed that the outcome of the central bank's policy-setting meeting on Tuesday remained uncertain. Indeed, with the economy enjoying an almost perfect combination of strong growth, low unemployment and stable prices, the decision is shaping up as one of the most difficult of Mr. Greenspan's nine-and-a-half-year tenure as chairman and a test of his resolve that monetary policy must anticipate inflationary pressures rather than react to them. 
 The Federal Reserve has not changed policy in nearly 14 months, since it reduced the two short-term rates it controls by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent. It last tightened monetary policy more than two years ago, when it pushed the more important of the two rates, the Federal funds rate, for overnight lending between banks, to 6 percent from 5.5 percent.
But economists said Mr. Greenspan's testimony today before Congress's Joint Economic Committee, including statements that growth remained strong and that the Fed was committed to moving pre-emptively to attack inflation, was a clear warning that the period of policy stability was about to come to an end.
Many analysts have predicted that the central bank will nudge rates up by the minimum increment, a quarter of a point, and follow up with another quarter-point increase in the spring or summer just to make sure the specter of inflation remains buried.
"I don't know how Chairman Greenspan could have made it clearer than he has about tightening monetary policy without actually saying he's going to hike interest rates," said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist of the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
Because investors have been anticipating an eventual rate increase by the Fed, Mr. Greenspan's testimony had only a modest effect on stock prices, which were also dragged down by a fall in tobacco company shares. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 57.40 points to close at 6,820.28. Bond prices fell and then rebounded, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond seeing its yield fall to 6.95 percent from 6.98 percent by the end of the day.
In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the economy had displayed "a great deal of vigor" since the beginning of the year, with demand "growing quite strongly in recent months." He termed the current balance among strong growth, low unemployment and stable prices "close to unprecedented." And he stressed the importance for the Fed of "acting promptly -- ideally pre-emptively -- to keep inflation low."
Yet Mr. Greenspan laid out the conundrum facing policy makers, saying the economy's performance "is really quite impressive" but adding that current conditions should not be seen as a basis for monetary policy, only as an indicator of whether inflationary pressures might be starting to build in the form of rising wages that could lead employers to raise prices.
What the Federal Reserve will have to judge, he said, "is not so much the question of where prices are or have been, but rather what is the state of the economy later this year and into 1998 when any actions we may or may not have taken would become effective."
Despite surges of growth and an unemployment rate, currently 5.3 percent, that is well below the level that most economists believe should lead to rising wages and prices, wage increases so far have been muted and inflation has remained dormant.
The Labor Department reported on Wednesday that retail prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February, or just 3 percent over the last 12 months. The Government's report last week on producer prices was even more benign, showing that prices on many levels of the production chain were actually falling last month.
Economists are divided over whether the economy has been changed so fundamentally by forces like corporate downsizing and global competition that strong growth, low inflation and low unemployment can coexist indefinitely, or whether the nation is simply benefiting from a temporary deviation from the long-established pattern of low unemployment leading inevitably to surging prices.
By leaving rates unchanged for more than a year, the Fed has tolerated the coexistence of strong growth and low unemployment since those conditions became pronounced last spring. In doing so, it was effectively engaging in an experiment about the economy's ability to tolerate inflation, though not without some internal dissent from inflation hawks among the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks.
They have argued that the same historical pattern that has marked business cycles in the past would ultimately assert itself, with employers being forced to raise wages and push through price increases to offset their increased costs.
If Mr. Greenspan comes down in their camp next week and leads the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee into a rate increase, he is likely to face a barrage of criticism for risking the continuation of the expansion to fight the theoretical possibility of inflation. But analysts said that Mr. Greenspan's experience in doubling rates to 6 percent from 3 percent over a year starting in February 1994 had given him confidence that he could move pre-emptively against inflation without sending the economy into recession.
Although the economy slowed markedly following those rate increases, it continued to expand throughout 1994 and 1995, and inflation never took root.
Having said repeatedly in recent months that stock prices might be overvalued, Mr. Greenspan seemed to acknowledge today that the markets might fall if the Fed tightened monetary policy, even if the investment climate ultimately benefited from an eradication of inflation.
"Should we choose to alter monetary policy, we know from past experience that although the financial markets may respond immediately, the main effects on inflationary pressures may not be felt until late this year and into 1998," he said.
But analysts said that today's relatively muted reaction in the stock market suggested that investors had already factored in the likelihood of a quarter-point rate increase next week.

HEADLINE: Executives Praise Lilco Deal As Likely to Save L.I. Jobs

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 20

 BODY:
Charles A. Gargano started reeling off a list of companies forced off Long Island by high electric bills.
"MSC Industrial of Hauppauge: they had 200 jobs and moved to Pennsylvania," said Mr. Gargano, Gov. George E. Pataki's chief economic development official. "Pass & Seymour, they had 300 jobs and made electrical outlets. They left Glen Cove and went to the Carolinas. Quoizel, 150 jobs, moved from Islip to Georgia. These are concrete examples." 
 Critics say the Long Island Lighting Company's rates -- the highest in the continental United States -- have cost the region thousands of jobs in recent years. But Mr. Gargano says he hopes that will stop, once regulatory agencies approve the Governor's plan to cut rates up to 23 percent in a $7 billion partial state takeover of Lilco. State officials began promoting the plan to business executives at a briefing this morning, and the cuts were welcomed by many.
"It's good news," said Scot Zimand, vice president of the Plascal Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., which makes vinyl sheeting. He said he wished the cuts were even bigger and said full energy competition was the ultimate answer.
His company, which stands to save thousands of dollars a month under the plan, has considered moving. "That thought has gone around many times," he said.
Mr. Gargano said he was proud of another list: companies that were induced to stay, like Nature's Bounty of Islip, L.I., which had been tempted to expand to Atlanta with 300 jobs. But those success stories involved a variety of incentives, including discounted electrical power through economic development agencies.
One example is Symbol Technologies, a manufacturer of bar code data collection systems that employs 1,700 people in Holtsville, L.I. Tax breaks and other incentives kept Symbol from moving in 1992. Now the prospect of lower electric rates is keeping the company in place again.
"There was a high degree of potential for us to leave," said a company vice president, Brian T. Burke. "Not only will we remain, but hopefully we will expand over time as well. We are a significant user of electricity. Consequently, we see this as a tremendous opportunity for cost savings," at an estimated $300,000 a year.
Retailers may be the most immediate beneficiaries. "Any time you have a rate reduction, you are making available additional money that will be spent in the region," said Thomas Conoscenti, an economist from Nesconset, L.I.
Louis W. Fortunoff, executive vice president of Fortunoff, the family's jewelry and department-store chain, which is building a major new mall in Westbury, L.I., near the Roosevelt Field shopping center, said lower rates would reduce his company's costs. "But the much greater impact would be the effect on the economic climate on Long Island," he said. "Every consumer would have more disposable income. That's what we're looking at."
Lower electric bills could also help businesses recruit workers. At Servo Corporation of America in Westbury, which makes infrared detectors, the president, Stephen A. Barre, said: "We need to be able to attract engineers from off the Island, and anything we can do to reduce the cost of living is helpful to us."
Lilco's bills have been a hurdle to enticing new companies to Long Island. "For all of them, almost the first thing out of their mouth is, 'How are we going to be assisted in energy costs?' " said Suffolk County's Commissioner of Economic Development, Thomas J. Junor. "It's right up there in the top three, with taxes and the cost of building space. This rate reduction puts it further down the list."
William S. Bruno, Nassau County's deputy commissioner for commerce and industry, said, "If rates go down, it will definitely be an attraction to companies to come here."
He said he was especially interested in companies with heavy computer use. "Those data centers operate 24 hours a day," he said, "and they eat a lot of juice."
Even with the proposed reduction, the Island's electric rates would still be among the nation's highest. Matthew T. Crosson, president of the leading local business group, the Long Island Association, cautioned that the Island could not match regions with low-cost energy.
"The plan would shrink the gap, and that is good, but it won't eliminate it," Mr. Crosson said. "It's still not competitive with Tennessee or Florida and places like that. It may, however, make a marginal difference in a company's decision to stay or leave." The association has not taken a stand on the proposal.
One favorable forecast of the rate reduction's effect came in a 1995 study by Mr. Conoscenti, the economist, premised on a 20 percent cut. He projected 10,000 new jobs and $218 million more in annual wages.
Mr. Gargano, who is New York State's Commissioner of Economic Development, said he viewed the rate cut as part of the Pataki administration's pro-business policies of reducing taxes, workers' compensation insurance rates and regulations.
"Any time you can lower the cost of doing business, it's a good thing," Mr. Gargano said. "It really sends a very important signal that New York and Long Island are places where you can do business."

HEADLINE: White House Is Taking a Look Around Town

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
On Monday, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, visited a high school here to talk about careers in health care. On Tuesday, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley and Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, visited another high school to talk about computer skills.
Today, Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater gave out children's automobile-safety seats at a day-care center, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman spoke at a food bank, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen visited a Young Marines program, and Acting Labor Secretary Cynthia Metzler went to a bank to announce a $3.4 million program to create 4,400 summer jobs for youngsters. 
 And on it goes, this week into next. Cabinet officials and other senior Clinton Administration officials are fanning out to unlikely corners of the capital in a White House effort to show concern for the city. Their appearances follow President Clinton's announcement in January of a $3.9 billion economic revitalization plan for the District of Columbia.
But some city officials, while applauding the visits this week, wondered why it had taken the Administration so long to step up its involvement, since the city had been struggling for years with financial stress and municipal mismanagement.
The answer, many have concluded, is Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., whose previous three terms in office effectively ended in 1990, when he was convicted on a misdemeanor charge for smoking crack cocaine and sent to prison for six months. In an extraordinary comeback, he was re-elected in 1994, the year the Republicans won control of Congress.
"This is totally political," said Councilman Kevin P. Chavous, a Democrat like Mr. Barry, whom other politicians expect to seek re-election next year. "So much of what drives the President's plan and folks in Congress is that Marion Barry is our Mayor. That still holds us hostage. It is a pervasive issue that hangs over our city."
Carol Schwartz, the only Republican on the City Council, said that "distancing himself from Barry" might have been part of the reason for President Clinton's lack of action earlier. But referring to Sharon Pratt Kelly, a Democrat who was Mayor from 1990 to 1994, Ms. Schwartz said Mr. Clinton "didn't do anything" for the city when Mrs. Kelly was in office either.
Administration officials discount the notion that Mr. Barry's experiences influenced Presidential strategy for the city, including Mr. Clinton's decision to wait until after he had been elected to a second term before intensifying aid to the District. They contend that the Administration was fully engaged in helping the city in Mr. Clinton's first term, playing a particularly active role in drafting legislation that led to the creation of a financial control board in 1995.
In addition, a White House District Task Force, which includes leading civic and business leaders, has been at work for three years, although largely behind the scenes. That, said Mr. Clinton's special adviser on the District, Carol Thompson Cole, was "partly by design," to give the control board and city government a chance to work.
Privately, however, some Administration officials acknowledged that Mr. Clinton had little to gain in his re-election campaign if he posed as a strong ally of a city led by a former prison inmate. One person familiar with the White House's thinking on the city alluded to Mr. Barry and the November elections and said that "it's not any great mystery" why the Administration had only recently increased its visibility around the city.
Mr. Barry denies that his past has had any bearing on White House initiatives. In a brief interview on the subject this week, he expressed his appreciation for Mr. Clinton's interest, saying, "Don't deprecate" the White House efforts.
"We'll take aid from whatever source, wherever it comes from," he said.
In recent months, the Mayor has had much to appreciate. Besides Mr. Clinton's economic plan, which includes a proposal for a Federal takeover of some of the city's state functions like operating a prison system, Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have visited a public school, and Federal agencies have donated to city schools and agencies a wide range of expertise and equipment.
These community visits by high-level officials are intended to be the start of a continuing relationship.
"I don't think this is only going to be a one-shot deal," a spokesman for the Office of Management and Budget, Lawrence J. Haas, said. "Clearly we have stepped up the involvement of the President and his team here in the District. The Cabinet members and the others will be back."

HEADLINE: Afraid to Compromise

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, took a chance last week when he called for a commission to reduce cost-of-living adjustments, an act that would lower Social Security benefits and raise income taxes. This would be a sensible, fair way to cut the deficit. President Clinton and Vice President Gore dismissed the idea, afraid to take on factions of their party that want no part of slowing Social Security increases.
Mr. Clinton had a second chance to forge a budget compromise this week when the Republican leaders Newt Gingrich, Pete Domenici and Tom DeLay broke with the conservative wing of their party by offering to drop for now the G.O.P.'s huge proposed tax cuts, the centerpiece of the Republican economic strategy. Again, Mr. Clinton made no equivalent concession. 
 This is a sorry turn of affairs. The Republicans are unlikely to take any more risks if the White House refuses to back their initial, timid steps toward a responsible budget this year.
Until Mr. Lott's move, budget negotiations were at an impasse. Both parties knew they could never fulfill their pledge to balance the budget in five years -- a regrettable pledge, in this page's view -- unless they chipped away at entitlements through a cut in cost-of-living adjustments.
Such a cut is justified because many economists believe the adjustments overstate the actual increases in the cost of living. But neither side would say so first, fearing a backlash from the elderly and other taxpayers. The deadlock appeared unbreakable until Mr. Lott spoke up. Sadly, Mr. Clinton refused to align himself with Mr. Lott, blaming the lack of bipartisan support. But the best way to create support is for the President to make the case for change.
The White House missed a similar chance to back away from harmful tax cuts. For months now, Democrats have criticized the G.O.P.'s proposed $200 billion tax cut that would be offset by equally huge cuts in welfare and other spending programs for the needy. Mr. Clinton knew that tax cuts have no logical place in a deficit-reduction plan, yet he felt politically compelled to offer his own, smaller tax-cut proposals during an election year.
This week Mr. Gingrich and friends offered the White House a risk-free way to drop tax cuts completely. The speaker suggested that the Republicans forgo tax cuts until after Congress passes a balanced-budget plan. Then the G.O.P. would reopen a fight for tax cuts, along with spending reductions to keep the budget balanced. Instead of embracing the idea and dropping his own tax-cut plan, Mr. Clinton merely called Mr. Gingrich's comments "a positive sign" and sought bipartisan talks.
Voters have a right to expect their President to lead Congress out of budgetary gridlock. Mr. Clinton ought to recognize the Republican offers as a good place to start.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Grows, Complicating Visit By Gore to Beijing

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
America's global trade deficit soared to $12.7 billion in January, the largest gap between imports and exports since the Commerce Department adopted a new method of measuring international trade in 1992. The figures included a 36 percent increase in the deficit with China that will further complicate the politics of Vice President Al Gore's trip to Beijing next week.
Mr. Gore's aides have made clear that they want to steer away from economic issues during his visit, in large part because questions of trade policy have lurked just beneath the surface of the investigations into Asian donations to the Democratic Presidential campaign. 
 But the figures today showed a $3.7 billion trade deficit with China for the month, compared with $2.7 billion a year ago. The widening disparity continues a trend suggesting that the trade gap with China this year will rival the one with Japan. That puts further pressure on the Administration to force China into lowering a vast array of trade barriers in negotiations, now under way in Geneva, concerning China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Gore had hoped to make only glancing references to that subject during his meeting with China's leaders next week. But as one senior Administration official said today, "This is not the time to appear soft on Chinese trade issues."
C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, who has been deeply involved in Asian trade issues, noted today that "there's no question now that Gore will have to go harder on market access issues."
The pressure on the Administration also increased today because three leading Democrats, including Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, introduced legislation that would require a Congressional vote before the Administration could agree to let China join the World Trade Organization.
White House officials have said in the past that they would "consult" Congress, but they want to avoid a lengthy debate that could link China's human rights record or arms proliferation to its membership in the club of trading nations.
"This is not a garden-variety entry into the W.T.O.," said Mr. Gephardt, who is widely considered a potential competitor with Mr. Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination in three years. "There are enormous implications of how this is done, for every worker in America and every major company in America."
At the White House today, Mr. Gore's aides changed course on one element of the trip, saying that the Vice President would attend the signing of a deal to sell roughly $1 billion in Boeing aircraft to China, if the deal is sealed in time for his visit. Earlier this week, when the Chinese offer was first made known, Mr. Gore's office said he would "consider" attending the signing.
In the past, that would have been just the kind of event that Administration officials would have unhesitatingly jumped at to make the case that exports and economic engagement with China were sustaining high-paying jobs in the United States. But recently there has been a rethinking of how deeply President Clinton and Mr. Gore should involve themselves in individual transactions. In part, that is in response to the Administration's critics, who say that it has been too close to business executives with interests in China and too mercantilistic in relations with Beijing.
The figures released today contained other complications for Mr. Clinton. The deficit with Mexico was flat compared with January 1996 but rose sharply from the end of last year, just as the Administration is seeking approval from Congress to negotiate an extension of the North American Free Trade Agreement, to embrace Chile and, ultimately, other Latin American nations.
Reading too much into one month's trade figures is always risky, because a few major sales -- especially of aircraft or computers -- can send the monthly numbers sharply in one direction or another. Over all, the decline of six-tenths of a percent in exports, to $70.8 billion, reflected a drop in military shipments and a slowdown in aircraft deliveries. Imports of goods and services rose 2.2 percent to $83.5 billion, due in part to increased auto shipments from Canada as well as higher prices and greater demand for imported oil. Using the old method, the Commerce Department said January's deficit of $19 billion for goods alone was the largest ever.
The widening trade deficit also reflects broader trends, including the fact that America's economy is growing at a faster pace than most of its major trading partners, sucking in imports and drying up markets abroad. The rise in the value of the dollar in recent months also appears to be starting to cut into America's exports.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Bargain Ticket Is Becoming A Luxury

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
IN the TKTS booth line in Duffy Square, the theater district's tempest du jour produced no fears that the age of discount tickets may be nearing an end.
Word was out that Broadway producers were thinking about setting up their own one-stop-shopping ticket booth: an indoor box office for all their shows. If such an operation does get going, it is not hard to imagine that TKTS, a Broadway institution run by the Theater Development Fund, may be forced to fold its tent. 
 But nothing has been decided, and, for all anyone knows, Broadway's status will remain quo. So it is understandable that no one in line was in a panic about possibly being deprived soon of generous ticket discounts of as much as 50 percent. Still, the TKTS issue was a springboard for some to reflect on how important such discounts have become for enjoying life in a city where high costs can make even relaxing stressful.
"For a lot of people, this is the only way they'll go to the theater," said Bernadette Artus of Manhattan. Her companion, Bo Fritz, disagreed. "You can't really put a price on satisfaction," he said. "If it's something I want to see, I'll pay for it."
Ms. Artus held her ground. "My parents would never go unless the tickets are half-price," she said.
She hit the mark on a big problem with New York's entertainment industry, which is, after all, the soul of the city. Whether entertainment means "Carmina Burana" at the City Opera or Patrick Ewing at the Garden, it is often priced beyond the means of even those graced with incomes well above average.
FOR the premiere of "Faust" at the Metropolitan Opera tonight, tickets come in two prices: $400 and $250. The cheapest seats for the New York Philharmonic's program at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow night cost $32.
Broadway shows run to $75 a ticket. At major rock concerts, so many seats are snapped up early by brokers or scalpers (the distinction between the two being lost on many) that people who are neither rich nor well connected often have no chance to go. Movies may seem like a relative bargain. But at $8.50 each, many families are forced to think twice about an evening out.
Sports? Let's not talk about the $1,000 a seat in Spike Lee territory at Knicks games. While $17 seats do exist upstairs, an average ticket goes for $55, assuming you can find one. The Rangers have raised prices for the opening playoff rounds by 16 percent over last year. Yankees and Mets tickets this season are up by 10 percent or more for many seats. This at a time when inflation is at 3 percent.
There are good reasons for some increases, notably the economics of accommodating the likes of Cecil Fielder, the Yankee hitter who acts as though life has dealt him a bad hand while he makes $7.2 million a year. And yes, Broadway offers group and student rates. There are "senior citizen" discounts, and the two baseball teams, as ever, provide low-priced tickets to nonprofit organizations. "They do try to reach out," said Jim Dolan, sports director of the Police Athletic League.
But that does not alter the fact that the cost of entertaining oneself in New York is reaching the ionosphere and is sure to keep going higher.
One person who has given the matter careful thought and does not like what he sees is Doug Logan, the commissioner of Major League Soccer, whose average ticket price is a more proletarian $13.
TIME was, he said, when movies and baseball were "the great democratizers," with mogul and riveter sitting side by side and sharing a common experience at more or less similar prices. Sports and entertainment, Mr. Logan said, were "the glue that held us together as a society."
"Unfortunately," he added, "they are not only getting away from trying to erode classism but they're actually perpetrating it, separating people by class."
He was referring specifically to the luxury "skyboxes" that sports franchises feel they cannot do without. "They're creating a living-room environment so that 'we' don't have to hang out with 'them,' " Mr. Logan said.
That situation is likely to get only worse, and soon, now that a new baseball season is upon us. Once again, we are certain to hear about the unwhetted appetite of George M. Steinbrenner 3d for a Yankee stadium with ever-more skyboxes.
Does anyone believe that building a new ballpark, or refitting the old one, to enable New York's privileged to watch ball games insulated from the masses can be accomplished without requiring the masses to pay for it in part with their own tax money?

HEADLINE: Bonds Slip as Investors Await Fed Meeting

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices were generally lower yesterday, as market participants settled in to wait for the Federal Open Market Committee meeting next week that will determine monetary policy for months ahead. Also adding to the negative tone in trading was weakness in the dollar, which makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors.
The spread between the 2-year note and the 30-year bond has narrowed to 69 basis points, from 77 basis points before testimony Thursday by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the Joint Economic Committee persuaded more market participants that an interest rate increase is more likely now at the March meeting of the F.O.M.C. than at the May meeting. 
 The 30-year bond slipped 4/32, to a price of 95 25/32 to yield 6.96 percent, up from 6.95 percent on Thursday.
A market news service, Bridge News, had a report yesterday on a speech in Lincoln, Neb., on Thursday by Alice M. Rivlin, the Fed vice chairwoman, under the headline "Rivlin Says Rubin Has Set 'Limits' to Strong-DLR Policy." Although the Fed later denied that she had said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin had set limits to the strong-dollar policy, the report "gave the market something to ponder," said Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif. He said that the report could cause the dollar to drop, creating a drag on Treasury securities in the absence of any other fresh news.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, said, "If we take Greenspan at his word, the Fed is certain to move short-term rates up by 25 basis points."
Referring to Mr. Greenspan's testimony before the Joint Economic Committee on Thursday, he said: "Clearly we learned this week that Mr. Greenspan has begun to exhibit significantly more signs of urgency than he espoused at his last set of Humphrey-Hawkins presentations. However, if we look at the economic fundamentals, it's fair to say that the early warning signs of inflation have actually turned somewhat favorable as evidenced by the year-over-year changes in the P.P.I. and even C.P.I. relative to the levels that they were hovering in over the last several months." The reference was to the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index.
Responding to the argument that any lack of a move next Tuesday would cause the Fed to lose credibility, Mr. Chan said: "I would argue that they will also lose some reverence if they move on the back of no real deterioration in either the P.P.I., C.P.I. or even the average hourly earnings data, because investors are going to ask themselves if Greenspan sees fit to move now, why didn't he move earlier when the inflationary warning signs were just as bad. For this reason, I would argue that the Fed is better off waiting until May." By then the economic data might make a stronger case for a rate rise, he added.
In when-issued trading late in the day the two-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was offered at a price to yield 6.29 percent and the five-year note going Wednesday, at 6.60 percent.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN HELSINKI: THE OUTLOOK;
New Yeltsin, Old Problem

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, March 21

 BODY:
A thinner, rejuvenated Boris N. Yeltsin has given a boost to an American-Russian relationship that had seemed to stagnate with Mr. Yeltsin's health until his heart bypass operation last year.
Not many months ago, President Clinton was excoriated for sticking with an enfeebled Mr. Yeltsin, who at the very start of his second term seemed helpless to manage a Russia drifting into political and economic paralysis. A former general, Aleksandr M. Lebed, called openly for Mr. Yeltsin's resignation and new elections, and some American officials were looking past Mr. Yeltsin to possible successors. 
 Today Mr. Yeltsin looked and acted confident and in charge, to the relief of American officials, who did not try to disguise their happiness at the outcome here. He did "my friend Bill" a tremendous favor, not just by repaying past loyalty, but by looking past the awkwardness and embarrassment of NATO expansion to put down a bet on Russia's future.
While Mr. Yeltsin continues to insist that NATO expansion is "a grave mistake," as he repeated today, he has also decided that Russia has no choice but to live with it in the interests of a larger cooperative relationship with Europe and the United States that promises important benefits to ordinary Russians.
Still, Mr. Yeltsin's new confidence in his political rejuvenation may be tested when he faces questioning by the Russian parliament on his bargaining at the summit talks.
Not only will Russia sign a charter with NATO governing its security relationships and its access to NATO planning and counsels, Mr. Yeltsin said, but he expects the charter will be signed before July, when NATO meets in Madrid to invite its first new members from the former Warsaw Pact.
Mr. Yeltsin knows that Russia needs foreign investment, that it must be a part of the larger world and try to share in its technological and managerial advances. If Mr. Yeltsin gave in to the idea of this first NATO expansion, American officials suggested tonight, it was for this larger aspiration.
The price of stopping or slowing NATO expansion would be threatening, blustering politics -- backed up by a much weakened army and central Government -- that would only isolate Russia further, doing more damage to Russia's future than, for example, Polish membership in NATO.
In Russia's fractious politics, where nationalists and Communists dominate parliament, the Duma, it cannot be assumed that the deputies will make the same bargain. Asked if he could get parliament to ratify Start 2, the pending strategic arms reduction treaty, Mr. Yeltsin said firmly, "As far as Russia is concerned, I expect that the Duma will make a decision based on my advice."
But if a weakened Russia is not the Soviet Union, Mr. Yeltsin is not the Communist Party boss either, and parliament rarely does him political favors.
Even bolstered by an agreement about missile defenses that seems to answer some of the Russian legislators' concerns about potential American defenses against strategic missiles, Start 2 may be a hard sell.
Some lawmakers have also linked Start 2 ratification to NATO expansion, and Mr. Yeltsin himself said today that even if the NATO countries did not have to have their parliaments ratify the proposed NATO-Russian charter, he intended to have the Duma do so.
In previous confrontations, Mr. Yeltsin has threatened to disband parliament and call new elections, or has resorted to a national referendum.
And every time he has gone over the head of his legislature to the Russian people -- who do not much care about the intricacies of European security -- they have supported him.
In any event, American officials insist, NATO enlargement will proceed, though the first countries expected to join -- Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and possibly Slovenia -- will not do so before April 1999.
Mr. Clinton's aides were especially relieved that despite the sharp disagreement over NATO, Mr. Yeltsin was willing to discuss important bilateral business on economics and arms control, agreeing in principle to a deeper cut in strategic nuclear warheads than most people thought possible five years ago, agreeing that planned American missile defenses were allowable under an earlier treaty and trying to help Mr. Clinton get a chemical weapons treaty through the Senate.
The talks here, American officials said, was a kind of answer to those American critics of NATO enlargement who said it would alienate Russia, strengthen anti-reform forces there and undermine the bilateral relationship.
Not only has Mr. Yeltsin put market reformers back in charge of Russia's economy and not "on the ash heap of history," one senior American official said; he has also set Russia firmly on the path toward a cooperative partnership that can only benefit both countries and stabilize Europe.
If, that is, Mr. Yeltsin stays healthy and is not undermined himself by the bargain he has set in motion here.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN HELSINKI;
Clinton and Yeltsin, and How They Faced 'Three Fundamental Challenges'

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of statements by President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin at a news conference yesterday after their meeting in Helsinki, Finland. Mr. Yeltsin's remarks were translated by his interpreter.
By President Clinton
I would like to begin by thanking President Ahtisaari, Prime Minister Lipponen, all the people of Finland, for their very gracious hospitality to -- the extremely constructive role that Finland plays in a new era for Europe.
This is my first meeting with President Yeltsin in each of our second terms, our 11th meeting overall. At each meeting, we have strengthened our nations' relationship and laid a firmer foundation for peace and security, freedom and prosperity in the 21st century. 
 Here at Helsinki, we have addressed three fundamental challenges: First, building an undivided democratic and peaceful Europe for the first time in history; second, continuing to lead the world away from the nuclear threat, and third, forging new ties of trade and investment that will help Russia to complete its remarkable transformation to a market economy and will bring greater prosperity to both our peoples.
A Europe undivided and democratic must be a secure Europe. NATO is the bedrock of Europe's security and the tie that binds the United States to that security. That is why the United States has led the way in adapting NATO to new missions and opening its doors to new members, in strengthening its ties to non-members of the Partnership for Peace, and seeking to forge a strong, practical partnership between NATO and Russia.
We are building a new NATO, just as the Russian people are building a new Russia. I am determined that Russia will become a respected partner with NATO in making the future for all of Europe peaceful and secure. I reaffirmed that NATO enlargement and the Madrid summit will proceed, and President Yeltsin made it clear that he thinks it's a mistake. But we also have an important and, I believe, overriding agreement.
We agreed that the relationship between the United States and Russia and the benefits of cooperation between NATO and Russia are too important to be jeopardized.
We didn't come here expecting to change each other's mind about our disagreement, but we both did come here hoping to find a way of shifting the accent from our disagreement to the goals, the tasks and the opportunities we share. And we have succeeded.
President Yeltsin and I agreed that NATO Secretary General Solana and Russian Foreign Minister Primakov should try to complete negotiations on a NATO-Russia document in the coming weeks. It would include a forum for regular consultations that would allow NATO and Russia to work and to act together, as we are doing today in Bosnia.
It would demonstrate that a new Russia and a new NATO are partners, not adversaries, in bringing a brighter future to Europe. We also agreed that our negotiators and those of the other 28 participating states should accelerate their efforts in Vienna to adapt the C.F.E. [Conventional Forces in Europe] treaty to the post-cold- war era by setting new limits on conventional forces.
The second area of our discussion involved our obligation to continue to lead the world away from the dangers of weapons of mass destruction. We have already taken important steps. We signed the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. We extended the Nonproliferation Treaty. We stopped targeting each other's cities and citizens. We put Start 1 into force.
And we're both committed to securing ratification of the Chemical Weapons Convention before it goes into force next month so that we can finally begin to banish poison gas from the earth.
Today President Yeltsin agreed to seek the Duma's prompt ratification of Start 2, already ratified by the United States Senate. But we will not stop there. The United States is prepared to open negotiations on further strategic arms cuts with Russia under a Start 3 immediately after the Duma ratifies Start 2.
President Yeltsin and I agreed on guidelines for Start 3 negotiations that will cap at 2,000 to 2,500 the number of strategic nuclear warheads each of our countries would retain and to finish the reductions of Start 3 by the year 2007. Now think about it: This means that within a decade, we will have reduced both sides' strategic nuclear arsenals by 80 percent below their cold war peak of just five years ago.
We also reached agreement in our work to preserve the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, a cornerstone of our arms control efforts. Distinguishing between ballistic missile systems restricted by the ABM Treaty and theater missile defenses that are not restricted has been a very difficult issue to resolve. Today, after three years of negotiations, we agreed to preserve the ABM Treaty while giving each of us the ability to develop defenses against theater missiles.
Finally, we discussed our economic relationship and the fact that the strong and secure Russia we welcome as a full partner for the 21st century requires that the benefits of democracy and free markets must be felt by Russia's citizens.
President Yeltsin recently demonstrated his determination to reinvigorate economic reform in his State of the Federation Address and with the appointment of a vigorous new economic team. His bold agenda to improve the investment climate and stimulate growth includes comprehensive tax reform, new energy laws and tough anti-crime legislation.
To help American companies take advantage of new opportunities in Russia, we will mobilize support to help finance billions of dollars in new investment. We will work with Russia to advance its membership in key international economic institutions like the W.T.O. [World Trade Organization], the Paris Club, and the O.E.C.D. And I am pleased to announce, with the approval of the other G-7 nations, that we will substantially increase Russia's role in our annual meeting, now to be called the Summit of the Eight, in Denver this June. Here in Helsinki, we have proved once again that we can work together to resolve our differences, to seize our opportunities to build a better future.
Before I turn the microphone over to President Yeltsin, let me say one word about the bombing today in Tel Aviv, which we have both been discussing in the last few minutes. Once again, an act of terror has brought death and injury to the people of Israel. I condemn it, and I extend my deepest sympathies to the families of those who were killed or injured.
There is no place for such acts of terror and violence in the peace process. There must be absolutely no doubt in the minds of the friends or of the enemies of peace that the Palestinian Authority is unalterably opposed to terror and unalterably committed to pre-empting and preventing such acts. This is essential to negotiating a meaningful and lasting peace. And I will do what I can to achieve that objective.
 By President Yeltsin
Our meeting was quite frank, and on the whole it was successful. And I am completely in accord with what the President of the United States, Bill Clinton, just said.
We have opened a new stage of Russian-American relations. We discussed in detail the entire range of Russian-American issues -- issues of Russian-American partnership, which is quite broad in scale. After all, our countries occupy such a position in the world that global issues are the subject of our discussions.
Both sides defended their national interests, and both countries did not abandon them. However, our two great powers have an area, a vast area of congruent interests. Chief among these is the stability in the international situation. This requires us to develop our relations, and there has been progress in that direction.
Five joint statements have been signed as a result of our meeting. President Bill Clinton and I just concluded signing these: on European security, on parameters of future reductions in nuclear forces, concerning the ABM missile treaty, on chemical weapons, and we also signed a U.S.-Russian economic initiative.
But we have not merely stated our positions; we view the signed statements with the U.S. President as a program of our joint action aimed to develop Russian-American partnership. I would say that emotions sometimes get the upper hand in assessing Russian-American partnership. This is not the approach that Bill and I have. Let's not forget that establishing the Russian-American partnership relations is a very complex process. We want to overcome that which divided us for decades. We want to do away the past mistrust and animosity. We cannot accomplish this immediately.
We need to be decisive and patient, and we have both with Bill Clinton. I firmly believe that we will be able to resolve all issues which for the time being are still outstanding. Today's meeting with Bill convinced me of this once again. We will be doing this consistently, step by step. We will have enough of both patience and decisiveness.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Loses 15.49 Points; Nasdaq Index Is Off 5.19
Stock prices declined, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing down 15.49 points, at 6,804.79, depressed in large measure by three stocks: Eastman Kodak, Philip Morris and I.B.M. For the week, the Dow lost nearly 2 percent. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, up early in the day, slumped at the end, falling 5.19 points, to 1,254.07, with Microsoft, Intel and Cisco Systems losing ground. After peaking in late January, the Nasdaq has lost nearly 10 percent, largely because technology stocks have been in their worst downturn since early last summer. [Page 36.]
 
Bond prices generally fell, with investors reluctant to take positions ahead of Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which many expect to raise interest rates. The 30-year bond slipped 4/32 , to a price of 95 25/32 to yield 6.96 percent, up from 6.95 percent on Thursday. [40.]
 
Smokers Likely to Ignore Warning
Liggett Group Inc.'s decision to warn all its cigarette buyers that smoking is addictive breaks new ground in the long-running tobacco wars, but is unlikely to affect many smokers' decision to light up, according to experts on both sides of the issue. Tobacco use has recently shown a striking increase among young people, despite the Government's 30-year history of requiring health warnings on cigarette packages. [9.]
 
Healthdyne's Capitol Friendships
Healthdyne Technologies, a medical equipment maker based in Marietta, Ga., which is facing a hostile takeover offer from Invacare, an Ohio company, may have an ally in the state government of Georgia. The State Senate approved a proposal to require that Georgia-incorporated companies have staggered boards, which would prevent opposition directors, even if elected, from commanding a board majority straightaway. Senators of both parties spoke of the need to take care of Georgia. [38.]
 
Deal Off, Ivax Shares Plunge
Shares of Ivax plunged 14 percent after the collapse Thursday of a plan for the troubled generic drug maker to merge with Bergen Brunswig in a stock deal originally valued at $1.66 billion. Each company blamed the other, and both said they would seek new partners. Some analysts had disparaged the deal. [40.]
 
A Merrill Executive's Mixed Feelings
E. Stanley O'Neal, who becomes one of the top executives of Merrill Lynch, as an executive vice president and co-head of the firm's corporate and institutional client group, is now one of the most senior African-Americans on Wall Street -- and he expressed mixed feelings. Mr. O'Neal said he found it "bothersome" when people focused on his race. "I never asked for any quarter, and I don't think I have received it," he said. Still, such recognition is important because it allows "young people to have role models." [39.]
 
Icahn to Lead Marvel Effort
Bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn said that they would elect a new board to take control of Marvel Entertainment Group, a comic book and sports card company, on Tuesday. The move reflected the failure of negotiations between the bondholders and the banks that lent money to Marvel when it was controlled by Ronald O. Perelman. To reorganize Marvel, Mr. Icahn and the others will either have to reach an agreement with the banks, led by Chase Manhattan, or persuade a bankruptcy court to force the banks to accept the plan. [39.]
 
Bre-X Says Freeport Studies Gold
Bre-X Minerals of Calgary, Alberta, responding to speculation that an Indonesian gold deposit might not be as big as reported, said that Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold, a partner in the deposit, was still examining it and had not yet commented. [38.]
 
Steel Collapse Hurts Seoul Banks
In South Korea, the collapse of Sammi Steel, following the filing for receivership earlier this year by Hanbo Steel, has worsened problems for the nation's banks, which have been hobbled by bad loans, weak management and shrinking stock investments. South Korea's central bank has promised to support Korea First Bank, Hanbo's prime creditor, which also lent money to Sammi. [38.]

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Unemployment Rate Drops

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate for February fell to 5.5 percent, its lowest level in more than six years. But the rate is still slightly higher than the national rate of 5.3 percent, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.
Labor Department officials attributed the improvement over January, when the unemployment rate was 5.9 percent, to the addition of 5,900 retail jobs and to relatively warm weather, which led to 700 new construction jobs. 
 But in the last month, the state has lost 500 financial services jobs and 1,800 manufacturing jobs, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the department.

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
An Antidrug Journalist Is Killed in Colombia

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 21

 BODY:
A gunman has killed the chief editorial writer of Cali's main newspaper, who was a harsh critic of Colombia's drug corruption.
The editorial writer, Gerardo Bedoya, 55, was killed on Thursday night by six or seven shots after leaving a condominium in southern Cali, home of the country's leading drug cartel, said an executive of El Pais, Mr. Bedoya's employer. The gunman fled on a motorcycle driven by an accomplice. 
 A lawyer, economist and former congressman, Mr. Bedoya had recently written stinging criticisms of the drug corruption that has plagued the Government of President Ernesto Samper.
In a Feb. 27 column entitled "Though they may call me Pro-Yankee," Mr. Bedoya wrote, "I prefer the pressure of the U.S. Government to the pressure of the narcos."
Mr. Bedoya was the most prominent journalist killed since the 1986 assassination by drug cartel hitmen of Guillermo Cano, publisher of the Bogota newspaper El Espectador.
