LENGTH: 1183 words

HEADLINE: The View From: Essex;
They Call It the Best Little Town in America

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
WHEN the annual New England Governors Conference was held in Connecticut a few months ago, Gov. John G. Rowland was able to do something that no other Governor could -- offer the best small town in America for the two-day event.
Essex, a Colonial seaport town of 5,900 about a half hour's drive from New Haven and New London on the west bank of the Connecticut River, is the only Connecticut town mentioned in Norman Crampton's second edition of "The 100 Best Small Towns in America" (Simon & Schuster, Macmillan Company, 1995). 
 It is also, says Mr. Crampton, not only at the top of the list, but a far better place to live than any other small town in the country. "Quite frankly Essex is way, way out in front compared to any other small town; it's just off the charts," he said. The rating is based on eight criteria for towns with populations of 5,000 to 15,000 including age (a population mixture inclusive of a stable older group and children to guide the future), crime rate (the lower the better), per capita income (high) , community involvement (pervasive is ideal) and educational quality.
Now come the tourists, to visit the 220-year-old Griswold Inn, said to be the oldest continuously operating inn in America, and a main street filled with antiques stores, novelty shops and refurbished Colonial houses.
The town's zoning laws are designed to preserve the wide array of housing styles and setbacks, winding roads and lanes and there's even a "street tree ordinance" that encourages shady walks and driveways.
"We get a lot of curious people who used to pass right by the town stopping in to see why we were named the best," said First Selectman Peter Webster.
Mr. Crampton, whose own town of Greencastle, Ind., placed 80th on the list, said that Essex "has a storybook-like quality -- kind of like a Norman Rockwell painting." It is "the Hollywood of small towns," evoking the picturesque locales portrayed in 1940's and 50's movies, and "a wonderful place to live."
But wonderful for whom? Like a Norman Rockwell painting, and like all the other towns on the select list, Essex is lacking in at least one key area that has become synonymous with progressive minded thinking during the 1990's: ethnic and racial diversity. "I found very, very little non-white representation in just about every small town across the country," Mr. Crampton said, "and that's not a judgment or political viewpoint to be debated; it's just a fact. Whether we like it or not, small towns just do not attract people of color." (According to the 1990 United States census, there are 59 black and 19 Puerto Rican residents of Essex.)
Mr. Webster said the homogeneity was more a matter of choice and economics than of exclusion.
"Of course we don't keep anyone out of Essex who wants to live there," said the First Selectman, a Democrat who moved to the town a decade ago from Old Saybrook.
Per capita income in Essex is $26,590, compared to the state average of $20,198, and median family income is $47,426, also well above state and national figures. Just 2.2 percent of the population lives below the poverty line.
"We're not close to an urban center, and the fact is that housing in the entire Connecticut River Valley region is not inexpensive," said Mr. Webster.
Despite Mr. Crampton's assertion that Essex is full of affordable homes in the $150,000 range, the census data backs up Mr. Webster. It indicates the average home in Essex costs well over $200,000, with lower prices concentrated in the blue-collar Ivorytown section (which includes the Ivoryton Playhouse).
Mr. Crampton points to Essex's kindergarten through sixth grade elementary school, where 500 pupils prepare for regional middle and high schools. "One of the things we're most proud of is that our school board is completely apolitical, so we don't have the kind of political controversies and fighting involving education that many other towns have," said W. Campbell Hudson, chairman of the school board and a lawyer who has lived in Essex for 20 years.
The town spends about $8,200 a year for each student, ranking it 26th among the state's 169 towns, but Mr. Hudson said the quality of education in Essex really is a reflection of a high degree of parental and community involvement.
The elementary school's principal, Karen Bailey, who resides about 20 miles away in Salem, says "Essex is an absolutely wonderful place for families to bring up their children." Ms. Bailey said that to make up for the lack of racial and ethnic diversity, the school is taking part in programs with schools in Hartford, Middletown and New Britain.
"It is important for the children to have a more global perspective and by interacting with pupils from city schools, that's one way of doing it," she said.
Many of the people who live in Essex say they weren't surprised by its selection as the best small town in the nation.
"I grew up here and always felt it was the best," said 42-year-old Doug Paul, an owner of the Griswold Inn. "When I was away at college, all I could think about was coming back home -- and staying home."
Jerome Cutone, 79, a life-long resident of Essex, said "We're just a small, quiet close-knit New England town . . . and if a town had to be chosen as the best, I guess it might as well have been Essex."
In the American-as-apple-pie category, residents talk proudly about the town's eight annual parades -- including a Ground Hog Day parade that drew more than 2,000 people last month.
They even have an annual "burning of the ships parade" on the second Saturday in May to commemorate the torching of 28 ships by a British raiding party during the War of 1812. It was later called the nation's worst disaster, with a $160,000 loss, during the two-year war. During last year's parade, Mr. Webster stood at the edge of the river and told the hundreds who had gathered: "People ask us why we commemorate the burning of the ships this way every year . . . and I tell them because in Essex we just look for any excuse to hold a good old fashioned parade." The town historian, Don Malcarne, a life-long resident, said that "You can literally leave the door to your home unlocked here."
But he is quick to point out that things were not always so. Essex, he said, was a downtrodden, poverty-ridden mess for more than a century. It was not until the 1940's that wealthy out-of-towners decided that the decaying seaside Colonial buildings could be transformed into a town of quaint and historic elegance -- and did so.
Mr. Malcarne doesn't deny that the town's residents now have a somewhat elitist attitude -- more so in Essex Village than in the town's other villages of Ivoryton and Centerbrook.
"Let's not kid ourselves, Essex is not representative of the average population," said Mr. Malcarne. "Is it snobbish? Yes, it does have a kind of elite attitude about it. But that kind of goes with the territory. I think the people are basically a lot like the New England region we represent -- sturdy, proud and neighborly . . . but not all that demonstrative."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 34; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: POP/JAZZ;
A Hip-Swaying State-Sponsored Export

BYLINE: By PETER WATROUS 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
IT'S 4 IN THE MORNING AT WHAT MAY BE THE best dance hall in the world, Havana's La Tropical, and the singer Issac Delgado, the king of Cuban cool, is crooning in front of 10,000 people. Manolin, el Medico de la Salsa, the most popular singer in Havana right now, comes out to join him, and the audience goes beyond euphoria, seeing two heroes on the stage together.
Everyone dances; everyone sings the chorus of the song, and the place seems as if it's going to levitate with the joy of the Cuban soul. And all this joy comes after four nights and five days of nonstop music called El Son Mas Largo del Mundo (The Longest Son in the World), a Cuban Woodstock that was part of the Government's first annual music-trade exposition this month. 
 The weeklong exposition, the Feria del Disco Cubano (the Cuban Record Fair), which ended on March 12, brought to light the changing relations between the the Cuban Government and capitalism and the rapid international growth of the Cuban music industry. The Government used this trade show to promote Cuba's music as both a cultural ambassador to the world and a way to earn badly needed American dollars -- dollars kept from the country, in part, by the United States embargo. Last year, 3,500 of Cuba's roughly 11,600 state-sponsored musicians performed abroad, raising what label executives say could run into the millions though there are no figures available from the Government. News organizations and impresarios from all over the world came to sample what the Government was selling.
Beyond the trade exposition, the Cuban Government has already begun taking cautious steps in entrepreneurship. It has signed a deal with Magic Music, a Spanish record company that specializes in Cuban music, to release "La Isla de la Musica," a 41-CD set of selections by virtually unknown Cuban musicians. The Government is also inviting multinational companies to set up booths at next year's exposition. And it has given permission to Eduardo Bautista, president of Sociedad General de Autores y Editores, the Spanish version of ASCAP, based in Madrid, to set up an office here.
"That they've let us set up an office can be read in all sorts of ways," Mr. Bautista said. "But the most important is that it shows what's happening to the system here, that the Government is opening up more and more to the outside."
The exposition also provided a showcase for the Government-run music education program that has contributed to the level of excellence displayed by the dance bands, choral groups, classical ensembles, rap groups and folkloric ensembles that performed during the weeklong event.
"If you're a musician anywhere in Cuba, from an early age, you can go to music school," said Alicia Perea, a classical pianist who is also president of the Instituto Cubano de la Musica, which oversees the entire Cuban music industry. "We don't teach them just to play notes. They have to study philosophy, and literature and history along with several instruments.
"El Tosco, the leader of the group NG la Banda, is the perfect example," she continued. "I've played Bach with him -- he plays flute -- and he's an exceptional jazz musician, and he leads perhaps the hardest dance band in Cuba."
The free national music schools were started in 1962, after the Cuban revolution, and they were devoted exclusively to training musicians in the European classical tradition. But in the late 70's and the early 80's, the curriculum was expanded to include jazz and Cuban music. The musical excellence that has flowered over the last 10 years is a result of these schools.
The world, except for the United States, is catching on. Magic Music's growth is doubling yearly, and one of its artists, Lucretia, who now lives in Spain, has been snapped up by MCA, the multinational label. Another small label specializing in Cuban music, Caribe Records, which is owned by a Spaniard but based in Panama, is reportedly poised to be bought by a large multinational record company.
"The thing that I'm worried about is that this invasion of foreign interest will fundamentally change the Cuban experiment, its idiosyncrasies," said Francis Cabezas, the president of Magic Music. "For all its problems, the Government here has supported the music in an extraordinary way, and while there may be problems, the system has created the future."
That system involves total Government regulation. Musicians are Government employees. A lesser-known band that finds work in a local club, for example, must go to the Government to be paid. Bands with larger followings perform where the Government tells them to. When bands perform abroad, the Government extracts up to 50 percent of their earnings in the form of a newly imposed tax.
Musicians also complain about the system for other reasons. El Tosco says he is overwhelmed by the amount of work NG la Banda gets. "It's like being in a prison of popular music," he said. "I have to play it to support my three children. I'd rather be playing serious music."
The drummer Jose Sanchez says that although he plays for the popular singer Rojitas, his earnings do not cover his living expenses. Like many Cuban musicians, Mr. Sanchez moonlights to earn American dollars, the only currency with real power in the country. "I teach students," he said. "I charge them dollars. Even Rojitas doesn't make much more than we do. When we go to Europe we make more, but not that much."
Ms. Perea, head of the music institute, is sympathetic toward their plight. "Socialism isn't there to deny riches," she said. "It's there to distribute the riches fairly. The problem is that we Cubans are very, very bad at making riches. Our distribution system is incompetent. We don't know how to market. But we're learning. We have to because, for example, we don't make basic things in Cuba like violin strings or music paper, which means we have to pay dollars for them."
Whatever the complaints of performers, for audiences the system works. At the outdoor night club La Tropical, for instance, which attracts no tourists, there's little distinction between audiences and musicians. Women regularly jump on stage to show off their steps, and singers improvise about the woman in the white dress in the front row or a fight breaking out in the back. In a country of profound material deprivation, where items from CD's to aspirins are virtually unknown to the average person, all the things that are free -- language, movement, sensuality -- become mythologically powerful. The bands, steeped in European, African and American sensibilities, are some of the best dance groups in the world.
In Cuba, even dance music, which has replaced the more folky Nueva Trova style that was popular during the 60's and 70's, is politicized. "Intellectuals think that salsa is the product of capitalism and is bad," Mr. Cabezas, the record label head, said. "Those opposed to the Government think that salsa is a product of Communism and is bad. But the truth of the matter is that salsa is a product of the people, who want to hear it and dance to it and live by it. Street music used to be marginalized, but it's not anymore."
At the exposition itself, which was held at the Pabellon Cuba, representatives of Cuban and foreign record companies vied for business at 10 stands. The air was pungent with rum and cigarette smoke, and on three stages bands from rural areas, rap bands, folk singers, salsa bands and choral groups performed from noon until the wee hours.
Back at La Tropical, the bands played dreamlike sets, and dancers challenged one another in the sweet, sometimes hard, language of the hips. Singers chanted about the streets and about the country, sometimes in code, sometimes not. The rhythm drove it all, and the music's intelligence and pleasure were indisputable.
And all over town, musicians, business people and Government officials talked about America and the relationship between the United States and Cuba. American flags were in evidence on many people's clothes, and among musicians around town and backstage at La Tropical there was a sense that America was the next frontier. Music, it was hoped, would help end the blockade, and there are signs that it has already begun to happen. Cuban music is making its way into the United States, like smoke curling under a door.
For Juan Formell, the leader of Los Van Van, one of the great Cuban groups that recently toured the United States, an end to the embargo could mean more work. "They loved us in the United States," he said. "I already don't have enough time to write and relax, so if the blockade vanishes, I'm in trouble."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Concertgoers at La Tropical in Havana, above; at right, the singer El Calvo of the band Los Van Van mingles with the crowd. HEADLINE: For an Australian Wunderkind, the Glitter of Hollywood

BYLINE: By BRUCE NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AT THE END OF "The Destiny of Nathalie X" William Boyd's scathing short story about Hollywood -- a character who has tried to corrupt a young African director consoles him by saying: "It's just a dance. It's just a dance we have to do." To the amazement of the hard-bitten Hollywood character, the young director just laughs. The point of the story is that he still can.
Seated on a bench at the Griffith Park Observatory here, Emma-Kate Croghan, the 25-year-old Australian director of the antic comedy "Love and Other Catastrophes," laughed, too. 
 A year ago, she was living on welfare in Melbourne. Now, her no-budget film about the entangled lives of a group of students at Melbourne University will play at the New Directors/New Films series on Wednesday and open in theaters on Friday -- this, after making a successful tour of the three most important film festivals: Cannes, Toronto and Sundance.
Ms. Croghan, who has skin the color of parchment, was this day looking down on Hollywood, literally. And she was contemplating what the town had in store for her. Hollywood, it should be noted, has already accepted into its negligible ranks of women directors two other Australians -- Jocelyn Moorhouse, whose forthcoming film is "A Thousand Acres," and Gillian Armstrong, who made "Little Women." Ms. Croghan may be poised to join their ranks.
Bob Aaronson, who, as vice president for acquisitions of Fox Searchlight, sees more than 200 movies by young film makers each year, thinks that despite her youth and inexperience Ms. Croghan has a big future as a director. "A lot of new film makers tend to work in familiar genres, and sometimes tend to fall prey to derivativeness," he said. "Emma-Kate's work has a kind of exuberant, loose-limbed quality to it that is completely ingenuous. There's an intimacy to it that seems very real and true, and that's rare."
Ms. Croghan came here after Sundance, to this place where people move and shake -- and dance -- to take meetings with studio executives who, she says, are "like teen-age boys." This very day she met with Bill Mechanic, the chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment; nine months ago at Cannes, Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax, gave her a tour of the French Riviera in his limo.
It has been a fast transition for Ms. Croghan from her start in the film business just two years ago, when she set out to make her semi-autobiographical screwball comedy. She had read that the old Hollywood screwball comedies were written and shot at breakneck speed. So she wrote the script for "Love and Other Catastrophes" with two friends in two weeks. Then she and her boyfriend of five years, Stavros Andonis Efthymiou, shot her $37,000 film in 17 days.
"Love and Other Catastrophes" hurtles along at a kinetic pace as it portrays students trying to pay library fines, find roommates or switch classes -- all the while looking for love, of course. Several times, Ms. Croghan had no idea where her team would get the money to buy film stock to shoot the following day, and they were constantly trolling for backers.
"We were desperate," she recalled. "I think people could see the madness in our eyes and the sheer velocity of the energy we had."
That velocity carried Ms. Croghan and the film's lead actresses -- Alice Garner, who had known Ms. Croghan at film school in Melbourne, Frances O'Conner and Radha Mitchell -- to a kind of screwball comedy of their own at Cannes, where they periodically dived under tables to escape the small army of Hollywood agents and lawyers that were stalking them.
"That was the first time that we met Hollywood," Ms. Croghan said. "Or Hollywood met us. I was just so freaked out by the whole experience that I wasn't ready to talk to anybody."
To get out of Australia, she had already been obliged to talk her way past a government bureaucrat. She had lost a clerical job that had been paying the rent and, while wading through the often interminable financing process for Australian films, had gone on welfare.
"I was on the dole before I went to Cannes, totally unemployable," she said. "And I had to go in and explain how I was able to leave the country, that this was just a little hobby film that had been picked up by somebody who was paying my way to Cannes. The priceless look on that man's face."
Ms. Croghan gazed wistfully across the hills at the Hollywood sign. "And two days later, I was sitting on a yacht with Al Pacino."
The cast of "Love and Other Catastrophes" got its first taste of the international press last May at Cannes. "We were all waiting for the three questions that we had already answered a million times," Ms. Croghan said, "and this man from Czech television says" -- here she switches to a rumbling Slavic voice -- " 'How much for your soul?'
"Well, we all just looked at each other, and he asked again, 'How much will you sell your soul to Hollywood for?' "
That, of course, is the question that hangs over every young film maker. Ms. Croghan knows she will be answering it in the choices she makes over the next few years. Back at Cannes, she replied meekly that she hadn't yet been required to sell out.
"Nobody goes into it to sell their soul," she said now. "The truth is, people give it up for free."
When Fox Searchlight bought the worldwide distribution rights to "Love and Other Catastrophes" for $800,000 just a week before the Cannes festival, Ms. Croghan checked to see if her soul was leaving her body.
"You always think big bad Hollywood is going to take your film away," she said. "So my first question was, 'Do they have another film that's the same, and they want to stop ours from coming out?' "
HER EDUCATION IN American film making continued earlier this year at Sundance. There she met a young director from Los Angeles who was distributing posters for a film he had not yet actually made.
"It wasn't until I was in Sundance, and I saw all those people schlepping around desperately trying to get people to go to screenings, and unable to finish their films that I realized how lucky we'd been," she said. "In Australia, film making has always been about making the film, but people from L.A., even young film makers, are obsessed with the deal."
Making deals was not of interest to Ms. Croghan. Growing up in Melbourne on what she described as a commune, she was taken to see Truffaut's "400 Blows" when she was 5 or 6. (Someone read the subtitles to her.) After high school, she attended Australia's top film school, the Swinburne Institute of Technology, where she was one of only a handful of teen-agers admitted.
"She was pretty sophisticated, even then," said Jenny Sabine, dean of the school, which is now called the Victorian College of Art, in Melbourne. "I remember turning to someone after her interview and saying, 'Hasn't she made a mature presentation for someone so young.' " Ms. Croghan made two award-winning shorts, "Sexy Girls, Sexy Appliances" and "Desire" before she was 20.
With the increasing attention being conferred upon "Love and Other Catastrophes" -- it has already grossed $1.2 million in Australia, where it opened last summer -- Ms. Croghan hopes she can work within the Hollywood system without being consumed by it. For now she is waiting and does not yet have a new project.
Although she appears to be inside the velvet rope of the big dance, she can still laugh at Hollywood. At the Sundance festival, which she attended with her cast, she encountered one overheated Hollywood type being denied entrance to the party for "Love and Other Catastrophes." In a fury, the man ordered the film's publicist never to call him again. "Lose! My! Number!" he screamed.
"So now every time we see each other in a hotel lobby," Ms. Croghan said, "we start yelling 'Lose! My! Number!' "
Lose her number. But you may want to remember her name.

(Robin Holland; 20th Century Fox)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Housing Market Shows Slow, Steady Improvement

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WHEN their third child was born Ernest and JoAnne Zappitelli knew they needed to sell their 1,600-square-foot bilevel in Ringwood and buy a larger home for their growing family. But they delayed the move for three years, waiting for a stronger housing market.
That time came last January. After five months of house hunting the couple sold their smaller home in two weeks, getting their asking price of the low $190,000's, and bought a 2,400-square-foot center-hall colonial in the mid $300,000 range on one acre in Franklin Lakes. 
 "With interest rates good and houses selling more quickly we felt we could get the price we needed from our old house and upgrade to a bigger one," said Mrs. Zappitelli, whose husband moves heavy equipment from one job to another for a construction company. "We just felt it was the right time and for us, having just turned 40, it was now or never."
The Zappitellis forged ahead at a time when the state's housing market is healthy, but not spectacular. "There is a strong demand for and an adequate supply of homes," bringing the market "back to normalcy," said Bruce Zipf, president of the New York region for Coldwell Banker, a large brokerage in Short Hills.
After a flat 1995 the market rebounded in 1996, riding a wave of slow but steady improvement that so far has spilled over into 1997 said Michael Ford, president of the New Jersey Association of Realtors. The spurt was helped by stable, moderate mortgage interest rates and an improving economy and job picture, which nudged up the state's median household income by about $3,000 to $58,850 at the end of 1996.
The belief that the worst of the corporate downsizing is over also helped. One surprise, analysts, brokers and developers agreed, was that the impact of AT&T's breakup into three companies on the residential market, as in the office sector, was less harsh than expected.
As for the new-home market, the problem is supply, not demand, said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro. Zoning and regulatory constraints remain hurdles to developing new housing and the situation shows no sign of easing, he said.
As 1997 progresses, many industry experts are betting more buyers will react like the Zapitellis did and buy. That sets the stage for an active, albeit not a booming, home-buying season through the spring and summer, they said. Unless there is a break in the pattern, the consensus is that 1997 should wind up on par with 1996.
"There are no wild cards on the horizon," said Keith T. Gumbinger, vice president at HSH Associates, a Butler firm that tracks mortgage activity. Interest rates should hover near 8 percent through year's end, he said.
Job growth is also expected to remain steady in the state, which added 60,000 net new jobs in 1996, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "The modesty of the state's recovery, now in its 60th month, has contributed to its longevity," he said, adding a prediction for a recession-free 1997.
There is a general air of caution in the stable housing climate, said Neils Guldbjerg, vice president at the Otteau Appraisal Group in East Brunswick. Buyers remain cautious; owners have trimmed their expectations of price appreciation and builders are more flexible in meeting buyer preferences to close sales, he and others said.
On average existing homes are selling for 90 to 97 percent of their asking price and staying on the market for three to three and a half months, brokers say. The supply of resale homes in some areas does not meet demand, underscoring a lack of urgency in the market, some brokers said. Talk in Washington of lowering the capital gains tax also may have discouraged some owners from selling.
THE active markets were, and will be, communities that offer good schools and hold their appreciation and those in growth corridors, said David J. Schoner, vice president of the metropolitan New York region for the New Homes division of Coldwell Banker.
Among them are towns 20 miles west of the Interstate 287 corridor in Morris, Somerset and Monmouth and Middlesex Counties where corporate expansions are occurring, he said.
Sales of existing homes increased by 6.8 percent to 147,800 at the end of 1996. That is the best level reached this decade, and one not seen since 1987 when 158,400 homes were sold, according to the state's realtors association. The rise pushed up the median year-end sales price by 3.8 percent to $148,000.
The improvement was reflected in varying degrees in all three regions of the state. In northern New Jersey sales rose by 2,800 to 58,400 and the median sales price rose to $197,300 from $188,100; in central Jersey sales increased by 3,600 to 49,500 and the price increased to $145,900 from $140,200. Sales also rose by 3,100 to 40,000 in south Jersey, where the median price inched up to $109,200 from $106,700.
About 32 percent of the sales were for $100,000 to $160,000 homes, showing that first-time buyers remain in the market. But 26 percent were for $200,000 to $400,000 houses, indicating that trade-up buyers have increasingly entered the scene. Many are baby boomers with children who will be a marketing focus this year, added Dean Hughes.
Peter Mosca, spokesman for the state's realtors, said the active spring and summer season his association foresees should help the resale market remain strong and measure up in the first half of the year to its 1996 pace, when nearly 75,000 existing homes were sold. But the pace may slow by the fourth quarter, he said, noting that year-end sales could wind up the same as this year or 2 to 5 percent lower.
Many brokers said sales so far this year had been strong. Weichert Realtors, the state's largest broker, said 500 more contracts for new and resale homes had been signed through the first week of this month than the 3,200 signed in the same time last year. "There are more buyers than inventory," said Paul R. Christman, a senior vice president at the Morris Plains-based company. "But March is a big listing month and as the market heats up more sales will be made."
New homes, for the most part, are also geared to the higher-end market, with an average price of $250,000. But with homes priced at $150,000 to $175,000 most in demand "there's a mismatch between what builders can build and what people can afford," said Mr. O'Keefe of the builders' group.
The state ended 1996 issuing 24,647 permits, up from 23,408 in 1995. Half of the homes are targeted for six counties -- Ocean, Middlesex, Morris, Burlington, Monmouth and Somerset. "What we see is the peak level of production and it will trail down from here for the rest of the decade," said Mr. O'Keefe. Added John G. Udell, president of Weichert New Homes & Land: "That spells upward pressure on land and in turn on new home prices."
Still, developers say new homes are selling and that they are moving ahead with projects. "So far this year our sales are even with those of last year," said Wayne Patterson, senior vice president at Toll Brothers in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., among the larger developers in the state. "But given the generally strong New Jersey market, and as we open projects, we expect sales to increase by 20 percent over last year when 519 contracts were closed." He said Toll expected to begin projects this year that will ultimately have 900 homes, most costing $300,000 or more.
And K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the state's largest builder, reports that the just under 800 sales made so far this year is slightly up from last year. It is also expecting year-end sales to be higher, rising from 2,364 to just under 2,500, said Gabriel M. Pasquale, senior marketing adviser for the company's northeast region.
He said 15 percent of those homes will be for the active adult market as the company follows baby boomers. He said the company also would focus on homes for trade-up buyers as well as continue to build entry-level town houses and one-family homes.
The sense of optimism is not limited to builders. Mrs. Zappitelli said she and her husband felt that buying today garnered them more house for their money. "Whatever we put into this house," she added, "we will get back, plus more."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Housing Starts Dip, Prices Rise as Fairfield Prospers

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS are calling the climate in Connecticut mostly sunshine with some light showers. Housing starts were down by about 7 percent in 1996, compared with 1995, but employment inched up nearly 2 percent since 1990. Moreover, housing prices have been rising in a brisk market driven by a mild winter.
Residential real estate conditions vary, with lower Fairfield County prospering in tandem with Wall Street, New London County profiting from the Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun gambling casinos and from submarine contracts for Electric Boat. But the central and northern areas remaining stagnant. 
 While the 7,714 housing starts statewide in 1996 were below the 8,307 in 1995 -- and represent a startling drop from 28,000 starts in 1986 -- rentals and sales of both existing and new homes are lively. John M. Clapp, professor of real estate at the University of Connecticut at Storrs, said, "I think people are responding positively to moderate interest rates and job growth."
One phenomenon worth noting is the widening of suburbia. Because of an acute shortage of land in lower Fairfield County and its ever-escalating cost of housing the borders of what had been considered a reasonable commutation range from New York City have been expanded. They now stretch from Milford on the New Haven County shore, through Orange, Shelton and Newtown in northeastern Fairfield County and into New Milford in Litchfield County.
It is possible to find well-designed homes up to 2,900 square feet for $269,990 at Lexington Green in Milford, one of the most active building locations in the state.
"Young marrieds who can't afford to live near their jobs in Stamford, White Plains and New York are our primary buyers," said Larry Blum, director of sales for the 261-lot subdivision. "We are five minutes from the Metro-North station, and an hour and 20 minutes from Grand Central."
"We're seeing people move here because it's the most affordable area in Fairfield County," said Kim Danziger, a builder in Newtown and Brookfield who has 2,800-square-foot homes for sale in the mid-$300,000 range.
Toll Brothers, a nationwide builder based in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., will open Huntington Estates in Shelton next month, with homes up to 3,300 square feet selling from the low to mid-$300,000's. One hundred Toll Brothers homes in the Town of Fairfield and 24 in Newtown range in size from 2,200 to 4,200 square feet and in price from $300,000 to $550,000.
But such activity is limited geographically. Will McEachern, a University of Connecticut at Storrs economics professor who is editor of The Connecticut Economy, a university quarterly, had this overview:
"It's clear we have a recovering economy and a housing market that never did recover because we had enough overbuilding in the 80's to last another decade."
And Edward Deak, economics professor at Fairfield University, had this to add:
"The Hartford housing market will remain slow until the whole insurance and banking evolution is concluded. We won't see a strong revival in the Connecticut housing industry until the 21st century."
But talk to any real estate broker, banker, or builder in Fairfield County about a downturn in housing, and the response will be: "What downturn?"
"As soon as a new house comes on the market it sells," said Laurie Crouse, a Preferred Properties broker in Westport. "A lot of what is happening is that a property comes up for sale and a builder will buy it, tear down the house and build a new one on the same lot."
ONE builder didn't even have to demolish the old house, she recalled. He let the fire department burn it down in a practice exercise.
"What we have in new construction goes quickly, before it's completed," said Charlotte Felt, office manager at the Kelly Associates real estate agency in Darien. "Builders are buying houses, tearing them down and building on speculation."
A three-acre farm in the exclusive Tokeneke section of Darien was bought by Sean Shay, a local builder who turned the farmhouse into a guest cottage and built an 8,000 square-foot French country manor, tennis court and swimming pool on the property, soon to be marketed for more than $3 million.
For much of the Gold Coast market, brokers say, house sales of a million dollars have become common, although there are houses available from $200,000 fixer-uppers to multimillion-dollar mansions in most Fairfield County towns.
"Last February we had 727 homes on the market in Westport and Weston," said Ms. Crouse of Preferred Properties, "with a median price of $475,000. This year we had 444 houses in February and a median of $549,950. We sold 82 houses so far this year and have 38 under contract."
"Inventories are trending down and prices have firmed up," agreed Peter Helie, president of William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford. "Our unit sales are up 13 percent this year over the same period last year. The high end is moving, the middle market is the thinnest in terms of inventory because it's where the most demand is."
"We've been looking at the Milford market," said Terence Beatty, vice president of new home sales at Pitt. "It can absorb 60 homes a year in one neighborhood. In Seymour and Derby bigger neighborhoods can absorb 100 homes a year."
Builders, he noticed, are raising prices as they build and sell, charging more for lots 4 through 8 than lots 1 through 3, and still more for lots 9 through 12, and so on.
Assessing conditions around the state, Gerald R. Kunde, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Realtors, said:
"We'll see more development creeping into New Haven County if prices continue to go up in Fairfield. In New London, investors are buying up homes and renting them to people who work at the casinos, but we haven't seen any increase in home values."
A LOT of people in northeastern Connecticut," he continued, "are commuting up Route 395 to Waltham, Mass., where there is a huge upturn in technology jobs, and agents in Waterbury say they are having the best year ever."
He said he would like to see a cut in capital gains taxes on the sale of homes "because it would encourage activity in the real estate market."
"People accept the fact that they are going to pay something, but they would certainly like more money in their pockets," he observed. "On the investment side you find a much greater response. The amount of tax is the same, but investors can't defer payment when buying a more expensive property, or take an elderly exemption the way a homeowner can, so he has less to reinvest."
"People are not going to worry about a drop in capital gains," said Mr. McKeever, the accounting firm executive, assuming that it will be a small drop at best. "If they are elderly they may stay put because it's all going to be taxed in their estates. So why pay capital gains as well inheritance taxes?"
Real estate brokers as well find the issue of little concern to sellers; nor does Todd Martin, a first vice president at People's Bank in Bridgeport, see sellers holding back. What he does see is a window in interest rates.
"It's a coin toss whether the Fed will tighten monetary policy before May," he said, "and any change will be minor. We are looking for the rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage to go down to 7 or 7.25 percent this summer from a current 7.5 percent, and adjustables to decline to 6.25 percent, with plenty of credit available."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Home Buyers Out in Force in a Humming Market

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
WHEN the Quartos put their four-bedroom Cape Cod in New Hyde Park on the market in January for $249,000, they were not unduly worried about selling it. Their target date for moving to St. Augustine, Fla., was June.
"The house is in a good neighborhood, and it's in good condition," said Joseph Quarto, who worked as a customer-service representative for a bank and is now retired. "And a lot of people are out looking." 
 But he and his wife, Carol, were not quite prepared to find a buyer so quickly. A few days after listing their home with Atanas Realty in Williston Park they had an open house and their first offer of $235,000.
Two days later they received a second offer -- this one for $232,500. They accepted the second because it came from a young couple pre-approved for a mortgage. The closing will be in early June.
Brokers report that, following a strong 1996, buyers have been out in force in the first two months of 1997 -- usually a quiet period in the real estate market -- and that this bodes well for another strong year. Even co-ops, which many buyers at one time shunned, are once again in demand, said June Shapiro, a Great Neck broker.
The Quartos' experience of getting more than one offer is no longer unusual and in some cases the final offer is higher than the asking price.
A four-bedroom colonial in Glen Cove that was recently listed for $359,000 by the Coldwell Banker Sammis agency in Locust Valley went for $360,000 -- and had a purchaser within one weekend, said Sandi Lefkowitz, the office manager. "It has to do with confidence in the economy and the fact that interest rates are still good," said John Juliano, a broker with Prudential Long Island Realty in East Meadow.
The Multiple Listing Service of Long Island, which has more than 1,350 member agencies in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens, sold 17,204 homes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in 1996, compared with 15,607 in 1995. The number of listings over the same period fell from 58,145 to 55,970.
"We still have a lot of inventory, but it's stuff that's been around for a while," said Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive officer of the Long Island Board of Realtors and its Multiple Listing Service. "It's the newly listed and realistically priced houses that are getting attention and that buyers have to move quickly on."
Nevertheless, house prices in Suffolk and Nassau have remained stable, Mr. Mottola noted. "We had more sales last year, but not a corresponding increase in price," he said.
Most of the price appreciation occurred in Suffolk. For example, the median price of a house in Suffolk that closed in January 1997 was $135,000 compared to $131,000 in January 1996. In Nassau, the median dipped slightly from $176,800 in January 1996 to $176,000 last January.
William Davis, owner of the Long Island Profiles Publishing Company in Babylon, said he expected prices to move "slowly upward" at an annual appreciation of 5 percent. The research firm, which gathers data from deeds filed with county clerks, and thus covers the entire spectrum of property, counted 41,394 closings in Nassau and Suffolk in 1996 -- up about 7 percent over transactions that closed in 1995.
In some real estate offices the concern is no longer a lack of buyers so much as a lack of new listings. "I have qualified, serious buyers, but I don't have enough houses to show them," said Evelyn Atanas, the owner of Atanas Realty, the agency that represented the Quatros. Its listings are primarily in Williston Park, East Williston Albertson and Mineola.
Mrs. Atanas said that this time last year she had 30 listings in those three areas, while this year she has about 15 houses to show. Among her potential buyers are Christopher Guglielmo, a New York City fireman, and his wife, Julia, a police officer. The Guglielmos are currently renting an apartment in Williston Park and want to stay in the community, but they are finding that choices are limited.
W E'VE been looking for a year, but it's hard to find something to our taste, and I find prices are high," Mr. Guglielmo said. Recent offers he made on two houses were rejected, he added, because owners held out for a higher price.
Other brokers say they are also experiencing a shortage of listings. "We usually have to put on our rollerskates to go out and inspect 14 to 16 new listings at this time of the year," said Patricia McCormick, a broker with the Douglas Elliman-Van Riper real estate agency in Manhasset.
"This year it's more likely to be four new listings and two re-inspects," she added, referring to houses that for one reason or another were withdrawn from the market and are being relisted.
Bob Ceilly, a broker with the Eric G. Ramsay Jr., real estate agency in Bay Shore, attributed the reduction in inventory to a spurt in sales.
Inventory is down, Mr. Ceilly said, because sellers who have had their houses on the market over an extended period of time decided to come down to a more realistic figure and were able to sell. "As a result, the stock has been depleted," he said.
But shortages appear to be occurring only in select areas.
David Lurie, owner of Lurie Realty in Great Neck, for example, said he had more buyers, but also plenty of houses to show.
Ray Manzoni, owner of the ERA Manzoni agency in Mount Sinai, also noted that he had a "good supply" of houses and a "good balance" between people who were looking and serious sellers.
Wall Street profits are strengthening sales in the Hamptons. "It's a good healthy marketplace right now," said Jack Hangen, owner of Agawam Realty in Southampton and president of the Eastern Suffolk Chapter of the Long Island Board of Realtors.
"Prices are moving up 5 to 8 percent over last year, but they're not spiking up," he said.
Interviews with sellers and buyers indicate that worries over difficulties in selling a house or, from a buyer's perspective, that house values might still go down, are largely over.
"We knew Jericho is in great demand because of the location and because of the schools," said Rosa Taranto, who with her husband, Joseph, recently signed a contract to sell their four-bedroom colonial in Jericho. He is a plant manager in New Jersey, she works as an executive secretary in Manhattan. They are moving to Paramus to be closer to Mr. Taranto's job.
They listed the house with ERA Gatewood in Syosset and had an offer within a week, Mrs. Taranto said. They paid $380,000 for their Jericho house in 1994. Their asking price was $429,000 and they accepted an offer for $410,000.
Schools remain an important factor in attracting buyers from New York City. Valery Shubov, a commercial property manager, and his wife, Valentina, will be closing this June on a three-bedroom ranch in Jericho, moving there from Brooklyn.
They are paying $275,000 for the house, which they found through the ERA Gatewood agency. "My decision was driven by the reputation of the school district," Mr. Shubov said.
Debra and James Murphy, who are first-time buyers, closed on a colonial in Miller Place on Feb. 26, paying $150,000 for the three-bedroom house with a pool on half an acre. They had been renting a one-bedroom apartment in Farmingdale for five years, paying $800 a month.
They decided it was time to buy a house "for tax reasons" and because interest rates are still relatively low "and may go up," said Mrs. Murphy, who works as a customer-service representative for a musical instrument company. Her husband is a New York City fireman.
Linda Albo, owner of the ERA Albo Agency in Rocky Point, the real estate agency that negotiated the sale, said that sales in her area -- Mount Sinai to Wading River -- had been active because of the good mortgage products available for first-time buyers. With rents in short supply and very high "people have come to the conclusion they might as well buy," she said.
A year ago, the average time on market for a house in her area was 100 days. Now it is down to 74 days, she said.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
New Stores Raise Northern Boulevard's Profile

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
SHOPPING-CENTER developers love to fly. When they fly over central Queens and Brooklyn, they perceive in an instant what a research firm will later confirm in a study: In relation to the density of population, there is a shortage of the large modern supermarkets and big stores that shoppers find in the suburbs.
A push is on to correct this situation, even in the face of New York City's unusually restrictive zoning system and local resistance to the City Planning Commission's recent efforts to make more retail development "as of right" on land zoned for manufacturing. 
 Along Northern Boulevard in Queens that push is succeeding, most strikingly of late on a stretch that runs through Long Island City and Woodside, just north of Sunnyside. Large tracts of underutilized land with obsolete industrial buildings have given way to new retail uses, normally with a special permit from the City Planning Commission. The land is zoned for light manufacturing.
Major redevelopment began six years ago with a shopping center that features Pergament and Toys "R" Us stores. Since then a new Pathmark has arrived, OfficeMax has become the anchor of a strip shopping center, and Sports Authority, Staples and Tops Appliances have opened free-standing stores.
Now the most ambitious project of all, The Shops at Northern Boulevard, is in construction. It is a $40 million project, with a building of 220,000 gross square feet of space on a ground floor and second level, plus roof parking for 630 cars. It will house a 63,000-square-foot Edwards supermarket, a 34,000-square-foot Marshalls clothing store, an 18,000-square-foot Kids "R" Us store, and a 32,000-square-foot Creativity arts and crafts store. The project replaces a Gallo Wine distribution warehouse that was on the five-acre site.
Since parking is on the roof, the building can fill almost the entire lot, with stores entered directly from the sidewalk on 48th Street and on Northern Boulevard. The facade materials will be brick and glass, with brick-colored stucco used for the upper half.
The developer is Forest City Ratner, the Brooklyn-based company that built Metrotech, the downtown Brooklyn office complex, and Atlantic Center, with 400,000 square feet of retail space and parking for 600 cars at Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues, also in downtown Brooklyn. Forest City is now New York's most active retail developer outside Manhattan.
"Our business plan is to do 700,000 square feet of retail space a year over the next three or four years -- about $150 million in development a year," said Bruce Ratner, president. Mr. Ratner is a former New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, a position that he says made him acutely aware of a need for better supermarket service in many city neighborhoods.
In contrast to attitudes toward big-box development elsewhere, local businesses seem pleased by the new Northern Boulevard projects.
"We welcome new development on Northern Boulevard -- it will enhance the entire region," said Tony Barsamian, chairman of the Steinway Street Business Improvement District and publisher of the West Queens Gazette, a weekly newspaper. There are 300 businesses on the five-block stretch of Steinway Street in Astoria running from 28th Avenue to 35th Avenue. Besides many mom-and-pops, there is a Gap, a Nobody Beats the Wiz, and other newer magnet stores.
The Steinway Street owners are even planning to operate a shuttle bus that will take shoppers from Northern Boulevard to their own locale. They expect regional shoppers -- including many on weekends from the East Side of Manhattan --to be drawn to Northern Boulevard, and from there to neighborhood shops and ethnic restaurants on Steinway Street.
As for Forest City Ratner, it has emerged as the only commercial developer operating outside Manhattan that is currently showing the interest and capacity to take on a lengthy and uncertain pre-construction development process. Its competitors are the major users -- Home Depot or Costco as examples -- that seek out and develop large sites for themselves. The large users have one advantage: they don't have to make an investment profit on the real estate.
Users do take risks, however. Kmart is reported to have paid about $18 million for the Northern Boulevard site it later decided it could not develop, and now wants to sell. The cost of carrying it unused has increased its investment. Whether it will recoup that investment in a sale is unclear.
O UR problem is not in finding tenants -- we can lease everything we can build," Mr. Ratner said. "The problem is to find decent-sized sites where we'll be allowed to build. We are not so much retail developers as we are site finders and entitlers." As an entitler, it must be capable of winning local and city approval for development.
According to Sandeep Mathrani, director of retail development for Forest City Ratner, there are no more than 20 locations on main streets in Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Staten Island that are appropriate for major retail development, irrespective of how they are zoned. Forest City itself is "working" on 17 sites -- sites it does not own but could purchase if there were reason to believe they could be rezoned. Only five sites that are already zoned for commercial use are appropriate for a modern shopping center of 100,000 square feet or more, Mr. Mathrani said.
Forest City has other centers in construction besides The Shops at Northern Boulevard. In Maspeth, Queens, it is building a 100,000-square-foot neighborhood shopping center on Grand Avenue, anchored by a 52,000-square-foot Edwards supermarket. And in the New Springville section of Staten Island, near the Staten Island Mall, it is in contract to build a 77,000-square-foot center anchored by Circuit City, an electronics chain based in Richmond, Va.
The big-box tenants usually have to be willing to accept ratios of parking space to operating space far smaller than they are accustomed to on suburban sites. "It's not easy to persuade the big-box retailers to go into these sites when they have to make concessions to their prototype," said Peter T. Ripka, president of Ripco Real Estate Corporation, in Jericho, L.I. Forest City Ratner had a particularly hard sell at Atlantic Center in Brooklyn, which has exceptional access to mass transportation. It has a ratio of 1.5 parking spaces per 1,000 square feet of shopping center.
The typical suburban ratio is about 5 parking spaces for each 1,000 square feet of shopping. In Queens, users have been willing to accept ratios of 2.5 to 3 cars per 1,000 gross square feet of space.
ON Northern Boulevard, with 630 spaces, there will be a 2.85 ratio at the Forest City project. Customers will drive up one of two ramps, and proceed to the stores via elevators large enough to accept six customers with shopping carts.
An even bigger issue for tenants is the need to to attract an exceptional amount of business to justify the cost of operating in the city. Mr. Ratner said that discount department stores in New York City had to generate sales on a square-foot basis almost double what they are elsewhere in the metropolitan area to justify the rents they must pay for new space. These rents (upwards of $24 a square foot a year for 100,000 square feet of new space) are at least 40 percent higher than are elsewhere, he said.
The Forest City Ratner project will not complete the redevelopment of the block. Next door is the vacant Ronzoni building on 11 acres. The property was sold to Kmart two years ago, but it is now is on the market again, with Home Depot reported to be near a deal. And along 37th Avenue near the railroad tracks, the vacant Weeks Furniture building, only 13 years old, is also on the market, through Lawrence T. Smith, a land broker with Sholom & Zuckerbrot, a Queens brokerage. Weeks Furniture moved to Maspeth in a merger last year.
"Thank heaven for the retail development," said Sanford Zuckerbrot, president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot. "The market would be dead otherwise."

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
The Envelope, Please: A Downtown Makes the Cut for an Award

BYLINE: By JULIE BEGLIN 

 BODY:
Attention, Westfield shoppers: your town is the only New Jersey community to have been named a semi finalist in a competition for the nation's best downtown area. The third annual Great American Main Street Awards -- jointly administered by the National Trust for Historic Preservation and Edward Jones, a St. Louis-based financial services concern -- looked at 92 applicants and named Westfield one of 20 national semifinalists. Five winners, each of which will receive $5,000, will be announced on April 28.
The judges looked for towns that had gathered broad-based community support for their downtown revitalization projects, successfully improved the local economy and preserved important historic buildings, said William McLeod of the National Trust. "Westfield has excellent building stock," he said. "It's an ideal, traditional American town. It has a variety of stores, churches, a fire house, post office, everything." 
 Westfield Main Street, a nonprofit organization that oversees downtown revitalization, submitted the application on behalf of the town's 425 businesses. Michele Picou, program manager of Westfield Main Street, discussed the designation.
Q. What makes Westfield's downtown stand out?
A. I think there's so much going on. It's compact; there are good restaurants, some really unique shops, and it's the only town I know of where there are policemen directing traffic in the streets.
Q. How important are those police officers to the town's character?
A. Violent street crime is not exactly an everyday problem here, but in any downtown a sense of caring and safety by public officials is essential, and I think the fact that these guys are on the street corner reassures people. It's one of the identifying hallmarks in Westfield. I don't know of any other town with this in New Jersey. I think we're it, and I think it's essential.
Q. The award committee made special note of the former Norris Chevrolet building at Central and North Avenues. Why?
A. One of the things we've done with the Westfield Main Street program is a facade renovation incentive program. The maximum grant we give is $2,000, which the store owner or landlord must at least match. In return, our office has input into the design, so we don't end up with a bunch of neons and awful-looking signs. The Norris Chevrolet building, which is now the home of Coldwell Banker Realtors, was being redesigned, and we gave advice on how to retain that Spanish Colonial look the building had, without it looking too hokey. The judges must have liked the slides of that particular project.
Q. What improvements would you like to see?
A. I'm concerned with variety. I would like to see something in home furnishings come in, for instance. I would also like to see more healthy mom-and-pop type operations. I'd like to see some type of gourmet food operation. And I wouldn't mind seeing a brew pub. Also, we plan to get our businesses up on the World Wide Web so we can get the word out.
Q. Can you go too far with these types of improvements?
A. I think there's always a chance of that. One of the things we've never advocated, and never will, is very tight design guidelines. I think it's wrong when a community becomes a theme park, of all Western design or something. I don't think there's too much danger of that in Westfield. People here tend to respect the basic architectural structure of the community. You don't put socks on a rooster, and you don't ignore matching the design to the architecture. We try to encourage tasteful common sense. JULIE BEGLIN

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michele Picou in Westfield, which is a semifinalist in a competition for the nation's best downtown. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business in 31st Year Succeeds in Its Niche

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN a fledgling company loses all its capital after only six weeks in business, what then? "We hung in," recalled Dennis Mehiel, who saw his first venture -- as a subcontractor assembling fiber containers for war materiel -- fail when orders were curtailed during the Vietnam War.
In 1966, Mr. Mehiel and his brother Chris pooled their savings of $8,000 and with an additional $8,000 from a Small Business Administration loan started the Four M Corporation in Baltimore. "We carved out a slot for ourselves in the corrugated packaging industry," Mr. Mehiel said. "Our niche in the market was supplying the corrugated partitions that required hand assembly. We put together a labor force, and business was so good that we invested in cutting machines just before the big orders folded." 
 What followed was a difficult time. "I saw seven years of payments to the S.B.A. facing me when I couldn't even keep up my car payments," Mr. Mehiel said. "Eventually, my car was repossessed. There was a certain irony there, since one of my first jobs was repossessing cars for G.M. Auto Finance. In those days I was working three jobs. That was my night job. By day, I was a bill collector, and on the weekends, I collected coins for a car wash."
Despite the first business failure, Mr. Mehiel said: "We never thought of not being in business. We were still the only interested and reliable supplier of corrugated interior packaging partitions in Baltimore, and our marketing strategy made sense. Big companies didn't want to bother manufacturing corrugated partitions. It was a declining market, but we saw a niche we could fill, supplying partitions to giant companies like Colgate, Procter & Gamble and General Foods, who used lots of them."
This year marks the 31st anniversary of Mr. Mehiel's company, the Four M Corporation, now with headquarters in Valhalla. Together with its two affiliated companies, Box USA and the Fonda Group, Four M is the country's largest independently owned producer of corrugated-box packaging and shipping containers. It is also the country's leading producer of private-label paper cups and plates. Nationwide, 37 factories, with 4,500 employees, contributed to revenues of $900 million last year.
In an industry dominated by large, publicly traded corporations, Mr. Mehiel, an entrepreneur, became a major player by acquiring insolvent companies in the packaging industry.
"By 1980, we realized that we were limiting our growth by concentrating on only one product," he said. "So we started diversifying. In the years from 1984 to 1994, we bought 17 facilities, including box factories, all of them bargains. We borrowed to the hilt and when we started running out of money, we began buying bankrupt businesses from creditors who financed us because we were willing to pay them a higher rate of return than they could get otherwise. Only two of our purchases turned out badly. One we sold; the other is only a partial success." But the company's employment policy can be described as an unequivocal success. Almost all employees who were slated to lose their jobs at their former companies were retained by Four M. New people were added as business increased. And many people once on public assistance found employment.
"We apply a strategic rationale to business," Mr. Mehiel said. "In the communities where we have plants, we are able to save jobs and create new ones through internal growth. By expanding and developing the facilities we acquire, we have opened new markets."
And when larger companies in a kindred field began downsizing, Four M seized the opportunity to expand in another direction, Mr. Mehiel said.
"We managed to pick up small divisions of mega companies and cobble them together, which is how we developed the Fonda Group," he said. "For instance, when Scott Paper downsized its $70 million paper napkin-paper cup division employing 500 people, we bought it and stitched it together with other acquisitions of ours in what is known as the 'white business.' Fonda is now the leading producer of private-label paper cups and plates nationwide."
Although Mr. Mehiel and his management teams have been able to increase capacity, and consequently the sales, of all their acquisitions, their record is not flawless.
"There have been disappointments," he said. "For instance, when we acquired 15 box plants from the St. Joe Container Company in Port St. Joe, Fla., last May, we also had to buy the paper mill, which we did in a 50-50 joint venture with Stone Container of Chicago."
Shortly afterward, he said, the price of paper dropped 40 percent, forcing Four M to cease operations at the mill.
"Right now the mill is temporarily shut down, putting about 450 to 500 people out of work," he said. "Certainly detrimental to the local economy, but we intend to secure our asset. We believe in the mill and hope to have it back in operation as soon as is possible."
As a hands-on chief executive officer, Mr. Mehiel recently scheduled breakfast, lunch and dinner meetings with raw-materials vendors, customers and plant managers who were all in town for the American Forest Products Paper Week. "It's our industry's biggest annual event," Mr. Mehiel said, "an opportunity to network and transact business."
Business is only one of his interests. He is the founder of All the Way, a multimillion-dollar, year-round educational program for youngsters who live in large cities. It begins in kindergarten and continues through college. And, as a longtime resident of Armonk, Mr. Mehiel said he has been active in charities, in the Democratic Party and as a member of many boards.
When asked what influenced his outside activities, he said: "It's in the nature of a giveback. One of my grandfathers was a janitor, the other an elevator operator. Our family has prospered. I've done well in my life so I look for opportunities to recycle the American dream for other families."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis Mehiel, center, of Four M Corporation based in Valhalla, at a meeting in Manhattan. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Rising Interest Foreseen in High-End Houses

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
PHILIP ADLER was amazed recently when a center-hall colonial he was building on a small waterfront lot in Rye sold for the asking price of $1.1 million.
"We were putting in the foundation when it sold," said Mr. Adler, managing director of North American Properties Group, of Stamford, Conn. "We were surprised it sold so soon, and without the buyer being able to even see the house." 
 Also surprising, he said, was the fact that it went for the asking price, since it's a "rather modest house," with 3,200 square feet on less than one-third of an acre.
"I think it speaks to how few vacant lots are left in a place like Rye," Mr. Adler said, "especially on the water."
According to brokers and builders throughout the county, there are some indications of an increased demand for certain properties in very desirable locations, which may place an upward pressure on prices.
Diane Guarino, branch manager of Houlihan/Lawrence's office in Larchmont, said she could almost predict which listing will immediately generate a bidding war.
"In our area," Ms. Guarino said, "young couples will bid on a house that's priced appropriately and in good condition."
She cited one recent example of a house that attracted multiple bids -- a 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath colonial in Larchmont that was listed in the high $600,000's and sold for $60,000 above the asking price.
"It was in a real white-picket-fence neighborhood," Ms. Guarino said. "It had a terrace and a study, all the bells and whistles people look for."
Brokers expect more multiple bids on single properties in 1997, and a rising interest in the higher end of the market. "Our market is tied to the stock market," said Ebie Wood, Houlihan/Lawrence's regional manager for central Westchester. "We're so close to Manhattan. A lot of young couples have gotten good bonuses. They now have the money to buy the house they want."
Merritt Mitchell, owner of Merritt Associates, a real estate brokerage concern with offices in Larchmont, Scarsdale and Rye, said that while he had not seen much price appreciation in his market, the improved economy has created a more upbeat atmosphere in general.
A FTER schlepping along in the early 90's, people seem to be more enthusiastic now," Mr. Mitchell said. "They're finding more money in their coffers. But they're still looking for value. It's still crucial for sellers to price their homes properly. Then they might be in a position to generate multiple offers. If a house is overpriced, no one will even come look at it."
Westchester entered 1997 after having had a record-breaking sales year in 1996, posting 7,576 residential sales, including co-ops and condominiums, amounting to nearly $2.3 billion in total value, according to the annual report of the Westchester Board of Realtors. That represented a 7 percent increase above the previous record of 7,076 sales set in 1994.
Sales have been so good, in fact, that many brokers are now complaining about low inventory, which they hope will be replenished by spring.
"Overall there's a shortage of listings," Mr. Mitchell said. "But people tend to get their houses on the market by mid-April, so we're expecting it to get better soon."
In 1996, inventory dropped to 7,568, which was 13 percent less than the 8,657 in 1995. "There is a possibility that relative spot shortages in certain price ranges and locations could generate price increases in excess of inflation," according to P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors.
The median sale price for a single-family house in Westchester last year was $285,000, just 1.8 percent ahead of 1995 and 3 percent above 1994. "Now we're just seeing increases based on inflation," Mr. Mercurio said. "In fact, the recovery of Westchester's real estate market is due in large part to the stability in prices. It's enabled more buyers to enter the market."
While house prices are stable, the price of individual building lots has seen a "definite appreciation," according to Mr. Adler. "I've seen increases of 10 to 15 percent for approved and improved building lots for single-family homes," he said.
At a development called the Pinnacle at Purchase, Mr. Adler said, there was a bidding war for a one-acre lot at the site. "We were asking $320,000 for the lot and it sold for $325,000," Mr. Adler said. "Last fall, these same lots were selling for $275,000 to $285,000."
Some builders of single-family homes are taking advantage of a greater demand for new construction by increasing prices beyond inflationary levels.
Mitchell C. Hochberg, president of Spectrum/Skanska, a residential builder based in Valhalla, has raised prices 5 to 10 percent at the Highlands at Riverwoods, a 148-unit single-family-home project in New Castle. When Mr. Hochberg began to market his project in 1995, prices for the 2- to 3-bedroom houses were in the high $300,000's to low $400,000's, he said.
"Now in the third phase, we're raising prices to start in the mid-$400,000's to mid-$500,000's," he said. "Normally we raise prices phase by phase. But it depends on how well a project is doing. I like to base any price increase on sales velocity."
Overall Mr. Hochberg senses that the market in Westchester is strong, but has "no significant room for price increases," he said. "Just a little bit of room."
TOLL BROTHERS, based in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., is now building 222 new homes in the county, and in the approval process for 183 more. Most of the company's developments fall into the $450,000 to $500,000 price range.
It is planning modest price increases this year of 2 to 3 percent, according to Robert Parahus, a Toll vice president. "We're increasing prices to keep pace with inflation," Mr. Parahus said. "Since sales at all our developments continue to be strong, we think they can absorb the higher prices."
The lower end of the market is much more price sensitive, according to Martin Ginsburg, president of Ginsburg Development Corporation, of Hawthrone, which in recent years has concentrated on building in the $225,000 to $350,000 price range.
"With land prices rising, and limited land resources available," Mr. Ginsburg said, "we may have to reinvent the way we do things in order to continue to offer moderate-priced housing. We may have to work closer to our margins."
By necessity, Mr. Ginsburg said, his company will probably diversify this year or next by moving toward the higher end of the market, with houses in the $400,000 to $500,000 range.
"It's a very competitive market right now," Mr. Ginsburg said. "A lot of builders are doing well at that price range. But regardless of what price you're building, buyers are still extremely price sensitive. They want good solid value. And if builders don't provide that, they won't succeed at any price level."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mitchell Hochberg, president of Spectrum/Skanska, at the Highlands at Riverwoods in New Castle. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

EVOCATIVE PAINTINGS
Peter Lampke's large, evocative oil paintings will be on view at the Schoolhouse Gallery in Croton Falls until April 6. 
 His forte is placing people in situations that can be interpreted in many ways. Why would a man be standing stolidly next to train tracks under an umbrella in the rain, with a train passing behind him? The picture's caption indicates that he has just been divorced.
Another painting depicts three men lying on a beach either unaware or unperturbed by the ocean surging toward them a few inches away. In still another picture a boy enters a room where his father is at the window looking through binoculars at . . . at what?
Gallery hours are Wednesdays through Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. For directions or more information, call 277-3461.
 
PIANO RECITAL
The pianist Masanobu Ikemiya is equally at home with the classics, for which he was trained, and ragtime, to which he is dedicated. He will give a recital today at 2 P.M. at Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, performing the music of Gershwin, Joplin, Brahms and Schumann and David Blake,
Mr. Ikemiya founded the New York Ragtime Orchestra in Manhattan and has presented his musically diverse repertory in Russia, Canada, Mexico, Argentina, Bulgaria, Portugal, India and various countries of Asia as well as the United States. Tickets at $12 include admission to the gardens and landscaped grounds of Wave Hill at 675 West 252d Street. Call (718) 549-3200 for directions.
 
SKATING BENEFIT
Performances by world champion figure skaters, including Jo Jo Starbuck, will be featured at the first Starlight, Starbright Skating Extravaganza on Thursday at the Westchester Skating Academy at 91 Fairview Park Drive in Elmsford.
The event, from 7 to 9 P.M., will also include amateur figure-skating performances and a raffle of sports memorabilia, including items signed by the New York Rangers. Proceeds will benefit the Starlight Foundation, a nonprofit organization that helps children ages 4 to 18 who are critically, chronically or terminally ill.
General admission tickets are $10, and V.I.P. tickets, which include reserved observation deck seats and refreshments, are $50. Tickets are available at the Westchester Skating Academy or by calling 347-8232.

HUNGER BANQUET
For the last decade Manhattanville College in Purchase has organized a Hunger Banquet to call attention to the estimated billion people in the world who are chronically underfed. According to the college staff, the reason is not lack of food but the unequal distribution of resources.
This year's banquet on Tuesday at 7 P.M. will benefit Oxfam America, and it will include a presentation on "Why World Hunger?" by Geoffrey Martin, a professor of economic geography at Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven. Folk music will be provided by the Don Richards Band.
Admission will be by a minimum donation of $25, and guests will draw lots for seating in one of three groups. Group One, made up of 15 percent of the diners, will be served a gourmet meal. Group Two, or 25 percent of the remaining guests, will have a meal of rice and beans. The final 60 percent in Group Three will be served rice and water. The banquet is to be held in Reid Castle on the campus at 2900 Purchase Street. Call 694-3425 for reservations.

HOLOCAUST SCROLLS
Dan Regan, a photographer who developed a process that produces what he calls photographic sculpture, has created a six-foot, three-dimensional work on three scrolls, depicting the plight of Holocaust victims.
Entitled "Scrolls of Remembrance," it is linked to recorded chants, and it may be seen in a preview exhibition at the Rockland Center for Holocaust Studies in Spring Valley through April 10. It will then tour five cities in the United States through the rest of the year and embark on a world tour next year. The center, at 17 South Madison Avenue, is open Sundays through Thursdays from noon to 4 P.M. Call 356-2700 for more information.
 
FOUR ART SHOWS
Four exhibitions at the Center for Curatorial Studies Museum at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson display the innovative quality of the college's master's degree program and of the four second-year students who organized the show.
Virgilio Garza, former head of research and development and curator at the Museo de Monterrey, Mexico, from 1991 to 1995, chose to combine the work of Roni Horn and Gabriel Orozco, the former focused on forbidding Icelandic landscapes, the latter on the human concerns of urban life. He calls the result "Sleight of Mind/ The Angle of Landscape."
Melissa Hiller came to the center from an internship at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, organizing an exhibition titled "Unfolding Memory -- Embodying History." It consists of 10 large-scale paintings by Hung Liu, in which the artist interpreted photographs of the tumultuous period in China before the Communist Revolution.
"Picturing," small installations of architectural models imbued with imaginative and humorous overtones, were executed by Kim Adams, Michael Ashkin and Steven Brower, curated by Tomas Pospiszyl, a writer and curator from Prague. Concurrently working on a public art project in Prague, he was the gallery manager for Prague Castle, the office of the President of the Czech Republic.
The fourth exhibition, called "Coda," is the work of four photographers who manipulate color, focus and composition to their own ends. Cityscapes by Uta Barth, museum interiors by Carolien Stikker, architectural studies by Jack Pierson and Modernist architectural icons by Gunther Forg were curated by Brian Wallace. Mr. Wallace is a former media arts developer at the Computer Museum in Boston and a former assistant curator for the advancement of science in art at Cooper Union in Manhattan. The exhibition is open to the public free of charge Wednesdays through Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M. For more information, call 758-7598. ELEANOR CHARLES
