HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Big Deals -- Maybe;
Behind the Buzz, Possibilities Waiting to Happen

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THERE is a buzz in the air. Deals may be in the offing. Big companies seek large blocks of office space in midtown Manhattan as the market begins to tighten for the first time in this decade.
As the deal makers are eager to complete their deals, developers are watching carefully, hoping the lack of suitable existing space will impel companies with large space needs and solid credit to sign up as the anchor tenants for new buildings whose construction has been on hold for years. 
 "I've been talking to sophisticated people who have lived through several cycles and they say this is as active a market as they have seen," said Kenneth M. Krasnow, director of business development at Cushman & Wakefield.
Although the companies seen as being in the market for large hunks of space do not advertise their intentions, it is well known in industry circles which companies are looking for new homes and how much space they want. One of the biggest prospective deals involves the investment banking firm of Bear Stearns & Company, which is said to be looking for as much as 1.2 million square feet for its trading floors and offices.
The company is under pressure to find a replacement for its quarters at 245 Park Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets, where its lease expires in 2002. The building is in need of renovations and company executives have said it would be too disruptive to move around the Park Avenue building as the floors are refurbished. William J. Montgoris, the company's chief operating officer said he expected that a decision would be made by the end of the year.
Another is Reuters America, the United States arm of the British-based news and financial information company, which is said to be looking for up to 800,000 square feet to consolidate operations that are now scattered in four major locations around the city. "Reuters America has been exploring its options in the real estate market in New York City and its environs," said Robert Crooke, the company's vice president for media relations.
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield is reported to be considering selling its building at 622 Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets and relocating in 700,000 to 800,000 square feet of cheaper space downtown. The change may be driven by economics, despite having to give up the convenience of a midtown location.
The building, like many in midtown, has increased considerably in value over the last few years, while the city is offering incentives for companies to move to downtown, which has had a large amount of vacant space. A spokesman for Empire said the company was evaluating its real estate options, but that no decisions had been made.
Standard & Poor's division of McGraw-Hill, now at 25 Broadway, is said to be looking for 700,000 square feet of space, which it may split between New York and New Jersey. A spokesman for McGraw-Hill said the company continuously reviews its space needs, but would not comment directly about Standard & Poor's plans.
And Citibank, reportedly looking for 800,000 square feet of space, is said to be considering shifting some of its operations from New York to New Jersey. John M. Morris, a spokesman for the bank and its parent Citicorp, said the company "is in the market on a continuous basis, but we do not have anything we want to announce at this time."
"With an operation of our size we are always surveying what is available to meet our needs," he added.
Other possible seekers of large amounts of space include the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, Grey Advertising, and the Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison law firm, brokers say.
One deal that is off the front burner involves the investment firm of Morgan Stanley, which had been reported to be looking for 400,000 square feet. In the wake of its announced merger with Dean Witter, the securities firm, the company is said to be re-evaluating its real estate needs.
WHILE it is possible that Bear Stearns might ultimately decide to remain on Park Avenue and that none of the other transactions will come to pass, brokers say the reports are more than rumors. "These people are actively shopping the market," Mr. Krasnow of Cushman & Wakefield said. "They have hired representatives and they are spending time and money on searches."
With, as Bruce Mosler of Cushman & Wakefield puts it, "nine million square feet of tenants looking at four million square feet of space," it is likely that some will be unable to find what they need in existing buildings. Brokers say this is especially likely for banking companies, which need large, open floors with the latest in power and communications for trading rooms.
"In the top 65 buildings in midtown, the vacancy rate is 3 percent," said Steven A. Swerdlow, manager of CB Commercial's offices in the New York region. "The upper end of the market is very tight and big blocks of space are scarce."
That scarcity may drive a big tenant into the arms of a developer in a new building project. After the excesses of the 80's, developers are not likely to get financing for a new building without a top-quality tenant signed up for a large part of the space.
New construction means a delay of several years while the structure is built, but it can be customized for tenant's needs.
Since there are so few available building sites in midtown, the same sites are discussed over and again. According to industry executives, five sites are the most likely for new construction: the three remaining in Times Square, on the northwest, southwest and southeast corners of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue; 383 Madison, the blockfront between 46th and 47th Streets that has been vacant for almost 10 years, and an empty lot on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets that is usually called Rock West because of its links to Rockefeller Center.
Because of the success of the first office building in Times Square, which is being developed by the Durst Organization and was almost fully rented before excavation was completed, many in the industry say development will happen there first. Last week, executives of the Prudential Insurance Company, which controls the Times Square sites, said development rights to all three were for sale.
"The next buildings will almost certainly be in Times Square because the subsidy is worth $5 to $7 a square foot," said Andrew Roos of the Williams Real Estate Company, referring to tax breaks intended to spur redevelopment. "They will be developed before 383 Madison or Rock West."
Subsidy or not, Times Square has become an attractive area to be in, said Jeffrey Katz, the president of Sherwood Equities, which manages the triangular building at 1 Times Square that will house a Warner Brothers Studio Store.
"Times Square is more popular than Third Avenue now, and that would have been unthinkable three years ago," he said.
Douglas Durst, the president of the Durst Organization, acknowledged that he was interested in developing another office tower at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue.
The building at 383 Madison has been snarled in an ownership dispute and an extended struggle over whether a new building on the site could take advantage of the air rights over Grand Central Terminal, which is three blocks away.
Nevertheless, brokers say the site's proximity to the station helps make it an attractive location for development.
The Rock West site was assembled and cleared in the 80's, but became a parking lot when the collapse in real estate values made building impossible. It went with the company that controls the four buildings on the west side of Sixth Avenue when the Rockefeller holdings were divided last year.
Jonathan D. Green, president of Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, acknowledged that the company had been talking to prospective tenants and was prepared to redesign and re-permit a project that had completed the process in the 80's. "The market is demanding bigger, bulkier floors, and we will redesign to accommodate the right tenant," he said.
He said no deal to develop the site was imminent, but added that he expected one to be concluded by the end of the year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A likely site for demolition and new construction, industry executives say, is 383 Madison Avenue, vacant for almost 10 years. The blockfront site, between West 46th and 47th Streets, is attractive because of its proximity to Grand Central Terminal. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: South Jamaica Innovator;
A Library Mindful of Light's Uses

 BODY:
The new one-story South Jamaica Library to be completed at 108-41 Guy R. Brewer Boulevard in two years has been designed to use natural light in ways that will please library users as well as environmentalists and the city's accountants.
Innovations in the $2.2 million energy-efficient, environmentally responsive library will help the New York City Department of Design and Construction develop higher environmental performance standards in public renovation and new construction projects citywide, according to a department spokesman. 
 "We are projecting using about one-third less heating energy than a conventional building," said Carl Stein, partner of The Stein Partnership, which designed it.
Sunlight will enter the brick, glass and concrete building through three skylights, or clerestories. It will be softened by reflector diffusers and filtered by solar shades.
"As the the sun comes out, electric lights will dim gradually," said Mr. Stein. "As sunlight levels drop late in the day or during a sudden storm, the lights will brought back on automatically."
The 7,500-square-foot library will offer 75,000 volumes, at least 10 computers for public-use and after-school programs for children.
Passers-by will be able to look inside through a large glass-curtain wall.
"We are part of an urban renewal initiative for the South Jamaica community," said Robert J. Waters director of engineering, facilities planning for the Queens Borough Public Library System.
The new library will rise three blocks south of York College and two blocks north of the existing library, which now rents space in a church-owned building.

HEADLINE: For Region's Housing, a Solid '96

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
LIKE a wanting child longing for a hug, the New York metropolitan region's residential real estate market enjoyed an uplifting squeeze last year, with welcome pressure from the city's robust housing market and the nation's healthy economy helping to turn 1996 into one of the best years in a quarter of a century.
A year ago, housing scholars and institutionally-optimistic industry representatives were using such terms as "sluggish" and "muddled" to describe the market. And with fears of downsizing casting a cloud over consumer confidence, several observers predicted that 1996 would see "further uncertainty" with the market "in a stall, rather than a dive." 
 All proving that prognostication is a perilous exercise.
In fact, 1996 turned in a solid performance. All 11 counties in the suburban ring around New York City enjoyed increased sales in 1996. And of the 426 ZIP-code areas in those counties, 364 registered price appreciation, while only 62 showed price depreciation.
"Most economists were surprised how strongly the national economy performed in 1996," said James Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "That powerful national momentum filtered down to the region."
At the same time, Dr. Hughes said: "New York City had a particularly strong performance, led by Wall Street. The huge bull market is having a major positive effect on the regional economy, which translates into house sales."
That was apparent in data for the suburban ring.
For example, single-family home sales in Westchester, according to the county's Board of Realtors, increased to 5,211 last year, up from 4,561 in 1995, with median prices increasing by 1.8 percent to $285,000. In Nassau, according to the Long Island Board of Realtors, the increase in home sales was 7.8 percent, up from 6,792 in 1995 to 7,319 last year. In Fairfield County, statistics provided by The Commercial Record, a business weekly, showed that the number of single-family homes and condos sold last year was 16,177, up 6.2 percent from 1995; and the median price in 1996 was $197,000, up 4.8 percent from '95.
And in New Jersey, according to statistics from the New Jersey Association of Realtors, single-family home sales rose from 138,300 in 1995 to 147,800 last year -- a 6.9 percent jump, while median prices increased 3.9 percent, from $148,000 to $153,800.
Among the thousands of housing nomads in the region last year were Tim Esperto, an accountant, and his wife, Irene, a bank manager, who just wanted to get out of the third-floor walk-up they were renting in Baldwin, L.I. They both work in Manhattan.
After 40 house viewings, the Espertos moved last May into a four-bedroom colonial in Cranford, N.J. They paid $235,000. "The price was not much of a problem," Mr. Esperto said, "maybe a little more than what we had in mind."
But other factors overrode price considerations. One was that "although the commute is almost the same, Long Island traffic is out of control," Mr. Esperto said. Another was that "it's closer to Staten Island, where my wife's family lives."
Of such mundane concerns are individual deals done. But broad market trends are the stuff of large, synergistic forces. Among those forces spurring the regional market last year were substantial job growth, low and stable mortgage rates of about 7.5 percent, the housing demands of the baby-boom generation, Wall Street's bull market and relaxation of fears about downsizing.
John L. Weiting, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, cited "a strong pickup" in job growth regionally as a potent element in the resurgence of real estate -- with calmed fears of downsizing as the key underlying factor.
NEW YORK, New Jersey and Connecticut added 167,400 private-sector jobs, Mr. Weiting pointed out, up from 10,883,000 at the end of '95 to 11,050,000 at the end of '96 -- a 1.2 percent rise.
"Downsizing wasn't as severe as originally feared," Commissioner Weiting said. In particular, AT&T in New Jersey did not lay off as many people as it had announced, he said, " and they've also been doing some hiring."
Arthur Zabarkes, dean of New York University's Real Estate Institute, concurred: "Telecommunications reconfigured, and some of the big old-timers, AT&T being the most notable, declined in market share. But meanwhile, the industry as a whole expanded significantly, so people found jobs" -- primarily in the so-called "new media" industry that is burgeoning in downtown Manhattan and significantly contributing to the city's economy.
That phenomenon illustrates the mix of ingredients in the regional real estate brew. Just as national factors exert their effects on the tri-state area, the effects of what happens in the region churn through the city and, obviously, vice versa.
A particularly powerful force at work in the regional market has been the record profits on Wall Street and, more specifically, the historic highs in year-end bonuses for the 150,000 workers in the financial industry.
A recent report by the New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said that while the year-end bonuses of 1995 had pumped $6.1 billion into the region last year, the bonuses handed out at the end of last year would leap to $8.1 billion this year -- with individual bonuses ranging from $10 million and more for the biggest winners to a few thousand dollars for clerks.
Those fistfuls of cash stir up a wave of sales throughout the region: luxurious co-ops, condos and lofts in Manhattan, brownstones in Brooklyn, single-family homes of all sizes and types throughout the boroughs and the suburban ring, summer homes in the Hamptons and even farther.
"Certainly the engine of New York City is felt all the way through New Jersey into the contiguous Pennsylvania counties," said Susan Wachter, a professor of real estate economics at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business. "Bucks County is the fastest growing county in Pennsylvania, in terms of population."
KarenAnn Covais-Orlando and her husband, David Orlando, both work for Wall Street companies -- she as assistant to the managing director of KSH Investment, a new brokerage firm, he as an equity trader for Paine Webber.
Ms. Covais-Orlando got a $10,000 raise when she agreed to move with her old boss after he started the company last year. Mr. Orlando received a bonus from Paine Webber, the size of which he is keeping private.
THREE weeks ago, the couple moved from an apartment in Whitestone, Queens, to a four-bedroom, high ranch in East Northport on Suffolk County's North Shore. "No, not near the water," Ms. Covais-Orlando said. "The bonus was good, but not that good.
"But we were able to get half an acre with a built-in pool. And it has a brand new kitchen, a gorgeous kitchen, and that's what sold me." The couple paid $212,000.
"It's not that the bonus made it possible," Ms. Covais-Orlando said, "but it helped so that we weren't crunched at the closing."
Whatever the yearly bonus boost to the housing market, it has been sales of single-family homes to baby boomers that have steadily fueled the suburban market. "This decade has been a continuation of the baby-boom hegemony, with single-family units at the metropoltian ring the leading edge of growth," said Dr. Hughes of Rutgers. "They are now the second-time buyers, and their children are going for starter homes."
"The people who built the housing in the suburbs 50 years ago are at a stage where they are selling those homes and trading up or building," Dr. Hughes said. "And now they are selling to some of the X-generation, the ones who are now married and thinking of having a family.
"It's the circle of housing."
As evidence, Dr. Hughes cited data on housing starts in New Jersey, the state he most closely watches. "We have had, through the 90's, record shares of new construction in the single-family sector, as opposed to multi-family," he said. "The share has averaged more than 85 percent for the decade," while, over the last 35 years, the single-family sector has averaged only 60 percent. "It indicates the sheer impact of the baby boomers on the market."
DEAN ZABARKES at N.Y.U. both concurred and demurred: "Yes, the increased demand by the baby boomers explains a great deal about new construction. But I suggest we not lose sight of the fact that real estate is driven as much by the money train as by demand."
Stretching a phrase made famous by filmdom's evocation of a baseball field in the boondocks, Dean Zabarkes said, "Where financing is available, people will build and people will come."
Since the housing market collapse of the early 90's, he said, "We've seen a gush of money heading toward real estate." And as the statistics from so many communities in the region indicate, they have come.
Pointing to a 14.3 percent jump in sales for the state last year, the executive vice president of the New York State Association of Realtors, Charles M. Staro, attributed the gains, in large part, to "the lack of any major fluctuations in interest, which makes mortgages that much more attainable.
"You don't see those big spikes and the craziness of the market," he said, "which boosts consumer confidence."
But Mr. Staro also said that part of the credit goes to the state government, which, under Republican control, he said, has evinced a "much more friendly attitude toward business." He specifically cited the repeal last year of the so-called Cuomo tax -- a 10 percent surcharge on the capital gain on property sold for over $1 million.
"The removal of that onerous tax has spurred development, construction and renovation of existing apartments, shopping centers and businesses in general," Mr. Staro said. "People are willing to put the money into property knowing that if it were sold they would not have to share their gain with the state."
The effect of those factors, among others, was to spur the market, Mr. Staro said.
In Suffolk County, for example, the New York State Association of Realtors reported a 12.2 percent jump in sales volume, from 8,812 in 1995 to 9,885 last year. And median prices in the county increased from $134,000 at the end of 1995 to $137,000 last December -- a 2.5 percent increase.
Those trends were confirmed by an alternative measure of the market -- the repeat-sale survey by Case Schiller Weiss, a real estate statistics firm in Cambridge, Mass.
Case Shiller Weiss has devised an index to track fluctuations in price. The survey is based on a table showing the average price of all single-family homes sold in ZIP-code areas, year by year. To determine price fluctuations in 1996, for example, the survey took the purchase price of each home sold in each ZIP-code area during the year just ended, compared it to the price that the house brought the last time it was sold, and then, using the annual index, adjusted the earlier purchase price to what it likely would have been had it sold in 1996.
Of the 80 ZIP codes in Suffolk, only 6 showed price depreciation, while 74 experienced appreciation.
IN Nassau County, where sales volume jumped 7.8 percent last year, median prices increased from $168,300 in December 1995 to $175,000 at the end of 1996. And, according to Case Shiller, all 63 ZIP codes in Nassau experienced price appreciation.
John Juliano, a broker in the East Meadow office of Prudential Long Island Realty, doesn't need the numbers to know "it's been real strong."
The local economy "seems to be solid," Mr. Juliano said. "No big companies, but you can see that they are building hotels, shopping centers, a lot of commercial building" -- all creating new jobs.
"For a long time," Mr. Juliano continued, "people were afraid of losing their jobs; now they are working overtime and are able to take on a bigger monthly payment."
And the buyers are sticking close to home. "There was a time when 80 percent of our buyers came from Queens," Mr. Juliano said. "Now it's only 20 percent. People are staying on Long Island."
Jack MacCarthy, a systems technician for Chase Manhattan, is one of those homebodies. Along with his sister, Mr. MacCarthy owned a small Cape Cod in Levittown, next door to their parents.
WHEN he and his bride, Andrea, got married last August and bought a four-bedroom Levitt ranch for $160,000, it was in Hicksville -- three miles away. "I just like the area," Mr. MacCarthy said.
In Westchester, according to the county Association of Realtors, there were 5,211 single-family home sales last year, a 14.3 percent increase over the 4,561 sales in 1995. And prices rose from an average of $284,650 in '95 to $289,850 last year, a 1.8 percent increase.
Of the 64 ZIP codes in Westchester, according to the Case Shiller survey, 8 experienced depreciation and 56 appreciated. Those numbers indicated a significant turnaround from 1995 when 31 ZIP codes experienced depreciation -- all of them across the northern tier of the county.
For Fairfield County -- where The Commercial Record survey indicated a 6.2 percent increase in sales, from 15,233 to 16,177, and a median price rise of 4.8 percent, from $188,000 to $197,000 -- the Case Schiller survey showed that 39 of the 45 ZIP codes appreciated.
The New Jersey Association of Realtors calculates its data by separating the state into three regions.
In the northern section (Bergen, Bloomfield, Hudson, Hunterdon, Morris, Passaic, Somerset, Sussex and Warren Counties -- sales volume rose from 55,500 in 1995 to 58,400 in 1996, a 5.2 percent increase, while median prices appreciated by 4.9 percent, from $188,100 to $197,300.
The central section of New Jersey (Monmouth, Middlesex, Mercer, and Ocean) experienced a 7.8 percent jump in sales, from 45,900 to 49,500. And prices increased 4.1 percent, from $140,200 to $145,900.
AND in the southern region (Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Gloucester and Atlantic), sales jumped 8.4 percent, from 36,900 to 40,000, while prices rose by 2.3 percent, from $106,700 to $109,200.
Of the 283 ZIP-code areas in the 8 counties that comprise New Jersey's piece of the ring around the boroughs of New York City, 234 showed price appreciation last year, with only 36 experiencing depreciation.
As there long has been, said Michael Ford, president of the state realtors' association: "There's a lot of Staten Island and Manhattan buyers coming over to the central-northern section of the state. And we have a great influx of buyers coming out of the Philadelphia area to our southern shore."
"But the push in the market right now," Mr. Ford said, "is the first-time buyer."
Vanessa Van Brunt qualifies.
Officer Van Brunt, 25, a member of the Cranford Police Department for the last 5 years, recently moved out of her parents' home in Cranford into a three-bedroom cape -- across town. "The big break," she called it.
And she used her policing skills in the search.
"Basically, all I do is drive around all night," Officer Van Brunt said. "I probably go into 8 or 9 houses a shift, on calls and reports. Sure, you notice when one has a for-sale sign up. If a house is vacant and it's for sale, it's part of our job to keep an eye on that."
She kept an eye out for a month, perusing 10 homes before going back and buying, for $162,000, the first one.
"I'd miss living in the town I work in," Officer Van Brunt said. "You're not just patrolling any town, it's your own town."

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT;
Can Betting (Though Not Necessarily on Horses) Save the Track?

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
Wally Medio fell in love with horses when he started to win bets he made on them."Before that, I never once rode a horse," he said. "I never much took a look at them until the track opened."
Mr. Medio, 67, of Vineland has been training horses to win at all five New Jersey race tracks since 1970. He said he wasn't sure which he loves more: the horses he has coached to finish-line victories or the spring day he walked into "the track" -- Atlantic City Race Course -- for the first time. 
 "My life began at the track," Mr. Medio said. "Atlantic City's not in the best shape anymore, but I'd still call it the best track for racing horses in the state, and one of the best in the country. To hear the talk about closing Atlantic City and Garden State makes me boil."
What has raised Mr. Medio's temperature is a recommendation this month by State Senator Richard Codey, Democrat of Essex County, to end live horse racing at Atlantic City Race Course and its South Jersey sister, Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, in hopes of improving attendance and betting at the Monmouth, Freehold and Meadowlands race courses. Mr. Codey is one of 19 members of the State Racing Industry Study Commission appointed by Governor Whitman to come up with recommendations to increase gambling revenues at the state's race tracks.
Mr. Codey's recommendation has received cautious approval from James Murphy, Atlantic City Race Course president, because of a provision that would require the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority, the state agency that channels casino revenue to local and state improvement projects, to finance renovations at the two Soth Jersey tracks and essentially keep them open as simulcast betting parlors.
Although the Commission has yet to make a formal report, Mr. Codey's proposal is among the most extreme among what Stanley Pancow, president of the 400-member New Jersey Thoroughbred Breeders Association, based in Bordentown, calls "the trial balloons they've been floating around."
Among the proposals Mr. Pancow mentioned were the addition of simulcast betting at Garden State, NASCAR automobile racing at Atlantic City and slot machines in the grandstands there. "It's too soon to judge how closing the tracks would affect the breeders," Mr. Pancow said. His organization has commissioned an economic impact study of live racing and expects to release his findings this summer.
Overall attendance and gambling at New Jersey's race tracks was declining before legalized casino gambling came to the Boardwalk in 1978. In an effort to keep the Atlantic City Race Course open in winter, when no live races are held, New Jersey voters approved simulcast betting there in 1986. Then Atlantic City Race Course then sold off part of its parking lot for construction of the Hamilton Mall shopping center. In 1991, citing a recessionary economy and increased competition from other gambling meccas, the State Legislature approved simulcast betting in Atlantic City casinos, on the condition that the casinos carry races from all five New Jersey tracks and return some of the proceeds to the tracks in compensation for lost business.
Business was booming when the Atlantic City Race Course opened. Founded on the Black Horse Pike in McKee City, about a half hour's drive west of the Boardwalk, by the Philadelphia blue blood John Kelly (father of Grace), the track numbered nightclub stars like Bob Hope, Frank Sinatra, Harry James, Xavier Cougat and Sammy Kaye among its stockholders.
"You should've seen the limousines pulling up," Mr. Medio recalled. "You couldn't get into the clubhouse unless you were dressed to the nines. Milton Berle once presented me with a trophy when one of the horses I trained had won. He said he'd bet on the wrong horse."
Now, the limousines seen on the Black Horse Pike rarely stop at the track. Most of them follow busloads of gamblers bound for the casinos, which, despite numerous casino-sponsored races, "are killing the track," Mr. Medio said.
In 1992, gamblers bet nearly $20 million at Atlantic City Race Course, about as much as the average Boardwalk casino hotel takes in in two weeks. A condition of the state's casino simulcast legislation required Atlantic City Race Course to stop offering simulcast betting from 1993 to 1995. Less than $9 million was wagered at Atlantic City Race Course in 1996, when simulcast betting resumed there. Mr. Murphy, the Race Course president, said live racing had been "a money-loser" at his track and at Garden State Park, where an awkwardly placed stop on New Jersey Transit's rail line from Philadelphia to Atlantic City has yet to bring back the Philadelphia gamblers who used to flock there.
On March 12, members of the Racing Industry Study Commission visited Stanton, Del., where the addition of 1,000 slot machines netted profits of $56 million in 1996, enough to pay for improvements to the track and increase Delaware's 1997 live racing season to 139 days.
By comparison, Atlantic City Race Course will have live horse races on only 31 days this year.
"It's impossible to run a track these days without slot machines," said Mr. Medio, who has visited the Delaware track and others that have added slot machines. "The gamblers want them, and gambling is all that's keeping horse racing alive. Atlantic City got slot machines because it was in trouble and needed a way to come back. Now horse racing is in trouble and needs a way to come back."
Mr. Medio doesn't approve of NASCAR automobile racing proposed for the race course. "Only thing I ever got from watching cars race was a headache from the noise and pollution," he said. "If you care about horses, slot machines are the only way to go."
Because more than two-thirds of Atlantic City's casino revenues come from slot machines, Donald Trump, the casino owner, who is also a member of the Racing Study Commission, has said he would block any attempt to put slot machines at Atlantic City Race Course or any other track in New Jersey.
Michael Vukcevich, deputy director of the New Jersey Racing Commission, said the commission would "observe the status quo" for this racing season. "We have people studying the problem, but there's nothing on our table right now about making any changes at the tracks," he said.
But "things can't stay the way they've been much longer," he added. "Something has to be done."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If you care about horses, slot machines are the only way to go," says Wally Medio, a trainer, seen at the Cherry Hill track. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Some Investors Just Won't Deal Without the Net

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
BRUCE BENNETT would rather spend his money on fishing equipment than on commissions for his stock trades. That's why Mr. Bennett, a fourth-year medical student at the University of Mississippi, has used three different brokerage firms in the last year. Interestingly, those three firms share another trait besides cheap deals: they all offer trading over the Internet.
That is no surprise. The Internet is the speediest part of the fast-growing area of on-line trading. Investors can trade on line through a company's proprietary software, through commercial on-line services or directly on the Internet. But while only 5 of the 12 on-line traders, or 42 percent, offered Internet access in 1995, 25 of the 33 on-line traders this year, or 76 percent, are offering Internet service, according to the American Association of Individual Investors, which conducts this annual survey. 
 "All the growth in on-line investing is over the Internet," said Andre Scheluchin, managing editor at Mercer Inc., which also tracks this data.
When financial-services firms decide to start offering on-line trading, the Internet is more and more often their choice. Consider full-service brokers. Merrill Lynch recently announced it would begin offering Internet trading to qualifying customers in January 1998, and in December Dean Witter purchased Lombard Institutional Brokerage, which does about half of its trading on the Internet.
Mutual funds, which often offer prospectuses and applications on the Internet, are also edging into trading. The Scudder, Fidelity, Strong and American Century fund families now allow exchanges, redemptions or both over the Internet. And the last two also allow the purchase of additional shares on the Internet, if the fund is linked to the customer's bank account.
It is not surprising that bargain-seekers like Mr. Bennett have flocked to this system. The average minimum on-line trading commission has fallen from $35.33 in 1996 to $34.48 this year, and some trades -- particularly the Internet ones -- go for as little as $9 or less.
"As more and more brokerages go on line and offer Internet trading, the competition for who can offer the lowest fees is heating up immensely," said Kenneth J. Michal, an analyst with the American Association of Individual Investors.
Another reason for the low prices is low overhead, said Julio Gomez, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "It costs brokerages very little, if anything, to offer trades via the Internet," he said.
But investors must realize that these bargain deals sometimes come with conditions and hefty side charges. That is to be expected; discount brokers, the biggest presence in on-line trading so far, often use this approach in their off-line business, too. "What's happening right now with the price wars," Mr. Gomez said, "is that these firms are simply giving customers what they want -- cheap trades -- and extracting their pound of flesh elsewhere."
Scottsdale Online, for example, charges a flat fee of $9 a trade. To get that price, however, investors must keep a $10,000 account minimum; otherwise, they must pony up $19 a transaction.
Investexpress On-Line charges $13.95 a trade, but the trade must be for at least 500 shares, with a minimum share price of $3.
Some firms charge execution fees on each trade. At Computel that fee is $2.50; Net Investor charges $2.75.
"Investors should always call and ask about extra charges -- processing fees, handling fees, sometimes they're called different things," Mr. Scheluchin said. "All firms put it in their literature, but sometimes it's hard to find." Optional services can be steeply priced, too; Datek Online, for instance, charges $50 to mail stock certificates.
Large fees for inactive accounts -- Net Investor charges $50 -- are often levied on investors who fail to generate a minimum dollar amount of commissions within a certain period. And limit orders, through which investors set a price limit on a stock sale or purchase, can cost extra. A regular trade at Lombard and E-Trade costs $14.95, for instance, but limit orders are $19.95. Individual retirement accounts can be hit with high special fees as well.
Some researchers think cheap, no-frills trading -- with or without hefty side charges -- may not be what many investors want.
"What we're seeing is that most people want a higher level of service than deep-discount brokerages offer when it comes to on-line investing," Mr. Gomez said. "Though deep discounters will continue to exist, firms that offer more services and broker support will become the on-line brokerages of choice." And they will thrive even if they charge more for trades, he said.
Among such firms, Mr. Gomez said, are American Express Financial Direct and e.Schwab, which charge $31.95 and $29.95, respectively, for trades of up to 1,000 shares.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH STREET SEAPORT;
Plan for Apartment Towers Returns. So Do Protests.

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
When a 20th-century history of New York's great real-estate battles is written, a particularly long citation will have to be included for 250 Water Street, a trapezoidal site just inside the South Street Seaport Historic District that has been the subject of 10 unbuilt designs since 1983.
Year after year, Milstein Properties has proposed commercial towers for their blocklong parcel, most of which have been shot down by the Landmarks Preservation Commission as unforgivably large and incompatible with its small-scale, 19th-century surroundings. 
 But in 1991, after the Milsteins scaled back what had once been a 43-story building to one with 11 floors, the commission gave the developers a green light. By that time, however, the sluggish demand for office space in lower Manhattan helped kill the project.
Now that the Wall Street area is a nascent residential community, Paul and Seymour Milstein have returned with plans for an apartment complex that features two towers: one 14 stories tall and the other, 30.
To area residents who have been fighting the project for more than a decade, it is if they are back to Square 1.
"We feel like we're living a recurring nightmare," said Gary Fagin, a musician who lives on Water Street. "There is no comprehensible logic in what they are doing."
Others say the Milsteins may be betting that the commission's 10 members, 7 of whom were appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, may be more inclined to approve the project than their Dinkins-appointed predecessors were.
"The Giuliani administration really wants to see this built, and if you're appointed by the Mayor, you're more likely to do his bidding," said Franny Eberhart, executive director of the Historic Districts Council.
According to several appointees who spoke on the condition of anonymity, there is a good chance the commission will approve the $90 million project, which if built, would be the first unsubsidized residential housing in the Financial District in more than two decades. One commissioner who is undecided about the proposed design said he was troubled by the building's size.
"No matter how good the design, I don't see any graceful way to hide 400,000 square feet of building," he said.
James M. Yasser, executive vice president for Milstein Properties, declined to comment.
In the meantime, the Seaport Community Coalition, an organization of area residents, has hired an architect to study the economic feasibility of a low-rise building and to come up with an alternative design that it plans to present to the Landmarks Preservation Commission next month. Barbara Marks, the architect, said she hoped the commissioners would see that a smaller structure could still be profitable.
"To approve the design as it stands would be an absolute disgrace," said Ms. Marks, who has lived in the neighborhood for 20 years. "We need to spark their imaginations, to show them that there are other possibilities."
Opponents of the Milstein project, citing the landmarks commission's past denial of similarly sized proposals, say they are prepared to sue the agency if it approves the current plan. ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;
Relief on IRT, but Summer Squeeze Awaits

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
While cramped commuters on the No. 7 IRT train will receive some long-awaited relief this month when full express service is resumed, local politicians and riders are grumbling that riders will be squeezed again this summer when the Transit Authority cuts back on service.
The IRT line's rush-hour express from Main Street, Flushing, to the Queensboro Plaza, is scheduled to resume March 31. 
 The express service, which was cut back in 1993 because of track reconstruction, runs between Flushing and Woodside from 6:30 to 9:30 A.M and reverses from 12:30 to 8 P.M.
The resumption in service is expected to eliminate three minutes of commuting time for the more than 115,000 rush-hour riders.
"The increase in service will save money, recycle the trains more often, and move people through Queens more quickly,"said Termaine Garden, a spokesman for the Transit Authority.
"That's the good news," said State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky, who sent a letter last week to the Transit Authority complaining that the summer cutbacks were unwarranted.
As part of the Transit Authority's summer plan, the number of cars per train will be reduced to 10 from 11, leaving 29 cars to accommodate the 332,000 daily rides, instead of the usual 31.
Trains will alternate as express and local carriers.
For more than a decade, the Transit Authority has reduced service in July and August, citing a 10 percent drop in demand when many people go on vacation.
"The Transit Authority's numbers are outdated," Mr. Stavisky said, admitting that he had not taken the train in nearly a year since he had knee replacement surgery. "Flushing has changed. You have people working at all hours and on the weekends. In this economy, people don't take vacations. The No. 7 is very busy year round, and the cutbacks are not justified."
Mr. Stavisky is asking for a new summer-use study.
Mr. Garden acknowledged that the No. 7 was one of the busiest subway corridors in the city.
But he defended the plan to shorten trains during the summer.
"It's not a matter of money, although the taxpayers will save money," he said. "It's a matter of running the system more efficiently."
Yet many Queens commuters who work late on weekends said the trains were erratic at best at that hour.
"You come home at 8 on a Saturday night and you'll wait a half an hour for a train," said Jose Farvion, a painter in Manhattan. "Sometimes you feel forgotten." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
Rental Car Insurance: Staying Out of Financial Potholes

BYLINE: By BRUCE FELTON 

 BODY:

Q. Is there a way to beat the high cost of insurance on car rentals?
 
A. Vacationing in France last summer, I drove my rented Audi into a pillar in an indoor parking garage, amputating the side-view mirror and putting a sharp crease in the front fender. As unnerved as I was by the accident, I was also pleased, because it meant I'd be getting a tangible payoff from the exorbitantly priced $20-a-day collision damage waiver I'd bought. 
 Given the high cost of car rental insurance, I'm probably not the first renter to rejoice about a minor smack-up. If you've rented recently, you know that checking the "accept" box next to all the options offered on a typical rental contract can add $30 or more to your daily costs.
Of those options, the collision damage waiver, which relieves customers of financial liability for loss or damage to the vehicle, is often the most expensive. According to a 1994 report by the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, a consumer advocacy organization in Washington, the price of the collision damage waiver increases the base rental price of the car, on average, by 46 percent a day and by as much as 93 percent.
Indiana, California, Nevada, and Texas limit the amount that can be charged for collision damage waivers, and New York and Illinois ban them altogether. Elsewhere in the United States, the insurance can easily cost about $19 a day, or the equivalent of nearly $7,000 a year, depending on the rental company, the location and the class of car. Hardly a bargain when you consider that a 30-year-old driver living in a high-premium area like New York City can insure a new Ford Taurus for about $2,100 and receive more coverage than what a collision damage waiver would provide.
But that isn't to say that the rental insurance must always be avoided. If you rent a car and don't have another means of insuring it, taking the insurance makes sense, regardless of the price. Otherwise, you will have to bear the full cost of repairing or replacing the car if it's stolen, vandalized or involved in an accident.
What many renters don't realize, however, is that there are often more economical alternatives. If you have your own car insurance, chances are that it covers rentals, at least in part. Moreover, some credit cards provide excess collision insurance that reimburses you for any costs not covered by your own policy, including the deductible. But even that coverage is rife with exceptions and could leave you with a big bill if you have an accident.
For example, the collision damage waiver and credit card insurance don't cover personal injury or personal liability. In other words, if you or your passengers are injured, no one is covered. If the accident involves another car, neither option will pay to repair it or to treat the injuries of the car's passengers. And if you are sued, the coverage will not pay your legal costs or pay any judgment against you.
The cards generally do not insure off-road vehicles, trucks, or cars valued at more than $50,000. Actually, off-road driving, regardless of the vehicle type, is a deal breaker: Should you have an accident while taking a shortcut across a peat bog or golf course, your coverage will be voided.
American Express excludes damage resulting from causes like illegal activity. The Mastercard Gold card will provide coverage only for a rental of up to 15 days and American Express for 30 days.
If you can live with these conditions, decline the insurance on the rental contract and stand your ground if the agent tries to pressure you into reconsidering. It happens. Renting a car at National Airport in Washington from Alamo Rent-a-Car, Anna Aurilio turned down the rental insurance because she was paying with an American Express card. The agent wasn't pleased. "He said to me, in a very unpleasant way: 'Never mind the credit card. You'll take complete responsibility for the car if anything happens to it,' " she said. "I still refused the coverage, but left feeling very paranoid."
Leslye Lewis-Page, a spokeswoman for Alamo, said that rental agents "are in no way encouraged to coerce customers into buying specific items." She did note, however, that compensation for employees was partly based on total sales of ancillary products, including collision damage waivers.
 While collision damage waivers and credit card insurance offer no liability or injury coverage, most rental companies are happy to fill the void with "personal accident insurance," for about $2 a day, and a "liability insurance supplement" for about $7.
Usually, you can safely pass on the personal accident insurance because "you're most likely covered against injury by your health insurance or the personal-injury protection in your own auto insurance," said Loretta Worters, a spokeswoman for the Insurance Information Institute.
Personal liability is more complicated. A Hertz brochure called, "Are You Protected?" states that without buying supplemental insurance some Hertz locations offer "no liability protection under the terms of the rental agreement from claims of injury by others against you resulting from an accident," and that others provide only as much protection as state law requires. Taking the liability insurance supplement increases your coverage substantially, but it may not be the most cost-effective approach.
If you're a frequent renter, consider buying an umbrella liability policy, which supplements the liability coverage in your homeowner's and automobile insurance. In New York City, $1 million of coverage from State Farm costs about $200 a year, said Steve Witmer, a company spokesman. There is also a form of auto insurance for people who don't own cars, but still drive. They are called "named nonowner" policies and cover drivers for liability. They generally cost $300 to $600 a year.
If you aren't sure where you stand, the time to find out is before you reach the car rental service counter. "Many renters wrongly assume the rental agent will know if they're covered," says Jan Armstrong, president of the American Car Rental Association, an industry group. "The best way to find out is to call your insurance agent and credit card company."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Auto Stocks: Beneath the Metallic Glow

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
RESENTED with the prospect of buying something for nearly nothing, investors might pull out their wallets or they might fret that their pockets are about to be picked. When it comes to investing in the auto makers, fretting seems to carry the day.
For more than a decade, various Wall Street analysts have periodically suggested that investors could get something for nothing by buying the Big Three auto makers' low-flying stocks. By their argument, the non-automotive assets alone are worth almost as much as all the outstanding stock at these companies, so investors essentially get the automotive operations free. Auto executives frustrated by the low values placed on their stocks have been quietly encouraging this analysis lately. . 
 But the argument has some serious shortcomings, as stock analysts and executives alike acknowledge when pressed. After the calculations are adjusted for these shortcomings, the auto makers' stocks are not such clear bargains.
"The initial reaction is, 'My gosh, this is a great time to buy the stock,' " said Jack Kirnan, an auto stocks analyst at Salomon Brothers. But after closer examination, he said, "what on the surface looks like a very attractive valuation may in reality still be too high a valuation."
The rosy view of the auto makers' balance sheets, particularly those of General Motors and Ford Motor, is that they are loaded with valuable, noncore assets that could be spun off or sold outright.
An estimated value for these non-automotive assets can be derived from the share prices and earnings of similar businesses elsewhere, like lending companies. Adding up the values of the non-automotive subsidiaries and dividing the total by the number of shares outstanding shows that the non-automotive assets appear to account for roughly all of the current share prices of Ford and G.M., and for roughly half the stock price of Chrysler. Such calculations by investment banks indicate that the troubled automotive operations at G.M. and Ford account for no part of the share price and that even Chrysler's highly successful auto businesses are selling for only 3.4 times earnings.
Critics of this approach say it relies on three flawed assumptions. The analysis treats each of the auto makers' huge finance subsidiaries as non-automotive assets that could be separated out, even though they are closely linked to the daily business of selling cars. The analysis also assumes that all the non-automotive assets could be sold or spun off without incurring heavy taxes. And, finally, the implicit suggestion is that the automotive operations would be worth owning even at a low price. (Some analysts think that the automotive operations may be worth nothing if the economy runs into trouble and causes the auto makers to lose billions of dollars again.)
The biggest issue lies in whether to classify the lucrative finance units as non-automotive assets. These units -- the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, Ford Credit and the Chrysler Financial Corporation -- mainly offer auto loans and leases to buyers of the parent company's vehicles. They also lend money to dealers to finance their inventories.
Auto executives are very reluctant to sell the finance businesses. In recessions, the finance units can be counted on to lend money to their customers when banks cannot. The units are essential to building good customer relationships in other ways, too. For example, they track when a customer's lease is set to expire and then try to sell the customer another car from the parent company; outside finance businesses typically try to lend money for any brand of car. The in-house finance businesses also make low-interest loans on car models that the auto makers need to move. And because independent dealers, not auto makers, actually sell the cars, it is often only through the finance company that an auto maker can glean information on who is buying its products.
Ford Credit is the most successful of the finance units, having made money every year since its creation in 1959. Ford Motor's low stock price suggests that investors give the parent company little extra for holding such a thriving business. Yet Ford Motor has little interest in letting go of it. "You never say never, but I can't see it -- the linkage is very important," said John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer.
Even Chrysler resisted selling its financing arm during its repeated struggles for survival over the last 20 years, and it has no plans to do so now. "Chrysler has been shedding its noncore operations and Chrysler Financial is deemed a core asset -- it's considered part of the distribution network," said John R. Ferry, a Chrysler Financial spokesman.
A FEW experts say the finance units could be sold. Frederick W. Zuckerman, who was Chrysler's treasurer through the 1980's, said the company had come close to selling its financial arm, and he thinks that one of the auto makers will eventually do so. He said it should be possible to write a contract with a spun-off finance subsidiary requiring it to keep serving the parent company's needs.
So far, the auto makers' attitude has been "I don't want to go first," he said. But such a sale might be a few years away, he added.
The tax consequences of selling some subsidiaries are hard to measure. G.M. spun off Electronic Data Systems last year while convincing the Internal Revenue Service that it did not owe any taxes, after putting $8 billion of E.D.S. stock into its pension fund.
G.M.'s pending sale of the military businesses of its Hughes Electronics unit to the Raytheon Company has also been carefully structured to avoid taxes. But the deal has attracted so much attention that it may have "poisoned the well" for favorable tax treatment of other deals, said a Big Three executive who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Counting the finance units as part of the automotive businesses, and making a rough estimate of any taxes that might be due, the automotive operations of the Big Three still sell for extremely low multiples of their estimated 1997 earnings.
But many analysts argue that these low multiples are justified given the risk that rising interest rates and a strong dollar pose to the cyclical auto business.
"In effect we've got a business with no growth, vicious competition, that is littered with overcapacity and has little control over its destiny," said Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz, a New York brokerage firm. The auto makers are powerless to stop the dollar's strengthening, which has caused auto imports from Japan to soar in the last six months.
If the economy stays strong with low interest rates, and if Ford and G.M. can generate consistent profits from their core auto businesses, the stocks could someday turn out to have been tremendous bargains now, said Nicholas J. Colas, an auto analyst at CS First Boston.
G.M.'s stock rose only 3.5 percent for the 12 months ended on Thursday, while Ford's stock fell 5.6 percent and Chrysler's fell 7.5 percent. During the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 20.6 percent.
For now, with the dollar and interest rates rising, Mr. Colas said, "things will be very tough, and they will get worse before they get better."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Business District Looking to Stretch Its Boundaries

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
Three years after its formation, the 125th Street Business Improvement District, which runs from Fifth Avenue to Morningside Avenue, has received a grant to study whether to expand its boundaries to Second Avenue and 12th Avenue.
The grant -- the amount has not been determined -- is part of a $2.4 million package from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone to help improve business in northern Manhattan by expanding three BID's, including the Washington Heights BID and the Lower Heights BID. The package would also provide grants to 150 merchants along major commercial arteries near 116th, 125th, 159th and 181st Streets. 
 Property owners, some major commercial tenants and Community Boards 9 and 11 have enthusiastically endorsed the expansion of the 125th Street BID. But the number of tax-exempt properties, like nonprofit organizations, churches and government-owned buildings in the expansion areas, is likely to be a major stumbling block for the BID, which already has five such properties within current boundaries. BID's are supported by special taxes collected from commercial property owners, which are typically passed on to tenants.
"In an area like Harlem, the presence of government entities and social services agencies on our commercial strip make it more challenging for us," said Barbara Askins, executive director of the 125th Street Bid.
Ms. Askins said the two major developments in East Harlem -- the Magic Johnson theater complex and the Pathmark commercial complex -- and the commercial property base in West Harlem make it feasible for the BID to expand. But she added that it would still be a challenge to finance services for the expanded area. She cited the number of city-owned vacant lots, empty store fronts and the general lackluster economic climate in East Harlem, as well as the mammoth public housing project, the Grant Houses, in West Harlem.
The cost of providing BID services to the five fully or partly tax-exempt properties -- the Apollo Theater, LaGree Baptist Church, the Post Office, Empire Baptist Missionary Church and the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building -- is offset by the larger tax-producing properties such as Nynex, Con Edison and the Theresa Towers, Ms. Askins said. That would not be the case in East Harlem, which lacks the large businesses. But Ms. Askins said the BID will be aided by a resolution passed by the City Council Thursday that would make it possible to collect taxes on the commercial portion of the 15 city-owned buildings in East Harlem.
To make up for the gap, Ms. Askins is negotiating with property owners within the existing BID to provide services in lieu of the assessed taxes.
Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation, said her agency has agreed to pay the BID to manage the city-owned parking garage and nine storefronts it owns in the State Office Building. Ms. Askins said similar plans are also being worked out with the Apollo Theater to provide support services. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: U.S. Mustn't Meddle in Russia's Politics

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Helsinki Hopes" (column, March 16), William Safire gets some facts wrong. For example, it is incorrect to say that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia is "$10 billion short in payments of wages to teachers, police and the military"; only 20 percent of this sum is owed by the Government, the rest by privatized factories. 
 But more to the point, Mr. Safire makes the remarkable, even fanciful recommendation that President Clinton should impose political conditionality on President Yeltsin by making it plain that "America would respond positively to a Yeltsin coalition with Yabloko's democratic reformers," led by Grigory Yavlinsky.
This suggestion must be roundly rejected. Economic conditionality is hard enough to impose. But the idea that Mr. Clinton can get Mr. Yeltsin and Anatoly Chubais, the First Deputy Prime Minister, to accept a political coalition, especially with Mr. Yavlinsky under the latter's "condition," as Mr. Safire desires, is hard to take seriously.
This is all the more so when Mr. Chubais has just consolidated his position within the Government, with the appointment of key loyalists like the reformist governor Boris Nemtsov, the privatizer Alfred Kokh and the economics expert Yakov Yurinson to the new Russian Cabinet, weakening any bargaining position that Mr. Yavlinsky may have hoped for earlier. Indeed, Mr. Yavlinsky may well find himself in the role of a "permanent oppozitsioner," a title bestowed on him by Gen. Aleksandr Lebed.
But then Mr. Chubais's own commitment to reforms need not be doubted. Nor his strategic sense, which was in full display in insuring Mr. Yeltsin's re-election and is to be inferred from Mr. Yeltsin's anointment of him as the economics czar leading the next stage of reforms. Mr. Safire's misgivings, prompted by his admiration for Mr. Yavlinsky, are misplaced.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, March 18, 1997
 
The writer is Harriman Professor of Economics at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: COPING;
A Farewell to Two Nobles Who Never Met

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
PEOPLE make places. The Queen of Gramercy Park and the Mayor of Union Square moved on this month, to greener acres. They lived less than 10 blocks apart, but came from different centuries. Both represented the duchies that flourish within democracy.
Mrs. Constance D. Gibson, who died on March 15, three weeks before her 95th birthday, was a Victorian lady, warm, elegant and witty. She owned a large town house overlooking the locked, private park, of which she was a life trustee. Connie Gibson, a member of the Daughters of the British Empire, was far surer of her education and social position than most of the people around her, and so could use the whip of manners for political effect. Her generation's stewardship of the park as a bucolic sanctuary for the fortunate few has been challenged in a legal mud-wrestling contest that carefully avoided spattering her. 
 It was the one local fight that Robert W. Walsh, a brash 37-year-old who rented in Stuyvesant Town, absolutely refused to join. Rob Walsh is smart, ambitious and charming in that handsome bad-boy way that wins the hearts of older men who admire the steel behind the smile. A master deal-cutter, he recently cut a deal for himself to revitalize the downtown area of Charlotte, N.C., where he will move this week.
As executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District and Local Development Corporation, he presided over the neighborhood's return to the gold and glory of being a "destination" and a "hub" after years of decay and neglect. He helped turn Union Square Park into an urban oasis for everyone.
In recent years, the Gramercy Park gardener, Peggy Herron, took to wearing bright red berets so that Mrs. Gibson, from her window, could follow her progess along the flower beds. The Queen was always watching, even when she was no longer "full of beans." Her friend and helper, Sally Holmes Holtze, the writer, remembers conversations that ranged from 13th-century Limoges enamels, which Mrs. Gibson studied at the Sorbonne after Bryn Mawr, to such practical advice as "never to trust a man to remember to mail letters."
The last time I saw Mrs. Gibson she urged me to stay until midnight when her husband, Brig. Gen. Herbert D. Gibson, would return from his inspection of upstate boys' schools. The general, she said, was concerned about the erosion of discipline in modern youth. I declined the invitation because I knew Mrs. Gibson needed her rest, not because I also knew that the general had been dead for 16 years. She was so confident that I would not have been surprised if he had marched in then, in dress blues, and swept Connie across the dance floor, as he would forever in the photo on the dresser.
Rob Walsh was raised mostly in Bensonhurst, the fifth of seven children of an Italian mother and an Irish father. He went to Fordham and worked in city government. The first time I saw him, he told me a story that may just define him, if only because he tells it. In 1989, he came back from a vacation at the Yankees' spring training camp to be interviewed for the Union Squre job by the president of the New School, Jonathan F. Fanton. Mr. Fanton asked him what he thought of Tommy John's chances. Mr. Walsh said that the aging pitcher was washed up and should retire. Mr. Fanton said Tommy John was his favorite player.
Mr. Walsh said he immediately stood up, walked out of the room, came right back and said, "Hi, I'm Rob Walsh, just back from spring training, where I saw Tommy John, my favorite player." He laughed and winked when he told that story.
Mr. Walsh helped improve 14th Street, and he built bridges between the business and arts communities and the struggling Washington Irving High School. He thinks he made his mark by closing down the Underground, a violent disco whose patrons would pour out into Union Square at dawn on Saturdays and attack the farmers setting up in the Greenmarket, which became the public jewel of the neighborhood.
Mr. Walsh merely rolled his eyes when asked about the private jewel, Gramercy Park, and its tree wars. That was a no-win for a deal-cutting, unelected politician whose job is to represent business interests, which want a more stable, long-term government than the one in City Hall. Mrs. Gibson represented older money's need to protect itself from the incursions of the less or more recently fortunate. Their constituencies intersected, often at the National Arts Club. But Connie and Rob, in their different orbits, did not even know of each other.
Mrs. Gibson was cremated and her remains will be buried in the Arlington National Cemetery beside the general, although there were romantics who imagined her secretly interred beneath a tree in her park. It would not take long to recruit that pick-and-shovel crew. And I think Mr. Walsh, who will someday be back, has the heart to dig it, too.
