SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3018 words

HEADLINE: Tour de New York

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
FOR a time in the 1970's, Alan F. Lowe was high on cycling in New York. He would slip out from his Houston Street apartment, straddle his 10-speed bike, and speed north up the Avenue of the Americas to Central Park, trying to achieve "harmony with the traffic" and not to stop even once. "The idea was to never have to put my feet down on pavement," he said.
He and other cyclists exchanged heady talk of bike paths that would crisscross the five boroughs and hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers who would abandon their cars for human-powered, pollution-free transportation. 
 But in the 80's, the Balkan wars broke out, with cyclists pitted against cab drivers, bike messengers against pedestrians and in-line skaters against all of them. Add a boom in bike thefts, deteriorating streets and increasingly sclerotic traffic, and New York cycling seemed mired in a funk more paralyzing than a flat in the mud. In 1990 Bicycling magazine named the city (along with Orlando and Pittsburgh) the worst for cycling in the country.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Lowe, 59, the producer of a cable television program, "The Bike Show," began feeling less in harmony with the city's traffic. He had two concussion-inducing accidents -- one when a defective handlebar broke off in Times Square, the other when a car pulled in front of him in Chelsea. Last month another accident, again with a car, left him with a scrape from his right eyebrow to the left side of his chin. Still, he said: "I love to ride. I'm just older and more cautious now."
Today, cycling in the city seems to have reached, if not the top of the hill, then a point where the worst of its climb is behind it. The city's Department of Transportation counted a record 14,890 cyclists in Manhattan on an average day in 1995, up 36 percent from 1990. Transportation Alternatives, a bicycle advocacy group, estimates citywide ridership at nearly 50,000. Bike thefts are down and 350 miles of new bike paths are planned for the five boroughs by the year 2020. The paths are known as Greenway projects and can be used by joggers, pedestrians and in-line skaters as well.
Construction on the first of these is to begin this summer, and in the next two years 11 paths and esplanades totaling 45 miles are to be completed. Another part of Greenway, focusing on repairing and expanding an existing 500 miles of bike paths, some dating to the 1930's, is also to begin in earnest this year.
"This will be a big change," said Irv Weisman, a former president of the New York Cycle Club who has ridden a bicycle in the city since 1948. "We're talking Central Park without cars, except it's all over Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island. It'll be a cyclist's highway."
But before you try out that highway, it's wise to learn about the equipment you'll need, the rules you have to follow and where you want to go. This cyclists' guide to New York does not resemble Douglas Adams's novel "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy," except for that mythical electronic guide's friendly advice: Don't Panic.
One school of thought asserts that the perfect city bike is a clunker, a rusty-fendered monster ugly enough to repel thieves but durable enough to resist potholes. Adherents tend to be bike aficionados adept at replacing worn seats and bent fenders. But if they were car owners, they would be members of the "My Other Car Is a Lamborghini" School because they also tend to own $3,000 Italian racing bikes for more serious cycling.
But for the sake of comfort, getting around the city on a garage-sale model is a no-go. Most city cyclists recommend either a mountain bike, with its knobby fat tires and upright handlebars, or its close cousin, the hybrid, which has smoother, narrower tires for a faster ride. On city streets mountain bikes and hybrids shake less than racing and touring bikes, which have thinner frames, more slender tires and curved handle bars. And their tires resist punctures better.
 
Wanted in Bike Shops: Service and Inventory
Buying such a bike means visiting a New York bike shop. Like supermarkets, city bike shops tend to be smaller than their suburban counterparts. Thus, two things a cycling customer wants -- inventory and service -- are often lacking. Some cycling cynics buy all their parts from catalogues since mail-order companies can at least provide inventory.
But those customers also tend to be from the "My Other Bike Is a Racing Bike" School. For both the novice and the enthusiast, a good bike shop is often essential. After more than 15 years of living and cycling in New York, David Perry, a former bike racer from bike-friendly Palo Alto, Calif., and the author of "Bike Cult" (Four Walls Eight Windows, $23.95), says it is important to look for seemingly small features in such a shop.
For example, he said, female employees may indicate that the shop will have less of that "obnoxious adolescent male techno-geek sarcasm" of an all-male bike shop. The same, he said, would be true for middle-aged employees of either sex because their presence might show "a sense of loving cycling versus being in the cycling business."
Parts bins and a variety of bicycles are also good signs because they indicate the store depends on repairs and repeat sales. And a community bulletin board, with lots of cycling literature and local cycling newspapers, shows that the store has ties to the neighborhood.
Like an auto dealer, a bicycle dealer is giving advice on an expensive purchase. The best-selling bike at A Bicycle Shop, a well-known shop at 349 West 14th Street on the edge of Greenwich Village, is a Specialized "Hard Rock" 21-speed mountain bike, costing from $270 (for a mostly steel frame) to as much as $400 (for a lighter, mostly aluminum frame).
But unlike an auto dealer, a bike dealer also fits the vehicle to the rider's exact body type. Among cyclists, "fit" continues to be a subject of much academic debate, with esoteric theories and arcane mathematics used to determine the perfect relationship of frame, seat and handlebars to legs, neck and back. But the wrong fit will mean a far-from-academic reduction in performance and a possible source of pain, like buying skis that are too long.
The last decade has seen marked improvements in bike equipment. Tires lined with the fiber Kevlar, also used in bulletproof vests, resist punctures better than earlier tires, important on glass-strewn city streets. "Index shifting" makes for smoother gear-changing, not the Marley's Ghost clanking of chains from a baby boomer's youth. Most manufacturers have also moved gear-shift levers from the bottom tube of the frame to the handle bars, making it easier for the cyclist to shift gears without shifting body position or attention, another important factor in urban cycling.
However irritating non-cyclists' japes about "helmet hair" might be, helmets are critical to cushioning the head in a fall. When the head hits the ground, the brain remains in motion, colliding with the inside of the skull and bruising brain tissue. Helmets made out of specially hardened foam that weighs a few ounces can absorb most of the shock. But helmets should conform to American National Standards Institute or Snell Memorial Foundation standards. And they should fit snugly, since a loose helmet tipped rakishly to the side provides no protection at all.
No tire is impregnable to New York glass, nails and other detritus, so it is a good idea to put together a roadside repair kit consisting of a spare tube, tire levers, a patch kit, a saddlebag and a portable pump that can be mounted on the frame.
But unless you're a championship bodybuilder, such a pump is good only for inflating a flat tire to rideable pressure. A floor-mounted pump with a pressure gauge will enable tires to be inflated to 80 pounds or more. Another bonus: a floor pump's pressure gauge is often more accurate than the gauges at filling stations, which helps a cyclist to avoid under-inflation (which can lead to flat tires) or overinflation (and possible explosion).
Adults carrying children should remember that rear-mounted seats are designed for youngsters up to 40 pounds, roughly 4 years old or so. (It is illegal to carry a child less than a year old.) Seats that mount on the frame, between the adult and the handlebars, can be dangerous because the child can interfere with the adult's concentration or steering.
Once a shiny new bike is properly equipped, attention turns to the inevitable New York question: how long will it take for thieves to steal it? With the right precautions, maybe forever.
For the most expensive bikes, eternal vigilance is the only answer. Conrad's, a bike shop at 25 Tudor City Place on the East Side that caters to elite racers and enthusiasts, carries very few locks. The owner, John Tsang, points overhead to exotic titanium and carbon-fiber bike frames costing $3,000 and up.
"Nobody in their right mind," he said, "would lock up one of these bikes."
Police statistics show a drop in bike thefts, but whether this is due to the recent decline in crime citywide (many bikes were stolen to finance drug purchases) or better security tactics by bike owners, or both, is unclear.
Thefts peaked at 15,316 in 1975. From 1990 to 1995 annual thefts averaged fewer than 6,300 bikes. In 1995, the latest year for which data are available, 6,178 bikes were stolen with an estimated value of nearly $1.5 million, or about $240 per bike. And once-notorious open-air markets that trafficked in stolen bikes, like the one near St. Marks Place and Second Avenue, seem to have disappeared.
 
'New York Lock' and $2,000 Guarantee
In the 1980's, when bike thefts were more rampant, the Kryptonite Corporation of Canton, Mass., first marketed its "unbreakable" U-shaped lock with a $1,000 guarantee to cover the cost of replacing any stolen bicycle. But deluged with successful claims from New York, it withdrew the lock from city stores in 1988.
At the time it discovered that nearly half of its Manhattan claims came from just four zip codes: 10011 (Chelsea and Union Square), 10003 (Gramercy Park and Union Square), 10014 (the West Village) and 10023 (the Upper West Side).
In 1994, the company introduced a stronger, heavier "New York Lock," which carried a $2,000 guarantee.
Another bicycle lock, a favorite of bike messengers, is the Quadrachain, a 5.1-pound, six-foot behemoth of "through-hardened" steel alloy that the manufacturer says requires 50 percent more pressure from the bolt cutters commonly used by thieves. The chain's unusual square design, which differs from the more common tube design of other chains, is said to disperse the cutters' slicing pressure rendering them less effective.
Serious bikers commonly use two locks -- a U-shaped one like the Kryptonite lock and a hefty chain like the Quadrachain -- on the theory that roving thieves will carry either bolt cutters or lead pipes (used to pry open U-locks) but rarely both. Even if carrying a full larcenous assortment of tools, a thief may not want to spend twice the time with a double-cosseted bike.
Finding a place to lock a bike in the city may soon be easier. Some $1.1 million in state and Federal money has been set aside for 2,200 bike racks to be installed by next year. The city's Department of Transportation has installed 170 so far, with another 330 due this summer. And six privately owned garages and 12 city-owned garages in Manhattan and the other boroughs offer free space for bikes.
Assuming your bike evades theft, how do you avoid colliding with cars, buses and trucks? Mr. Weisman, the former New York Cycle Club president, who teaches a class on "effective cycling" in Central Park, suggests three principles.
First, "stay conspicuous." Cyclists should wear bright colors so drivers can see them, especially at dusk.
"I hate what's in fashion now," Mr. Weisman said, referring to the blues, grays and blacks that are the current trend-setters in helmets, jerseys and saddlebags. "It's a suicide-watch with that stuff."
"Ride as if something is going to happen" is Mr. Weisman's second principle. "Don't weave in and out of traffic," he said. "Be as predictable as possible because drivers associate bikes with children and children are unpredictable."
Colliding with open taxi doors is one of the most common accidents in New York. Among bike messengers, "Look for the lean and listen for the click" is a familiar adage. It is based on the tendency of taxi passengers to lean back before opening their doors. The click of the door lock can often be heard a car-length away before the door itself swings open.
The third Weisman principle is "Let the world know what you're doing" with standard hand signals and some not-so-standard, but obvious, ones. Often oncoming vehicles fail to signal that they are about to turn left, Mr. Weisman said, swerving in front of a cyclist. But a cyclist who points at the intersection ahead, will alert most drivers that he plans to ride through the intersection.
 
A Legacy Of Failed Lanes
The number of collisions between cyclists and pedestrians in the city remains high, but has declined somewhat from its peak of 707 in 1985 (with 747 injuries and two deaths). Crashes totaled 625 in 1994, up from 329 in 1990, according to the Department of Transportation, which compiles Police Department statistics. A computer glitch destroyed data for 1995 and data for 1996 is not yet available.
If Robert Kotch, a former bike messenger and president of Breakaway Courier Systems is any indication, bike messengers are getting in fewer collisions. In 1995, his 115-messenger firm had 20 accidents serious enough to file for workers' compensation; last year the total was three. The firm has intensive safety seminars, and Mr. Kotch disciplines riders he considers unsafe.
"If I think they're reckless, I make them deliver packages on foot," he said. "Most of the time, they quit. Sometimes I have to fire them."
For many seasoned cyclists, crowded Manhattan is the borough to escape from, but a new Federal-city project is trying to provide a reason other than the loop in Central Park to cycle in the borough.
The project is, in part, a legacy of the failed bike lanes installed by Mayor Edward I. Koch in the summer of 1980 on the Avenue of the Americas and two other avenues between Washington Square and Central Park. When ridership declined abruptly that fall the Mayor ordered the lane barriers removed. In 1994, the project, known as Bicycle Network Development, began identifying 500 miles of possible bike paths, some in Manhattan, to be marked by signs and sometimes by lane markings.
Like the Bicycle Network, the more extensive Greenways projects are being paid for out of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act, the omnibus Federal highway construction bill known as "Ice-T" for short.
But unlike Bicycle Network paths, Greenways paths are to be separated from traffic by barriers or landscaping. About $12 million is scheduled to be spent for 11 Greenways projects by early next year, the largest of which is the Queens Pedestrian/Bicycle Greenway, about 22 miles from Little Bay Park, near the Throgs Neck Bridge south to the Ridgewood Reservoir.
 
Bridges Are Keys To Green Paths
Smaller stretches are planned near Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, where Amelia Earhart once flew, and between Ocean Parkway and Brighton Beach.
Two projects are scheduled for the Bronx, near Pelham Bay Park and Soundview Park. Staten Island is to get an extensive five-mile bike path, stretching from near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge southwest to Great Kills Bay.
And new paths are planned in Manhattan this year: Cherry Walk, a mile-long path along the Hudson River between 96th and 125th Streets, as well as a mile-long path connecting the South Street Seaport with East River Park.
"But Greenways won't work unless the bridges to and from Manhattan become more accessible," said David Lutz, the program director for the Neighborhood Open Space Coalition, a nonprofit advocacy group. At the moment, only the Brooklyn and George Washington bridges are fully ramped and well-maintained enough for cyclists to use, he said.
As part of a plan to ease traffic congestion on the Upper East Side, cyclists are banned from the bike paths of the Queensboro Bridge from 3 P.M. to 8 P.M. and must ride with their bikes in city-operated vans. Besides, Mr Lutz pointed out, the bridge's metal grating is wide enough to trap bike tires and throw riders.
The Williamsburg Bridge is so poorly maintained that cyclists call it the "Ho Chi Minh Trail" for its numerous cracks. And the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge between Staten Island and Brooklyn bans bicycles altogether.
For New York cyclists, the ideal would be a major Manhattan avenue permanently closed to cars. Mr. Kotch, of Breakaway Courier Systems, maintains that Lexington and Madison Avenues are able to carry enough traffic to allow the city to close Park Avenue. With its grass median, "Park Avenue would make a great bike lane," he said. "I dream of it at nights."
Then he pauses. "Fat chance."
 
Where Bikes Are Welcome
 "We're the most bike-friendly borough," declares the president of the Staten Island Bicycling Association, Richard J. Coronato. Many of the club's 200 members will meet visiting cyclists at St. George Station, the docking point of the Staten Island Ferry, which allows bikes on board at no extra charge. Members will then show the visitors around the 60-square-mile island.
Staten Island has a variety of elevations, like Todt Hill (pronounced "tote," Dutch for death), which at more than 400 feet is the highest natural coastal elevation between Maine and Florida. The terrain offers challenges for A-rated riders, those who can speed along comfortably at 18 miles hour, as well as C-rated riders, who chug along at 13 miles an hour or less.
Mr. Coronato recommended the following casual ride for C riders, which is over flat terrain along the waterfront and should take about two hours. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

Charts: "Lingua Bikea"
Bicyclists have developed their own vocabulary for the cycling life. Here are a few typical expressions:
DOORED -- Transitive verb describing the collision of cyclist with opened automobile door.
ROAD RASH -- Scrapes and bruises after a fall.
ENDO -- Going face first over your handlebars.
FLATSO -- What you are after going endo.
POTATO CHIP -- What a wheel looks like after an accident.
COPSICLE -- Police officer on a bicycle.
FRED -- Weekend cyclist, sometimes marked by small rearview mirrors attahed to eyeglasses or helmet. (pg. 1)
 
 
"The Law: Bike Riding by the Book"
New York City traffic rules apply to bicycles as well, along with some special rules just for cyclists:
-- No riding on sidewalks unless sign allows or bike wheels are less than 26 inches in diameter and rider is 12 years or younger.
-- Cyclists must have hand on steering device or handlebars.
-- Cyclists cannot wear more than one earphone attached to radio, tape player or other audio device while riding.
-- Bike must carry only number of persons for which it is designed and equipped.
-- Bell or other audible signal (not a whistle) is required.
-- Cyclists are required to use hand signals when turning left and right and stopping or decrease speed.
-- Cyclists under age 14 must wear an approved helmet. (pg. 16)

Fire Island Ferries (516-665-3600) -- No bikes allowed. May be shipped on separate freight boat. (pg. 17)

PUB-DATE: March 23, 1997

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 4; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 957 words

HEADLINE: Loyalty and the Press;
Why Clinton Is Such An Ink-Stained Wretch

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REMEMBER the 'giant sucking sound' that Ross Perot kept talking about?" The Philadelphia Inquirer editorialized last week. "It turned out to be Bill Clinton's money pump.
"The 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign," the editorial continued, "was pumping funds from everybody and anybody, legal or not, with a reckless abandon that will go down in the history books." 
 This, mind you, was not from some Republican organ. The Inquirer advocated President Clinton's re-election and normally supports Democratic candidates and Democratic policies. Now, like so many other such papers, the Inquirer has turned against him with a vengeance on the editorial page.
"In journalistic terms, Bill Clinton has no friend in court," said Stephen Hess, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who specializes in the relationship between the Government and the press.
When Republican politicians get in trouble, the instinct of Republican editorial writers and columnists is usually to circle the wagons.
Editorial pages like those of The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Times have been critical of Speaker Newt Gingrich on some matters, but they defended him without reservation in his ethical tribulations early this year.
As the Gingrich controversy was being debated, The Weekly Standard, the political magazine launched in 1995 by Rupert Murdoch to air his conservative, Republican views, ran an editorial under the headline: "Stand By Your Man."
Conservative editorialists and columnists were also solidly on the side of President Reagan during the Iran-contra tumult a decade ago.
Even during Watergate, the conservative editorial pages of The Chicago Tribune and The Omaha World-Herald remained on the side of Richard M. Nixon until the damaging contents of the White House tapes were finally made public. The Wall Street Journal went even further, defending Mr. Nixon almost until the day he resigned.
 
Piling On
 But no comparable Democratic press exists. When a Democratic politician runs into difficulty as Mr. Clinton has now, or as former Speaker Jim Wright did in 1989, the instinct of normally Democratic editorialists and columnists seems to be to pile on.
A White House official who follows press coverage could not identify any big-city paper or national magazine that has defended Mr. Clinton against charges of abusive campaign finance practices.
The New York Times, which also endorsed Mr. Clinton for re-election, has been among the most critical. After a Clinton news conference this month, The Times editorialized: "It was a fluid performance in Mr. Clinton's best slide-and-glide style. But most Americans do not believe in a universe where Johnny Chung hustles Presidential photo ops, Vice President Al Gore's telephoning is described as a model of political dignity and Maggie Williams's palming of a $50,000 check is praised as artful handling of a strained social situation."
Even The Nation, the most doggedly liberal of the national magazines, has criticized Mr. Clinton on the subject of campaign finance.
Mr. Clinton's standing is even worse than it might otherwise be because clean elections and campaign finance reform are staples of liberal doctrine.
Tom Rosenstiel, director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism, sponsored by the Pew Charitable Trust, described the situation this way: "There is more of a team mentality on the conservative side. There is, for instance, a great deal more intellectual collaboration between The Wall Street Journal editorial pages and Republican policy-makers than there is with any liberal editorial page and any Democratic policy-maker. There is no sense of loyalty to party among liberal commentators and editorial pages."
Commentators on both sides agree with that analysis. "We feel very loyal to principles; we do not feel any loyalty to a particular party or politician," said Jane R. Eisner, editorial page editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer.
Howell Raines, the editorial page editor of The Times, said that the healthiest development in journalism since World War II has been journalists' "shedding the mantle of partisanship and beginning to think of themselves as politically independent."
Robert L. Bartley, editor of The Wall Street Journal, took a somewhat different tack. He said he did not think of the matter in terms of party but in terms of conservative versus liberal.
"You didn't see us jumping up and down in defense of Bob Packwood," he said. Senator Packwood, a moderate Republican who supported abortion rights and disavowed supply-side economics, was forced to resign in 1995 over charges of sexual misconduct. What if the same charges had been brought against Mr. Gingrich or Dick Armey, the House Republican leader, or some other staunch conservative? Mr. Bartley was asked.
"Yeah, we would have defended them," he replied. "That's the way it is.
"The drift of American journalism is liberal," Mr. Bartley said. "What we do a lot of is lean against the wind of the general news coverage. That's not a problem for liberal editorial pages. They don't have a wind to lean against."
William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, had another distinction. "Democratic Party leaders," he said, "don't mean as much to liberals as Republican Party leaders have meant to conservatives."
He added: "Reagan and Gingrich weren't just party leaders. They were leaders of the conservative movement. Therefore, the assaults on Reagan and Gingrich were assaults on the conservative movement."
Conservative editorial writers, Mr. Kristol said, often think of themselves as "shaping the agenda for a movement." Their liberal counterparts, he said, have more "the tone of preaching eternal truths to an unenlightened citizenry."

HEADLINE: The World;
Albania Is Cast Adrift

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania

 BODY:
WHEN James A. Baker 3d visited this dilapidated capital as the American Secretary of State six years ago, hundreds of thousands of Albanians thronged the streets, and those who could get close enough kissed his car. While here, Mr. Baker met with the opposition leader Sali Berisha, a tall, ruddy-faced heart surgeon with leonine hair and a tempestuous personality who had been anointed as the man Washington would do business with.
Mr. Berisha went on to win the elections America hoped he would win, and to install a semblance of democracy. Then -- more to the point -- he went on to provide a quiet base for America's efforts to calm the volcano erupting next door in what had been Yugoslavia. 
 Now, little more than five years later, Mr. Berisha's rule has been discredited as a sham democracy in the service of greed, and Albania has collapsed in anarchy. But the crisis next door seems in remission, and so the rest of the world has until now maintained its distance. Certainly, nobody is rushing to prop up Mr. Berisha -- or his country. Quite the contrary. Mr. Berisha's former backers in America are calling for him to quit, while offering Albania little else.
It seems reminiscent of other crises in other strategic places -- Central America, Afghanistan, Zaire -- where America would pick an ally, promote him as a lover of freedom and rely on him to help guard the Free World's far-flung ramparts. When the cold war ended, the truth would emerge about these allies, and their countries would be left more or less alone to pick through the wreckage that these lovers of freedom had wrought.
All this was supposed to have ended with the cold war, but then came Bosnia.
And now, Albania.
 
Stability
 Mr. Berisha, the argument in his favor went, was more than an internal reformer for Albania; he offered stability in the Balkans. What his American supporters seem to have missed was that he had been indelibly shaped by the Marxist-Leninist regime of his Communist predecessor, Enver Hoxha; today it can be admitted that, as one American official put it, he turned out to be "a crackpot dictator." In other words, just another Balkan strongman who, in his case, served Western interests during the Bosnian war and can now be counted as expendable.
In the beginning, the match between what Washington wanted and what Mr. Berisha was offering seemed ideal.
Shut off from the world during xenophobic Communism, Albanians had long hungered for all things American: blue jeans, Coca- Cola, women's makeup, Hollywood videos. Mr. Berisha was elected in 1992 after a campaign in which America's then-Ambassador, William Ryerson, appeared on his campaign platforms.
Mr. Berisha espoused free market policies, and once-drab Albania soon began to feel like an exotic bazaar (even though many of the imports were smuggled goods). A country that had only one fax machine in 1991 soon had mobile phones and imported cars. The International Monetary Fund gave Mr. Berisha glowing reports for clamping down on inflation and encouraging privatization, even as it ignored the corruption that was coming to pervade the economy.
Meanwhile, as Yugoslavia cracked wide open, Mr. Berisha, who comes from the rugged northern part of Albania near the border of Kosovo, promised to be useful in containing the war. Kosovo is an Albanian enclave in Serbia where the Albanians are kept in check by a repressive Serbian police force, and even before Bosnia exploded it seemed likely to become a nightmarish flashpoint for ethnic hatreds. So Mr. Berisha repeatedly did Washington's bidding to help calm Kosovo, using his influence there to insure that its Albanians did not challenge the status quo.
And as the war in Bosnia intensified, Mr. Berisha proved more than happy to have his country used as a doormat by the Pentagon. American unmanned spy planes were based at an airfield in the northern region of Lezhe for their missions to identify NATO bombing targets. American warships had access to the Albanian waters of the Adriatic Sea that the Soviets had once used to flank Marshal Tito in Yugoslavia.
For all of this, Mr. Berisha's price was low: About $30 million of nonlethal military equipment like used trucks and uniforms was sent by the Pentagon. Military officers were offered training in the United States. (Several defected.)
 
Advice
 Although Albania was so backward, it seemed such a desirable piece of real estate during the Bosnia war that the United States and Europe treated it like a colony. Influence in the Government was divided up: the United States put advisers in the presidency and the Ministries of Finance and Defense, Italy advised the Privatization Ministry, and Germany helped out at the Ministry of Interior. The European Union poured in about $800 million in assistance, making Albania the recipient of the highest per-capita aid of any country in Eastern Europe.
While they still felt they needed Mr. Berisha, his Western benefactors ignored his authoritarian habits. Six months after his election, Mr. Berisha fired his attorney general for opposing a law that gave the police wide discretion in searching homes. Journalists were harassed by the secret police, the main opposition leader was convicted of fraud in a trial that human rights advocates consider suspect, the ruling party was purged, and officials who didn't toe the Berisha line were dismissed from the courts, the army, even the Institute of Fine Arts.
Last May, Mr. Berisha went a step too far and blatantly rigged parliamentary elections, then sent police to beat up protesters. The United States complained publicly, but by that stage it was easy to do. The fighting in Bosnia had been declared over, and the need to have Mr. Berisha on Washington's side had diminished, at least for the moment.
Officials in Washington also warned the Berisha Government that the pyramid schemes in which most Albanians had invested money would collapse, wreaking havoc in the economy. Even so, few in Washington seem to have foreseen just how bad the wreckage would be -- how many Albanians, such dreamers of the American dream, would be left even poorer than when they had emerged from Communism. Nor did anyone predict that Mr. Berisha's misrule would ignite the popular insurgencies that have left the country such a thoroughly disorganized armed camp.
"The irony is that Berisha was supported as a factor of stability in the region," said Fred Abrahams, a research associate at Human Rights Watch in New York. "And now we have the greatest threat to stability in the region since the signing of the Dayton peace accords."

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Guess Who's Giving the Voters a Choice

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

 BODY:
IT is not what one might expect from Iran.
On May 23, all Iranian citizens over the age of 15 -- both male and female -- are eligible to cast their ballots in the most significant contest for the Presidency in Iran's 18-year-old revolution. 
 Officially, none of the candidates has been approved and the campaign is still weeks away.
But the front runner, using his power base as speaker of the Parliament, is making promises to improve the economy, keep away from the United States and enforce stricter Islamic law. The leading underdog, wooing women and teen-agers for their votes, is pledging more personal freedoms, more jobs and no more male supremacy. And eight other would-be candidates are struggling to be heard.
This is Presidential politics, Iranian-style: tough, nasty, confusing and full of alliance-building, horse-trading and mud-slinging. And all of it falls within the confines of the Islamic Republic.
 
Repression and Debate
 Is it democracy? Not by Western standards. But it is not the dictatorial system that the State Department has called it either.
Rather, Iran is at the same time a country of brutal and unnerving repression, and one with flashes of surprisingly open political debate. It is a combination designed to keep an elite acceptable to the Islamic Republic in power, and the population in check.
"There is space -- but only restricted space -- for political competition in Iran," said Shaul Bakhash, a historian who writes extensively on Iran. "The competition is limited to candidates and groups acceptable to the regime, and outsiders are not allowed to seriously participate in elections or the political process. I call it the politics of the ruling elite."
The reason there is a Presidential election at all is that President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani has already served the maximum two four-year terms allowed under Iran's Constitution.
For months now, the leading candidate has been Ali Akbar Nateq-Noori, the speaker of Iran's Parliament and a mid-level clergyman with unimpressive religious credentials. Just a few months ago, he seemed a shoo-in.
But at least one other candidate has emerged as a serious contender: Mohammad Khatami, a cleric who served as Minister of Islamic Guidance for a decade until he was forced to resign for allowing too much freedom in the press, publishing and the arts.
Still, it isn't just anyone who can run for president. The Council of Guardians, a body that is dominated by the clerics and supervises elections, must approve all candidates. In last year's parliamentary election, the council disqualified about 40 percent of the 5,000 would-be candidates. In the last Presidential election, in 1993, more than 100 candidates tried to run; only three eventually did. And although Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has declared himself neutral in the coming presidential election, no candidate who did not meet with his approval could run.
Still, as the balloting draws near, what looks like a campaign of genuine issues and candidates is playing out.
Officially, political parties are banned in Iran, but clearly identifiable factions with clearly identifiable views are not. Mr. Nateq-Noori has the endorsement of the Society of Combatant Clergy, a political grouping he heads that is dominated by socially conservative clerics and supported by those bazaar merchants who care about free foreign trade but not necessarily about foreign investment. That support brings with it the power of a well-organized political machine with the resources to get out the vote: the nationwide network of mosques.
There are no reliable opinion polls in Iran, but a three-week tour of the country last December -- including interviews with dozens of workers, students, academics, teen-agers and retirees -- suggested that there is a widely held view that Mr. Nateq-Noori would only make Iran's economic problems worse and that he by no means enjoys the popular support that Mr. Rafsanjani does.
 
The Challenger
 Enter Mr. Khatami. He has the backing of two strong groups on opposite ends of the political spectrum: the left-leaning Coalition of the Imam's Line, which supports state control of the economy and more equal distribution of wealth; and, if some of Iran's newspapers are to be believed, all but one member of the Servants of Construction, a group that opposes state control of the economy, favors more foreign investment and better relations with the West, and is aligned with Mr. Rafsanjani. (Mr. Rafsanjani himself has vowed not to endorse any candidate.) Mr. Khatami is also popular among university students and intellectuals. Teen-agers are important, since about half the population of Iran has been born since the revolution.
Even though the campaign does not officially start for weeks, Mr. Nateq-Noori is crisscrossing the country in an effort to boost his strong lead. He traveled recently from town to town in his native Mazandaran province, visiting hospitals and schools, inaugurating factories, bakeries and even buildings -- trailed all along the way by crews from the state television, which extensively aired his pronouncements every night.
The fact that he is acting as if he has already been elected has incensed his political opponents. "Why is the television showing him every hour on his trip and broadcasting an anthem written especially for him?" one reader asked in a call-in complaint column in the daily Salam, which favors Mr. Khatami's candidacy. "Can television still claim it is not taking sides for the presidency?"
Another reader asked: "Please tell me why is it the speaker of the Parliament is the one inaugurating projects and not the President? If the President is busy his deputy should do it."
In their speeches, the candidates say little about the cultural onslaught of the West or confronting world arrogance, and much, much more about corruption, inflation, inequality and jobs. Some subjects are too hot for debate -- the Arab-Israeli peace process or the death warrant on the author Salman Rushdie, for example. But there have been hints that there is even room for some discussion of Iran's relationship with the United States.
On a campaign stop in Urumiyeh last month, Mohammed Mohammadi Reyshahri, a former Intelligence Minister and another Presidential hopeful, did not even mention "death to America" on his list of priorities. And Ibraham Yazdi, an English-speaking former foreign minister who once had a green card and lived in Texas, announced last Sunday that he favors "normal relations with America" and the creation of "a democratic atmosphere" in Iran.
But, then, Mr. Yazdi's group, the Liberation Movement of Iran, has never been allowed to run in any Iranian election. It's just not considered Islamic enough by Iran's theocrats.
"In a true democracy, the people give legitimacy to their government," said Stephen Fairbanks, a visiting scholar at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars who is writing a study of Iran's political system. "But Iran's system claims its legitimacy comes from God."

HEADLINE: The World;
What Goes Around Comes to Zaire

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
IF the map of Africa could be turned on its side, it would bear a passing resemblance to a pistol. And the country known as Zaire, as the writer Frantz Fanon once said, would be the trigger.
This image of Africa's third largest country has a lingering resonance that has little to do with geographical whimsy. From this country's birth, with independence from Belgium in 1960, Zaire, more than any other African state, has been the place where explosive crises begin. 
 All at once, Zaire is caught up in a civil war sponsored by its neighbors, economic collapse and an open struggle over succession. For anyone who has followed the country's turbulent history, this dangerous moment can only seem like old times.
In its first year of statehood, Zaire, then known as the Congo, experienced an attempt at secession by one of its provinces. In the heat of the cold war, the breakaway bid by Katanga Province quickly drew in the superpowers. Soon, the country was the scene of the first United Nations intervention in Africa, and the word Congo rarely appeared in print without being followed by the word crisis. In the immediate post-independence years, the Congo would continue to be an unfortunate pioneer in foreign interventions, armed rebellions and the use of mercenaries to put them down.
The essential event that has most marked this country was the 1965 coup, another African first, by a 34-year-old Lieutenant General, Joseph Desire Mobutu. If not entirely invented by the Central Intelligence Agency, Mr. Mobutu had been sponsored and, at critical moments, propelled forward by it. As army chief of staff during the first five years of independence, the general was covertly used as the lever through which Washington could manipulate the country's fragmented political system.
His tentativeness in the heat of early crises earned the young general the epithet of "one of the weakest strongmen in history." He was called a "a black Hamlet" by the American diplomat Smith Hempstone.
But once in power, Mr. Mobutu almost single-handedly went on to invent a new brand of African politics, which he termed Authenticity.
His bold project was nothing less than reinventing his country under his leadership as the all-powerful "Guide." Fashioning himself as a kind of supreme chief rooted in African tradition, he set out to create a sense of African pride and nationhood among over 250 tribes in a nation the size of the United States east of the Mississippi. The Congo became Zaire, cities were stripped of their Belgian names, and citizens were forbidden to use Christian names.
For a time, many Zairians felt a sense of hope from the country's strong currency and from the dams and factories and other big industrial projects that were launched. There was relief, too, when the incessant rebellions of the early years seemed over.
Today the Guide's project lies in shambles, eerily similar to what he inherited in 1965. His experiments crashed on the shoals of cynicism, greed and his all-consuming ego. There is no better symbol of his hubris than the name Mr. Mobutu chose in reinventing himself: Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu wa za Banga -- "the all-powerful warrior who, because of his endurance and inflexible will to win, will go from conquest to conquest leaving fire in his wake."
 
Personal Militia
 Of the military that has badly failed Mr. Mobutu in the country's current war, one dissident army colonel said: "The Mobutu system was destined to die this way. What we have is not a national army but a personal militia at the service of Mobutu, his family and a certain clique."
If Julius Nyerere of Tanzania influenced many with his "African socialism," Mr. Mobutu championed African dictatorship, which he sought to make respectable by cloaking one-man rule in the trappings of cultural authenticity.
The Zairian example proved to be a powerfully seductive model emulated by men like Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo and Idi Amin of Uganda -- some of the continent's most sinister heads of state.
In the midst of his would-be nation-building, Mr. Mobutu busied himself playing mischief maker in many of the nine nations bordering his country, and beyond. In Angola, he did the handiwork of the C.I.A. for years, turning Zaire into the rear base of the Western-backed Unita rebel movement that was fighting against a Marxist Government in Luanda. At France's behest, he sent his soldiers to support dictators in Chad. And assassins were reportedly sent to kill the Marxist President Marien Ngouabi of neighboring Congo (a former French colony), changing the regime there in Paris's favor just as Congo was tapping huge oil reserves.
Since the mid-1990's, this tendency toward adventurism has come back to haunt Mr. Mobutu and finally seems likely to undo him at a time when he is ill with advanced prostate cancer and seen as having a tenuous hold on power.
The Zairian President was a longtime sponsor of the Hutu-led dictatorship that ruled in neighboring Rwanda. And when it was overthrown by Tutsi insurgents in the midst of a Hutu campaign of genocide against the Tutsi minority, Mr. Mobutu, working with France, came to the rescue of the defeated Hutu forces. Under the cover of huge numbers of refugees gathered in Zaire, the Hutu fighters reassembled and were soon mounting armed raids on Rwanda.
 
Rwanda's Revenge
 The rebellion that now threatens to sweep away what is left of Mr. Mobutu's power began in October as a minor uprising by ethnic Tutsi Zairians being threatened with deportation. The Tutsi-led Government in Rwanda saw its opportunity for revenge against Kinshasa. With its heavy assistance, what had been a minor revolt spread quickly in the face of a disintegrating Zairian army.
Suddenly an ethnic revolt had become an outright bid to usurp power. And casting about for a leader, Rwanda backed Laurent Kabila, a lifelong revolutionary and nationalist, against the Mobutu Government.
Several of Zaire's other neighbors -- Uganda, Burundi, Angola and perhaps more -- have seen in Mr. Kabila's rebellion a chance to put an end to a Zairian state that had become a source of instability throughout Central Africa. For Yoweri Museveni, the influential Ugandan President who is seen as something of a political godfather to Mr. Kabila, the crisis of Zaire is what he says is simply a "management problem." By this theory, inspired by Mr. Museveni's own experience in turning around Uganda, a strong and lucid leader is all that Kinshasa needs to get its house in order.
By backing the relatively unknown and unproven Mr. Kabila, Mr. Museveni and his allies in Zaire's upheaval may be committing an act of hubris as great as any committed by Mr. Mobutu.
"It is tempting to see in the rebellion's success a lot of new hope for Zaire, but the little that is known of Kabila inspires caution," said one Western diplomat here. "Mobutu's death will be a cause of celebration here. But Zaire and its problems are so big and so difficult that what comes next could be merely new, without being any better."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 793 words

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
Basketball Gains the World and Loses Its Soul (and Profits Nicely)

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
There are probably enough Federal agents who care about hoops to slow down the current point-shaving investigations involving Arizona State and Fresno State until we get through this last critical week of March Madness. This is not to suggest that any team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament is dealing with gamblers. But it would certainly stain the old school tie to even think that this youth festival could be about anything other than winning games to finance higher education.
It's been years since we've had a board-rattling basketball scandal, and this is hardly the time for another. Too much serious money is involved. And ever since 1992, when the so-called Dream Team perverted those aspects of the game that had made it socially worthwhile for a century, basketball has been on morally shaky ground. 
 Sometime in the 70's when we weren't looking, basketball became America's Game. The news media were besotted by the mythic Knicks and poor neighborhoods were inflamed by drugs and hoops, two ways to become somebody or to forget that you weren't. Here was the only team game you could play by yourself, in schoolyard or hayloft. No field, no equipment, no socio-historical-psychobabble baggage. Yet.
By the 90's, a team effort by the booming sportswear industry, television and David Stern's National Business-Ball Association helped the game become a truly gross national product, portable and exportable.
On the game's lowest level of skill, where players actually pay for their own shoes, the game was still about feeling good and earning street credibility. But the highest levels sent messages. In one of the country's best recreational programs, the Flames of Brooklyn, youth coaches like Gerard Papa bemoaned trash-talking and those behind-the-back dribbles in which the ball is invariably stripped. But coaches could do little about it; kids were mimicking ballplayers on television.
The "Hoosiers" dream of a raggedy little high school beating bigger and richer teams, as Coach Gene Hackman's did in that 1986 film, is still alive in Indiana and New York. Tiny Delta High of Muncie got to the state tourney in Indianapolis last week, and Manhattan's Washington Irving High School not only won every game on its way to a city title with eight players and no home court, but reached the state championship.
But even on this level there are problems, hard to believe when so much N.B.A. and Nike money is available. The Flames, whose players are predominantly Hispanic and black, have been forced out of the Catholic Youth Organization in a series of machinations that seem wholly out of character for C.Y.O.'s parent organization, Catholic Charities. Racism has been charged.
And the Horsemen of Washington Irving had to be shod through the dealings of a local power broker who had, small world, played for Papa 23 years ago. Rob Walsh, executive director of the 14th Street-Union Square Business Improvement District, got the nearby Paragon athletic equipment store to sell shoes at cost to the Princeton Club, which footed the bill.
Which brings us to March Madness, more accurately Media Madness. The men's game has been devalued of late by top players taking an early buyout. It's hard to watch big-time players without thinking that if they were really any good they would be in the N.B.A. already. All that news media fuss over the integrity of Tim Duncan, supposedly the best college player, for playing his senior year, dissipated after Wake Forest was eliminated from the tournament. Maybe he was just the best college player left.
Why would anyone want to stay in college when he could spend his teen-age years with Dennis Rodman? While the deep thinkers decide whether Rodman is a psycho, or a kamikaze (he is very popular in Japan) dispatched by the league to stir up interest and then self-destruct -- or both -- he is out there teaching behavior that looks like fun to me.
And lots more fun than being around campus if the Federal Bureau of Investigation finds more than rumors about point-shaving at Arizona State in 1994 and at Fresno State this year. Moreover, what if these are threads in a national gambling web?
Web's the word. The epidemic of sports gambling on college campuses has been documented, but its spread over the Internet is becoming a new subject of concern to the N.C.A.A. Most recently, a service based in Antigua allows Net-minders to bet on players and Final Four games while the games are in progress. While such gambling is illegal in most states, the cyber-bookies maintain that the gambling is occurring on their offshore premises, therefore legally.
With all this money in the game, the cry of the old gambler is new again: "C'mon, baby needs shoes."

HEADLINE: THE EMERALD TIGER: A special report.;
Irish Eyes Turning Homeward As a Country's Moment Comes

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: CORK, Ireland

 BODY:
This river town of steeples, hills and vividly colored quayside storefronts is now the second city of the republic, but in the grayer past it was the last city in the country that millions of Irish men and women ever saw.
They were participants in one of the world's greatest migrations, forced by famine, poverty, colonial persecution and lack of jobs to board ships in Cork's port in nearby Cobh and sail away to America, England and Australia in the hope of finding a future that this beguiling land could not provide. 
 Over time the travelers changed from the bewildered, tattily attired farm workers pictured in sepia photographs with their life's possessions in battered steamer trunks to purposeful young men and women with college degrees in their suit pockets. But for more than a century the pattern persisted: To get ahead, you had to go abroad.
Now quite suddenly and dramatically, they are no longer leaving, and thousands who had fled are coming back. Ireland, the country that once stood accused by James Joyce, its most famous writer, of conferring honor only on those who went into exile, and that as recently as 1991 was still losing 26,000 people a year, is in the unaccustomed role of no longer being an emigrant nation. The end of this dominant feature of Irish life is emblematic of the profound changes that have come over this society.
The place whose self-confessed national gesture was the tug of the forelock and whose talismans bespoke nostalgia, diversion and melancholy finds itself today with Europe's fastest-growing economy and a young, continental-inclined citizenry redefining Irishness in exuberant new ways.
The Irish have thrown over what they considered the inhibiting influence of the church and explored the possibilities opened up by higher education. If the centerpiece of the Irish workplace was long the plow, now it is the computer keyboard, a telling symbol of the new Irish condition because while it promises progress for the growing numbers of the literate, it also leaves even farther behind dismayingly large numbers of the unskilled.
"These people returning from England and America are very important for us," said J. J. Lee, a historian from University College Cork and a member of the Irish Senate. "They bring back the message that they went abroad and found that the Irish could be competitive."
Joe O'Brien, 37, an architect who has returned here to his home city after years of designing and building in London, said, "There is a fantastic buzz in the country, there's a really good feeling." Eighteen of the 20 members of his University College Dublin School of Architecture class of 1984 emigrated, and he said he believed that almost all have now come back. "When I left, I had no illusions about returning," he said. "I remember my parents waved goodbye to me as if I was boarding one of the old ships."
Mr. O'Brien stood on one of the stone bridges spanning the Lee River talking to Jeff Robinson, 32, a graduate of Trinity College Dublin who was one of the 14 of his class of 16 engineering students in 1986 who emigrated, but is now back to head the new Cork office of Ove Arup & Partners consulting engineers. "Back then there was so little opportunity that there was no point in staying," he said.
Now there is so much opportunity that industries are holding recruitment fairs in downtown hotels, setting up booths at airports and publishing "We need you back in Ireland" ads aimed at persuading young Irish men and women abroad that the country now offers the challenge for their skills and the wages to make returning a good bet. The posters hold out the promise of a re-encounter with "craic," the Gaelic word for fun that describes the gaiety the Irish are able to wrest from life even when times are not as heady as they are now.
What is luring them back is a country that has an annual economic growth rate of 7 percent, inflation of less than 2 percent, a declining deficit and surging consumer confidence represented by record levels in telling indices like new car sales and housing starts. Ireland's growth rate is nearly three times that of Britain, which is credited with having the most buoyant economy of any major European country. In a statistic that is arresting when considered in the context of the traditional relationship between Ireland and Britain, the per capita gross domestic product here has just surpassed that of Britain.
In words he must have taken mischievous delight in composing, Garret FitzGerald, the former Irish Prime Minister, ended a column in the London Observer this month by saying, "Over all, the performances of our two economies suggests that Ireland may have more to teach Britain than the other way around." Mr. FitzGerald presided over a series of agreements with unions that produced efficiencies without the strikes and confrontations with workers that his counterpart, Margaret Thatcher, faced in Britain.
Ireland has even made an asset of its previous backwardness. There were no rusting hulks of abandoned plants and factories and no obsolete technology that needed demolishing before state-of-the-art industrial, transportation and communications equipment could be installed.
"The Industrial Revolution is the best thing that never happened to Ireland," is a popular phrase here these days.

The Change
 
A Boom Unleashed By Europe's Funds
The revolution is happening now, though its origins date to 1973, when the Irish traded in the underconfidence born of centuries of subservience to the British for the independence it truly felt only when it became a member of the European community.
"The Irish people of my day definitely suffered from an inferiority complex, and we had 30,000 to 40,000 emigrating to Britain every year," said Tom Mitchell, provost of Trinity College Dublin. "We had achieved political autonomy from the British, but no other kind," he said. "Ireland took to Europe like a duck to water."
Designated as one of the less wealthy nations in the European Union, Ireland qualified for subsidies of more than $3 billion a year and has been canny in putting it to use.
"The Irish played the E.U. card well," said Nicholas Koumarianos, a Briton who is the managing director in Ireland of Cable and Wireless Ltd., based in an industrial park in suburban Dublin. "They saw an opportunity to leapfrog their historic obsession with the British. They basically cleaned out the till."
As a result, the country has established a sound infrastructure and attracted a vast number of multinational companies in information technology and pharmaceuticals with generous development deals and draws like a corporate tax rate of only 10 percent. Ireland's small farm-based agriculture has been particularly well suited to the European Union's Common Agricultural Policy that has established secure prices in what had long been an area of Irish life that was particularly vulnerable to pressures outside the country's control.
In the most visible benefit of European benevolence, Ireland's cities are now linked by modern highways. Big rectangular blue billboards with the European Community symbolic corona of stars overlook intersections and cloverleafs announcing where major financing for the improvement came from.
"Every time I hit the road, I say, 'God bless the German taxpayer,' " said Kieran McLoughlin, the Dublin director of The Ireland Funds, one of the country's largest foundations.
Giant cranes lumber across Dublin's skyline, and glass and steel buildings are rising in areas of the city that once were so derelict and dreary that Western film makers favored them as stand-ins for inaccessible Eastern bloc locations. Gracious Georgian residences in city centers are being restored.
What will be the largest employment site in Dublin, the International Financial Services Center, is going up on the abandoned docks next to the old Customs House on the Liffey. A principal project manager of the development is, predictably, a 32-year-old Irishman named Stephen Kilroy who joined all but one of the 24 engineering graduates in his 1987 class in emigrating, in his case to the United States, and has now returned.
Sixty percent of all business-application software and 40 percent of all personal computer packaged software sold in Europe is made in Ireland. The Irish have established such a lock on the teleservicing business that whether your computer crashes in Barcelona, Berlin or Biarritz, the person who takes your exasperated call for help will most likely be sitting in Dublin. In fact even the devices designed to protect computers from breakdowns are now made in Ireland.
"It's quite amazing that a country as prickly as this one is about its independence would feel so comfortable in the community," said Dermot McAleese, a professor of political economy at Trinity. "But 'Brussels' is a good word. Can you imagine anyone here saying, 'We're happy to abide by the London criteria?' "
Ireland has done so well that it will probably find itself no longer on the receiving line when its deal with Brussels, where the European Union is headquartered, comes up for review in 1999.
"It will be interesting to see how we react when we suddenly are asked to go and pay for roads in Poland," said Kevin Myers, a columnist for The Irish Times.
The one deeply preoccupying aspect of this spreading prosperity is an unemployment rate of nearly 12 percent and the dismaying fact that the creation of more than 45,000 new jobs a year does little to cut into it. The rate reflects a group of unskilled and untutored people in the inner-city slums and concrete-block suburban housing projects whom the new Irish economy does not accommodate.
"And we are not talking small numbers," said Mr. Mitchell. "There are tens of thousands of them."
A poster at Dublin Airport unintentionally points up the problem. It shows young Irish graduates in gowns and mortarboards beneath the legend, "Hire Them Before They Hire You." In other words, the uneducated need not apply.

The Left Out
 
In Dublin Enclaves, A Pattern of Despair
There are neighborhoods in Dublin with unemployment rates as high as 70 percent along with drug addiction and crime that is being passed along generationally. "The children are trapped," Mr. Mitchell said. "There is no equality of opportunity in terms of education and teaching skills for them."
Hugh Frazer, head of the Government's Combat Poverty Agency, acknowledged the gravity of the problem but said he thought some aspects of Ireland's culture might ease it.
"There's a degree of social solidarity here because we are a relatively classless society," he said. "The concept of structural poverty has been accepted, and our challenge is to see if we can make a modern society an inclusive one."
Mr. Frazer also argued that the newness of Irish prosperity gave the country a leg up.
"In an expanding situation it's easier to get at the resources," he said. "It's more difficult to redistribute existing resources."
There is broad consensus on what is behind the Irish resurgence.
"The credit must go to the reforms in education," said Mr. Koumarianos, managing director of Cable and Wireless Ltd. Mr. Mitchell dated the moves to the middle 1960's, when the Government made secondary education free and put school buses on the back roads to ferry students from remote areas.
At the time only 20 percent of the population went to high school; today the figure is 80 percent. College and university attendance, then 7 percent, is now at 46 percent, close to the European norm. "Our education has developed at a massive rate," Mr. Mitchell said.
It also has become more ambitious and more competitive. "The students are much bolder than they used to be," said Professor McAleese. "They will take risks, turn down jobs to travel and get experience. They are very pro-Europe, and they all study a foreign language."
If education and progress are the new adopted religion of Ireland, the Roman Catholic Church is rapidly becoming the old discarded one. Cabinet ministers freely use the phrase "post-Catholic Ireland," and a well-regarded new book by the writer Mary Kenny is titled "Goodbye to Catholic Ireland."
Rocked by a series of sexual scandals involving pedophilia and priests who have secretly fathered children, the church confronts an increasingly secular society that no longer follows its dictates on social and sexual behavior. Sectarian violence in Northern Ireland has lessened the sense of identification and responsibility for co-religionists in the North to such a degree that the subject of The Troubles arises in conversations with people about the state of their island almost as an afterthought. "But there's still a gut feeling," warned Mr. Myers, "and all it will take is one British atrocity to resurrect it."
Tourism is so successful that more people visit here each year (4.7 million) than live here (3.6 million). And the Irish confess with no apparent smugness that among the selling points are themselves.
"We're friendly, great communicators, well educated and good to do business with," said Noel J. Toolan, 38, who markets the country internationally for the Irish Tour Board with skills learned at Procter and Gamble. Mark Ryan, an Irish writer based in London, said he once saw a beggar doing smashing business in Paris with extended hand and a sign that said simply, "Je suis Irlandais."

The Icons
 
What Nostalgia? Stars Stay Put
Much comment in Dublin is made over the fact that directors like Jim Sheridan and Neil Jordan, rock groups like U2, playwrights like Brian Friel, writers like Roddy Doyle and Nobel Prize winning poets like Seamus Heaney remain in Ireland even after achieving international success.
"In the old days if you made it, you disappeared -- vanished," said Mr. Myers. "Ireland was an unsuccessful entity you left behind and spoke about all the time with romance and nostalgia."
Irish writers, musicians and artists have always been prolific, and success and the new domesticity have seemed to give them fresh impetus. There is the added incentive of a quintessentially Irish exemption on paying taxes on the proceeds of "products of creativity."
"This is the first generation of artists who are actually doing well," said Peter Murray, curator of the Crawford Municipal Art Gallery in Cork. "What you have here is that charm, that free-flowing conversational thing." Michael Colgan, director of the Gate Theater in Dublin, said: "They have found that they don't do well by not being Irish. They do well by being Irish."
Mr. Murray said cultural and heritage centers were appearing all over Ireland. One of them is in the old railway station at Cobh, Cork's port, and commemorates with photos, mock-ups and memorabilia the more than three million Irish who left the country from its docks from 1815 to 1970. The center's manager, Maighread Rutledge, 33, is the only member of her family to have stayed in Ireland. One sister went to England, one to the United States and one to Australia. All three have returned.
As evidence of what influence the British presence had in Ireland, the port's name, Cove, was changed to Queenstown in 1849 after Queen Victoria set foot on Irish soil for the first time there. In 1920 it took back its original name and gave it its Gaelic spelling.
Bob Crowley, 44, the Cork-born associate designer at London's Royal National Theater who won a Tony award in New York for "Carousel," finds an illustration of the altered condition of life in Ireland in the stories of his own career and that of his brother John, a director at Dublin's Abbey Theater, who is 17 years younger.
"When I left Ireland, I knew I would never come back, except for visits," he said. "It was a terrible feeling. I remember packing a huge metal trunk for the boat journey and watching the horizon disappear. I felt part of the Irish diaspora.
"For about 15 years I felt very angry with Ireland, but for John it's very different. He grew up in Roddy Doyle's and U2's Ireland, and they're desperate to hold on to him. John's generation don't consider themselves immigrants, and John hops over the Irish Sea with ease because Ireland has become an amazingly attractive country to be young in."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Loyalty Pays Dividends

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland, March 22

 BODY:
"I know you trust me," Boris N. Yeltsin once told Bill Clinton, American officials say. "But I know it's because you are afraid of what may come after me."
As much as the Clinton Administration is accused of personalizing Russian politics in its devotion to Mr. Yeltsin -- an accusation similarly leveled at the Bush Administration for its loyalty to Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- the summit meeting here this week showed the value of Mr. Clinton's trust. 
 Mr. Yeltsin came through for Mr. Clinton, choosing to minimize Russian anger and humiliation over NATO's coming expansion in the interests of a larger strategic partnership with Washington and Europe.
Mr. Yeltsin, who suffered a heart attack during his re-election campaign last summer and who was written off by many Russians, let alone Clinton critics, has emerged from successful multiple bypass surgery to reassert his authority over a chaotic Russia -- or at least to try.
American officials say Mr. Yeltsin is much improved from his surgery. In fact, they say, he seemed more mentally acute in Helsinki than at any time in the last two years -- speaking clearly and wittily, without slurring his words.
But the summit meeting also showed the fragility of the Russian state, where the whims and wisdom of one man, even if elected democratically, can still dictate the policy of the nation. And Mr. Yeltsin understands that in some fundamental way, Russia is still on probation.
Five or six years of haphazard democracy and a wayward path toward a market economy are not enough to make Central and Eastern Europeans confident that Russia has turned its back on its imperial, totalitarian history. That is reason enough for them to want to join NATO -- in case Russia reverts.
And Mr. Yeltsin, who as President of Soviet Russia supported the independence of the Baltic nations in his battle against Mr. Gorbachev, knows it very well.
Never a "greater Russia" chauvinist, like his first Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, Mr. Yeltsin has shown moderation on nationalist issues, like the fate of ethnic Russians living in Ukrainian Crimea, that could have led to serious confrontation.
It was only in Chechnya, within the Russian Federation itself, that Mr. Yeltsin agreed to use force to end a secession attempt. But the outcome -- the humiliation of the Russian Army, the international embarrassment and condemnation, the revulsion of some of his closest political allies -- became a warning not only to the countries of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, but, it seems, to Mr. Yeltsin himself, who was betrayed by the blustering confidence of his military leaders.
Faced with an expanding NATO -- the cold war enemy against which the Warsaw Pact was founded, and which now seeks to absorb some of Moscow's former allies in Europe -- Mr. Yeltsin made a difficult choice.
Instead of bluster and opposition, which would have been more popular at home, Mr. Yeltsin chose to look past what he could not stop, to secure Russia's cooperation with the West and avoid a new isolation.
His choice seemed to vindicate Mr. Clinton's faith in him -- and served as a rebuff to those in the United States who argued that NATO expansion was a fundamental mistake that would only embitter Russia, doom its slow transition to democracy and a market economy, and create an enemy for the future.
American sages as respected as George F. Kennan -- the 93-year-old former historian and diplomat who framed America's post-World War II containment strategy toward the Stalinist Soviet Union -- agree with scholars like Michael Mandelbaum of Johns Hopkins University that NATO expansion is a fatefully stupid response to Russia's first extended chance at democratic politics in more than 1,000 years.
Such warnings may prove right in the long run. But Mr. Yeltsin decided to bargain as best he could to win concessions from NATO in return for a first round of expansion he knew Russia was too weak to stop.
He received some softening of the military aspect of NATO expansion, some confidence that American technology will not drive Russia into a new arms race, some further commitment that America will push to invest in Russia and some stronger promises that America will welcome Moscow as an important member of international institutions like the World Trade Organization, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the group of main industrialized countries.
Mr. Yeltsin also got a chance to cut strategic arms, save money and preserve Moscow's cherished nuclear parity with the United States.
In an agreement on firm guidelines for a third strategic arms reduction treaty, or Start 3, both Presidents said nuclear warheads for each side would be cut to 2,000 to 2,500 by the end of 2007 -- a third fewer than Start 2 limits and two-thirds fewer than under Start 1.
The point is to give the Russian Parliament the confidence to ratify Start 2 first, in the knowledge that Start 3 limits will mean Russia will not have to build a new generation of missiles to keep up with Washington.
"I would say that emotions sometimes get the upper hand in assessing the Russian-American partnership," Mr. Yeltsin said Friday. "That's not the approach that Bill and I have."
The two Presidents have now met 12 times, and they feel a clear sense of loyalty to each other. A sense of their relationship came out in the dinner that ended the long, exhausting Friday of the summit meeting. The day had been difficult, officials say, and it was not clear until nearly 4 P.M. that one key American goal -- to allow the continued development of short-range American missile defense projects -- got settled.
But at the dinner, there were jokes and toasts, American officials said. Mr. Yeltsin gave Mr. Clinton a cane, and Mr. Clinton gave Mr. Yeltsin a small statue by the American artist of the Wild West, Frederick Remington. The statue depicts an Indian chief on a horse, picking through a difficult landscape.
In his toast, Mr. Clinton said the statue was a metaphor for Mr. Yeltsin's own extraordinary ability "to stay in the saddle, and not lose his footing even in rough terrain."
For all his foibles and maneuverings, it is Mr. Yeltsin who has kept Russia most closely to the path of economic and democratic reform. Mr. Clinton has to hope that Mr. Yeltsin maintains not only his health, but his capacity to keep his seat.

HEADLINE: Samm Sinclair Baker, 87, Author Of Dozens of Self-Help Books

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Samm Sinclair Baker, whose 30-odd self-improvement books counseled readers on how to help themselves to anything from svelte figures to good sex to making money by writing books, died on March 5 at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Mamaroneck.
He had suffered a stroke, his family said. 
 Mr. Baker, who had an earlier career in advertising as a copywriter and agency executive, changed professions in 1963 to write books but also continued as a self-employed personal business consultant.
He teamed up with a number of diet and fitness experts to publish their best-selling advice.
He was a co-author, with Dr. Irwin M. Stillman, of "The Doctor's Quick Weight Loss Diet" (1967), and "The Doctor's Quick Inches-Off Diet" (1969). With Dr. Herman Tarnower, he published "The Complete Scarsdale Medical Diet" (1979).
He joined Dr. Stillman for "The Doctor's Quick Teen-Age Diet" (1971) and "Dr. Stillman's 14-Day Shape-Up Program" (1973). Among his more recent titles, as sole author, was "Erotic Focus: The New Way to Enhance Your Sexual Pleasure" (1984). Mr. Baker published three mystery novels in the 1950's.
He also wrote popular gardening books, like "Miracle Gardening Encyclopedia" (1961), "Samm Baker's Clear and Simple Gardening Handbook" (1964) and "Gardening Dos and Don'ts" (1970).
He was born in Paterson, N.J., and was a 1929 economics graduate of the University of Pennsylvania. He went into advertising in Manhattan, starting as a copywriter and ending as president at the Kiesewetter, Baker, Hagedorn & Smith agency.
In 1955, he joined the advertising agency of Donahue & Coe as a vice president and member of the executive staff.
Mr. Baker is survived by his wife of 60 years, the former Natalie Bachrach, an artist; a daughter, Wendy Cammer of Larchmont, N.Y.; a son, Jeffrey, of Newbury, Mass.; two grandsons, and a great-granddaughter.
