HEADLINE: 'Other Governor' of Texas Turns His Flaws Into Assets

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 19

 BODY:
Bob Bullock, the Lieutenant Governor of Texas, does not have the standard attributes for political success.
Married five times, a very public alcoholic in office before he went to what he calls "drunk school" and became a recovering alcoholic in office, the craggy-faced, gravelly voiced Mr. Bullock has mastered what might be called the politics of redemption. 
 When a state senator from East Texas -- a member of the opposite party, no less -- was arrested a few weeks ago and charged with soliciting oral sex from an undercover police officer in Austin, Mr. Bullock conspicuously passed on the opportunity to say he was shocked by such news about a public servant.
"I will not judge him, lest I be judged," the 67-year-old Mr. Bullock, a Democrat, lectured reporters. "I myself have been to the point of desperation before in my life, to the point of low ebb, of despair and loss of self-respect."
Such candor may be unusual in a politician, but it seems to work for Mr. Bullock: across the span of a 40-year career in Texas politics, he has never lost a race, including six statewide elections.
While he is often called the most powerful and most feared political figure in the state, both arguable propositions, Mr. Bullock has unquestionably emerged recently as a principal figure in the increasingly heated battle in the Legislature here over Gov. George W. Bush's mammoth plan to overhaul the Texas tax code. The plan is widely seen here as a potential signature issue for Mr. Bush to use if he runs for the White House in 2000.
The plan itself is in serious trouble, in no small part because of Mr. Bullock's objections to its increase in the state sales tax and other taxes, which Mr. Bush, a Republican, wants in return for sweeping property-tax reductions and a vastly expanded role for Texas, the nation's second-largest state, in school financing.
At the same time, though, Mr. Bullock is working to fashion an alternative that could allow Mr. Bush to claim victory anyway, and he is hardly considered an obstructionist when it comes to Mr. Bush's national ambitions: he makes a point of calling the Governor a "fine fella" who, he says, will probably be President someday. (If that occurred while Mr. Bullock was still in office, Mr. Bullock would just happen to become the Governor.)
What if a tax overhaul helps raise Mr. Bush's national profile? "It doesn't bother me at all if it's good for Texas," Mr. Bullock said with a chuckle in an interview. "That's no problem."
Texas has an unusual system under which the Governor and Lieutenant Governor are elected separately. And in terms of raw power over legislation, the Lieutenant Governor actually has much more of it: he presides over the Senate and controls the movement of bills and committee assignments.
A casual visitor to the State Capitol here might even think the state had two Governors, since everyone calls Mr. Bullock "Governor."
Around the Capitol, the Lieutenant Governor is viewed as an epic figure, whose ego, heart, temper, virtues and flaws are all outsized.
"He's one of the two or three most fascinating political figures I have ever known," said George Christian, a former top aide to Lyndon B. Johnson, a man to whom Mr. Bullock is often compared. "His knowledge of government is just overwhelming. He knows what it takes to get things done. And he works like a dog."
Mr. Bullock is hardly the only political figure to be so candid about personal weaknesses: former Gov. Ann W. Richards, for instance, essentially found a way to turn her status as a recovering alcoholic into a political asset. Still, Mr. Bullock's political survival in the face of numerous publicized personal difficulties -- "all self-inflicted," he quickly points out in an interview -- is particularly impressive. These include alcoholism, past marital infidelities (he says he is now happily and faithfully married to his wife of 12 years, Jan) and troubles with the law, including guilty pleas on a drunken-driving charge and a ticket for driving 106 miles an hour on an interstate.
He also has so many health problems that many people marvel that he is still alive. He has been hospitalized for heart surgery, lung and kidney problems, and severe depression. But he has a morbid sense of humor about it all: in the late 1970's, he told his staff to issue a few press releases that began: "If still alive, Comptroller Bob Bullock will. . . . "
Newspaper and magazine articles over the years about his excesses and potential scandals read like epitaphs, except that Mr. Bullock is still in the Capitol. Despite two grand jury investigations into allegations of wrongdoing, he has never been indicted for misusing any office.
Mr. Bullock is hardly universally admired. In a recent issue, the liberal Texas Observer called him "The Last Don" of Texas politics, and some Democrats grumble that he has been too accommodating of the Republicans, who are fast becoming the state's dominant political party. There are signs that his formidable power is waning.
Mr. Bullock, who has been Lieutenant Governor for six years, is the highest-ranking Democrat left in the state, now that Republicans hold the Governor's office and both United States Senate seats. While Mr. Bush was upending his predecessor, Ms. Richards, in 1994, Mr. Bullock, recuperating from a heart operation, stayed off the campaign trail but won re-election handily anyway.
Thus began an intricate relationship between the two men, in which Mr. Bush, then 48, started off by seeming to play the role of professional son to Mr. Bullock, constantly seeking his advice. That made for a harmonious legislative session in 1995, Mr. Bush's first year in office.
More recently, though, their relations took a frostier turn, when Mr. Bush, having perhaps grown a bit cockier in office, abruptly announced last fall that he wanted to use the $1 billion surplus in the state budget to cut school property taxes for homeowners across the state. Mr. Bullock was widely described as livid that he had not been consulted.
Now, Mr. Bullock could wind up doing Mr. Bush a favor, by pushing an alternative plan that closes some tax exemptions and avoids more obvious increases that the Governor had proposed, like a half-cent increase in a sales tax that, at 6.25 percent, is already high.
In any event, it is clear that Governor Bush is relying on Mr. Bullock for help: when a reporter for The Economist magazine, based in London, came here several weeks ago to do an article on the tax plan, he looked up Mr. Bullock and pronounced him "exactly the sort of Machiavellian bully Mr. Bush needs" to get a tax plan through the Legislature.
Of course, the final chapters on the relationship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Bullock have yet to be written. Both men are up for re-election next year, and one question that fascinates people here is whether Mr. Bush will recruit a top-ranking Republican to run against Mr. Bullock.
The potential benefit to the Governor is obvious, especially if he decides to run for President and needs an ultraloyal stand-in (and would-be successor) back in Austin. But so is the risk: it could amount to an all-out declaration of war in which the powerful Mr. Bullock might make Mr. Bush's re-election as Governor a more tenuous proposition.
The Lieutenant Governor said he had never even discussed next year's elections with Mr. Bush. "He's busy; I don't see him as much as I used to," Mr. Bullock added. But he said he was planning to run for re-election next year, and most legislators here certainly expect him to do so.
"There's only one way that Bob Bullock ever wants to leave the state Capitol," one said. "And that's in a pine box."

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Lure of Fly Tying Is in the Preparation

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant 

 BODY:
As the angling season approaches in the Northeast, many fly fishermen are hunched at their desks, work benches or dining room tables of an evening, creating hook-bearing imitations of insects, minnows and other creatures on which fish are wont to dine.
Tying your own flies is a way to heighten the anticipation of fishing and to conjure up recollections of seasons past. My 1997 fly tying began a month ago, when I noticed an Atlantic salmon fly hanging from the spine of an anthology of modern American poetry on one of the bookshelves above my fly-tying desk. It was a low water Blue Charm on which Bob Winthrop of Glen Head, L.I., had taken a nice salmon on the Restigouche River in Canada last summer during a period when the fish were dour. Noting that the fly was unusually sparse, I had asked Bob whether I could take it home with me to make copies. 
 I made those copies, and while putting them away I noticed that standard versions of Blue Charms were in short supply and immediately fashioned more of them. That night I read several chapters of the recently published "Fishing Atlantic Salmon -- The Flies and the Patterns" (Stackpole, 1996) by Joseph Bates Jr., which was completed after his death in 1988 by his daughter, Pamela Bates Richards.
A big, handsome, lavishly illustrated book, it is an inspired blend of salmon fly history and salmon angling lore, and it reminded me that I needed additional Rusty Rats in various sizes for salmon, as well as more salmon dry flies, notable among them White Wulffs, Royal Wulffs and Bombers.
With the Atlantic salmon flies out of the way, I was about to start on a striped bass fly of my own design when Cooper Gilkes, who runs an Orvis fly fishing shop on Martha's Vineyard, where I live, asked whether I had ever encountered a streamer known as the Maynard Marvel during my years in New Hampshire. I had, but couldn't remember how to build it. I found a description of that fly in my copy of Eric Leiser's "The Book Of Fly Patterns" (Knopf, 1987), an invaluable reference work.
Leiser gives two versions of the fly, one from Bill Hunter, the other from Dick Stewart, both knowledgeable and accomplished fly dressers. I chose the Hunter fly -- which calls for a wing of 12 golden pheasant crest feathers -- because it best resembled the Marvel I remembered. Such feathers are costly, and, according to Hunter, the original Marvel, designed by Ora Smith of Keene, N.H., had 24 of them. But that pushes the expense and the time involved in creating the fly beyond reason. In economic terms, the simplest bucktail streamer can cost $3, and complicated patterns, such as a classic Atlantic salmon fly, are much more dear.
I resolved to tie up half a dozen Marvels for my annual June trip for landlocked salmon on the Rapid River in Maine. Having used up all my golden pheasant crest feathers for tails on the Blue Charms, I obtained a fresh batch from Cooper, and while tying the Marvels I realized that I was running low on Muddler Minnows, my most productive fly to date for the Rapid River's land locks.
Last June, the largest landlocked salmon I have ever seen in the Rapid River grabbed my Muddler beside the canoe, hurtled aloft flinging spray on me, threw the hook and departed. Perhaps the best-known fly in North America for trout, Atlantic salmon and landlocked salmon, the original Muddler, which has many versions, was the creation of Don Gapen of Minnesota in the 1930's.
After fashioning more Muddlers, I decided that I needed some extra Gold Ribbed Hare's Ear nymphs, a venerable and highly productive trout pattern that has a fuzzy body of dubbed fur from the head and ears of the hare. I couldn't locate the hare fur that I bought last fall, so I substituted muskrat for it.
Another reason for tying your own flies is that it enables you to experiment with new patterns. There is always the possibility, albeit remote, that you may come up with something as effective as the Muddler. It wouldn't make you rich -- for obvious reasons, you can't patent a fly pattern -- but it would bring you recognition among your peers. And it would catch fish.
While sorting out my saltwater flies this winter, I came upon several boxes marked "Junk Flies." In them were hundreds of experimental striped bass flies, some more than 40 years old, that had failed to live up to my expectations. But I have a new striper fly in mind, a sparsely tied tandem hook streamer with a slightly curved Corsair body. The tail hook is intended to deal with the problem of stripers striking short, which often happens when they are simply hanging in the current letting the little forage fish come to them.
I am so confident that this fly will not wind up in my junk fly collection that I have already given it a name. Because its basic colors are red, white and blue, it will be known as the "Patriot."

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Glenn Wolff)

HEADLINE: White House Open to Separate Vote on Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The White House has told Congressional Democrats that it would support Speaker Newt Gingrich's idea of separating the issue of tax cuts from balancing the Federal budget, Administration officials said today.
White House support for the proposal could provide important momentum in the budget negotiations aimed at eliminating the Federal deficit by 2002. 
 Administration officials said they were not backing away from the tax-cut proposals included in the budget President Clinton sent to Congress last month, including tax breaks for college expenses and credits for families with children.
But they said they wanted to send a signal of support to moderate Republicans who back the idea floated by Mr. Gingrich on Monday to balance the budget first and address the question of tax cuts separately. The idea is also backed by many moderate and conservative Democrats, including a group known as the Blue Dogs that has been pushing for a budget that would not include any tax cuts.
The White House chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, met with several groups of Congressional Democrats this week and told them of the Administration's willingness to consider splitting the budget and tax issues.
Gene Sperling, the chairman of the White House's National Economic Council, said: "The President's budget shows you can balance the budget with tax cuts, and our preference is to have a balanced budget plan with tax cuts in it. But if having a separate vote on tax cuts is the key to getting a budget agreement, we will be open to it."
Mr. Clinton is calling for almost $100 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, largely paid for by closing tax loopholes and extending some existing taxes. Republican proposals range up to $200 billion in tax cuts over five years. Republicans have not yet specified how they would pay for those cuts.
Mr. Gingrich's proposal to split taxes from the budget, at least in a procedural sense, has left his party's right wing on the verge of revolt, raising questions about Mr. Gingrich's future and making clear just how complicated budget politics will be as the two parties try to work out an agreement.
On Friday, Mr. Gingrich said in a speech from the House floor that he had been misunderstood, and he declared, "I'm deeply committed to lowering taxes."
Mr. Gingrich has said that considering taxes through legislation separate from the budget would make it easier to force the Administration to agree to deep and permanent spending cuts, especially in politically sensitive entitlement programs like Medicare.
Mr. Gingrich's critics contend that it would be politically impossible to push through a tax cut of any size outside of the budget agreement, and that his strategy endangers a goal that has been the centerpiece of the conservative economic agenda for years.
The White House is now walking much the same line as Mr. Gingrich, and although tax cuts do not have as powerful a constituency among Democrats as among Republicans, Mr. Clinton's strategy could expose him to criticism that he is not serious about providing tax relief to the middle class. His failure to follow through on promises of tax cuts in his first two years in office is among the reasons cited for the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994.
Mr. Clinton met with Congressional budget officials last week in an effort to get negotiations between the two parties back on track. Although there have been quiet negotiations on the staff level over the last several months, both sides are now trying to speed up the pace and broaden the talks.

HEADLINE: Gore to Raise Prickly Issue, Campaign Finance, in China

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 22

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore said today that during his visit to Beijing this week, he would discuss earlier accusations that the Chinese Government tried to funnel money to American campaigns before the 1996 elections.
But in a conversation with reporters just before his airplane stopped here to refuel, Mr. Gore indicated that he would be restricted from discussing the issue in detail because it is under investigation by the Justice Department and because the Chinese have "vigorously denied" that they sought to influence the elections. 
 Still, Mr. Gore said, "In an appropriate and sensitive way, it'll be discussed, with every other matter that has potential for having some effect on our important relationship."
Mr. Gore was questioned repeatedly about the subject, underscoring how his long-planned visit to China has been rendered politically prickly by almost daily accusations about campaign finances that have brought intense scrutiny to any Administration contact with China.
"This is not what this trip is about," Mr. Gore said of the Justice Department investigation.
Mr. Gore is the highest-ranking American official to visit China since President George Bush went there in 1989, and his trip is intended to pave the way for a visit by President Clinton next year. His central missions are to strengthen ties with the Chinese and, he said today, to establish "a forum for ongoing discussion on the environment and development."
Mr. Gore said he also planned to raise other subjects, including human rights, the future of Hong Kong and the possible admission of China to the World Trade Organization. He is to meet with both President President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng, as well as other officials.
Although President Clinton recently acknowledged that the Administration's policy of engagement with China had produced few tangible benefits on human rights, Mr. Gore defended the approach today. "It is more than reasonable to place a bet that as the free market expands dramatically, so will free ideas," said Mr. Gore.
Some optimistic Administration officials have said that by raising the Vice President's profile and possibly advancing relations with China, this visit will enhance his image.
"If he just does what he's supposed to do," said one senior White House aide, "the politics will take care of themselves."
Such predictions notwithstanding, Mr. Gore's office seemed uncertain in recent days how to manage the campaign finance issues during this trip. Fearful of a deal-making image, they wrangled among themselves over whether the Vice President should preside over the signing of a billion-dollar deal for China to buy a small fleet of Boeing 777 aircraft. Now, Mr. Gore's aides say that if the deal is ready, he will attend the signing.
Mr. Gore is bracketing his visit to China with stops in Japan and South Korea, but he is most focused on his discussions in Beijing. He argued today that his visit was well-timed. "It's a more propitious time now than in the past," he said "because both our countries are clearly signaling to each other that we want to find a way to go forward in the relationship while being very respectful of the disagreements we may have."
Mr. Gore seems determined not to let the finance issue shoulder aside the subjects he would prefer to talk about. His aides said that the Vice President first began to explore environmental issues with the Chinese in meetings with visiting officials in 1994 and 1995. At a low point in United States-China relations, Mr. Gore met with Mr. Li in Copenhagen in March 1995. Mr. Li used the opportunity to upbraid Mr. Gore for what the Prime Minister called meddling in China's internal affairs, Western officials said, but since then, the two men have exchanged letters that led to this week's planned meeting.

HEADLINE: The New Push For Less Costly Electric Power

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
After years of having the nation's highest electricity rates, New York is pursuing a drastic reorganizing of the state's three biggest utilities, as it follows the lead of other states in a belated effort to stem a painful loss of industry and jobs.
With the increasing concerns about corporate flight and cutbacks in many states across the country, large industrial customers have provided the biggest push for deregulation of the electric industry. These customers assert that they need lower rates to keep up with competitors not only in other states with cheap power but also in other countries where costs are lower. 
 Big companies in states like California, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, where the drive to deregulate has advanced the furthest, are likely to reap the largest savings from competition. Many have already extracted rate cuts of 20 percent to 30 percent from utilities by threatening to build their own power plants or closing plants and moving to states with lower power costs.
By contrast, smaller commercial users and residential customers in most areas do not have the influence to force similar savings from the utilities. Even when deregulation is broadly put into effect, as early as next year in some states, the savings for smaller users are expected to be far more modest, raising concerns among consumer advocates that small users will be disproportionately subsidizing the effort to save jobs.
In New York, the plans promoted by Gov. George E. Pataki's administration and the State Public Service Commission are driven largely in response to plant closings and cutbacks that have cost the state an average of 3 percent of its manufacturing jobs each year in the last decade. Mr. Pataki campaigned for Governor on a promise to cut electricity rates and stop the loss of jobs.
Last week, the Governor announced a plan to cut electricity rates on Long Island up to 23 percent, the centerpiece of a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company. While homeowners on Long Island have been the loudest protesters of high electric costs, the Lilco plan is also a response to the complaints of industrial customers.
Earlier this month, the Consolidated Edison Company and the State Public Service Commission agreed on a sweeping plan under which big industrial customers would get rate cuts of 25 percent while homeowners and smaller businesses would receive cuts of only 3.3 percent.
Also this month, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, based in Syracuse, announced its own plan for relief, saying it had agreed to spend $4 billion to buy out long-term contracts for high-cost power from most of its independent suppliers. The buyout would allow the company to shop around for cheaper power and thus pass along lower rates to its customers.
Niagara Mohawk's situation demonstrates the critical importance of electric rates to the economy as states battle for the jobs and tax dollars that large plants deliver. The utility serves an area that includes much of the state's industrial heartland, including such major centers of manufacturing as Syracuse, Utica, Schenectady and Buffalo.
In an interview in his office in Syracuse, William E. Davis, the chairman of Niagara Mohawk, said he had repeatedly been confronted over the last several years by his major industrial customers, who threatened to move.
" 'Why should I stay here?' " he recalled them asking. "They say that to the local economic development people, to the Governor's office. It's hard to refute their argument. They are saying that things have to change -- and they have accelerated that change."
Among companies that have cited power costs in closing plants in Niagara Mohawk's service area in recent years have been Smith Corona, which phased out a typewriter assembly plant in 1993 in Cortland, costing 875 jobs, and the Miller Brewing Company, which phased out a brewery in the early 1990's that had employed 700 in Fulton.
Rarely, however, is the cost of power the only factor; other competitive forces are usually at play, too, as was the case in both the Miller and Smith Corona closings.
Electricity can become a significant problem, however, if other issues, like high taxes, are offset by incentives offered by local economic development agencies.
Ken Green, the president of the Saratoga Economic Development Corporation, said that Quad Graphics, a company that employs 1,000 people in Saratoga Springs, wanted to build a new plant in the area.
Even though his agency was able to reduce some of the plant's costs of environmental compliance, the high cost of energy supplied by Niagara Mohawk played a big role in management's decision to build instead in West Virginia.
"We still have that noose of higher energy costs hanging around our necks," Mr. Green said, "that knocks New York State off the table when industry is looking to locate here."
Clarence D. Rappleyea, the chairman of the New York Power Authority, agreed. "Low electric rates," he said, "have now become a key component of the industrial development packages offered by major states." The power authority, a state agency that owns and runs many plants with low-cost energy, has been working closely with the Pataki administration to offer cheap electricity to struggling industries.
The struggle has been particularly hard for the paper industry, a heavy user of power. For example, in Glens Falls, a city of 15,000 about 50 miles north of Albany, the Encore Paper Company has been weighed down in recent years by huge electric bills from Niagara Mohawk. These have totaled $3.8 million a year, representing 12 percent of Encore's operating costs.
"We're trying to sell our products in markets where electricity costs for our competitors are half of ours," said George E. Mangarelli, the chief financial officer of Encore, which employs 300 people and turns out tissues, towels and toilet paper.
Like other heavy power users, Encore thought it could not wait for the state to lift the barriers that keep lower-cost utilities out of Niagara Mohawk's service area. The removal of such barriers is at the heart of the deregulation effort.
Instead, under a special program to help industrial customers keep jobs, Encore was able to contract for cheaper power from the power authority, which will save the company $1.2 million a year. Under the program's rules, though, few companies qualify for such assistance.
The depressing effect of high power rates on the economy of Glens Falls worries many local political and business leaders.
"There has not been any expansion here," said Paul A. Kemnitzer, the town treasurer, who frets about a rising delinquency rate in property tax payments that he links to the loss of high-paying jobs.
He noted that another big local employer -- Finch, Pruyn & Company, a paper manufacturer with 1,000 workers -- decided to build its own power plant to lower its costs.
"If they were still buying power from Niagara Mohawk, they would not be in business," Mr. Kemnitzer said. Niagara Mohawk charges the average large industrial customer 7.9 cents a kilowatt-hour, double the rate of many areas in the Northwest and the South.
While Glens Falls struggles with its economic health, the loss of large customers like Encore and Finch has begun to sap the financial strength of Niagara Mohawk, which cannot cut its costs fast enough to offset the decline in revenue.
To keep more customers and prepare for the new competitive environment of deregulation, Niagara Mohawk decided to bite the bullet and buy out its long-term power contracts, under which it pays triple the going rate on the wholesale market.
It has also cut special deals with some of its most restive large customers, reducing its revenue by $230 million a year.
With revenue down, the utility has suspended its dividend and its stock has plunged. At times, it has warned of the possibility that it might seek protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
"It's very painful to work your way through this, and it's very complicated," said Theresa A. Flaim, the utility's vice president for corporate strategic planning.
The danger, she said, is that if the utility's revenue base erodes much more, it could end up not having enough cash flow to pay for its past investments in power plants and other so-called stranded costs.
And if it cannot recover those costs, she warned, "you could end up in a financial death spiral."
Thus, the state's politicians and regulators walk a fine line in deregulating the industry. A major step in this direction was the reorganization plan, announced March 14, to prepare Con Ed for deregulation. That plan could set a pattern for agreements with the state's other large utilities. And it underscores why most of the pressure for change in New York is coming from industrial users: The savings from deregulation will be negligible for most homeowners, other than those served by Long Island Lighting. Lilco is an exception because its high rates stem largely from the decision not to open the Shoreham nuclear plant.
The unequal split in savings is the case nationally as well. Big employers in other states, like Raytheon in Massachusetts, have been able to shape the drive for rate cuts in their areas along the same lines.
"This process is being driven by the large industrial customers and large marketers," said Edwin S. Rothschild, the energy policy director of Citizen Action, a national consumer group based in Washington. "After the dust settles, it will be the residential customer who will have less savings."
Despite the concessions they have already won, the biggest utility customers are pressing for more, in New York and elsewhere: full-scale deregulation, with the promise of even lower rates from wide-open competition.
Toward that end, they have formed trade groups to keep them informed and to lobby state legislators and governors.
While the Con Ed agreement and others like it nationwide have been attacked by consumer groups and some legislators as leaving small customers shortchanged, it is the kind of bitter medicine, state officials say, that is needed to save jobs.
"It may make the residential people upset," Mr. Rappleyea of the power authority said. "But the job factor is big in everybody's mind."

HEADLINE: March 16-22;
Clinton and Yeltsin Manage to Get Along

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials seemed heartened by the outcome of Mr. Clinton's summit meeting Thursday and Friday in Helsinki with the once-again vigorous Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin -- their first meeting since last April.
Rather than blustering about NATO's plans to enlarge, which Russia opposes, Mr. Yeltsin acted to preserve and revive Russia's strategic partnership with the United States. 
 The Russians had a weak hand, knowing they were unable to stop NATO expansion, but they played it well. They won some important concessions on strategic arms control, economic aid and the
nature of NATO's enlargement, which will emphasize political stability rather than military preparedness against some Russian threat.
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton, who was hobbled during the meeting by his knee injury, enjoy each other. Most important in Helsinki, Mr. Yeltsin put his trust in Mr. Clinton that NATO means no harm to Russia and does not mean to shut Moscow out of the heart of a democratic Europe.
Mr. Yeltsin, in a bargain for a better future, swallowed his pride. But it's not clear that his parliament, which is dominated by nationalists and Communists, will go along -- to finally ratify either the second strategic arms reduction treaty or the new NATO-Russian charter of security cooperation that both Presidents hope to sign before NATO meets in Madrid, to announce its expansion, in July. STEVEN ERLANGER

HEADLINE: The $1 Trillion Dogfight

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
YOU would think they were selling cans of cola to the chief executives of the world's airlines instead of flying machines that can cost more than $125 million apiece.
One Airbus marketing brochure depicts a Boeing 777 as an aging stretch limousine painted taxicab yellow and the Airbus A340 as a sleek Mercedes sedan. In another, Airbus cattily points out the age of the Boeing 737, noting that the plane entered service the same year, 1968, that Richard M. Nixon was first elected President. 
 And in a brochure from Boeing, Airbus is not even granted the respect of being mentioned by name, with the company's wares referred to only as "Theirs."
Such flippant selling materials show how serious the marketing battle has become between the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, the world's two superpowers in passenger planes.
In the last year, the skies were essentially cleared of second-tier competitors, as Fokker N.V. landed in bankruptcy and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation accepted a merger proposal from Boeing. That has left just two teams in the biggest contest in industry history.
"It will be like most Super Bowls," said Byron K. Callan, an aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch. "It's going to be a very, very close game or it's going to be a blowout."
The stakes are huge: an estimated $1 trillion or more in orders over the next 20 years. Industry forecasts suggest that more than 13,500 planes will be built -- eclipsing the size of the fleet now in service -- to replace aging fleets and accommodate the growing demand for air travel, particularly in heavily populated developing countries like China. The "sticker price" of a Boeing passenger jet ranges from $32 million for its smallest plane, the 737, to $171 million for its newest offering, the 777; Airbus jets range from $40 million for the A319 to $128 million for the A340.
With just each other to worry about, Boeing and Airbus might be expected to act like most duopolies, settling back and cruising profitably on autopilot as they divvy up the skies.
But that will probably not happen anytime soon. For one thing, airline orders are typically measured in billions of dollars, so a lot rides on each sale. And those sales contracts are getting bigger. As competitive pressures mount for the airlines, the economies of scale gained from flying just one maker's planes are proving irresistible. In the last four months, American Airlines and Delta have signed long-term exclusive buying deals with Boeing, and US Airways has signed a large, although not exclusive, one with Airbus. If a customer is lost, it might be lost for a very long time.
"It's downright bloody out there," said John J. Leahy, an Airbus senior vice president and the company's chief salesman.
When pressed for their definition of victory in this trillion-dollar dogfight, executives from Seattle-based Boeing, which has long dominated the industry, said they wanted to consistently win two-thirds of all new orders, about their current level. Airbus, a privately held consortium of manufacturers from Britain, France, Germany and Spain, wants to consistently win about half of all orders. That would represent a big jump for Airbus, which is less than half the size of Boeing. But considering how quickly this upstart has grown, its goal seems well within the realm of possibility.
Clearly, only one company will succeed in its goal, and at the expense of the other.
Comparing aircraft order statistics can be a dark science, but based on the companies' announcements of orders, compiled by Edmund S. Greenslet, an industry analyst, Boeing has won 63 percent of the plane orders over the last five years, Airbus has won 27 percent and McDonnell Douglas 10 percent. In the last year alone, however, Boeing won 66 percent of the orders, Airbus received 30 percent and McDonnell Douglas only 4 percent. (True to form, Airbus contends that the Boeing numbers are inflated because it counts less definitive orders, and that Airbus in fact won 44 percent of the orders last year.)
The battle is fraught with risks and uncertainties that could divide the market into larger or smaller slices than either company is projecting.
Airbus, for example, hopes to leapfrog over Boeing in jumbo-jet sales by building a double-decker plane that could hold more than 550 passengers. But if demand falls short of its projections, it may have trouble recouping its investment, which it estimates at $8 billion. Airbus could also stumble if its member companies start squabbling over the consortium's plan to raise money by going public. Boeing, meanwhile, may face difficulties of its own in digesting its planned acquisition of McDonnell Douglas, a deal that is considered unlikely to be blocked by antitrust regulators in Washington.
Because the stakes are so high, both sides appear to be fighting over every last order with everything they have.
Consider Airbus's failed effort to win over Delta. Among other things, Airbus bought $95,000 worth of television time in the airline's hometown of Atlanta for commercials about its planes. It was an unusual move, considering that Airbus really needed to sway just one person, Harry Alger, Delta's executive vice president for operations.
"At any corner, at any level of this company, they're there," Mr. Alger said of Airbus before he chose Boeing. Although he and other executives say they base their decisions on cost and technical capabilities of aircraft, such marketing efforts do not go unnoticed. "From a marketing standpoint, Airbus is very, very aggressive," he added.
SOMETIMES the manufacturers' marketing efforts get a helping hand from international politics.
Many airlines in the Far East, for example, have fleets that are largely from Boeing, a convenient and highly visible way for governments to put a dent in the United States trade deficit with Japan and the rest of the region. And when Saudi Arabia was in the market for new jets in 1995, President Clinton stepped in as part-time salesman and closed a 61-jet, $6 billion deal for Boeing and McDonnell Douglas to share.
Airbus has a clear edge in many European countries, where airlines like Lufthansa, Air France and Iberia tend to shop locally for new planes -- no doubt with encouragement from officials of the four countries in which Airbus's partners reside.
For all that, the political realities can hinder as much as help the home team.
For example, Boeing has been building a relationship with China for 25 years, setting up training centers and developing an air-traffic control system there, and even making the country a subcontractor to build tail sections for its 737's. Boeing has also been an unpaid lobbyist in Washington, stumping for most-favored-nation status for China. Nonetheless, China thanked Boeing last year by placing a $1.5 billion order with Airbus, sending a signal to the Clinton Administration that it could turn to Europe if the United States became too pushy on human rights and trade issues.
Just last week, a possible order by China for a small fleet of 777's also became snagged by politics. In that case, China wants Vice President Al Gore to preside over the signing of the deal, a ticklish situation for Mr. Gore in light of China's role in the Administration's campaign finance imbroglio. A decision from Mr. Gore and a final word on the deal were pending as of Friday.
Boeing executives say that they are often treated as a political football.
"We are exposed to being used as something to kick," said Ronald B. Woodard, president of Boeing's commercial airplane group.
Airlines have done their share of kicking the manufacturers, too, but to win better deals -- something they could do relatively easily when there were several manufacturers competing for sales. Continental Airlines found last year, for example, that it was able to get a better deal on 737's by telling Boeing it was considering buying MD-95's from McDonnell Douglas.
Over time, many industry experts say, Boeing and Airbus may be able to exert more control over pricing, particularly if they are able to sign up many airlines for long-term exclusive relationships. After all, an airline that flies an all-Boeing or all-Airbus fleet will have little desire to switch -- mixing fleet types sharply increases training and other costs -- and will therefore have less leverage in future negotiations for new aircraft.
The existence of just two major manufacturers may also smooth out the wide swings in this notoriously cyclical business. Historically, jet makers have ramped up employment and production to build planes when demand was high, only to have to lay off thousands of workers when it slackened. Now, with nowhere else for the airlines to go -- barring the entry of a new manufacturer or the revival of Fokker -- Boeing and Airbus should be able to manage those fluctuations better.
"The nature of the industry is changing," said Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers. "Traditional aircraft gluts, which were the product of airline-buying frenzies, may be a thing of the past."
For now, though, the two companies are competing more aggressively than ever.
When Airbus wins an order, Boeing excuses its loss by saying that Airbus, as a consortium that has received government support, does not have the same operating constraints as a big publicly owned American company.
"There is no doubt that they will take risks that we, as a practical matter, cannot take," Mr. Woodard said. "We have different sets of business realities forced upon us."
Airbus executives retort that they are not undercutting Boeing, that they are repaying all the government loans they have received and that Boeing has received plenty of indirect government subsidies of its own.
Airbus has also criticized Boeing's penchant for exclusive contracts, saying that such a practice is bad for the airline industry because it eliminates new competitive bids for decades.
THE two even jab each other over safety issues -- long taboo among airlines and airplane manufacturers. Under the auspices of an information bulletin for employees in December, Mr. Woodard pointed out that throughout the jet age, safety has typically increased with each new generation of airplanes. "However, note that the Airbus A320/321 are an exception to this pattern," he wrote, referring to four crashes over the last nine years.
Airbus executives point out that investigators attributed all of those crashes to factors unrelated to the planes' airworthiness. "The A320 family is as safe or safer than anything made by our competitors," said Mr. Leahy, the Airbus senior vice president.
Airbus executives also say that Mr. Woodard's statement in the Boeing newsletter incorrectly suggested that the A321 model had a history of accidents. In fact, the model has never been in an accident.
A spokesman for Airbus, David C. Venz, said that because Airbus aircraft use the most advanced data recorders, the cause of each accident of an Airbus plane has been quickly determined. "There have been no mysteries," Mr. Venz said in a thinly veiled reference to the uncertainty surrounding the cause of two Boeing 737 crashes, and the crash last summer of T.W.A. Flight 800, a Boeing 747.
And the spin goes on. Airbus likes to characterize its products as "money-making machines," compared with Boeing's "commodities." Airbus attributes Boeing's successes to the power of a "myth machine." In a presentation to reporters last year, Adam Brown, Airbus vice president for forecasting and strategic planning, talked about his frustration in sales campaigns with "a competitor who seems increasingly to treat the truth somewhat economically."
But Mr. Woodard of Boeing has registered similar complaints, even taking a shot at Mr. Brown personally. "I've watched him and his nose does grow longer when he talks," Mr. Woodard told reporters at the Farnborough Air Show in England in 1994.
But when the spinning stops, how do these companies really match up?
EACH company, of course, has its strengths and its potential weaknesses.
Boeing's 747, which is much bigger than any Airbus model, gives Boeing a a wider range of aircraft sizes. And with the combined resources, revenues and future profits from its acquisition of McDonnell Douglas, Boeing will have an enormous budget for research and development. (Last year, Boeing spent $1.2 billion in this area.) It also benefits from the transfer of technology between the commercial and military parts of its business. However, it is likely to have some difficulty integrating the McDonnell military operation and the Douglas aircraft business -- which have never seen themselves as one company as it is -- into Boeing.
Airbus has had many technological and marketing achievements. But it may trip as it tries to balance the varying interests of its members in creating a new, publicly held corporate structure.
Such a restructuring, though, also holds out the possibilities of greater efficiencies. Many functions, like market forecasting, are now done by each of its members, as well as by Airbus staff.
By all accounts, Airbus has taken a less conventional approach to designing and marketing aircraft, and that has paid off in its ability to oust McDonnell Douglas from the industry's No. 2 spot. Boeing made its mark by being the first to build jets, in the 1950's -- a move that catapulted it past Douglas Aircraft.
Airbus is also counting on technological innovation to set it apart. For example, it adopted the concept of commonly equipped cockpits as its signature, enabling pilots to switch from one type of plane to another with minimal training. Because this represents a huge savings to airlines, Boeing has followed suit and now builds its 757 and 767 with common cockpits.
Airbus can also take credit for building the first wide-body jet, the A300, to fly with just two engines. It was the first to make a key piece of a production plane -- the vertical tail fin -- out of composite materials, and the first to use an entirely electronic flight system, rather than mechanical controls, to move key parts like the rudder.
The structure of Airbus, which was established as a risk-sharing partnership 27 years ago, is also unusual: Daimler-Benz of Germany and Aerospatiale of France each hold 37.9 percent, British Aerospace holds 20 percent and Construcciones Aeronauticas, or Casa, of Spain owns 4.2 percent.
THE companies in Airbus are also its key subcontractors. Generally, British Aerospace makes the wings, Daimler-Benz builds the fuselages and Casa makes parts of the tail sections, while Aerospatiale produces the cockpits and assembles most of the planes in Toulouse, France, where Airbus is based. A former Aerospatiale executive, Jean Pierson, is the chairman of Airbus.
Boeing takes a much more traditional approach to business. It wants to know an airline's needs better than the airline itself does, and then offer a numbingly thorough and tailored sales pitch.
"The Airbus crowd tends to be much more image-driven," said Robert W. Baker, executive vice president for operations at American, who last November committed the airline to buying Boeing jets for the next 20 years, and placed an initial order for 103 jets worth $6.6 billion. "Boeing is a very methodical corporation, and has perhaps done a little better job of reading customers' desires."
For example, Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman, has long complained that when a reading light burns out on his company's aircraft, a mechanic is needed to replace it. Boeing took care of that problem on its new 777, in which the lights can be changed by flight attendants.
Airbus executives say they also listen closely to customers, and again blame what they call the Boeing myth machine -- in this case, for the common perception that Boeing was the first to grow ears.
If the companies' order books are any indication, though, Boeing does it a bit better. Over the last five years, Boeing has announced orders for 244 of its 777's, compared with 162 for Airbus's A330 and A340, which are comparable in size.
The ability to listen to customers will be increasingly important in coming years, experts say, as blockbuster technological innovations occur more rarely. Historically, the airline industry has responded and adapted to innovations from manufacturers, like the jet engines and the two-person cockpits that drastically changed the economics of the business. Now, as the airlines' involvement in designing the 777 suggests, it is the other way around.
But when listening to customers, these aircraft makers tend to hear different things. Boeing, for example, has decided that most airlines do not need anything bigger than a 747, which Boeing has been building and refining for almost 30 years.
Airbus, however, believes there is enough demand to develop its jumbo double-decker plane, which could hold about 120 more passengers than the largest 747 model. With encouragement from carriers like British Airways and Singapore Airlines, Airbus says the oversized planes will be needed to carry passengers more efficiently between cities like London, Tokyo and New York, where crowded skies are straining airport capacity.
Airbus plans to start delivering the plane, currently called the A3XX, in 2003 with a projected price tag of $198 million, and is trying to sign up more partners to help share the costs and risks. It spent a year in fruitless negotiations with Boeing over possibly building the aircraft together. (In hindsight, it was an effective, though not necessarily intentional, move by Boeing to delay Airbus's efforts.)
In many ways, the two companies' decisions on the issue of large aircraft crystallize their differences: Airbus, the challenger ever willing to place a risky bet with a potential payoff of one-upping the competition, and Boeing, the more conservative leader.
Not surprisingly, Boeing's steady course has won approval from investors. On Jan. 21, the day after Boeing announced that it would hold off investing $7 billion to develop larger versions of its 747, delighted stockholders bid up the shares 7 percent. Since then, the stock has fallen 7 percent, closing Friday at $105.75, giving Boeing a market capitalization of $38.1 billion.
Over the last four years, Boeing's stock has risen more than threefold. While some industry analysts say the stock is peaking, others still see more upside. Mr. Callan, the aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the maturity of Boeing's product lines and higher production rates meant that the company would be generating enormous profits.
Boeing, with sales last year of $22.7 billion and a net profit of $1.1 billion, is already more than twice the size of Airbus. And McDonnell Douglas will make it a lot bigger. Last year, McDonnell Douglas had a profit of $788 million on sales of $13.83 billion, mostly from its military business. By contrast, Airbus's sales last year were $8.8 billion; it does not report profits.
At some point after 2000, Airbus, too, may sell shares to the public. That will most likely prompt many investors to take their first close look at Airbus. Mr. Leahy, the Airbus senior vice president, said that because much of what investors have learned about the aerospace industry has come from skewed information from Boeing, Airbus will be able to illuminate what is really happening in the industry -- namely, that it is a bigger and more formidable contender than people think. "What investors really ought to do is look at the cold, hard facts," he said.
Boeing executives counter that their facts tend to be colder and harder than those offered by Airbus. Mr. Woodard, with feigned sincerity, will concede only one thing to Airbus.
"There is no doubt," he said, "they are superior p.r. types compared to us."

HEADLINE: Pondering the Inequities in Today's Job Market

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Occasionally one edition of your paper carries two news articles that, taken together, demonstrate the errors of our present self-centered society. March 19 was such a day. 
 A front-page article described how, in New York City, 4,000 job seekers showed up to apply for 700 jobs at the Roosevelt Hotel. Since the jobs are described as paying between $6 and $15 an hour, we can estimate the annual payroll for the 700 successful applicants as less than $14 million. Even adding a liberal 30 percent for benefits, the total cost of employing those 700 will be less than $20 million per year.
A Business Day article reported on I.B.M.'s proxy statement and included an analysis by Graef C. Crystal, an executive compensation consultant. He calculated that the chief executive of I.B.M. received $20.2 million in total pay last year.
The fundamental incongruity speaks for itself. As a friend once remarked, "Don't bother me with the details. Someone is stealing from someone."
 
EDWARD C. MCIRVINE
Charlottesville, Va., March 20, 1997

HEADLINE: Wave of Violence Unsettles Nerves in Haiti

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 21

 BODY:
With an election just two weeks away, Haiti is confronting another outburst of violence. The unsolved attacks have shaken confidence in the new, American-trained National Police and in the ability of President Rene Preval's Government to provide security for the increasingly frustrated and fearful population.
Since mid-February, more than 50 people have been killed in incidents whose origins remain unclear. Six police officers are among the dead, along with the security chief for the Ministry of Justice, a well-known businessman and the chauffeur of a senator who was himself wounded in the same attack. 
 The violence began with battles between rival gangs of drug dealers and traffickers in Cite Soleil, a sprawling slum here with more than 200,000 residents. At least 18 people were killed in those clashes, which have been followed by attacks by armed gunmen in more upscale areas and by incidents in which the police have killed innocent bystanders or people fleeing crime scenes.
"Is the climate of insecurity becoming a climate of terror?" the newspaper Le Nouvelliste asked in a recent editorial. "The specter of Haiti turning into a a sort of Somalia has shown itself to be a real possibility."
There have also been complaints that the United Nations mission here, greatly reduced in size since 23,000 American troops restored Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Mr. Preval's predecessor, to power in October 1994, is not doing enough. The mission continues to provide "technical support" and training to the Haitian police. United Nations officials have urged calm and say that some of the concerns are exaggerated.
"We're going through a bad patch right now," Enrique ter Horst, director of the United Nations mission here, acknowledged in an interview. But he described the situation as "exceptional and temporary," saying "there is no doubt that political stability is not in danger" and calling for "a sense of perspective."
As is often the case here, it is not clear whether the attacks have been carried out for political reasons, are ordinary crimes or are a mixture of the two. "It is hard to explain the spikes of violence that occur from time to time," the American Ambassador, William L. Swing, said.
Mr. Swing suggested that "a good deal of it reflects the economy," which has failed to provide jobs or the growth people expected after Mr. Aristide's return to power. Haitian officials have also pointed to Senate and municipal elections scheduled for April 6, which they say have set off partisan disputes in the countryside.
"Elections fan local struggles for power, above all for control of the local councils," said Prime Minister Rosny Smarth.
In addition, "it is possible that people who are boycotting the elections don't want them to happen," said Kely Bastien, the Speaker of the lower house of Parliament.
Twice this year, left-wing splinter groups claiming to support Mr. Aristide and to oppose Mr. Preval's program of privatizing state-owned companies have called general strikes in the capital. The latest effort, less successful than an earlier one in January, was on Thursday, and was accompanied by threats of retribution against those who failed to comply with the call.
Flyers distributed around the capital warned that "anything that moves, be it a mouse or a feather, will be shot to smithereens." Most schools and businesses remained closed and many people stayed in their homes.
In an interview, Mr. Smarth, who faces a vote of confidence in Parliament next week, dismissed the importance of such threats, attributing them to "groups that do not have public support, cannot mobilize anyone, and so have turned to intimidation."
"It all seems a little chaotic," he said of the current situation. "But that is the result of us leaving behind an authoritarian regime for one that is democratic."
Whatever its source, the violence has revived concerns about the ability of Haiti's poorly trained and inexperienced police force to maintain public order. The 5,200-member force was set up in mid-1995 to replace the Haitian Armed Forces, which Mr. Aristide dissolved in 1994, three years after he was deposed by a military coup.
Many Haitians express irritation with the police, calling them brutal, corrupt and imperious. At the same time, they complain that the police are incompetent, apparently unable to solve even simple cases.
"People are dying, and the same people are committing the same acts as always," said Philippe Paul, an unemployed 23-year-old. "The same people who had guns before still have them, and though the police want to do their jobs, people are getting killed, and the police don't know how it happens."
In a report issued in January, three American human rights groups severely criticized the Haitian National Police, blaming it for many cases of torture and "extrajudicial executions or the excessive, unjustified use of lethal force."
Though such abuses "do not reflect an official government policy," in contrast to previous military regimes, the report added, they do indicate a distressing lack of official accountability.
"It is alarming to see members of this new, U.S.-trained police force resort to abusive practices reminiscent of Haiti's repressive military," said Jose Miguel Vivanco, executive director of Americas Watch, a Washington-based human rights group that helped issue the report. "If the Haitian Government does not address these issues promptly, it risks institutionalizing abuse and undermining the legitimacy of the new force."
Mr. Swing, the American Ambassador, said the Haitian Government had taken steps to address such complaints, training more mid-level commanders and setting up an Inspector General's office that has dismissed nearly 100 officers for human rights violations. "The police are literally getting better by the day," he said.
The police force is supported by 1,300 United Nations soldiers and police, whose mandate expires July 31. In addition, nearly 500 American troops are here in a noncombat role, building roads, bridges and clinics and digging wells.
There is widespread concern among Haitians that the international force will depart, leaving the police on their own. Government officials said they had been talking with Canada about a long-term agreement that would replace the United Nations mandate, since it appears more and more likely the United Nations will not stay on in its present role and numbers.
Mr. ter Horst said he hopes "that we will be able to stick to our current July 31 deadline." After that date, he continued, he expects that "we will have mainly a technical assistance arrangement in the form of development projects."
But he added, "It is clear that if the Government needs any additional assistance, I don't see the international community leaving Haiti in the lurch, especially considering the very considerable investment it has made here."

HEADLINE: As Life Gets Even Harder, Albania Grows More Fractured

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, March 23

 BODY:
At the open market in the center of this ramshackle capital, shoppers stared this morning at the fresh fruit and vegetables piled high on the wooden stalls and at the meat, unable to believe the prices. Oranges had doubled in the last three weeks; the price of sausage was up nearly 50 percent.
But the price of food is far from the only problem here. Three weeks after Albania was consumed by armed insurgencies in the south and counter-rebellions here and in the north, picking up the pieces to mold a unified country is proving very hard. 
 The coalition Government of the Socialist Prime Minister, Bashkim Fino, controls little outside the capital. The Albanian Army, always one of the most feeble in Europe, evaporated during the rebellions and few deserters have returned to their posts.
A Western diplomat said the new Government might use some Albanian naval ships now in Italy to try to take back the southern port of Sarande, now in rebel hands. But "that's one big 'if,' " the diplomat said.
Another southern port town, Vlore, remains in the hold of rebels. A committee from Vlore met in Tirana with Mr. Fino on Saturday -- but there appeared to be little progress in bringing the town back into the Government's fold. The delegation said it was still insisting that President Sali Berisha resign before any consideration would be given to surrendering arms seized from army depots in the town one month ago.
To illustrate their anger, one group from Vlore circulated a petition saying it had found a modern-day Avni Rustemi, a legendary Albanian hero who went to Paris in 1924 and gunned down the Albanian Prime Minister because the people believed he had robbed the country. The new Rustemi would kill the head of the secret police, Bashkim Gazidede, unless he resigned, according to the petition.
The rebels have also demanded the resignation of Mr. Berisha, who still controls the important Interior Ministry and its secret police. But he said in an interview with the Italian newspaper La Repubblica that he would not be "blackmailed" into resigning.
He blamed the "Mafia and rebels" for terrorizing the population, and said former Communists had organized the rebellion in the south because they lost parliamentary elections last May. Mr. Berisha's Democratic Party claimed a resounding victory in those elections, which were deemed deeply flawed by the United States and other Western countries. The opposition parties have refused to sit in Parliament since then, making the body a rubber stamp for Mr. Berisha.
Mr. Fino, together with his new Finance Minister, Arben Malaj is expected to visit Rome on Tuesday to meet with European officials as well as some from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Mr. Malaj said he would ask for assistance to help manage sectors of the economy, and for an initial $150 million for balance-of-payments support.
"We have no revenues," Mr. Malaj said in an interview.
He said he understood that Albania had to "re-establish public order" to qualify for assistance.
Economists say they cannot recall another recent instance where a European country faced such an economic collapse. Many banks outside Tirana have been robbed. A large percentage of the population is worse off than at the end of Communism because they lost their savings in failed pyramid schemes, losses that touched off the revolt. The minimal production that Albania ever had appears to have ground to a halt.
In Tirana, the calmest spot in the country, there was a blanket of despair today.
"I have little hope with this new Government," said Flora, a 54 year old film editor at Albanian State Television as she started her weekend shopping. Flora, who did not want to give her surname, said the new coalition Government headed by Mr. Fino had made little headway during its 10 days of existence.
She was particularly distressed, she said, that Mr. Berisha, who many Albanians blame for encouraging the fraudulent financial schemes, had survived the turmoil.
"After all this and all that he has created, it is irritating to see him back on television," she said.

HEADLINE: By the Sea, the Specter of Drugs and AIDS

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 19

 BODY:
The well-being of this old whaling city whose cobblestone streets Herman Melville once roamed can be measured at Millie's Laundry.
"I used to have fishing bags all the way out this hallway," said the proprietor, Millie Barlow, standing in her laundry down by the waterfront, with a clamshell mobile above the dryers and a shark's jaws mounted on the wall. 
 That was a decade ago, when the fish were still abundant and there were plenty of commercial fishermen making good money. Ms. Barlow would stay open all night, pulling their blood-, salt- and gurry-soaked clothes out of the bags and piling them into her specially designed machines, with two wash cycles and two rinse cycles.
"They came from Texas, down South, from the Carolinas, from New Jersey," she recalled. "They came from everywhere. We were the biggest fishing industry in the country."
But fishing has changed, and so has New Bedford. Where once there were more than 3,000 working fishermen, they now number fewer than 1,500. And with Government restrictions to conserve fishing grounds, each season means fewer fishing days. And that means less laundry.
It is not only the depleted fishing grounds that have devastated the city. The textile mills that once provided jobs for thousands of uneducated immigrants have long since shut down, and jobs are scarce for everyone.
Now, amid the deepening poverty, the city is being visited by the deadly plague of drugs and AIDS.
Ms. Barlow keeps an unofficial record of the dead on the wall of her laundry, posting the obituaries from the local newspaper of the men and women she knew. Most of them died young, in their 30's or early 40's.
"Died unexpectedly -- that means a drug overdose," Ms. Barlow said, reading aloud from the obituaries on her bulletin board. "Died after a long illness -- that's AIDS."
At the fisherman's bar next door to Millie's, the National Club, Dick Alcobia, the owner, a former fisherman, talks angrily about the obituaries. "They put it in the newspaper -- died unexpectedly," said Mr. Alcobia, who has been dispensing drinks -- and interest-free loans -- to fishermen in this town for 35 years. "Why not be honest? Why not let the guy die for a reason? You go to the wake, the casket is closed because some guy who used to weigh 200 pounds is shriveled up to 65 pounds, and they don't want anybody to see."
New Bedford, with 100,000 people and 417 reported AIDS cases since 1981, has the fifth-highest rate of AIDS in Massachusetts. Three-quarters of the cases are caused by intravenous drug use, health officials say.
Ms. Barlow recently went to the funeral of a scalloper in his 30's who died "after a long illness."
"He was a real nice guy, smart guy," she said. Sadly, she added, "A heroin addict."
Up the street from Millie's at the police station, Lieut. Melvin Wotton, a fisherman's son who heads the narcotics unit, held up a small plastic bag filled with heroin. "It used to be $20 a bag," he said. "Now it's $8 to $10." The heroin, he said, comes up along the highways from Providence and New York.
Away at sea for 10 to 16 days at a time and then home for less than a week, a fisherman has a life that can be stressful and lonely. Some turn to drugs and alcohol for comfort, Ms. Barlow said, and social service workers agree. By all accounts, the drug dealers prey on fishermen with money in their pocket, a few days to unwind and, for many, no families. "They sit down and wait for them at the dock," Mr. Alcobia said.
There are no records showing the extent of drug use among fisherman, and Lieutenant Wotton and other experts here say the problem affects people throughout the city.
Ms. Barlow knows of as many as 40 fishermen who have died of AIDS or drug overdoses in the last five years, she said, but she also knows plenty of fishermen who do not use drugs. The local newspaper, The Standard-Times, reported last July that a review of death certificates showed that 50 fishermen in New Bedford and surrounding communities had died of AIDS or drug-related causes in the previous five years.
Construction workers, carpenters and teachers are also among the dead. Ms. Barlow lost her best friend, a waiter, to AIDS.
Ms. Barlow, a former waitress, got into the laundry business 12 years ago when her two sons, Brian, 42, and Tim, 33, were fishing; only Brian still does. "I had two sons fishing," she said. "I used to wash all their clothes and all their friends' clothes. I thought it was a great idea to open a laundry." She started her business in what used to be Skip's Marine Supply, two blocks from the Whaling Museum, where she likes to show off New Bedford's proud heritage to her four grandchildren.
Her customers, most of them single fishermen, call her Mom. They walk around with their clothes smelling sweetly of Snuggle, the fabric softener she puts in the dryers.
Ms. Barlow also offers her customers coffee, home-cooked meals, bleach for those who use needles to inject drugs and respect.
"I've been on the boat," she said. "I've seen how they work. I've seen how my son works. I think it's one of the hardest things I've seen in my life." Ms. Barlow knows all about hard work. She left high school at age 15 to go to work as a sales clerk to help her mother and father and 11 brothers and sisters.
Sometimes the fishermen drop off their bags of clothes but never come back. Pointing to a worn blue duffel bag on the floor, Ms. Barlow said the owner, from Poland, had drowned.
While there is not much washing to do these days, there is plenty of hubbub at Millie's. Ms. Barlow's ex-husband, Chic, is usually around, folding clothes and watching television in the back.
The visitors this afternoon included Ms. Barlow's sons and Patricia Holland Heaps, a psychotherapist who says her fisherman father died at sea of pneumonia two weeks before her 13th birthday.
Harry Morris, a fishing captain about to head off to sea, sat on a chair, waiting for his laundry.
The day before, another fishing captain, Carl Corrao Jr., had come by, back from his father's funeral in Florida. Ms. Barlow hugged him. "I'm so sorry about your father, Carl," she said.
Mr. Corrao held out a medallion he had received recently to mark his eighth year without drugs. Ms. Barlow congratulated him.
New Bedford, with its mix of Portuguese, Cape Verdean, Cambodian, Polish, Dominican and Guatemalan immigrants, had the highest unemployment rate, 10.6 percent, of any city in the state last year. But the city, which was among the richest in the world back in the 19th-century whaling days, is trying to make a comeback. Hopes were raised last year when the neighborhood that includes the laundry was designated a national historic district. There is talk of building an aquarium that would attract tourists.
"New Bedford has a lot of potential," Ms. Barlow said.
A sign over the laundry advertises her name in big black and white letters: Millie's. "I want people to know who I am when I come down here," she said.
There are days, though, with business lagging and the bill collectors calling, that she would rather not be Millie, she said. "When certain people call, I say, 'Millie's not here anymore -- she went to Florida.' "

HEADLINE: Down-and-Out Town Sees Survival in a Private Prison

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: FALLSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
Frank Kaplan, the town supervisor here, scans Main Street in South Fallsburg, one of the six communities that make up this Catskills town. He looks at the sagging buildings that used to house grocery stores, clothing shops, a pizza parlor and like a mantra he utters the obvious: "Empty. Boarded up. Empty. Boarded up."
The town is hurting. There are few jobs, few people and still fewer tax-paying businesses. There are several Orthodox Jewish temples and schools, but they are all tax exempt. There is a sprawling ashram on land once owned by three hotels. It is tax exempt. There are three state prisons. Again, tax exempt. 
 It's no wonder that when Corrections Corporation of America, the world's largest operator of private prisons, proposed building the first one in New York State here, Mr. Kaplan and other local officials perked up. The land and building would be taxable. "It would help stop the hemorrhaging," Mr. Kaplan said.
Corrections Corporation has already paid $470,000 for 185 acres on the site of the former Rothstein's Olympic Ranch and Fitness Resort, and plans to build a 1,000-bed "minimum to medium security" substance-abuse treatment prison, said Susan Hart, a spokeswoman. About 250 jobs would be created, she added.
But beyond its purchase of the land, the company has yet to detail its plans, and it is unclear whether it can legally build a prison in Fallsburg. New York prohibits private companies from housing the state's prisoners, and Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco says he is studying whether the company would be allowed to hold prisoners from other states under the law. To that end, he has asked to company to state its intentions.
Although Ms. Hart would not say where prisoners would come from, she said: "There is a need for a specialized type of correctional facility in this part of the country. We do not have a presence in New York State, and we're expanding not only the number of beds we have and the number of contracts, but we're expanding geographically. This would add to our book of business."
Corrections Corporation of America, based in Nashville, runs 59 prisons in 17 states and in Puerto Rico, Britain and Australia. It runs a detention center for illegal immigrants in Elizabeth, N.J. (It took over management of the center from another private prison concern, Esmor Correctional Services, after a disturbance.)
But it has not said whether it would try to hold Federal immigration detainees, or Federal prisoners, at the Fallsburg location.
Gov. George E. Pataki, generally known to support privatization, is strongly opposed to private prisons, as is the Commissioner of Correction, Glenn S. Goord, said James B. Flateau, a spokesman for the Department of Correctional Services.
"The Governor and the Commissioner believe that there are certain functions of government that government must perform," he said. "One of the most onerous functions of government is denying someone their liberty. That should be the responsibility of the Governor and the people he appoints."
None of this sits well with Mr. Kaplan and other members of the town board, who are still smarting from the State Senate's vote in January against legalized casino gambling in the Catskills and the rest of New York State.
"Why not let local people make up their minds about what they want?" Mr. Kaplan said. "What we lack are jobs, and jobs come from business. We need commercial tax-paying property. We're losing $10 million a year in assessed valuation. We don't appreciate these obstructionist attacks. How would the Governor have felt when he was Mayor of Peekskill if someone would have told him he couldn't have a business in town?"
Steve Levine, the town's deputy supervisor, agrees. "Let the state give us some money to augment what we lose from the tax-exempt businesses that are here, since their laws are hurting us," he said.
Mr. Kaplan thinks the Governor is pandering to the correction officers union.
Bob Lawson, communications director for Council 82, a union of 26,000 correction and law enforcement officers, makes no bones about the union's opposition to private prisons, most of which hire nonunion workers. "We have vowed to do everything from the grass roots to the Governor to oppose it," Mr. Lawson said. "The track record of private prisons in other states is dismal, to say the least, from the safety of the prisons to the training of correction officers."
Mr. Flateau pointed out that legislatively, much stands in the way of operating private prisons in New York. For example, he said, under New York State law, an escapee from a private prison cannot be charged with escape. (A judge in Texas ruled that inmates breaking out of private prisons could not be charged with escape. In Texas, which has more private prisons than any other state, legislators are considering rewriting the law to close that loophole.)
In other states, private companies have housed prisoners imported from elsewhere. But Attorney General Vacco said he would oppose importing prisoners into New York State.
"They ought to find a place like Texas or Florida where they're authorized by law to operate a private prison," he said. "I'm not going to stand idly by while they bring in prisoners from an undisclosed jurisdiction. We can do other things to enhance the economic climate in Sullivan County. Why do we want to turn the beauty of the natural landscape of the Catskills into a region of out-of-state prisoners. We have enough difficulty with our own prisoners."
Companies like Corrections Corporation of America can build prisons for 15 percent to 25 percent less than government agencies because they are not subject to the same construction contract rules.
They often operate their prisons for 10 percent to 20 percent less by hiring fewer administrators, procuring goods and services at lower rates and, finally, because most are not bound by civil service and union rules.
But for Mr. Levine, the union issue is a nonissue. He said he just wanted help for his dying community. "Let them be unionized," he said. "We don't care. We'll take another state prison for the jobs. It's like Albany has forgotten about us. It's like Sullivan County is second-class."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jobs and tax-paying businesses are in short supply in South Fallsburg, N.Y., officials say. A resident walked past boarded-up shops on the town's Main Street. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. B1)
 
Map showing the location of Fallsburg, N.Y.: A company wants to build a private prison in Fallsburg. (pg. B4)
