LENGTH: 676 words

HEADLINE: An Endangered Act

 BODY:
Last week the city of San Diego approved the first stage of the most ambitious effort ever undertaken in this country to reconcile the competing needs of environmental protection and economic development. The unanimous vote by the San Diego City Council means a virtual Noah's Ark of endangered plant and animal life will now have a fighting chance to survive the relentless development that has disfigured so much of Southern California. It may also give the Federal law that made the plan possible, the Endangered Species Act of 1973, a better chance of surviving Congressional efforts to weaken it.
Under the plan, out of a 900-square-mile region, 172,000 acres will be set aside as protected habitat for 85 endangered species. One of these is a vulnerable little bird called the California gnatcatcher, whose shaky hold on survival got the whole process started six years ago. Eventually, state and Federal planners hope to create a network of nature preserves covering an additional half-million acres from Los Angeles to Mexico. 
 In exchange for giving up all rights to develop this acreage, developers will be freed from any further obligation to protect endangered species on the rest of the land covered by the San Diego plan. The Clinton Administration has already built this "no surprises" policy -- shielding landowners from future challenges under the Endangered Species Act -- into scores of habitat conservation plans around the country.
Many conservationists do not like "no surprises." Nature, they note, is not static, and even the most beautifully designed habitat plan may need midcourse corrections. They have a point. In future agreements, the Federal Government should insist on the right to negotiate additional protections if they become necessary.
That said, the plan and its endorsement by a conservative city could not have come at a better moment for supporters of the Endangered Species Act. By protecting an entire ecosystem, the plan should reduce the need for the costly tract-by-tract, species-by-species struggles that provoke political opposition. The plan is also proof that the existing law can reconcile even the most bitter opponents without requiring the massive overhaul that some members of Congress have in mind.
The question is whether Congress is paying attention. The Endangered Species Act is the most controversial of the landmark environmental statutes passed during the Nixon era. Property-rights advocates hate it. The Republicans who run the key environmental committee in the House would just as soon get rid of it. Even in the more hospitable Senate, John Chafee of Rhode Island and Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho are circulating a draft bill that, while offering useful improvements, would leave the basic law in a weakened condition.
Mr. Chafee, for years one of the Senate's most dependable defenders of the environment, apparently believes that he has to offer a few compromises to head off the zealots on his committee. But the Administration is not so encumbered. It should march up to Capitol Hill with the message that the bill is unacceptable.
The bill would undercut the authority of the Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Marine Fisheries Service to review and when necessary modify Federal projects that harm species and their habitats. That job would be largely handed over to the very agencies whose projects are causing the threat -- agencies like the Forest Service, which has a dismal record on environmental matters. The bill also shifts control over water rights to the states, which in many Western jurisdictions would mean serious trouble for threatened fish species like the Pacific salmon. Finally, in codifying the "no surprises" policy, the bill fails to provide for the kind of midcourse review that would have made the San Diego plan much stronger than it is.
Bruce Babbitt, the Interior Secretary who worked hard to bring the San Diego plan into being, cannot rest on that achievement. His next task is to go up to the Senate and demand a better bill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Disabled Children Feel Budget Cuts;
Long-Term Care Is Reduced Under Managed Care Programs

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va.

 BODY:
Three-year-old Samantha can say about 10 words. She can say "stuck," as she tries to slide out of her wheelchair on her powerless legs. Peppy and playful now, Samantha started coming to the Children's Therapy Clinic here in the winter of 1996 with a range of disabilities that seemed to preclude any thought that she would ever speak or navigate a wheelchair.
"We had been told that she was severely, profoundly mentally retarded," said Connie Miller, Samantha's foster mother. "All she did was cry. She wanted to be flat on her back on the floor." 
 In 90-minute sessions every Tuesday, therapists have been working with Samantha and had ever rising hopes that she would eventually be able to function on her own. "She just hadn't been worked with," Ms. Miller said.
But those hopes are dimming. The state sharply cut financing for Samantha's therapy in January. Like many of the nation's children who have chronic and developmental disabilities, like cerebral palsy, Down syndrome, autism, sensory impairments and fetal alcohol syndrome, she has been caught in the move to limit state and Federal spending for welfare and health care, particularly for Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor whose costs the states share with the Federal Government.
Chronically handicapped children in West Virginia are not alone, though they are among the most severely affected because the state's weak economy has forced budget cuts. Most states are shifting to the businesslike practices of managed health care, and many are turning their patients over to health maintenance organizations that provide little chronic or long-term care for children.
Peggy McManus, co-director of the Maternal and Child Health Policy Research Center in Washington, a private group, said of children served by managed care: "It's a hot potato. The bottom line is these kids are not getting access to services."
In a study of the impact of managed care on children in four states -- Oregon, Hawaii, Rhode Island and Tennessee -- Ms. McManus said she found that "the infrastructure that has been created as a safety net for kids with special needs is crumbling."
The effort to cut costs has exposed sharp differences between health care services and government agencies over how much professional attention a child needs. "What we're finding is that the state is not going to want to pay to maintain these children," said Jennifer Bezjak, director of the Children's Therapy Clinic here. "The trend is to get children to a certain level and place the burden on the parent to continue the process."
West Virginia health officials do not dispute Ms. Bezjak's findings. They argue, however, that years of largely uncontrolled Medicaid spending, based mainly on the prescriptions of doctors and health care providers, led to excesses and inefficiencies at the Children's Therapy Clinic and the three other privately run clinics in the state for disabled children.
"No one denies they provide very good services," said Philip Shimer, Acting Commissioner for the Bureau for Medical Services, the state's Medicaid agency, speaking of the four clinics. But he said, "They were asked to better align what they were providing with what we pay for."
Medicaid was one program that President Clinton persuaded Congress not to cut in the overhaul of the welfare system last year. But cuts in care for the children in poverty who are eligible for Medicaid are coming anyway because of the cost-saving initiatives of many states.
"It's a real squeeze, from one state to the next," said Joseph Romer, executive vice president of the National Easter Seal Society, which operates 105 clinics for one million people with disabilities nationwide, including 350,000 children. Most of the clinics receive Medicaid support.
Depending on the strength of their economies, states contribute an average of 25 percent of the cost of Medicaid, and the Federal Government pays the rest. The states are allowed wide latitude in the type of care they provide. But when states cut the cost in their Medicaid programs, the Federal contributions decline in line with state spending.
For children with chronic disabilities, new state curbs on Medicaid pose a difficult question for politicians and bureaucrats, and not solely because of compassion for the children. Unlike most disabled adults or people needing short-term therapy after an accident or a bout with disease, a child with a chronic disability is often an uncharted terrain of human potential.
No one knows yet, for example, how far Samantha can go in learning to speak, to dress and feed herself, to use her muscles and limbs. But advocates of frequent professional therapy say that the more that government and charities invest in helping Samantha learn to function as a child, the less they will have to spend to support her as an adult.
Samantha's weekly therapy sessions cost about $5,000 a year, and foster care for her and her two foster brothers costs about $30,000 a year. But one year in an institution for one child costs $80,000 a year, according to the National Easter Seal Society. For the moment, the Children's Therapy Clinic here is keeping Samantha on her regular schedule of therapy by delaying admission of new patients and digging into its reserves of charitable donations, mostly from the United Way, which it uses to cover services that Medicaid does not and to treat children who have no insurance.
But that well, too, is running dry. Jack Blair, president of the United Way agency in Charleston, said the clinic was one of the city's most popular charities and the second-largest recipient of United Way grants. "But the private sector just cannot replace the revenue sources that have come from the government," Mr. Blair said.
In West Virginia, Medicaid spending, for which the state pays $1 for every $3 from the Federal Government, has become an enormous burden, leaping to $1.3 billion a year in combined state and Federal spending, from $400 million a year in the late 1980's. The state is trying to slice $150 million from that total.
Even West Virginia's relatively small share -- about $3.25 million -- has begun to put strains on a state that vies with Mississippi and Louisiana as the nation's poorest. Twenty-nine percent of West Virginia's children live in poverty.
And yet the state had become a model in caring for them. With the big expansion of Medicaid, the state's infant mortality rate dropped from 9.9 deaths for every 1,000 children up to the age of 1 in 1990 to 6.7 in 1994, lifting the state from 41st in the nation to 14th.
To achieve the new cut, West Virginia, like many states, has turned to the tight scrutiny and business practices of managed care in allocating money to health care providers like the Children's Therapy Clinic.
With 385 patients and a waiting list of 60, the clinic is the biggest of the four in the state providing therapy for disabled children, whether rich or poor, and the only one serving Charleston and a 10-county area.
About 220 of its patients are covered by Medicaid. Fifteen have no insurance and are covered entirely by charitable contributions. The rest are covered by their parents' private insurance policies.
The clinic charges $45 for a half-hour of occupational or physical therapy. Before the cuts, Medicaid reimbursed $35 of that amount and allowed up to 120 half-hour sessions for each patient a year. Under the cutback, Medicaid pays from $17 to $32 for sessions of 15 minutes to one hour and restricts the number of covered sessions to 20.
Experts in child development argue that children with chronic disabilities like Samantha's typically need regular and individually tailored professional therapy based on frequent evaluations of their progress by doctors and therapists. Without that, the experts say, the children can regress.
"Often what may be true for adults is absolutely not true for children," said Katy Neas, senior government relations specialist for the National Easter Seal Society. "They change so fast. You can get parents to help them with their exercises, but that's not therapy."
The state is also rationing the care. Jack Frazier, a senior policy analyst in the Medical Services Bureau, explained that a health care provider might seek financing for speech therapy for a 4-year-old child whom a doctor finds six months behind in learning to speak. The state could well reject that request now. "We would say he has a mild delay and that it's not significant," Mr. Frazier said.
Many patients, however, pose more difficult choices. Donna Manning's foster son, Kiry, 5, given up by an unwed mother at birth, is about 6 months old in development. He has to be carried. He gurgles and drools. He still drinks from a bottle and wears diapers. He cannot stand or even crawl. "He's got cerebral palsy and a brain deficiency," Ms. Manning said.
With regular therapy and practice at home, Kiry has begun sounding out vowels, his first signs of speech. He is showing some curiosity. "What he needs now is a wheelchair," Ms. Manning said. But with the new restraints, she said, the state would not buy him one.
Vicki Douglas, a Democratic state legislator, said the Medicaid budget planners' unilateral prescriptions for all children did not allow for the vast differences in children's needs. "Those T-shirt solutions, do not work very well for those who do not fit the T-shirt," she said.

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 1; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Flood as a Turning Point in the Nation's History

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

RISING TIDE
The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 and How It Changed America
By John M. Barry
Illustrated. 524 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.50. 
 It's a great idea for a popular history that John M. Barry has come up with in "Rising Tide: The Great Mississippi Flood of 1927 and How It Changed America." And he gets off to a wonderful beginning.
A political reporter whose first book was "The Ambition and the Power," about the downfall in 1989 of Speaker of the House James C. Wright Jr., Mr. Barry understands well how to create drama through conflict. And in the competition between two brilliant and fascinating 19th-century engineers, James Buchanan Eads and Andrew Atkinson Humphreys, he has a conflict amounting to a duel to the death with slide rules. Both of them shaped by an age that thought science could solve any problem, Eads and Humphreys were determined to master the chaotic forces of the Mississippi River. Through their separate studies they came to disagree with the conventional wisdom of the time, which held that the river's tendency to flood could be contained by levees, or earth mounded into hills along its banks.
Eads logically objected that levees only exerted their effect when the river rose to their high level. Levees would therefore not consistently speed up the flow of the water and produce the scouring effect needed to deepen the riverbed. His alternative proposal was to build jetties along each bank that would narrow the river and accelerate its flow, and its scouring effect, even when it wasn't flooding.
To demonstrate, Eads set about in 1875 to construct jetties in the mouth of the Mississippi that would cause the scouring out of the sandbars that were preventing ships from sailing up the river. By this time he had aroused Humphreys's enmity, and Humphrey had enough political pull to thwart his rival's project at every turn. Eads finally had to test his jetties' effect by getting an oceangoing steamship to sail between them. When the ship's bottom wasn't gouged out, his point was proven.
This first section of "Rising Tide," 100 pages long, is excitingly told, full of breathtaking twists and vivid scenes. Alas for posterity, Eads's point didn't stick, and the organization in charge of controlling the Mississippi went ahead with a levees-only system.
The catastrophic effect of this error was shown by the 1927 flood, when it washed out the levees in key places, and, as Mr. Barry writes, "put as much as 30 feet of water over lands where 931,159 people -- the nation's total population was only 120 million -- had lived."
Unfortunately too, Mr. Barry's narrative loses its breakneck momentum when his two engineers leave the scene. The focus shifts north to the Yazoo-Mississippi Delta and the story of how four generations of a family named Percy founded the city of Greenville, Miss., and tried to build an agricultural civilization around it based on rich cotton and cheap labor.
There is dramatic conflict here too, particularly between the Percys, who wanted to keep black labor in the South, and the Ku Klux Klan, whose purpose was to drive blacks away. And there is much portentous prose about dark secrets, family scandal and a Faulknerian curse on the land. But despite Mr. Barry's pumping up of his story, its events are too diffuse in their occurrence and abstract in their significance to match the opening section's excitement.
All the same, "Rising Tide" remains worthwhile to read as history. Because of the levee system's failure, two particularly disastrous chains of events were set in motion. When a levee upriver from Greenville was breached, the flooding of the Delta led to a situation in which, as Mr. Barry describes events, the black population was betrayed by the Percy family and suffered severe mistreatment.
Because Herbert Hoover, then Secretary of Commerce, had seized the flood as a way of promoting his candidacy for the Presidency in 1928, he got himself appointed in charge of relief and, Mr. Barry argues, exploited the plight of the blacks for his own ends.
Meanwhile, the city of New Orleans panicked over the rising waters and determined to lower them by dynamiting a levee downriver from the city and flooding a community of 10,000. When it came time to compensate this community, Mr. Barry writes, the leaders of New Orleans in effect reneged on their promise to do so.
The upshot of all this was considerable, as Mr. Barry sees it. Hoover won the Presidency, but betrayed the blacks who helped him. As a result, black voters began to shift from the Republican to the Democratic Party, and black labor began leaving the South in large numbers. The arrogant behavior of the New Orleans power elite helped get Huey Long elected as Governor of Louisiana, and sent the city into an economic decline.
Most significant, writes Mr. Barry, because of the South's insistence that the Federal Government pay for the flood damage, the resulting law "set a precedent of direct, comprehensive and vastly expanded Federal involvement in local affairs." A foretaste of big things to come, Mr. Barry points out. Meanwhile, the last in the direct line of Percys, William Alexander, when his cousin LeRoy committed suicide, adopted LeRoy's three sons, LeRoy, Phinizy and Walker, the last of whom would grow up to become the award-winning novelist.
Today, Mr. Barry concludes, the Mississippi has been equipped with some of the flood-relieving adaptations, like spillways and reservoirs, that the two engineers opposed to the levees-only system so presciently advocated. What the reader never gets, however, is an informed contemporary opinion of how the jetty system proposed by the brilliant James Buchanan Eads might have worked. But then by the time one gets to the end of "Rising Tide," Eads's proposal seems very far in the past. Too far in the past, as far as the real excitement of Mr. Barry's book is concerned.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Not Yet

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So it's all O.K. now?
That's the word from the Clinton folks. They got the mood music they were looking for in Helsinki: The Russians will complain about NATO expansion, but Boris Yeltsin will accept the goodies the U.S. offered him to tolerate NATO's moving closer to Russia's border. Therefore, we will have the best of all worlds: NATO expansion to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, vague assurances to the Balts and others left out that they can join later and even some progress on arms control thrown in to boot. As one U.S. official quipped to me, referring to my own criticism of NATO expansion, "When do we get to see the headline: 'Clinton Right on NATO Expansion, Critics All Wrong'?"
Not yet. 
 To be fair, if Clinton is able to achieve this best-of-all-worlds scenario, it would indeed merit real praise. My priority is that the arms control treaties with Russia be implemented and the reform process there be enhanced. That is what would really secure European stability. If the Administration can deliver both, while also pursuing its dubious, politically inspired NATO expansion scheme, then it would be churlish to oppose this Helsinki package.
But we are a long way from drawing that conclusion. To begin with, many of the key issues involving NATO expansion remain unresolved: What will happen to all the countries, particularly the Balts, that don't get into NATO now? How will the U.S. Congress react when it discovers that Clinton's Helsinki package comes with a price tag of at least $40 billion, and a U.S. military commitment to defend the Polish border? How will Russia's parliament react to this deal?
But beyond these unanswered questions, I remain a skeptic because this Helsinki "success" is based on two white lies. The first is that while the Russians don't like NATO expansion, they've decided to make the best of it. In truth, that is not what Helsinki demonstrates. What it shows is that "Russia has concluded it is simply too weak to stop expansion," notes Johns Hopkins University foreign policy specialist Michael Mandelbaum, a leading critic of NATO expansion.
And the problem with expanding NATO on such terms, Mandelbaum argues, is that up to now "the entire post-cold war security structure in Europe, whether the unification of Germany or the conventional and nuclear arms control treaties, has been based on Russian consent. NATO expansion will be a departure from that. After NATO expands, the new European order will rest not on Russian consent, but on Russian weakness."
In other words, what Helsinki proves is that we won the cold war. But we knew that. The question is, Are we making the most of it? Should NATO expansion be a priority, even if it weakens Yeltsin or diminishes Russian cooperation elsewhere, such as against Iran?
The other white lie is the Clinton argument that expanding NATO will stabilize democratic reform in Central Europe and be good for Russia, because NATO has changed and Russia has changed. In truth, the way to strengthen free-market democracy in Central Europe is by bringing these nations into the E.U. common market, not by giving them NATO nukes. But more important, the very reason Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic want to join NATO is that they think NATO has not changed -- that it is still an anti-Russian alliance -- and because they feel that Russia has not changed -- that it is still the Soviet Union. (Never mind that Russia now has a cabinet led by economic reformers more progressive than half the nations now trying to join NATO.)
What Clinton said to Yeltsin in Helsinki was: We will pay you to pretend that NATO expansion is something other than what it is. We will pay you to forget that NATO is expanding because you're weak and because we still see you as the main threat to European stability, not as an equal member of the club. For now, Yeltsin is willing to be bought because he has no choice. But we should have no illusions: Clinton's "New Europe" is being built on white lies.
Momma always said: When you don't call things by their real name, you get in trouble. That's what's going on here. I don't know when or where, but this sort of diplomacy will lead to trouble. So pardon me for sticking with the headline: "Clinton Still Wrong on NATO Expansion, Critics Still Right."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mobutu, Emerging, Vows to Unite Zaire but Doesn't Say How

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 23

 BODY:
Zaire's ailing President, Mobutu Sese Seko, made his first public appearance today since he returned home on Friday, promising to unite his shattering country.
But Mr. Mobutu, who is suffering from advanced prostate cancer, gave no indication of how he planned to pull together his vast country, which has been besieged by a six-month civil war. He hinted that he would outline his proposal soon. 
 "You will know within the next 48 hours," he said.
Mr. Mobutu spent part of the day with South Africa's Deputy President, Thabo Mbeki, who came here in an attempt to help resolve the crisis. Mr. Mobutu also received Cabinet members and other officials of his Government.
Wearing his signature leopard-skin hat, Mr. Mobutu, 66, looked frail and spoke briefly to journalists on the veranda of his villa perched above the Congo River at Camp Colonel Tshatshi.
"I'm as you see me," Mr. Mobutu said when asked about his health. He ignored other questions and recited what sounded like a prepared statement.
"I did not return to deal with the interests of Mobutu," said the President, who has ruled his country with an iron grip for 31 years. "Nor to deal with Mobutu's fortune, as you write from time to time, but to deal with the interests of Zaire -- our unity, our national integrity."
Mr. Mobutu, who had been in Europe for medical treatment, has few options. Western diplomats predicted that he might resign outright, form a new Government or create a "national council" free of his control and give opposition parties a greater role in government.
In the most widely discussed possibility, Mr. Mobutu would appoint his chief political rival, Etienne Tshisekedi, as Prime Minister, in the hope that the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, would then accept a cease-fire and negotiate.
"I don't know if Kabila is going to buy that," a diplomat said of the rebel commander, who leads a group called the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo. "But that's how it's going to be presented."
Since last October, the rebels have repeatedly routed undisciplined and demoralized Government troops, gaining control of much of the eastern part of the country. Now the rebels are pushing toward Lubumbashi, Zaire's second-largest city. President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, who has been playing a leading role in efforts to end the conflict, sent Deputy President Mbeki here with a letter asking the parties to halt the fighting and negotiate a settlement. The rebels have refused.
Although Mr. Kabila has steadily gained both territory and popular support, questions remain as to whether he could effectively govern the entire country.
Many here were deeply worried when Mr. Kabila announced recently that he would form a provisional Government excluding any political figures who had shared power with Mr. Mobutu. Mr. Tshisekedi, too, commands considerable support in the capital.
"We are the ones who have brought down Mobutu, the man who used to consider himself the colleague of the gods," said Kabanga Badadi, president of the National Christian Democratic Party, which has announced its support for Mr. Tshisekedi as Prime Minister.
"We were defeating him with the pen," he said. "Is it fair to come in now with the gun and say you're shutting out those who have fought for democracy?"
Wherever the rebels have taken control, however, Mr. Kabila has established an administration that diplomats call impressive. In every town, the rebels have included local people in policy discussions and have kept corruption to a minimum.
The streets in this sprawling city appeared calm today. Most people went about their Sunday routine -- attending mass, catching up on family gossip and seeking refuge from the blistering heat.
Still, there was unease as Western nations continued to make preparations for possible evacuations of their citizens. Belgium, this country's former colonial ruler, announced that it would fly soldiers to neighboring Libreville, Gabon, to rescue its 2,800 citizens in Zaire if necessary.
Today, as news of Mr. Mobutu's appearance filtered through the capital, residents reacted with annoyance and impatience.
"He's not going to change anything," said Jean-Marcaire Katunda, 38, who was discussing the event with a group of unemployed men. "He has been in power for a long time and he has done nothing for the country. We are awaiting Kabila, not Mobutu."
Standing nearby, Touby Mbengi, 31, said, "Mobutu never tells the truth."

HEADLINE: Schumer Criticizes Pataki's Plan to Increase Tuition at Public Colleges

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Already pressed for money, Harry Daguizam, a student at Hunter College in Manhattan, says that Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed $400 tuition increase for New York's public colleges may force him to delay plans to attend law school.
"The City University of New York was created for students who couldn't afford to go to a big-name Ivy League college," Mr. Daguizam, 21, said in an interview. "And I just want to say, 'Please, let's keep it that way.' " 
 At a news conference yesterday, Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of Brooklyn, criticized the Governor's proposal and urged the adoption of his own plan, which would allow parents to create tax-exempt savings accounts for tuition while their children are young.
He said that more and more students at New York's public universities are finding it harder to pay for their educations because of increases in tuition and cuts in financial aid -- a problem that may be forcing lower income students to drop out.
"One of the great things about New York is that we've always had people who have been well trained," said Mr. Schumer, who is considered a possible gubernatorial candidate. "That golden day may close."
To show the severity of the problem, Mr. Schumer said, he gathered figures indicating that students at the State University of New York who graduated in 1995 owed, on average, 65 percent more in Federal loans than those who graduated in 1990, even though inflation rose only about 16 percent over that time.
Students at the City University of New York also faced an increasing burden, Mr. Schumer said. The average Federal student loan balance at graduation was 34 percent higher in 1995 than in 1990.
In January, Governor Pataki proposed the $400 annual increase, which would bring tuition at SUNY to $3,800 a year and tuition at CUNY's four-year colleges to $3,600 a year. He also proposed a reduction in state aid for some of the neediest students.
Yesterday, Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Governor, defended the proposals.
"The State University system remains one of the best bargains in the nation," Mr. McKeon said. "Under Governor Pataki, New York State continues to provide tuition assistance that puts 80,000 students through SUNY and CUNY systems tuition-free."
Mr. Pataki's proposals still face scrutiny in the Legislature, which rejected similar tuition increases last year. Mr. Schumer called on state lawmakers to defeat the Governor's proposals, and he asked legislators in both Albany and Washington to pass bills similar to the one he has proposed.
Robert M. Hollander, who is studying linguistics and sits on the Doctoral Students' Council at CUNY, compared the combination of rising tuition and lower financial aid to "a vise" that squeezes students tighter and tighter. He said at the news conference yesterday that when students have to work to make up for a tuition increase, they must reduce the number of classes they take. That, in turn, forces them to stay in school for more terms, increasing their debt burden even more, he said.
Shamsun Naher, 27, said that she is still a Hunter College freshman, even though she has been attending classes since 1994. To afford school, she said, she must work full time.
"If you don't get a degree," she said, "you won't get a good job, and if you don't get a good job, how can you improve your life?"
Nora Dial, 32, a student in the 15-month midwife re-education program at the SUNY Health Science Center at Brooklyn, received her nursing degree at the school in 1996. In the fall semester 1995, Ms. Dial went to Albany with 100 other nursing and medical students to protest that semester's tuition increase.
"If I was an incoming student, an extra $400 or $500 increase would hurt quite a lot," she said. "I would be very upset. The added financial burden makes things much more difficult for students, and there's enough stress as it is. It makes you lose faith in the system."

HEADLINE: Study Shows Jump in Investing in China and Revival in Mexico

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
China now attracts more than a third of all the investment in factories and other manufacturing plants in developing nations, attracting $42 billion last year, according to a study of global investment trends released today by the World Bank.
The study also provided the strongest evidence yet that Mexico is recovering speedily from the financial crisis that started about two years ago and threatened to ricochet through other fast-growing emerging markets. And over all, capital flows into the world's emerging markets rose to more than $244 billion last year, a jump of $60 billion from 1995. That figure combines net investments in factories and real estate with commercial lending and investments in stocks and bonds. 
 Direct investment in factories and other manufacturing sites in Mexico totaled only $6.4 billion in 1996. That was a distant second to China's $42 billion, just ahead of Malaysia, and well below the investment levels in Mexico before the peso crisis of late 1994 and 1995. However, the Clinton Administration's effort to stabilize the Mexican economy so that private investors would return appears to have worked. Last year, a record $28 billion in total private capital poured into the country, twice the amount that went into Mexico in 1995, at the depth of the country's economic troubles.
The picture of Mexico drawn in the report bolsters the Clinton Administration's decision to use taxpayer funds to prop up the country's economic recovery. But perhaps the most interesting and politically significant conclusions in the report concern China, the emerging market that has become a battleground for developed nations seeking to stake a large economic foothold.
The figures show a huge increase in direct investment and commercial lending to China, though fairly cautious investment in China's stock markets. The rise in direct investment could make China more reluctant to make market-opening concessions in the negotiations to enter the World Trade Organization, the main club of trading nations.
"It frees the Chinese to say, 'Hey, even without making reforms everyone is breaking down the door to invest here,' " one Clinton Administration official familiar with the negotiations said recently. "These kinds of numbers help the hard-liners who don't want to deregulate or risk destabilizing the state-owned industries."
The report also concluded that China had been building up a huge war chest of foreign exchange reserves, now totaling more than $100 billion. The World Bank's economists, comparing that amount with the reserves of other nations around the world, concluded that China's reserves were "higher in absolute terms than Germany's foreign reserves, and equivalent to about nine months of imports."
But even as private investment in markets like China has surged, foreign aid from the governments of the wealthiest nations to the poorest has continued a rapid decline. Grants and concessional loans, which are offered at below-market interest rates, declined by nearly $1 billion, to $44.4 billion.
"What we are seeing is that aid is down to levels that no one has seen since 1990," said Fred Kilby, an economic adviser at the World Bank who assembled the report.
The bank's study concluded that the cuts for education and economic development programs in the developing world had been more severe than the numbers reveal, because a far larger portion of foreign aid now goes to refugee relief and peacekeeping in Haiti, Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia.
Much of the remaining aid now goes to sub-Saharan areas of Africa. East Asia has declined as a recipient of foreign aid, though there have been significant increases in aid to Cambodia, Laos and Vietnam.
Investors also returned to Europe and Central Asia over the last two years, the study concludes. The Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Lithuania, Poland, Romania, Slovenia and Turkey were all able to borrow significant amounts in private markets, and Russia floated a $1 billion Eurobond offer that marked its return to international capital markets.
But the chief economist of the bank, Joseph Stiglitz, who recently left the White House as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, cautioned on Friday that the world markets were increasingly unforgiving of countries that wandered off a narrow path in how they managed their economies and failed to open their markets to competition. "The stakes become higher for those countries that fail to undertake these reforms," he said.
The statistics in the report confirm what anyone trying to find a business-class seat on an airline flying to Asia already knows: Asia is awash in Western cash to build power plants, telecommunications facilities, airports, roads and other projects.
The study found that more than half of the $22.2 billion in infrastructure financing to developing countries in 1995 went to Asia. A decade ago, the region drew only about a quarter of the loans, bond issues and equity sales in infrastructure projects.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Israel Presses Arafat On Steps to Curb Attacks
Israel demanded that the Palestinian Authority take measures against further terrorism, but fell short of threatening to stop peace negotiations. The Government's statement was accompanied by declarations from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his security chiefs charging the Palestinian leadership with giving an indirect "green light" for terror attacks. Security forces maintained a high alert after Friday's bombing in Tel Aviv. A1
 
Palestinian police officers faced the wrath of their own people as they tried to control a crowd hurling stones at Israeli soldiers. A6
 
Zaire Leader Ends Isolation
Zaire's ailing President, Mobutu Sese Seko, made his first public appearance since returning home. He promised to unite his country, but gave no indication of how he planned to do it. Western diplomats predicted that he might resign, form a new Government or create a "national council" free of his control and give opposition parties a greater role in government. A9
 
An American Army airborne unit arrived in Congo to prepare for the possible evacuation of Americans from Zaire. A9
 
Chaos Continues in Albania
Albania's President, Sali Berisha, dug in his heels and said he would not be "blackmailed" into resigning. Rebels from the port of Vlore, for their part, repeated their demand that Mr. Berisha go. One group from Vlore circulated a petition threatening the head of the secret police with death unless he resigned. Inflation soared. A8
 
European officials said the European Union was expected to provide a small contingent to provide security for the delivery of food and other aid in Albania. A8
 
Philippine Cloak for Korean
Reporters scrambled frantically in the Philippines to try to find a North Korean defector being given refuge there temporarily after he was allowed to leave Beijing. The Government confirmed that he was in the country, but reporters were marveling at the success of officials at keeping their secret. A4
 
Belarus Expels U.S. Envoy
An American diplomat was asked to leave Belarus after taking part in an anti-Government rally, state television said. The statement said that the embassy's first secretary had been detained during a protest against the President's pro-Moscow policies. In Washington, the White House said that the official would comply. A8
 
Burmese Religious Conflict
Officials tightened security in the capital of Myanmar, formerly Burma, because of religious conflict. The unrest began a week ago in Mandalay, when Buddhist monks attacked mosques after reports that a Buddhist girl had been raped by a Muslim man. Monks play a major role in the affairs of the largely Buddhist country. A6
 
NATIONAL A10-13, B5-6
 
Deal With Cigarette Maker Yields Little for Smokers
Thousands of smokers and their families stand to gain little financially under a proposal in which one of the nation's large cigarette makers would settle all present and future lawsuits by smokers, their survivors, cities, counties and insurers. An Alabama judge has given preliminary approval for the settlement with the company, the Liggett Group. That settlement is separate from one in which Liggett agreed to admit that smoking is addictive and causes cancer. A1

Drug Corruption on the Border
Law-enforcement authorities said they had mounting evidence of systemic corruption of Federal and local officials by drug dealers in some remote counties along the Mexican border. Some of the suspicions involve customs and immigration inspectors, who had long been considered trustworthy defenders against the influx of marijuana, cocaine and heroin. A1

Rabbis Argue Over Judaism
A group of Orthodox rabbis said it would issue a statement declaring that the Reform and Conservative movements, the more liberal branches of the faith, are "not Judaism." A spokesman for the group said the statement was timed to counter efforts by Reform and Conservative leaders to gain official recognition for their movements in Israel. The statement was criticized by a number of Jewish religious leaders, including the president of the nation's largest Orthodox rabbinic organization. A11
 
New Guideline on Mammograms
The American Cancer Society recommended that women begin annual mammograms to detect breast cancer at age 40. Until now, the cancer society had urged mammograms every year or two for women in their 40's. The society's board of directors announced the change at a science writers' conference. A10
 
Thaw Floods North Dakota
Runoff from melting snow flooded hundreds of homes across North Dakota as ice jams sent rivers pouring over their banks. Several residents had to leave Beulah and Hazen, N.D., two small towns roughly 50 miles northwest of Bismarck where the Knife River spilled over its banks. The National Weather Service issued flood warnings for broad areas of western and south-central North Dakota, after two days of temperatures in the 50's. (Reuters)
 
2 Slain in Philadelphia
Two women were bound, gagged, raped and killed in the West Philadelphia row home they shared, the police said. Arnim Evans, 28, of Philadelphia was charged with murder and rape after officers pulled him out of the home of the victims, Pamela Blue, 24, and Roseann Young, 35. Six unharmed children, ages 1 to 9, were in the home. The police said Mr. Evans was an acquaintance of the women. Capt. Joseph Mooney said the women appeared to have been strangled. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-4
 
Whitman Assailed on Plan To Cover Pension Shortfall
Governor Whitman is seeking to borrow $2.9 billion over 35 years to help cover a shortfall in New Jersey's pension system -- the first time any state has floated bonds to cover pension liabilities. She faces a $750 million budget gap in a year when she is running for re-election. Her critics said the plan would burden future taxpayers with the costs of the tax cuts she boasts about now. A1
 
Objections to Private Prison
Several New York State officials said they objected to a company's proposal to build a privately owned prison in the Catskills and take in prisoners from other states. State law prohibits New York's own prisoners from being housed in private prisons, and Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco said he was not sure that the law would even allow the prison to take inmates from elsewhere. Officials in Fallsburg, where the prison would be built, said they needed it to shore up their tax base, especially since the State Senate's vote in January against casino gambling in the Catskills. B1

Schumer Criticizes Tuition Rise
Representative Charles E. Schumer criticized Governor Pataki's proposal to increase tuition for New York's public college students by $400. Mr. Schumer, a Democrat who is thought to be considering a challenge to Mr. Pataki next year, urged the adoption of his own plan, which would allow parents to create tax-exempt savings accounts for tuition while their children are young. B2

Giuliani Defends End to Plan
Mayor Giuliani vigorously defended his decision three years ago to dismantle an affirmative action program that steered city contracts to minority-owned businesses. He said the program, begun under Mayor David N. Dinkins, was of questionable legality. Critics have charged that minority-owned businesses are suffering under Mr. Giuliani. B2
 
Children See Murder-Suicide
A man fatally shot his estranged girlfriend inside her apartment in upper Manhattan and then killed himself in front of the woman's teen-age daughter and 2-year-old son, the police said. The children were not injured. The police said the deaths were the culmination of a dispute between the victims. B3
 
SPORTSMONDAY C1-9
 
Arizona and N. Carolina Win
Arizona yielded a 7-point lead with 1 minute 15 seconds to play, but held on to defeat Providence in overtime, 96-92, to win a trip to the Final Four. The Wildcats will face North Carolina, which earned its fourth -- and least expected -- trip of the decade to the national semifinals by exploiting Louisville's limitations in height and shooting ability to win, 97-74. The other semifinal game will pit Minnesota, which defeated U.C.L.A. 80-72 on Saturday, against Kentucky, which beat Utah 72-59. C1
 
Nets Apologize for Outburst
The Nets publicly apologized for an outburst in which Coach John Calipari had called a reporter a "Mexican idiot." The incident occurred when Calipari spotted the reporter while arguing with another writer in the team's parking lot. Calipari declined to discuss the incident. The reporter, Dan Garcia of The Star-Ledger, sent a letter about it to the N.B.A.; a league official said he could not comment because the letter had not yet arrived. C1
 
ARTS C11-15
 
Cuts Ahead for Lloyd Webber
Andrew Lloyd Webber's Really Useful Group is poised to reduce its New York staff in the wake of the closing of "Sunset Boulevard." The group's London office has already reduced its staff by half. The financial failure of "Sunset" was just one of several setbacks the group has suffered recently. A1

Independents Take On Oscars
The annual celebration of independent films that is held just before the Academy Award ceremonies took on the air of a rival Oscar night, with stretch limousines and hordes of camera crews at the entrance. Four of the five films competing tonight for best picture are independents. C11
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-10
 
China Grabs Investment Share
A study released by the World Bank showed that China now attracts more than a third of all the investment in factories and other manufacturing facilities in developing nations. China's share last year was more than $42 billion, the study said. D2

HEADLINE: Giuliani Defends His Decision on Issuing City Contracts

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Facing criticism that minority-owned businesses are suffering under his administration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday vigorously defended his decision three years ago to dismantle an affirmative action program that steered city contracts to such businesses.
Mr. Giuliani said that the program, a major initiative of former Mayor David N. Dinkins, had been of questionable legality ever since several court decisions declared such practices unconstitutional. 
 And besides, he added, the program often helped businesses that needed no help or employed few minorities or women. Since the program was eliminated, the city has instead encouraged banks to lend to small minority businesses and has expanded bidding on smaller contracts as a way to include more struggling businesses in poor neighborhoods.
But even as he touted this approach, the Mayor conceded that the city no longer keeps track of how many city contracts are awarded to minority-owned businesses, suggesting that officials have no way of knowing whether their efforts are working.
"I've done away with a lot of that race-based analysis," Mr. Giuliani said. He was responding to questions about an article in The Daily News yesterday that stated that the city had not compiled statistics on the number or value of contracts awarded to businesses owned by minorities or women since mid-1994.
"Our analysis is, 'How are we helping small businesses? How are we helping poor people in the city?' " Mr. Giuliani said. "How are we helping people who are poor, not people who are poor who are white or black?"
Under the old program, companies owned by women or minority group members could be awarded city contracts even if their bids were 10 percent higher than the lowest bid.
In its first year, 1992, the program increased the percentage of contracts awarded to such companies to 17.5 percent, up from 9 percent in 1990.
Two earlier studies had found that minorities and women represented 25 percent of qualified contract bidders, but received less than 8 percent of the public money spent in a given year.
While Mr. Giuliani defended the philosophy of his policies yesterday, he said nothing about what effect they have had, even in a general sense. Instead, he repeatedly emphasized that even if the city had wanted to keep minority contracting goals in place, it would have been foolhardy.
"Had I gone ahead with the program I inherited and awarded contracts on that basis, the City of New York would now be paying hundreds of millions of dollars in damages for unconstitutionally and illegally used race-based criteria as a way of helping people," Mr. Giuliani said.
Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington, who oversaw the implementation of the new policies when he was commissioner of the Department of Business Services, said the administration had focused on strengthening minority businesses to compete for contracts in an open market. "Most programs just seek to give somebody a contract and subsequently they default or fail on that contract," he said.
Although court rulings do not prevent the city from compiling data that identifies contractors by race or sex, Mr. Washington said, he questioned "the real significance of trying to keep data on 'Who's doing what?' " Rather than "sitting by idly and playing the numbers game," he said, "we wanted to do something proactive."

HEADLINE: Gore, in Japan, Pushes the Environment

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, March 24

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, visiting Tokyo at the start of a tour in Asia, proposed today that the United States and Japan take the lead in persuading countries to reduce their emissions of carbon monoxide and other greenhouse gases.
"Economic and security issues are vitally important," Mr. Gore said in a speech to an environmental forum intended to lay the groundwork for a global environmental conference in Kyoto, Japan, next December. "Yet they are undergirded and integrally connected to our stewardship of the planet." 
 Aides said that Mr. Gore hopes that an agreement can be completed in time for the conference.
Mr. Gore's one-day visit to Tokyo included dinner with Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda, a courtesy call on Japan's emperor and empress and meetings with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to discuss policies on China, trade and American leases for military bases in Okinawa.
Given the attempts to bring North and South Korea together for formal peace talks, Mr. Gore said, "this would be the very worst time" for the United States to consider shrinking its military forces in the region, which include some 40,000 troops in South Korea as well as forces in Japan.
The environment is high on the agenda for Mr. Gore's trip, which will take him to China for four days of talks, including discussions with Prime Minister Li Peng on China's plans to quadruple its energy supply over the next decade.

HEADLINE: San Diego: The Wireless Valley;
An Information Revolution Revives Its Economy

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
The economic boom from high technology that has led this area to start calling itself Wireless Valley will soon be hard to miss. The San Diego City Council recently accepted $18 million from Qualcomm Inc., the scrappy telecommunications company that is shaking up the cellular industry, to rename a sports arena Qualcomm Stadium.
If it appears that San Diego is borrowing a page from its northern neighbor, Silicon Valley, where the computer networking giant 3Com Corporation not long ago purchased the right to rename Candlestick Park, the resemblance does not end there. 
 From its roots as a military town, San Diego has been transformed in just half a decade into a vital entrepreneurial center spawning garage start-ups and attracting giant multinationals doing research, marketing and manufacturing.
A drive through the Sorrento Valley north of downtown San Diego shows Silicon Valley-like clusters of sprawling, low-slung, hyper-modern factories bracketed between the Pacific Ocean and the rolling desert foothills, and glinting in California sunshine.
Employment in telecommunications in the region jumped 65 percent in 1996 from the previous year, to 19,075. The two largest employers in the San Diego area are Qualcomm and Sony Electronics Inc. -- both wireless equipment makers -- with 7,500 and 4,000 workers, respectively.
The wireless industry is on the same growth curve that has marked other high-technology consumer industries like personal computers. Wireless operators are expected to increase their annual investment by 20 percent a year, from $29 billion last year to $86 billion in 2002.
As with any boom there are still reasons for caution. For example, in recent months Qualcomm has become embroiled in intellectual property lawsuits with two of its toughest competitors, Motorola Inc. and Ericsson Inc., over the wireless standard the San Diego company pioneered.
Moreover, the multibillion- dollar industry investment in spectrum licenses could still be a bust. Few think it will be, however. Currently, wireless penetration in the United States is estimated to be 16 percent and, according to the market research firm Paul Kagan Associates Inc., it is expected to be approximately 48 percent by 2006.
The development of the industry here highlights the way the geography of the information revolution differs from that of the industrial revolution. For information-based industries, labor is the most important natural resource.
Companies like Qualcomm, PCSI and Nokia Mobile Phones are clustering around San Diego because of engineering talent left over from the declining military industry and the proximity to the University of California at San Diego as a source of skilled workers.
"We're best known for biotechnology, but now telecommunications is growing faster," said William W. Otterson, a former I.B.M. executive who directs U.C.S.D. Connect, a program intended to transfer technology from the university into the private economy.
But Mr. Otterson warns that one possible factor could hold back growth: a serious shortage of trained engineers plagues the region.
Producing new engineers and keeping trained ones around was the focus of Richard Atkinson in the 1980's, when he was chancellor of the university campus. Like Stanford's former provost, Frederick Terman, who in the 1930's helped incubate the local electronics industry so that Stanford graduates could stay in the area, Mr. Atkinson in the 1980's built university-industry linkages in biotechnology and telecommunications. (He is now chancellor of the University of California system.)
In addition to the research activity at the university, Japanese, Korean and Finnish companies like Sony, Uniden, LG InfoCom and Nokia have moved wireless communications research and development activities to the area. The giant government-oriented research and consulting concern, the Science Applications International Corporation, last year acquired Bell Communications Research Inc. as part of a move into the communications field.
According to Douglas Henton, president of Collaborative Economics in Palo Alto, Calif., industrial clusters linking companies around the manufacture of personal communication devices are now growing up in San Diego, mirroring a similar process in Silicon Valley. "The big difference between the two communities is scale," he said.
What it lacks in bulk, however, the wireless industry makes up in competitive fire. Today, the San Diego area is the home base of a new digital cellular transmission standard known as C.D.M.A., now the fastest-growing wireless technology in the United States. A consortium of 14 companies has established the Center for Wireless Communications at the university campus. It has recently embarked on the design of a broadband wireless network that consortium members hope will transform the nature of all kinds of business and home communications.
And San Diego has its own version of the Hewlett-Packard Company, Silicon Valley's pioneering electronics concern. In 1968, two San Diego engineering professors, Irwin Jacobs and Andrew Verterbi, started Linkabit, a part-time consulting firm focused on digital communications. The company grew into a full-time endeavor, making satellite communications gear for the military.
Now almost three decades later, Linkabit has spun off more than 20 other companies, including Qualcomm, a business Mr. Jacobs founded with Mr. Verterbi after selling Linkabit in 1980.
But more than the rise of any one company, it was the ascent of the Internet and a telecommunications explosion in the developing world that propelled a dramatic turnaround in the recession-plagued San Diego economy.
Nearly 44,000 people had been employed in the military and aerospace industries in 1990, the peak for such employment. The contraction in Federal military contracting squeezed that labor force down to 14,600 today. Military contractors reduced their work forces or left the area.
But the wireless business has helped bring an end to the subsequent recession in a quick three years. The wireless work force, only 5,200 in 1992, is now nearly half of what the military work force was at its peak, and growing rapidly.
"The wireless communications business has changed the nature of San Diego's economy," said Robert Conn, dean of the school of engineering at the University of California at San Diego.
And although the transformation seems an overnight occurrence, it has not been particularly easy. "San Diego has had a problem of trying to retread a lot of guys who were at General Dynamics, which was military-oriented and slow moving," said Martha Dennis, vice president for engineering at Pacific Coast Services Inc., a wireless data company. That kind of corporate culture was far removed from the risk-taking style of companies like Qualcomm. "Some made the cut and some didn't," Ms. Dennis said.
Despite its proximity to Southern California's laid-back beach culture the new wireless communications industry has much more in common with the "90 hours a week and loving it" life style of Silicon Valley.
No company better exemplifies that spirit than Qualcomm, which is leading the battle for its particular cellular standard, called code division multiple access. If this standard can prevail, making competing standards like T.D.M.A., or time division multiple access standard, used in Japan and the United States, and the European favorite, G.S.M., or Global Special Mobile, into the industry's Betamaxes, Qualcomm stands to do extremely well.
Mr. Jacobs, who was traveling and unavailable for an interview last week, created Qualcomm as a company run largely by engineers. He had gained a reputation as an independent thinker while a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, long before digital communications systems were thought feasible.
Mr. Jacobs's company has demonstrated its ability to quickly seize business opportunities in new technology areas. For example, early in its rush to commercialize the Internet, Qualcomm licensed Eudora, an electronic mail software package. The program is now the Internet's most popular E-mail software.
If Qualcomm is Wireless Valley's leading enterprise, the University of California at San Diego's School of Engineering's Center for Wireless Communications is the area's intellectual engine. Founded two years ago with backing from Qualcomm, Sprint, Hewlett-Packard, and other companies, the center has begun work on a radically new communications network.
Led by an engineering professor, Anthony Acampora, a small team of faculty and students is exploring the possibility of leaping across the technology divide that until now has frustrated communications companies in their desire to reach America's homes with multimedia interactive data services.
It is called the "last mile" problem: copper wires will not carry high-speed transmissions, but neither telephone nor cable companies have been willing to invest in connecting homes to fiber optic cables.
But Mr. Acampora, who is a veteran wireless researcher with a 20-year career at AT&T's Bell Laboratories, said he was daydreaming during a long technical conference when he hit on another idea. Instead of using radio signals like today's cellular networks, he envisioned an optical-radio network.
Low-power high-frequency radios that would deliver tens of megabits of video, data and voice information would gradually be installed in homes and businesses. These local transmitters, called picocells, would in turn be connected to laser-based optical transceivers, installed on the rooftops of many structures, to carry digital information for the whole city at even higher data rates.
"Each house would have a transceiver that would have four beams," Mr. Acampora said. "It would create a dense web that could carry more information as more customers were added."
As with the Internet itself, each new participant would add value to the system as a whole. And the network would essentially be self-assembling, avoiding the billions of dollars in infrastructure investment that now stymies telephone and cable companies. Consumers would build the network themselves by buying transceivers at local stores, then installing them on their roofs.
Mr. Acampora acknowledges that his hybrid network is a totally unproven idea. Lasers are now the best solution for sending high-speed data over fiber optic cables, but sending laser beams through the air raises both safety and reliability issues.
"The idea of putting a laser cyclops on top of your house for fast data is really an interesting and novel idea," said James F. Moore, a telecommunications and computer industry consultant at Geopartners Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "Everyone else has been concerned with sending laser beams long distances through glass. These guys are thinking about short distances through the air."
The vision has captured the imagination of the center's small team of engineers, mathematicians and computer scientists, like Lawrence Larson, a professor of electrical engineering.
"I was frustrated that many things that I had worked on had never taken off in a commercial sense," Mr. Larson said. "I wanted to see something I had done in every home in the country."
If Wireless Valley continues to grow at its current remarkable pace, his chances are good.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 27, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Monday about the concentration of wireless telecommunications companies around San Diego referred incorrectly to the 1996 financial results of one of the companies, Hughes Network Systems. It had revenue, not net sales, of $1 billion. The company does not report net sales, a figure that omits some sources of income included in revenue.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Higher On Expectation of Rate Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered from early weakness against the yen to end mostly higher yesterday, strengthening on expectations that interest rates would be raised in the United States and on reports suggesting that Japan might impose more domestic sales taxes.
In New York, the dollar settled at 122.91 yen, up from 122.85 yen Friday. The dollar cost 1.6881 German marks, up from 1.6861. 
 Many currency traders were betting that the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee would nudge up short-term interest rates by 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent, at its regularly scheduled meeting today. Higher interest rates tend to lift the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets worth more.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has been hinting that pre-emptive steps are needed to thwart inflation, suggesting that the central bank is about to move rates higher for the first time in more than two years.
"Everybody's waiting for the Fed meeting, and a 25-basis-point increase has already been factored in," said Hans Boman, vice president for foreign-exchange sales at Swedbank in New York. "The underlying trend for the dollar is still up."
The dollar also got a lift after Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, suggested that the country's tax on consumption, scheduled to rise to 5 percent from 3 percent on April 1, might be raised even further. Mr. Mitsuzuka told Parliament he could not rule out another increase.
His remarks helped incite a selloff in Japan's stock market and dropped the yen on investor fears that an expanding tax burden could derail the slow Japanese recovery from a prolonged recession by discouraging consumers from spending.
Though the dollar rose against the yen, it fell against the British pound, which strengthened to $1.6186, from $1.6033 on Friday and the highest level since Feb. 28. Much of the increase reflected heightened expectations that interest rates would be raised in Britain, regardless of whatpolitical party wins the May 1 general election.
The pound was also helped by a British Government report saying Britain's broadest measure of trade showed a deficit in 1996 that was far smaller than expected.

HEADLINE: Albert Key, 71, Broker, Dies; Led Historical Society in 80's

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Albert Lenoir Key, a stockbroker and former investment banker who, as a trustee, president and chairman, helped steer the New-York Historical Society through its heaviest turbulence in the 1980's, died on Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 71 and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.
The cause was postoperative complications related to lung cancer, his family said. 
 At his death, Mr. Key remained a society trustee. He joined the board in 1984 and was its president and chairman from 1986 to 1989 as the society painfully pulled itself out of a crisis, with bankruptcy and the forced dispersal of its treasures looming all too real.
At 196 years old, the New-York Historical Society, on Central Park West and 77th Street, is the oldest of its kind in New York State and the state's oldest museum. Its collections have ranged from works of the Old Masters to old American manuscripts to Americana to Hudson River paintings, not to mention its stately landmark home.
At the root of the problem was the depletion of its endowment in an ambitious quest for growth. As its difficulties mounted, state and city support for a rescue effort was in serious doubt.
Under the guidance of Mr. Key and his fellow trustees, the society underwent a drastic regimen of cutbacks in staff, visiting hours, shuttered exhibits and assorted other economies. To clinch the survival with state help, it had to sell off some of its possessions in 1995 in an auction that brought in $17.6 million.
"He was the leader during a very, very troubled time," the current chairman, Miner H. Warner, said of Mr. Key yesterday.
Mr. Warner said he now liked to refer to it as the "formerly troubled New-York Historical Society," having seen "troubled" as the accustomed precede to its name for so long. He said it was now "doing extremely well, endowment way up and the plant completely refurbished."
Mr. Key was born in Washington and graduated from Harvard College. He was in the diplomatic service in the early 1950's, when he was posted to Israel to smooth the way for Jews wanting to emigrate from the Soviet Union.
Returning to the United States in 1955, he became a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a 20-year partner in the investment banking firm of Harris Upham & Company. Most recently, he was associated with H. G. Wellington & Company, an old-line stock brokerage firm.
He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Julia Bowdoin Key; their three sons, David M. and Albert L. Jr., both of Manhattan, and Robert L., of Denver; a brother, David M., of Vero Beach, Fla; a sister, Majorie K. Andrews of Atlanta, and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Last Pulp Mill in Alaska Closes, And Ketchikan Braces for Impact

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: KETCHIKAN, Alaska, March 24

 BODY:
After 40 years, Ketchikan breathed the last pungence of damp wood pulp today as the last pulp mill in the state shut down, partly because it needed up to $200 million in environmental renovations. The closing leaves 500 workers without jobs at the Ketchikan Pulp Company in a town that has depended on the mills for more than 40 years.
"A lot of people maybe will have to go work for McDonald's to make a living, and that isn't right," said Rob Izatt, a worker who will lose his job. 
 A money-losing operation, the mill was closed by its corporate parent, the Louisiana Pacific Corporation. Severance pay amounts to a year's wages or more for some employees, many of whom said they planned to fish, hunt and think about new careers in the summer.
For just about everyone else in this island town of 15,000 in the southeastern corner of the Alaska Panhandle, the effects are already apparent. Car and boat sales have plummeted. The housing market has been flooded, and other businesses have cut staffs and working hours. A shipping company is hauling 20 percent less freight and shipping out household belongings.
The mill has run around the clock almost every day since 1954, except for maintenance shutdowns and labor disputes.
Two pulp companies are near the end of 50-year contracts with the Forest Service to cut timber in the Tongass National Forest, deals that the Federal Government struck in the 1950's to spur job development.
Managers at the mill faulted lawsuits that hampered logging and a change in policies that increased the costs for lumber from the Tongass forest.
The company did win a concession that let it continue logging for two years after closing the mill, when Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, put a special provision in a bill on parks and public lands last October.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Gain Ahead of Fed Meeting

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday as investors prepared for a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers today.
Many market participants were expecting the Fed to raise short-term interest rates. "For the most part everyone is content with their positions heading into the meeting," said David Shabelman, a market analyst with MMS International. 
 And there was talk yesterday that if the Fed did indeed raise rates, short-term maturities could be hurt but that there was a potential for a rally in the long bond. Still, Mr. Shabelman said that any such gains would be limited by sellers waiting for upticks in prices.
The price of the 30-year bond ended up 19/32 yesterday, to 96 11/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.92 percent, from 6.96 percent on Friday.
Yesterday's gains, said Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management of Hartford, were "a reflection of the fact that everyone knows the Fed will tighten."
"When it's anticipated as much as that, then rates will not change very much," he said.
Many in the market were expecting the Fed policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, to raise its target on the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent. Those expectations were bolstered on Thursday when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, hinted again at a pre-emptive move to keep inflation low.
But not everyone is expecting an increase. Lou Brien, an analyst with Finacor Vendome Inc., a Chicago brokerage firm, said that if the Federal funds rate "is at a level that may help to accomplish the Fed's basic goal, then the Fed chairman may consider it appropriate to leave it alone."
"One rate hike will bring the anticipation that more will follow and among the costs of higher rates would be increasing the burden of debt-strapped families, sending the dollar even higher and exports even lower, swiftly ending the exuberance of the stock market and severely testing the resiliency of an expansion that has entered its seventh year," Mr. Brien said.
"On the other hand," he continued, "the cost of no action is the risk of inflation. But with inflation at 30-year lows and the real funds rate a half-point above its historical average, the Fed will take that risk and leave rates unchanged Tuesday."
Mr. Whelan of Aeltus Investment Management said there were several signs that the Fed would make only one move on rates. "The Fed generally doesn't tighten much when the dollar is appreciating, and when the gap between the Federal funds rate and inflation approaches 3 percent, which is usually sufficient to slow the economy," he said. "They are starting this tightening cycle with that gap already 2.25 percent, which suggests that the central bank does not have all that much to do."
Interest rates were up modestly at yesterday's Treasury bill auction, with the results about as expected on the eve of a Fed policy meeting. The average rate for a three-month bill rose to 5.26 percent, up 13 basis points from last week's auction, while the six-month bill hit 5.33 percent, up 7 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Today, the Treasury will be selling $17.2 billion of two-year notes, as the Fed is deciding monetary policy for months ahead. And the Government is selling $12.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow. In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year notes were yielding 6.26 percent, down four basis points from Friday, and 6.56 percent for the five-year note, down six basis points.
