HEADLINE: Dow Up 100, But Late Rally Skips Nasdaq

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A rally late yesterday lifted blue-chip stocks out of their worst downturn of the year. But it was not enough to salvage technology stocks, which extended their slump.
While the Dow Jones industrial average surged 100.46 points, or 1.5 percent, to 6,905.25, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fell for the ninth time in 10 sessions, closing down 11.43 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 1,242.64. 
 The rally came on the eve of today's Federal Reserve meeting on interest rate policy. Investors are typically reluctant to buy stocks before a possible move by the Fed, and indeed trading was light yesterday, as 452 million shares changed hands, down from 544.8 million on Friday.
Yesterday's rally was also unusual because many in the market expect the Fed to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today, and such expectations have caused a slump in stocks in recent weeks.
"What happened today should have happened tomorrow because the rate increase was already factored into the markets," Larry Rice, chief investment officer of Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said yesterday. "Everyone expected it, and when that happens you get the opposite response."
The 100-point gain in the Dow, however, was not indicative of yesterday's market performance. A large part of the gain was driven by program trading. According to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm based in Greenwich, Conn., two programs begun after 2:30 P.M. accounted for most of the Dow's gains.
Yesterday was the third time this year that the Dow has had a gain of more than 100 points. Analysts said that the Dow's gains continued to demonstrate how lopsided the market had become.
"It continues to be a professional traders' market, an index fund market," Mr. Rice said. "But if you take away the blue chips, we've been in a secular bear market. We saw program trading today. The rest of the market was pretty dormant."
Despite the rally in the Dow, more stocks lost ground than gained on the New York Stock Exchange. And along with the Nasdaq, the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks also fell yesterday, down 2.25 points, to 349.48. For the year, the Russell 2000 is down 3.6 percent.
For much of the day, though, investors were focused on technology stocks, which continued to get hammered. At one point, the Nasdaq 100 index had lost more than 3 percent, pulled down by declines in its five largest technology stocks.
Shares of Microsoft fell as many as 6 points yesterday after the company indicated that the next version of its Windows 95 software would not be out this year. Microsoft pared its losses late, closing down 3 7/8, to 90 1/8. And Intel, off early, also recovered, to close up 1/8 at 130 5/8.
The Nasdaq has lost about 6 percent in the last two weeks, and for the year it is woefully underperforming, down about 3.8 percent at a time when the Dow is up 7 percent.
"I'm betting it will accelerate on the downside," said Richard Eakle, president of Eakle Associates in Fair Haven, N.J. "Valuations are high and many companies are reporting disappointing earnings. And this market is showing no tolerance for earnings disappointments. They're taking them out and crucifying them."
One of the companies punished yesterday was Idexx Labs Inc., a maker of animal health diagnostic kits, based in Westbrook, Me. The company said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter earnings to plunge. The stock then plunged.
Shares of Idexx fell 63 percent, losing 20 points each, to close at 12. It was the third most actively traded stock yesterday, with volume of more than 22 million shares.
But among the blue chips, more than half of the Dow's 30 component stocks showed gains of better than one point, led by I.B.M., up 4 1/4, to 136 3/4; Philip Morris, up 4 1/4, to 115 3/4; Du Pont, up 3 1/2, to 114 1/4, and General Electric, up 3 1/8, to 105 7/8.
The rally in the Dow, however, came after four consecutive sessions of losses. At Friday's close, the Dow was 280 points, or 4 percent, below the peak of 7,085.16 it had reached on March 11.
Still, even with all the volatility -- and the severe downturn in the technology stocks -- the Dow has not fallen very far from the 7,000-point level.
And the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks -- up about 6.8 percent this year -- has fared almost as well. Yesterday, the S.& P. 500 gained 6.79 points, or 0.87 percent, to close at 790.89.
The late-breaking rally yesterday may again raise the question of whether blue chips have become too expensive, some analysts said, a question that the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has raised more than once.
Rao Chalasani, chief investment officer at Everen Securities in Chicago, even says yesterday's Dow surge might give Fed policy makers that much more conviction about raising short-term interest rates.
"The market's up 100 points the day before they decide to raise rates," Mr. Chalasani said. "They may think that if they don't raise rates the market will take off even more. The Fed may feel it has to raise rates just from a credibility point of view."

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 474 words

HEADLINE: Workers Deserve a Choice

 BODY:
The "comp-time" bill passed by the House gives workers the attractive option, impossible under current law, to take their compensation for overtime work in time off rather than extra pay. It might seem odd that Democrats would oppose a sensible idea that most workers say they want. But sensible or not, comp time is opposed by labor unions, which paid over $30 million during the fall campaign to guarantee that Capitol Hill Democrats would do their bidding. President Clinton also opposes the House bill, but at least in his case he has proposed a reasonable, if overly restrictive, alternative.
Under current law, workers must be paid one and a half times their hourly wage for every hour they work over 40 in a week. The Republicans would allow workers, at their discretion, to forgo higher wages and take their compensation in the form of one and a half hours of time off. The existing requirement for paid compensation might have made sense when it was passed in 1938 -- a time of widespread unemployment that put a mostly male work force at the mercy of employers. Sixty years later, competition largely dictates how employers treat workers, and according to polls, female workers yearn for the opportunity to cash in their overtime for time at home. Comp-time options work well in the one place they are currently legal -- for Federal, state and local government workers. 
 Critics point to employers that violate existing overtime pay rules and say they will surely violate the comp bill's prohibition on coercion and force workers to accept time off rather than extra pay. But the House bill would do nothing to make the lives of these victimized workers any worse. Under the new law, a few more companies might also be tempted to violate comp-time rules by pressuring workers to take overtime compensation in the form of time off rather than cash. But if the House bill lacks adequate sanctions, the answer, as the President proposes, is to add more. Besides, the House bill would terminate after five years. If Congress finds abuse, all it need do is refuse to renew the legislation.
The President's comp-time bill includes protections for vulnerable workers. It would provide better judicial protection against misbehaving employers and more control over when workers could use the comp time they accumulate. Unfortunately, the President adds other restrictions that look needlessly costly and complex. But the distance between the House bill and his is not large. There is room for a compromise measure.
The bigger threat lies in the Senate, where Democratic opposition could kill the bill. Voters will be treated to the spectacle of key senators voting for organized labor's support and against ordinary workers, who want nothing more than a choice of compensation that everyone working in Congress already enjoys.

HEADLINE: ON COLLEGE BASKETBALL: FINAL FOUR;
Changing Landscape Leaves Familiar Faces

BYLINE: By Malcolm Moran 

 BODY:
It's still a coach's game.
That is the unexpected result of the economic freedom that underclassmen have gained. The mass defections of young players to professional basketball have not created any shift in power during tournament time. This Final Four lacks star quality, and the rich subplot of a highly anticipated rematch may be gone forever. But those are marketing issues. The competitive reality is that the parity of the 1980's has been pushed deeper into the past and the influence of the coach has never been greater. 
 Unless Arizona completes an unprecedented achievement of back-to-back victories over No. 1-seeded teams in Indianapolis, a No. 1 will win the national title for the seventh time in the eight tournaments of the 1990's. In the 1980's, only three No. 1's became champions, and two of them -- North Carolina in 1982 and Indiana in 1987 -- had to come from behind in the final seconds to win by 1 point. The industry is a long way from the time when North Carolina State and Kansas won from No. 6 and Villanova from No. 8, when as many as 50 teams had a realistic hope of winning a championship.
That number had shrunk to 15, maybe 10, by the time this March arrived. As the trickle-down economics of the National Basketball Association and tightened academic standards complicate roster moves, the coach has remained the constant. The coach as personnel director, adapter, choreographer and propagandist. And maybe most important in this era of free agency at the college level, the coach as holder of the keys to the showcase.
Rick Pitino trumpeted Ron Mercer's decision to leave Kentucky after this sophomore season, and a potentially distracting issue vanished. The coach portrayed the Wildcats as an overachieving, injured group, and successfully camouflaged Kentucky's depth of talent.
Dean Smith criticized his poor preparation for a regional semifinal victory over California, and told his players to treat the game as a loss, and no one was asking about North Carolina's longest winning streak in 10 years.
Arizona's Lute Olson confronted the early-season loss of Miles Simon, his most experienced player, because of academic problems. With Mike Bibby establishing himself at point guard as a freshman and Simon unavailable until January, Olson could not begin developing a starting unit until after the Pacific 10 schedule had begun.
Clem Haskins created Minnesota's Midwest championship the old-fashioned way, by merging experienced leadership with younger talent.
If a coach of a high-powered program can assemble enough elite-level talent, a lack of depth does not have to become an issue. Three years ago, coaches bitterly protested a vote at the N.C.A.A. convention against restoring one scholarship per team. The scholarship was finally approved this January, but this Final Four, with most of the survivors going seven or eight deep, demonstrates that the additional player is an afterthought.
Kentucky could afford the luxury of redshirting Jeff Sheppard, a senior guard who played an important role in the national semifinals last year. North Carolina's Vasco Evtimov, a highly recruited freshman from Brookville, L.I., sits and watches until it is time to clear the bench. A lack of depth is not a problem now, when the stop-and-start pace divides games into segments and creates frequent breaks. "With those N.C.A.A. TV timeouts, you could almost take a nap," Smith said.
Smith once spoke of freshmen as if they triggered an allergic reaction, but now Ed Cota of Brooklyn comes off the bench to run his team. Smith decided early in the season that he had made a mistake in judgment, that this team was not capable of the pressure defense he had envisioned, and revised his approach.
There is one other area in which Smith dominates the rest of the Final Four field. North Carolina, with its 85 percent graduation rate according to the most recent N.C.A.A. survey, is the only remaining school with a rate above 33 percent.
The survey covers scholarship athletes that enrolled from 1986 through 1989. Pitino, who is in his eighth year at Kentucky, was in place for the last of the four classes in the survey, so he is not responsible for the program's 33 percent rate. But Minnesota's 24 percent rate has taken place with Haskins as coach, and Olson has been in charge of the Arizona program throughout a period that has produced a 23 percent rate, including just 14 percent among black players.
Smith will lead his fourth Final Four team of this decade, with his fourth group of starters. His place in the game and his team's level of play have not been altered by the new economics. Once upon a time, Rasheed Wallace and Jerry Stackhouse would have been seniors this year.

HEADLINE: GORE WITNESSES BOEING-CHINA DEAL

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Tuesday, March 25

 BODY:
In a move to underscore Washington's enthusiasm for expanding trade with China, Vice President Al Gore appeared today at the signing of two business deals worth almost $2 billion, including a purchase by the Chinese of five Boeing 777 jetliners for $685 million.
The Boeing agreement seemed jeopardized last week by the charges of illegal campaign finances now dominating Washington, as Mr. Gore's aides worried about associating the Vice President with anything that smacked of deal-making with the Chinese during his four-day visit here. 
 The agreements were signed at a long table in the Great Hall of the People at about 11:30 A.M. in Beijing. Mr. Gore stood shoulder to shoulder with Prime Minister Li Peng behind the signatories, turning to the Mr. Li and saying "very good," as the two men smiled and shook hands.
In the larger of the agreements, the General Motors Corporation and a state-owned Chinese enterprise will split the investment in a $1.3 billion joint venture to make 100,000 Buick Century and Regal sedans a year in Shanghai. In the second, Boeing will sell five 777-200 airplanes to the Civil Aviation Administration of China, a state-owned enterprise, for use by China Air.
Mr. Gore's decision to attend the signings doubtless will be welcomed by American businessmen in China as well as the Chinese leadership, which is anxious to consolidate its position after the death of Deng Xiaoping, by demonstrating that it can manage Beijing's all-important relationship with the United States.
The agreements could also give the Clinton Administration new evidence of the economic benefits of its China policy. Ginny Terzano, Mr. Gore's press secretary, hailed the deals as "proof positive that there is greater economic cooperation between China and the United States."
Administration officials who described the deals here said that their effects would ripple through the United States economy, creating and protecting jobs at the aircraft company, the auto maker and their suppliers. More than 4,500 companies provide parts for the Boeing airplanes, and General Motors estimates that its joint venture will require $1.5 billion in American exports over five years. However, after five years these exports will tail off because the plant in Shanghai will by then be producing nearly all of its parts.
But the business deals are unlikely to stem rising criticism in Congress that the Clinton Administration's policy is failing to expand human rights in China.
Representative Richard Gephardt, a likely rival of Mr. Gore for the next Democratic Presidential nomination, has already said he will oppose extending most favored nation trading status to China this year, partly because of human rights issues. He is also seeking a greater role for Congress in approving the possible admission of China to the World Trade Organization. On Sunday, Mr. Gore tersely declined to comment when asked about Mr. Gephardt's efforts on the trading organization.
But in a third agreement today, China will permit the United States to retain its consulate in Hong Kong after the colony reverts to Chinese control in June. Ambassador James Sasser signed that agreement, long sought by the United States, with China's Vice Foreign Minister, Li Xhaoxing.
Ms. Terzano denied that Mr. Gore and his aides ever wavered about attending the signing of the Boeing deal. "There was not a reluctance," she said.
But Boeing officials worried publicly last week about whether the Vice President would show up.
"If the Chinese Government thinks they are doing a favor to Al Gore by giving us this order," said Boeing's spokesman in Beijing, Chen Linde, "then they may take it back if he does not participate." Mr. Chen said that Chinese officials probed the company about arranging a ceremony that would include the Vice President.
Other businessmen expressed alarm last week. "I'm flabbergasted," said Eden Y. Woon, the director of a Seattle-based business council whose members do business in China. "People who are unhappy with this Administration's engagement of China policy are using this political tempest to handcuff the Administration -- and it's working."
Under the deal to be signed today, the first three planes are to be delivered by the fourth quarter of 1998, and the last two the following year. The president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, Ronald Woodard, is here in Beijing to sign the deal.
The United States airline industry and the Administration were bitterly disappointed less than a year ago when Mr. Li kicked off a visit to France by placing a $1.5 billion order for European planes. At the time, Mr. Li made clear that the Chinese would not give in to United States pressure on trade or any other issue.
Mr. Li presided over the 1989 crackdown on student demonstrators at Tiananmen Square, and during a meeting in Copenhagen two yeas ago he upbraided Mr. Gore for what he characterized as Administration efforts to meddle in China's affairs. But Mr. Gore and he have since corresponded, and their contacts led to this week's visit.
It is not clear what the long-term economic effects of these deals will be. Once the auto complex is up and running, the cars' high-value components will all be produced here. In addition to an assembly plant, the joint venture, to be called Shanghai General Motors, will include stamping, engine, and transmission plants. After the first five years of the venture, G.M. estimates that it will require only $100 million in parts from the United States.
But G.M., the world's largest auto maker, also argues that the joint venture will increase the chances for future imports of entire cars and trucks to China by creating a market-based distribution network here. It was not immediately clear how that network would function, since most of the cars are likely to be bought by the Chinese Government.
General Motors has long struggled to make pick-up trucks in a joint venture in northeastern China. Still, G.M., like the other American auto makers, is anxious to establish a firm foothold in China's dramatically expanding economy. The Chrysler Corporation also take part in a joint venture to produce vehicles in China.
As recently as January, Jack Smith, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, expressed impatience about the pending joint venture.
"We need to get going," he said in an interview at that time. "This is going to get stale." He was referring to Buick models, whose styling and technology is becoming dated. Today, Mr. Smith was here to sign the deal.
 
One of the articles also misstated Mr. Gore's role at the signing ceremony for the deal in some copies. He was a witness but not a signer.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 26, 1997, WednesdayApril 19, 1997, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Articles yesterday about Vice President Al Gore's visit to China misstated the day of his arrival and the day of the signing of a major Chinese-American trade deal in some copies. The Vice President arrived in Beijing on Monday, not yesterday, and the trade deal was signed yesterday, not on Monday.
An article on March 25 about Vice President Al Gore's appearance in Beijing at the signing of two business deals with China, including the sale of five Boeing 777-200 jetliners, misidentified the airline that would use them. It is Air China, the national airline, not China Air.

HEADLINE: A TASTE OF: Los Angeles;
And for Dinner? How About Fun?

BYLINE: By RUTH REICHL 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN the early 1980's, Los Angeles was the most exciting place to eat in America. Jonathan Waxman, who was the chef at Michael's in Santa Monica, Calif., told me at the time: "My customers will eat anything, as long as it is different from what I fed them the night before. They think of eating as entertainment."
In those days, the city was confident and prosperous and happily discovering the fun of food. Starchy old establishments like Perino's, where everyone had to dress up and mind his or her manners, were being replaced by exuberant young ones like Trumps, where the menu was wild (bananas with caviar) and anything went. 
 The East Coast was still wedded to European food, but in Los Angeles you could eat everything: California cuisine, upscale pizza, Southwestern cooking, Franco-Chinese, not to mention the most exciting ethnic food in America.
Then the recession came along, followed by riots and earthquakes. Together they put a damper on the city's spirit. Restaurants closed in droves. New ones opened, but they tended to play it safe; many were inexpensive clones of existing places. It was not a happy time.
Now, the city's restaurants are emerging from the doldrums. While Los Angeles has not totally regained its manic spirit, the signs are optimistic.
It is still, I think, the best place in America to eat ethnic food. This is mostly a function of demographics and geography. Whole sections of the city are Korean, Chinese or Salvadoran, which means that restaurants can cater to the neighborhood, serving authentic food without regard for American tastes.
Wine lists are reasonable enough to make those in New York seem overpriced. You can eat outdoors in the dead of winter. And there is a continuing sense of fun.
During five days of munching around town, I sampled a dozen restaurants. The best meal I had, unfortunately, cannot be replicated: it was a country French dinner cooked by Wolfgang Puck at Spago as a favor to an ailing friend of his. None of the dishes were on the menu.
The meal began with charcuterie produced on the premises: homemade salami and liverwurst, an oxtail terrine and fabulous rillettes. It went on to an extraordinarily intense fish soup. Then there was duck in an olive and red wine sauce, followed by leg of lamb with aligot -- potatoes pureed with garlic and fresh cheese. It ended with a classic mille-feuille filled with whipped cream and jam.
It was a spectacular dinner, and also a perfect metaphor for Los Angeles restaurants. When it opened in 1981, Spago was revolutionary, a new kind of celebrity restaurant serving light California cuisine in a casual atmosphere. The most imitated restaurant in the country, it will close on April 12 and reopen a day or two later in Beverly Hills on the site of the former Bistro Garden. After all this time, it is still vibrant, still reinventing itself.
So is the city. Here are a few of the places I found most interesting.

Fenix at the Argyle
It is a balmy night, and we are seated outdoors: plastic palm trees sway above us, a luminous swimming pool gives off a turquoise glow and below us the lights of the city sparkle like a twinkling carpet. The effect is slightly unreal, as if a curtain could drop at any moment and make the whole thing disappear.
The scene behind us is equally unreal. A woman with a bare midriff and eyes highlighted by a thousand colors of shadow snuggles up to her date. Then she excuses herself to go to the restroom and he turns to watch her. The moment she is out of sight, he picks up his cellular phone. "Sherry?" he says. "Hi, babe. Just wanted to see how you're doing. I'm sitting here thinking about you."
Fenix is the perfect Los Angeles restaurant, not least because the chef, Ken Frank, is the quintessential Los Angeles chef. Famous at 21, he was the original chef at Michael's in Santa Monica. He had his own restaurant, La Toque, by the time he was 23.
Now, at the ripe old age of 41, Mr. Frank has opened this glitzy new place. Like Andre Soltner of Lutece, he is known as a chef who never leaves his kitchen. This makes his restaurant consistent, which is a good thing, but it also makes his food self-referential, because he has had very little exposure to the work of other chefs. As a result, Mr. Frank's best dishes are ones he has been doing for years, like lightly scrambled eggs served in the shell with black truffles. Or foie gras, cooked so it has the delicacy of custard. Or a fine oxtail salad served with the tiniest haricots verts and a sprinkling of truffles.
My favorite main course is the chicken in "half mourning," stuffed under the skin with black truffles and served in a fine sauce. I liked Grand Central monkfish pan roast, too, with the fish in a rich, creamy and delicious sauce larded with clams and tasting like the famous New York pan roast.
The best dessert is the truffle ice cream, another dish Mr. Frank has been making for years. It has never tasted better.
Fenix at the Argyle, 8358 Sunset Boulevard, West Hollywood, Calif.; (213) 848-6677. Dinner entrees, $22 to $34.

Campanile
Food people don't go to Campanile just to eat the amazing doughnuts, pastries and fruit pies that the restaurant somehow manages to pass off as breakfast instead of dessert. They don't go to drink cappuccino and juice, either. They go because the casual self-service breakfast has become such an institution that if you're trying to find someone who cares about food early in the day, he or she is very likely to be there.
The building was originally constructed as a studio for Charlie Chaplin; the courtyard, fountain and pointed arches give it a slightly Moorish air. It's a wonderfully quirky space, and it never looks better than in the morning, when it is filled with casually dressed people on their way to or from their trainers, looking very guilty as they eat the world's most satisfying sticky buns.
Campanile, 624 South La Brea Avenue, Los Angeles; (213) 938-1447.

Obachine
Everyone agreed that I simply had to see Obachine, the latest outpost in the ever-expanding Wolfgang Puck empire. Like most of Mr. Puck's recent restaurants, this one was born to be cloned.
Contrary to my expectations, Obachine is not a low-rent version of his wildly inventive, French-inflected Chinois on Main. It is a pan-Asian restaurant serving creative versions of classic dishes from Thailand, Cambodia, China, India, Vietnam and Japan. This cuisine is rapidly capturing America, and Mr. Puck's spin on it is good but this is the least innovative of his restaurants.
What would I have if I went back? The crisp lamb samosas, which were filled with a thin but extremely spicy filling. The crab shumai. Smoked Peking duck not only was delicious, but also was served with a date-plum sauce that is a big improvement over the traditional hoisin. Seared scallops, in the shell, were served on a yam puree: who would have thought scallops and sweet potatoes would be a happy combination?
Grilled lemon and ginger chicken was a surprise, too. Steamed baby bok choy and duck fried rice were both delicious. The one dish I would definitely avoid is pad Thai, a terrible rendition of the dish.
Obachine, 242 North Beverly Drive, Beverly Hills, Calif.; (310) 274-4440. Dinner entrees, $7.95 to $17.95.

Jozu
Obachine is not the only new pan-Asian restaurant in Los Angeles. Andy Nakano, whose parents owned Imperial Gardens, a Japanese restaurant in Hollywood popular with screenwriters in the 70's, has just opened his interpretation of Los Angeles Asian cuisine.
I remember the space in a previous incarnation as clamorous and uncomfortable, but Jozu has been completely redone. Now, you sink into big cozy booths surrounded by neutral colors. The sound and light levels are serene enough to give you the relaxed sense of being in some underwater atmosphere. It is very pleasant. So is the food, cooked by Suzanne Tracht, who worked at Campanile.
The appetizers are so good it is tempting to order them all, washing them down with sake, which is served in delicate glass pitchers cunningly contrived so that the liquor can be iced without being diluted. The fried Ipswich clams are delicious, as are the oysters with lemon grass, garlic and chilies. Crisp marinated quail is brushed with tangerine and served with a shockingly spicy cucumber salad. Plump little crab-and-shrimp cakes the size of quarters are served with a fine green papaya salad.
The crisp sweetbreads taste of tamarind, and Chilean sea bass is simply roasted, drizzled with ponzu and served with a cabbage salad so that each flavor stands apart. Scallops are sauteed and served with green curry and noodles.
Should you feel like eating good old American food, you can have the fine grilled rib eye without the sichuan peppercorn teriyaki sauce, although it would be a shame to miss the horseradish potatoes.
Jozu, 8360 Melrose Avenue, West Hollywood; (213) 655-5600. Dinner entrees, $13 to $24.

Yuca's
The upscale stuff served in New York's Mexican restaurants just doesn't satisfy me the way any Los Angeles taco truck can. When I am in Los Angeles I stop in at every taco stand I pass.
That is not hard; there are hundreds of good places to eat Mexican street food. I spent one day just driving around East Los Angeles sampling antojitos. (The word, loosely translated, means "little things you crave," and the snacks are always cornmeal based.) But I would never leave town without at least one visit to Yuca's.
The family-run stand has been in a parking lot in the neighborhood of Los Feliz for years, right next to a liquor store. Everything on the small menu is good. My favorites are the small soft tacos filled with carnitas (shredded pork) and cochinita pibil (pork cooked in the style of the Yucatan). I like carne asada with green chili, too. But what I dream about when I am in New York are the burritos filled with slightly chewy and extremely delicious beans. "Not vegetarian," the sign points out. Well, of course not; it's the lard that makes them so good.
Yuca's, 2056 North Hillhurst Avenue, Los Angeles; (213) 662-1214.
 
Oye! at Xiomara
Patrick Healy is another homegrown Los Angeles chef. French-trained, he had his own much-loved Champagne restaurant for many years before he joined forces with Xiomara Ardolina at her eponymous restaurant in Pasadena, Calif.
Now, Ms. Ardolina has persuaded him to turn his talents to the food of her native Cuba. They have opened a restaurant within a restaurant, the nuevo-latino Oye! just behind Xiomara (pronounced SEE-oh-mara).
I am not convinced that Mr. Healy's heart is totally in this new venture, but the menu is fascinating and much of what we ate was very good.
The ceviche, for instance, which is served in a martini glass, features scallops, clams, rock shrimp, squid, sea bass and pickled chayote, and is as good as any I have tasted. He makes an awesome Cuban black bean soup, flavored with ham hocks and topped with okra croutons. Crisp little cakes of bacalao (salt cod) are excellent, served with a rich saffron-yuca and garlic sauce. Shrimp tamales are also innovative, served with a chanterelle salsa and so rich they seem like new-wave quenelles.
Among the entrees, I recommend the Cuban cassoulet -- black beans stewed with chorizo, rabbit, smoked pork loin and plantains. There is also a fine, but rather dry, ropa vieja.
Desserts feature a fine tres leches cake and a lovely trio of tiny flans flavored with guava, soursop and guanabana. At $8 a serving, they are a good indication of what is going on in Los Angeles. Five or six years ago it would have been impossible to imagine the staid citizens of Pasadena spending big money on fancy flan.
Oye! at Xiomara, 69 North Raymond Avenue, Pasadena; (818) 796-2520. Dinner entrees, $16 to $19.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
After Profit Taking, the Dollar Climbs on the Fed's Rate Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose strongly yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in more than two years, a move seen by some currency traders as the first in a series of increases.
The prospect of rising rates in the United States, combined with the uncertain outlook for rates in economically weak Japan and Germany, emboldened traders to buy dollars. Higher rates in the United States tend to bolster the dollar by making assets denominated in dollars more attractive. 
 "There seems to be at least one other rate hike down the pike, and I think that's good for the dollar," said Bob Near, vice president of foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of New York. "It was very much a Fed story today. Everything else doesn't really matter."
In New York, the dollar settled at 123.75 Japanese yen, up from 122.91 on Monday. The dollar cost 1.6914 German marks, up from 1.6881. The British pound cost $1.6184, down from $1.6186.
The Fed's policy-making committee raised the target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight lending, by one-quarter percentage point, to 5.50 percent.
Currency traders had bid the dollar higher before the Fed announcement because they expected it. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had hinted recently that the central bank would take pre-emptive steps, like raising rates, to thwart inflation.
The dollar initially seesawed on the news yesterday, rising on an initial burst of buying, then falling as profit takers sold dollars.
"There was a pretty big exhale after we finally got a Fed move," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "There was a little bit of a knee-jerk reaction to the topside, then we came off quite a bit."
But the dollar subsequently rallied as traders interpreted the Fed announcement as a signal that the rate increase was the first of several to be phased in over a prolonged period.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday, were: 1.4666 Swiss francs, up from 1.4586; 5.7045 French francs, up from 5.6900; 1,693.25 Italian lire, up from 1,688.80; 1.3779 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3795.

HEADLINE: Region's Economic Optimism Level Soars

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The level of economic optimism about jobs and business conditions in the Middle Atlantic states of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania soared over the last year, increasing at a faster pace than any other region of the country, a nonprofit business research group said yesterday.
The Conference Board, a group based in New York, said that in the first three months of this year, the region's consumer confidence index -- a combined measure of residents' current economic outlook and future expectations -- rose by nearly 62 percent, compared with the same period a year earlier. The report said that while the Middle Atlantic continues to have the bleakest perspective of any region -- a lingering hangover of the deep recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's -- many more people apparently now believe that better times lie ahead. The strongest component of the regional index for March, in particular, came from residents' thoughts about the future. 
 "Current conditions are still weak, but people are becoming more optimistic, and one fuels the other," said Lynn Franco, the associate director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
Separately, the New York State Department of Labor said that the unemployment rate, which has climbed sharply in the last few months, especially in New York City, as more residents have entered the job market searching for work, was little changed in February, at 9.8 percent. The statewide rate of 6.9 percent was also unchanged from the previous month.
Both the job report and the confidence index point to much the same conclusion, economists say: Brightened job prospects. Increased hiring on Wall Street, and the expansion of retailing, construction and film making -- along with other sectors of the economy -- have not only created new jobs, but also raised expectations for job seekers, and that, somewhat paradoxically, is what helps explain the higher unemployment numbers.
Economic growth, much of which has been concentrated in the city itself, rather than its suburbs, has apparently created a high level of optimism, with more new job seekers than there are new jobs. The confidence index underlines those heightened expectations.
But like the unemployment rate, which hints at the hidden frustrations that simmer within the economy, the consumer confidence number for the region also offers a very mixed message. The region's confidence levels are by far the lowest in the nation, followed by the New England region, which includes Connecticut, where the confidence levels are the second lowest.
In March, for example, the preliminary, not seasonal average of consumer confidence index for the Middle Atlantic region stood at 77.2, a level that Conference Board officials said is the rock bottom threshold for any growing economy. Anything below 70 is considered recessionary, while anything over 100 is an indicator of strong economic growth. One year ago, the confidence index for the region stood at 51.
By contrast, the confidence index for the nation as a whole now stands at 118.5, up from 98.4 one year ago. The index is based on written surveys sent to 5,000 households around the country, and has a response rate of about 70 percent, the Conference Board said. About 18 percent of the people in the sample -- reflecting the national population distribution -- live in the three Middle Atlantic states.
New Jersey reported last week that its economy added 8,300 jobs, statewide, in February, and that its seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 5.5 percent, from 5.9 percent in January. Connecticut's unemployment rate stood at 5.1 percent in January; it is to report its February numbers next week.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "On the Rebound" shows an index of consumer confidence in the economy for the Middle Atlantic states, New England and the United States, for 1996 and 1997. (Source: The Conference Board)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Bananagate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
I'm Chiquita Banana and I've come to say / Bananas have to ripen in a certain way . . .
"Soon we'll hear about Bananagate" was the prediction here two weeks ago, as a veteran right-wing tycoon and philanthropist -- Carl Lindner of Chiquita Brands -- was spotted giving $415,000 to the Democrats in hopes of getting the World Trade Organization to clear the way for Chiquita to make a bundle. 
 Time magazine's Michael Weisskopf and Viveca Novak advanced that story this week. Chiquita worked with the D.N.C. to steer another half-million dollars into the Democratic maw through two dozen state parties -- avoiding the scrutiny given Federal campaigns.
When donors go to great lengths to duck disclosure, they usually have something to hide. In this case, it was Chiquita's need to get President Clinton to bring American trade power to bear, even though few U.S. jobs were involved.
Lindner is a rock-ribbed Republican, a big giver to the G.O.P. for years; the very quiet largess to the other political side helped guarantee that Clinton would trounce the Europeans in trade.
When they are flecked with brown and have a golden hue / Bananas taste the best, and are the best for you.
The golden hue began on April 12, 1996, the day after U.S. Trade Representative Mickey Kantor asked the W.T.O. to take up Chiquita's grievance, on which the body ruled favorably this week. Within 24 hours, notes Time, Lindner and his men began shoveling heavy money into Democratic coffers in two dozen states.
Kantor, Clinton's 1992 campaign manager, insists to me from Bangkok it was a staff recommendation: "I had no earthly idea of his contributions. I was once asked by somebody in the White House -- no, I won't say who -- should he meet with Lindner, and I said, 'No, you should not.' "
Lindner not only met Clinton, but turned out to be one of the Lincoln Bedroom 900. And after its political investment of a measly million, Chiquita got U.S. sponsorship for a ruling that profits it a bunch.
Clinton has that Midas touch. Turn to his intimate, Webster Hubbell, who was able to multiply his earning power fivefold as the jailhouse loomed.
Just before entering the slammer on Aug. 7, 1995, the man who may hold the secrets that could bring Clinton down sent an intermediary (probably through a cutout unknown) to Michael Carlisle of the William Morris agency in New York. On Sept. 28, 1995, Hubbell signed a contract with Harper Collins for a $125,000 advance for a quickie book tentatively titled "Friends in High Places," interminably subtitled "an intimate look at the character of our President, his wife, his circle and perhaps his entire political generation."
The publisher (part of Rupert Murdoch's empire, but that mogul was unaware of a deal involving such small potatoes) paid the felon $41,667 on signing and $20,000 more in May 1996, which it is now trying to get back. Other providers of the more than $500,000 Hubbell received while he was deciding to clam up have been more understanding.
Hubbell did turn out a work product in jail, which is more than he did for some other "clients" -- thousands of pages of rambling ruminations on a yellow pad, plus answers to editors' queries and pleas for "more compelling" material.
Most of the manuscript was recently delivered under subpoena to the Independent Counsel, who is belatedly trying to establish a connection between Clinton and the college friend of Carlisle's who brought the agent the proposal.
What do the astounding financial successes of Chiquita Banana and Webster Hubbell have in common?
Only this: If you have a really nice bowl of golden-hued fruit to contribute to the flecked Clinton cause, you can expect your Government to make your case before the world.
Similarly, if you have information to withhold that could break the Whitewater case, you can expect to find Asian wheeler-dealers, financial cash cows and as-yet-unknown cutouts making deals for you that can bail the sleaziest fraud out of the most horrific hole.
So you should never put bananas/ In the refrigerator. No-no-no-no.
A 1 percent correction of the C.P.I. would save about $150 billion a year in 10 years, not in the first year, as misstated here Sunday.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Eye on the Bottom Line, Braves and Indians Trade

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., March 25

 BODY:
After "kicking the tires of this deal all spring long," the Atlanta Braves and the Cleveland Indians made a stunning trade today that was fueled by the economic concerns of both clubs. The Braves sent two-thirds of their outfield, David Justice and Marquis Grissom, to the Indians for Kenny Lofton, who is considered the best leadoff hitter in baseball, and relief pitcher Alan Embree.
"Quite candidly, I think we made a good baseball trade that was motivated by baseball economics on both sides," John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager, said. 
He said the two teams had been contemplating the deal throughout spring training. "We finally got to the point where we both felt comfortable with it," Schuerholz said. "We both approached this matter guardedly because we were talking about giving up significant talent from our clubs. But it suits our needs and theirs."
The trade between the two teams can be viewed in various ways:
*It is an exchange of Gold Glove center fielders, Grissom for Lofton.
*The Indians, by acquiring Justice, bolster an offense that has lost Albert Belle.
*The Indians get something for Lofton before losing him, like Belle, as a free agent. Lofton's contract expires after this season.
*The Braves open a spot for Jermaine Dye and Andruw Jones, two attractive outfielders, who contributed to the team's success last season.
*The Braves, who wanted to reduce their major league-high $63.8 million payroll, save $7.7 million in actual salary and luxury tax for this year. By shedding $26.9 million owed Justice (two years) and Grissom (three years) for the rest of their contracts, the Braves also create greater flexibility in their quest to keep Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine, who can be free agents next November.
By losing Justice's $6 million salary and Grissom's $4.8 million salary this season and taking on Lofton's $4.75 million and Embree's $206,000, the Braves emerge with a net saving of $5,844,000. They also save $1,870,400 in luxury tax. Combined, the reduction in actual salary and tax means a saving of $7,714,400.
The Braves will still enter the season with one of the five highest payrolls. The five clubs with the highest payrolls over $51 million will pay a 35 percent tax on payroll portions over that threshold.
The Yankees now have the highest payroll, $63.4 million. The trade sent the Indians, who had been seventh at $53.5 million, past the Braves, $58.8 million to $58.5 million. Payrolls for tax purposes will change with each player move during the season so the top five teams won't be known until the end of the season.
The Braves had made no secret of their desire to trade Justice, Grissom or Fred McGriff as a way of reducing their payroll and opening a spot for Dye and Jones. "If we can make a deal that allows our club to be championship caliber, as strong as it is now, and also diminish our payroll, we'll do that," Schuerholz had said early in spring training.
The only surprise was that Schuerholz was able to put Justice and Grissom in the same package. Lofton's status made that possible.
"We went through it last year with Albert Belle, and Albert left us," John Hart, the Indians' general manager, said at a news conference in nearby Winter Haven. "We are not prepared as an organization to let that happen again."
Lofton, who has usurped Rickey Henderson's status as the game's No. 1 leadoff hitter and the American League's perennial base-stealing leader, disputed Hart's view that Lofton "made it clear he wanted to exercise his right to go out on the market."
"I never planned on testing the market," Lofton said. "That didn't come out of Kenny Lofton's mouth. The Indians decided that." He alluded to the inability of the two sides to reach agreement on a contract extension.
Lofton, who batted .317, had 75 stolen bases and scored 132 runs in 1996, joins an Atlanta outfield that has Ryan Klesko as the incumbent left fielder and will now have Dye and Jones in right.
Dye, 23 years old, batted .281 in 92 games last season after Justice dislocated his right shoulder swinging at a pitch May 15. Jones, a native of Curacao who will turn 20 on April 23, became the youngest player to ever hit a post-season home run when he connected against St. Louis in the National League Championship Series, then surpassed that performance by hitting two home runs in his first two times up against the Yankees in the first game of the World Series.
Although it was initially assumed that the Braves would use Lofton only for this season, then let him go as a free agent so that Dye and Jones could play at the same time, Schuerholz disputed that conclusion.
"We're going to leave that agenda item wide open," he said by telephone from West Palm Beach. "We have demonstrated over the last six years our willingness to commit to whatever level is necessary financially to keep a championship-caliber team."
The Indians, anticipating Belle's departure, acquired third baseman Matt Williams from the San Francisco Giants last Nov. 13. They also signed Kevin Mitchell as a free agent, but they were evidently not satisfied with him or Brian Giles in their lineup as the left fielder.
Justice has never been the home run hitter Belle is, but he hit a career-high 40 in 1993, the last full season he played. He drove in 120 runs that season. Hart said the Indians were satisfied that Justice was healthy 10 months after he had shoulder surgery.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Harlem U.S.A. Project Is Progressing, but Tempo Lags

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Harlem U.S.A., the long-delayed entertainment-retail complex that is supposed to be one of the sparks for the redevelopment of 125th Street as a shopping district, is making progress, backers say, but more slowly than originally planned.
Drew Greenwald, the president of Grid Properties, the principal developer of the five-level, 275,000-square-foot project, said he has signed or made oral commitments for about 70 percent of the space -- up from 30 percent last June -- and is negotiating with banks about financing the estimated $56 million that it will cost to build. 
 The ambitious project, which would occupy most of the block bounded by 124th and 125th Streets and Eighth and St. Nicholas Avenues, is already scheduled to be the home of a Gap store, Chase Bank, Radio Shack and Watch World, as well as Disney. Other stores that are reportedly negotiating for space in the proposed building are HMV, a music store, and Modell's, a sporting goods store.
Unlike suburban shopping malls, where stores face an interior corridor, each of the planned 20 ground-floor stores will open to the street as part of an effort to make the project blend in with existing stores in the neighborhood.
The entertainment is to be provided by a nine-screen Cineplex Odeon movie theater, committed last year, with as many as 3,000 seats on top of two stories of retail stores. On the top level, an ice skating rink is planned with as many as 2,000 seats for watching ice hockey games. The rink is to be operated by Recreation World, a company that operates sports and entertainment concessions, mostly in suburban shopping malls.
But finding enough tenants for the development to attract the private financing it needs has not been easy. Banks have told the developer that 75 percent of the space must be committed before construction financing will be provided.
Mr. Greenwald is optimistic, even though predictions of when construction will begin have slipped. Early last year, the developers had said they hoped to start construction by the end of the year. Later in the year, the target was the first quarter.
"Negotiations are like that," Mr. Greenwald said. "They take longer than you would like. We are still hoping to do demolition and asbestos removal in the spring and start building in the summer." He said several banks had expressed interest in financing the project.
Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty Services, who is a leasing broker for the project, said one reason for the slow pace of leasing is the developer's desire to get first-class tenants. "We could have rented the space 20 times over if we were willing to accept lower-quality tenants," he said.
Retail real estate specialists said one problem for major retail employers is recruiting executive staffs to work in lower-income locations. Richard Seligman, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, a commercial brokerage concern, said, "If you say to a guy 'I'll pay you $55,000 to manage a store in midtown or $57,000, $58,000, to manage one on 125th Street,' he will probably say, 'keep the extra couple of thousand, I don't need the aggravation.' "
Nevertheless, he said, the community has relatively few stores in relation to its population, which presents an opportunity for retailers who can tailor their operations to the neighborhood.
"There is business to be done in Harlem, and it is not just sneakers and jeans," said Faith Consolo, a senior managing director of Garrick-Aug Associates. She said 125th Street was like 34th Street was before national retailers like Kmart started moving in. "It's been local businesses, and the area was always a cultural center."
Ms. Consolo said that because the 125th Street strip was in a Federal economic empowerment zone and the state has pledged to extend low-interest loans for projects in the area, more retailers from national companies will be persuaded to locate in the area.
Real estate brokers say that if a few national companies open successfully on 125th Street, others will rush to join them. "It's a herd mentality," said Alan Victor, executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation. "If one opens, the rest will follow."
Mr. Greenwald said plans are to relocate an existing Chase bank branch to the west side of the proposed L-shaped building before demolishing the present building so that there will be no time gap in the branch's operations. After that, the rest of the site will be prepared for the start of construction.

HEADLINE: Let's Get Our Superpowers Straight

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is the managing editor of Foreign Affairs.

 BODY:
Two simple facts define the geopolitical landscape today -- Russian weakness and Chinese strength. In the North Atlantic, across Eurasia, in East Asia, these two realities form the backdrop against which daily events occur, from the chaos in Albania to the cautiousness in Hong Kong. Yet increasingly the Clinton Administration's foreign policy looks as if it were intended to meet precisely the opposite challenges.
As Russia continues its political bumbling, economic muddling and military retrenchment, the Administration is spending vast amounts of time, energy, money and political capital to deter it from launching an invasion of Central Europe. 
 China, on the other hand, is surging economically, bulking up its armed forces and becoming more assertive by the day. Yet the United States has scaled back its military capability in the region, relying instead on good will and engagement with Beijing.
The diplomatic excursions of the last week perfectly symbolized the Administration's outlook: No sooner did President Clinton return from Helsinki, having informed Boris Yeltsin that NATO would expand whatever the outcome of their talks, than Vice President Al Gore was off on his trip to Beijing, toasting business deals.
Russia today is not a great power, but a great power vacuum. Its economy is half the size of what the Soviet Union's was, and it has declined continuously now for five years. Political instability in Moscow and the regions persists, and the present state of the Russian army, warns a recent report by a private Moscow think tank, "can only be described as a catastrophe."
Those who always worry about Russia reflexively insist that these crises are temporary, that Russia will return as a great power, as it always has. But has it? Czarist Russia was never an economic powerhouse, either agriculturally or industrially. And, other than World War II, Russia's record in power politics is one of failure followed by failure: the Crimean War, the Russo-Japanese War, World War I and the cold war.
Today Russia's borders are farther away from Central Europe than they have been for centuries. Even if we were to see the renewal of Russian expansionism in the next decade, the countries being considered for first-tier membership in NATO would not be vulnerable to attack. Ukraine, Belarus and the Baltic states are at greater risk, but no one really expects them to become NATO members in the foreseeable future. Indeed, it is unlikely that they will ever be made members precisely because they may face a real threat.
The historian A. J. P. Taylor said the Treaty of Locarno of 1925, in which Britain and Italy promised to defend France and Belgium, "rested on the assumption that the promises made in it would never have to be made good -- otherwise the British Government would not have made them."
NATO is now willing to make a similar guarantee to Hungary only because it, too, is assumed to be totally unnecessary. That is why Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott can assert that the movement closer to Russia's borders of the most powerful military alliance in the world does not actually threaten Russia. As Tweedledee says, "if it was so, it might be; and if it were so, it would be: but as it isn't, it ain't. That's logic."
Our problems with Russia all stem from its weakness: the danger of chaos within Russia and on its Central Asian borders; the fear of its losing control of its nuclear arsenal; a breakdown in relations between the military and the Government. President Clinton has been able to bully the Russians into accepting NATO expansion only because they are too weak even to maintain the rhetoric of obstruction. This, of course, raises the question of why they need to be contained in the first place.
All the while, of course, China continues its relentless economic march. In the last five years growth has averaged almost 12 percent, with exports rising even faster. Much of this expansion is in low-cost, labor-intensive goods, but increasingly China is gaining access to high technology, often aided by the Chinese diaspora in East Asia.
The Chinese military, too, is a growth industry. The People's Liberation Army is the largest in the world; it boasts the third-largest nuclear arsenal in terms of delivery vehicles. China's defense budget, a subject of great speculation, is probably around $30 billion and growing by 10 percent each year. The army's rapid reaction force has increased tenfold, to 200,000 troops. These trends are likely to continue because keeping the military happy is an important way to maintain power in Beijing, as Prime Minister Jiang Zemin has readily recognized.
This economic and military expansion is occurring in a region where other countries' economies and militaries are already bursting with growth. (Indonesia, for one, is building up its armed forces at a steeper rate than China.) Beijing has troubled relations with many of its neighbors; of the 14 with whom it shares land borders, four have disputed boundaries: Russia, North Korea, Tajikistan and India. Additionally, as the China scholars Andrew Nathan of Columbia University and Robert Ross of Boston College have written, "China's territorial interests overlap with those of 24 other countries."
American problems with China all relate to Chinese strength: the military buildup, increasing chauvinism, mercantilist economic policies, refusal to sign international agreements on proliferation. If a great power's potential for trouble is judged on the basis of a combination of its capabilities and intentions, China can only be rated a graver threat than Russia.
China is not a rogue superpower, mainly because it is not -- and is unlikely to become -- a superpower. Thus a policy of containment would be premature and unworkable. But the United States must increase its military presence to stabilize East Asia. This is the surest way to deter China from attempts at expansionism such as a military takeover of Taiwan.
Yet the Administration seems to assume that talking with Beijing can produce results on issues from trade to human rights, even as it whittles down our military deterrent. The United States has virtually no military forces left in the Philippines and has reduced its presence in Japan. Washington diplomats have already begun murmuring that if and when Korean unification takes place, American troops will not be able to stay in Korea, since China will object.
Thus if the Clinton Administration's policies are successful, 10 years from now a large, well-equipped American-led force will be in place on the central plains of Europe, fully capable of deterring a paralyzed Russia. Meanwhile, American military power and political influence will have been steadily shrunk in East Asia, the site of the rise of the world's next great power. Perhaps each policy on its own terms might seem plausible, but taken together the two add up to a global grand strategy that is topsy-turvy.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Drop as Fed Raises Rate

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices turned lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve fulfilled investors' expectations and raised short-term interest rates.
The central bank's monetary policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, raised its target on the Federal funds rate to 5.50 percent, from 5.25 percent. The rate, the interest rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, has not been adjusted since January 1996, when the Fed cut it a quarter-point amid concern that the economy was headed for a recession. The committee did not, however, adjust the discount rate, which is the rate the Fed charges its member banks for overnight loans. 
 While the rise in the funds rate had largely been expected, the hawkish tone of the Fed's announcement had not. "This action was taken in light of persisting strength in demand," the Fed's statement said, "which is progressively increasing the risk of inflationary imbalances developing in the economy."
The comments "suggest the Fed will not stop tightening until the economy shows signs of slowing," Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, said.
Indeed, concerns over the Fed's next move weighed down prices late yesterday.
The price of the 30-year bond ended down 18/32, to 95 25/32. The bond's yield -- a benchmark for consumer and corporate interest rates -- rose to 6.96 percent, from 6.92 percent on Monday.
Prices of shorter maturities also fell. The price of the two-year note fell 4/32, to 99 7/32 for a yield of 6.31 percent, up from 6.24 percent on Monday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions.
Prices were mixed in thin trading yesterday until noon, when prices surged briefly on speculation that the Fed would not raise rates. The rally forced investors who had bet that prices would fall to buy securities to cover their short positions.
When the Fed made its announcement on rates about 2:15 P.M., prices fell.
The question for the market now is: What will the Fed do next? Many are betting on at least one initial increase in rates.
"Barring any sudden and sharp deceleration in economic growth, it would be prudent to assume at least one more Fed tightening move going forward," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
Mr. Palash of MCM Moneywatch said he expected one or two more rate increases in the near term. "The whole point of the tightening is to slow the economy, and clearly 25 basis points will not accomplish that, so I think they have to go 50 basis points," he said, for a total move of at 75 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes was held before the Fed made its announcement. The auction's bid-to-cover ratio -- the number of bids compared with the size of the sale -- was a bit on the soft side, but noncompetitive bidding was stronger than expected, Mr. Palash said.
The two-year issue was sold at a high yield of 6.270 percent, up from 5.885 percent last month and the highest since July 23, 1996, when the yield was 6.288 percent. Today the Treasury is to sell $12.5 billion of five-year notes and $13.75 billion of new one-year bills. In when-issued trading, the five-year maturity was offered at a price to yield 6.64 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of two-year notes:

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Index Shows a March Dip

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Americans' confidence in the economy slipped this month, and their expectations for coming months dimmed as well, but both gauges remained close to the high levels registered recently.
The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence fell to 118.5 in March from a revised 118.9 in February, which was the highest reading in eight years. The February level was originally reported as 118.4. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg News had expected a March reading of 117.7. 
 The index that measures consumer expectations over the next six months fell half a point, the research group said.
"The message from consumers is that both business and employment conditions will remain upbeat through the spring and the summer," said Lynn Franco, associate director at the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
The report was issued as the Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee met. The panel decided to raise the Federal funds rate by one-quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent; the rate applies to loans that banks make one another overnight.
 "From the Fed's point of view, confidence is a sign that the economy is not about to slow down," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. "Each new release gives the Fed more reason to raise rates."
Analysts expect consumers' confidence, and their spending, to remain high. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity.
Yesterday's report did suggest, however, that consumers were less upbeat about their financial prospects. The index that gauges expectations for the next six months fell to 101, from a revised 101.9. The index that tracks consumers' assessments of present conditions fell to 144.1, from a revised 144.3 in February.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Likely Impact: Less Disruption Than Last Time

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Three years ago, a move by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates set off a huge retrenchment in a bond market where prices had been driven up by speculation. This year, such a move is likely to have a much smaller effect on the financial markets. For it is Japan's central bank, not America's, that has done the most recently to foster speculation.
The Federal Reserve's move yesterday to raise the Federal Funds rate, at which banks lend to one another, by one-quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent, caused little immediate market reaction, in part because it was widely expected. 
 The general Wall Street view is that the economy, and the stock and bond markets, can escape this round of credit tightening without major damage. But that could change if the Federal Reserve proves to be more determined to raise rates than most now expect, or if the Japanese were to join in raising rates.
In the early 1990's a huge amount of speculation had been built up, largely in bonds, by traders who borrowed at short-term American interest rates and then bought various kinds of longer-term bonds whose rates were higher. When the Federal Reserve moved to push up short-term rates, it cut profits of the speculators and threw fear into them. A selloff in bonds ensued.
There is no shortage of speculation now -- and stemming that speculation may have been one of the Federal Reserve's goals -- but it does not appear to be based on borrowing at United States short-term rates. Now, the speculation is more in stocks, and for many aggressive professional investors the preferred source of borrowing is Japan, where short-term rates are well under 1 percent.
"If you want to talk about the speculation associated with low short-term rates, you have to go halfway around the world," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
An increase in Japanese rates would be more likely to throw fear into speculators right now. But those rates are held down, as they were in this country in the early 1990's, in an effort to help banks that have been damaged by bad loans, as well as by a desire to stimulate economic growth. It is not clear how soon the Bank of Japan will feel it can afford to begin raising them.
The increase yesterday had been repeatedly hinted at by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and had been almost universally forecast. By contrast, Mr. Greenspan's hints in late 1993 and early 1994 were largely ignored, and the increase came as a shock to many. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 96 points, or 2.4 percent, on Feb. 4, 1994, the day the Fed acted, and the rate on long-term Treasury bonds rose to 6.35 percent, from 6.30 percent the day before. That was not a big move, but bigger ones were to come soon, as speculators sold bonds, driving prices down and interest rates up. By later in 1994, the rate was above 8 percent.
During the months after the first 1994 tightening, the Dow fell nearly 10 percent, and lesser stocks fell further. The Nasdaq composite managed to rise to a new high on March 18 that year, a few days before the Fed made clear it was serious by pushing rates up again, but it then fell almost 15 percent over the next three months.
Few expect bond yields to rise as much as they did in 1994. "The reaction will not be as vigorous this time around," forecast Henry Kaufman, the economist and money manager who runs the firm of the same name. He said 30-year Treasury bond yields "will be in the range of 7 to 7.5 percent" by the second half of 1997. That is not much of a move. Yesterday, the yield on 30-year Treasuries rose from 6.92 percent, to 6.96 percent.
The general view now is that the Fed is unlikely to push rates up more than one or two additional times, and that such moves will slow the economy a bit but not tip it into recession. And the Dow now is already down about 2.5 percent from the peak it reached earlier this month, while the Nasdaq composite is off 10 percent from the peak it hit in January. Yesterday, stock prices gyrated but ended with only modest changes.
If the view holds that the Fed's action will have little economic impact, and by delaying inflation indefinitely may even prolong the current six-year economic expansion, then the impact on stocks could be slight.
In announcing the move yesterday, the Fed said it was acting "in light of persisting strength in demand, which is progressively increasing the risk of inflationary imbalances developing in the economy." Wall Street found two ways to read that, one encouraging and one not.
Some said the talk of a "risk of inflationary imbalances" rather than of actual ones, meant that the Fed was unlikely to do more until it really saw inflation. Others said that the focus on "persisting strength in demand" might be a signal that the Fed would act until it was clear that strength had dissipated.
If the latter interpretation becomes widely accepted, that could cast a pall over the stock market, by raising the risk of recession or at least of an economy slowing enough to damage profits. Profits have grown rapidly in recent years, and stock prices generally assume that trend will continue.
Mr. Greenspan drew much attention in December, when he spoke of possible "irrational exuberance" in the stock market. Prices have gyrated some since then, but money has continued to pour into stock mutual funds at a rapid rate. So far, most investors, professional and amateur, appear to believe that the Fed will not do anything nasty enough to really damage one of the greatest bull markets in history.
But if Japan's central bank were to act decisively, that market confidence might weaken, if not vanish.
