HEADLINE: Invasion of the Stealth Antennas;
In Cellular Phone Era, Receivers Are Hidden All Over

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The air war over New York has begun.
On building rooftops and towers, billboards and water tanks -- and coming soon, perhaps, even to a city lamppost near you -- antennas are sprouting by the hundreds as the wireless communications revolution advances on the nation's largest, most densely populated, most lucrative and, for engineers, most maddening communications market.
But unlike the wiring of New York for electricity and telephones in the late 1800's, which choked streets with webs of wires and poles and construction teams, this new wireless world is being built very quietly. Block by block, building by building, new companies and familiar names like AT&T are racing one another to negotiate with property owners for placement of antennas that they say are needed to meet the exploding demand for cellular telephones, pagers and other more exotic wireless devices of an increasingly mobile society. 
 The number of these radio antennas in the five boroughs of New York has quadrupled in the last six months, to 1,000 or more, and is likely to double again within the next year, telecommunications experts estimate. But anyone trying to count these new antennas will need good luck and good eyesight. This emerging wireless communications network, perhaps in keeping with its ethereal medium, is being constructed with deliberate and almost complete invisibility.
Antennas are being concealed and camouflaged, painted to blend with building surfaces, hidden inside parking garage signs, tucked under awnings and stashed behind billboards. Along some blocks of midtown Manhattan or along Queens Boulevard in Elmhurst, Queens, there are dense clusters of antennas -- for reasons that only a radio engineer could love -- but spotting them, on rooftops or at street level, painted to look like bricks, would be like a telecommunications version of "Where's Waldo?"
In Herald Square, there are two waffle-sized antennas at opposite ends of a metal-framed awning. A Park Avenue office building near Grand Central Terminal has an antenna just under a stern-looking frescoed angel on its stone facade. At St. Bartholomew's Church on East 51st Street at Park Avenue, an antenna is visible just over the word "apostle" on the building's northwest corner.
Within the next few months, the city plans to award a contract for the first of what could be thousands more antennas to be mounted on city-owned lampposts. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is also negotiating with six companies that want to mount disguised cellular antennas in church spires or on other church properties.
"You're probably going to have more antennas per square mile than any other city in the country, and right now you've just seen the beginning," said David Roddy, the chief telecommunications economist at Deloitte & Touche Consulting Group in Atlanta.
But however quietly this part of the telecommunications revolution is proceeding, there are New Yorkers, in scattered buildings and neighborhoods, who have emerged to fight it, because of concerns about the health effects, which they say are uncertain, or about the esthetic implications for buildings or the cityscape as a whole.
In a cooperative building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, for example, residents are now in a standoff with Sprint PCS, a company affiliated with the Sprint Corporation, about a partly installed rooftop antenna. In Queens, residents circulated petitions and wrote to the New York City Public Advocate's office last year when they became concerned about a cellular phone antenna on a nearby apartment building.
But both of those instances also underline the power and momentum of the new wireless expansion. The Queens residents found they could not even learn the name of the company that had placed the antenna. Since the purpose complied with the health standards set by the 1996 Federal Telecommunications Act, city officials told them, the contract was purely a matter between the landlord and the wireless company. At the Manhattan co-op, Sprint has declared that its contract is valid and that it will take the building to court if necessary.
Health studies and tests conducted for the Federal Communications Commission have found no danger from exposure to radio transmissions, especially the newer systems that use very low power. Opponents say, however, that just as exposure to high-power electrical transmission lines has been linked by some researchers to higher cancer rates, the health effects from long-term exposure to cellular transmissions remain unknown.
A spokesman for the City Health Department, Fred Winters, said that the agency accepted the F.C.C.'s analysis that there was no basis for concern.
Opponents say that feeling helpless against antenna encroachment is as much a problem as any anxiety caused by the technology.
"I felt stuck," said Edward Drinkmann, a registered nurse from Whitestone, Queens, who unsuccessfully fought his neighborhood's antenna, on the roof of a building on 146th Place, two doors from his house. Mr. Drinkmann said he was concerned about the effect on property values, but even more worried about his two daughters, ages 9 and 13. "I don't want to hear 20 years from now that there is a pattern of health concerns found around the clusters of cellular telephone transmission sites," he said.
Nationwide, telecommunications experts estimate that more than 100,000 new radio antennas will be needed over the next decade to keep up with the exploding volume of cellular telephone use and the newly licensed technologies like personal communications services. The new technologies, which include new forms of cellular phone service, pagers and data transmission, using different radio band-widths and digital rather than analog technology, have been licensed in recent years as the Federal Communications Commission has begun selling off chunks of the nation's airwaves.
But telecommunications industry officials and New Yorkers who oppose rampant antenna installation agree that building the wireless machinery in New York is also a fundamentally different proposition from doing it anywhere else.
Because of the city's dense topography -- especially in Manhattan -- radio signals bounce in unpredictable ways through the urban canyons. That means more antennas are required. New York's population density, meanwhile, means that residents are more likely to find themselves living in close proximity to an antenna than residents anywhere else in the nation.
Wireless communication is also pushing into new uses. Copier maintenance companies, for example, are installing mobile transmitters on copy machines, which can then automatically call headquarters for service or repair. The next generation of soda machines will likely live in the wireless world as well -- they will call home when they run out of root beer. And every one of those systems needs an antenna.
For cellular phone traffic, antennas are essentially the conduits between footloose radio signals and land-based wire systems: a customer speaks into his phone and the signal bounces to the nearest of that company's antennas. From there, it goes into the regular telephone wires and then to the antenna nearest the person on the other end of the call.
But the pressure to build the antenna networks that will insure call quality means more than competition between companies.
Co-op owners at 67 Riverside Drive, the building that is in the dispute with Sprint PCS, said they worried about a long-term commitment to a technology that they realized they just weren't sure about. Sprint PCS, which is jointly owned by four communications giants -- Sprint, Tele-Communications Inc., the Comcast Corporation and Cox Communications -- signed the contract last year to pay the building $24,000 a year for the next 25 years to use a roughly refrigerator-size transmitter, connected to several antennas, each about the size of a box of long-stemmed roses.
A lawyer for the building's board said residents reconsidered when they saw equipment being moved in last month. That caused them to go back and look the contract, which the board now says may not have been validly negotiated or signed.
Sprint said the contract was valid, but offered to shorten the lease to five years. The building counter-offered a one-year-lease that Sprint says is too short to justify its investment.
"There's a sentiment in the building that it's just not worth the potential risk," said Lawrence S. Hirsh, the co-op's lawyer. "The building would be happy to have Sprint go away and give them back their money."
A lawyer for Sprint PCS, David L. Snyder, said the company had no such intentions.
"We have a valid lease, we have rent checks that have been cashed, construction plans that have been approved," Mr. Snyder said. "We comply with all Federal, state and local laws and we have a co-op which refuses to honor its obligations."
Keeping up with the aerial advance could also prove hard for the city government. In November, it said it wanted to lease out as many as 9,000 lampposts for antenna use and was seeking proposals. But the laborious municipal contract machinery moves at land-based pace; the untethered, deregulated telecommunications market does not.
At Omnipoint Communications, a company in Mountain Lakes, N.J., that began building its New York City system in August, initial company blueprints called for using lampposts. But Omnipoint's president, George F. Schmitt, said that only seven months later, without the use of lampposts, the system was more than 60 percent built, with more than 300 antennas in the city and 200 to go up within the next few months. There may still be Omnipoint lampposts, he said, but not that many.
A spokeswoman for the city's Department of Information, Technology and Telecommunications declined to comment because lamppost negotiations are still being held.
"It didn't happen fast enough for us," Mr. Schmitt said. "We couldn't wait."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 576 words

HEADLINE: Crisis in the Housing Program

 BODY:
Housing Secretary Andrew Cuomo and Attorney General Janet Reno this week jointly announced a vigorous program to stamp out fraud in the Government's major housing program for low-income families. The abuses in the Section 8 program, as it is called, are real -- as New York learned when Federal authorities took over a housing project in the Bronx two weeks ago after sanitary and building conditions had deteriorated to appalling levels. But fraud is not the program's major problem. A financial time bomb is. The Administration understood that Congress would not fork over the money needed for continuation and expansion if the programs were riddled with fraud and abuse.
Section 8 subsidies help millions of families that cannot afford even low-rent apartments. One rent subsidy goes to landlords, who are also provided government-insured mortgages. A separate subsidy, a rent voucher, goes directly to poor families that apply it to apartments of their choice. The financial crisis stems from the fact that many of the 20-year contracts with the landlords are coming to an end. Renewal will be hugely expensive. 
 The amount of money that the Government is turning over to landlords is often well above market rates. The high rents are often necessary to generate enough money for the landlords so they can pay off their mortgages. Washington is caught in a vise. If it tries to control the program's costs by reducing the rent subsidies, it may bankrupt the landlords, forcing them to default on their government-insured mortgages. To keep landlords in the program, Congress has to either maintain high rent subsidies or pay off some of the mortgages. Either way, costs are high. If Congress refuses to fork over the money, more than four million people will face sky-high rents or eviction next year alone.
The Administration has proposed a constructive solution. For next year, it asks Congress for an additional $5.6 billion, a 30 percent increase, in the Housing Department's budget. It is asking Congress for money to issue an additional 50,000 vouchers for the rising number of low-income families who cannot afford market rents. The Administration is also asking Congress for legal authority to pay off part of the mortgage of near-bankrupt landlords and to cut down excessive rent subsidies by renegotiating mortgages of landlords before they come due, perhaps offering the landlords tax breaks as an incentive.
Section 8 is the housing lifeline of seven million poor Americans, most of whom hold jobs and do everything taxpayers could ask. The program relies on the private market to solve the housing shortage of low-rent units. The program also has an admirable history. It gave landlords an incentive to rent to minorities and thereby chipped away at segregated housing patterns in both the North and South.
One danger is that Congress will balk at giving the Administration the budget and legal authority it needs, thus letting the program wither. Another is that it will tell the Administration to preserve Section 8 subsidies but find the billions elsewhere in the department's budget. That too would be unacceptable. The department has become, sadly, the repository of the only programs targeted on cities. A time when Congress is stripping blighted neighborhoods of Medicaid, welfare, food stamps and disability payments is no time to take away the only remaining trickle of Federal dollars to poor neighborhoods.

HEADLINE: Labor's New Organizing Tactic

 BODY:
American labor leaders are developing a new tactic to boost union membership. Frustrated by repeated losses in secret-ballot elections to determine whether companies must accept a union, key labor leaders now want to go for voluntary recognition without a formal election. In exchange they would offer managers the prospect of labor peace and even workplace concessions. As a desperate effort to thwart management's stunningly successful opposition to unionization elections, the new tactic makes sense. But the tactic is not likely to reverse labor's 20-year slide because managers will still be able to manipulate the ballot process in ways the labor laws never intended.
Under current law, unions must round up signatures from 30 percent of a workplace's employees on pro-union cards to trigger a Government-supervised secret ballot, whose outcome is determined by a majority of the votes cast. In practice, labor organizers usually try to get at least 70 percent of the workers to sign these cards in order to end up with more than 50 percent of the secret ballot. There is always a dropoff between the cards and the final vote. Management may persuade many workers to change their minds, for example, and some workers who actually oppose unionization sign cards to avoid confrontation with their peers, and then vote their hearts on the secret ballot. 
 But some companies use shameful tactics to thwart protections built into labor laws. They use legal tricks to delay ballots for years, fire union organizers with impunity and, once a union wins recognition, refuse to negotiate a first contract.
Secret ballots are not yielding many victories. Thus some union leaders now want to focus instead on voluntary agreements. The idea is to get more than half of a workplace to sign pro-union cards -- well under the 70 percent it usually takes to win an election -- and then ask management for voluntary recognition. The bait offered might include some contract concessions and uninterrupted labor peace. These would be accompanied by the threat of a labor-led campaign to pressure the company through demonstrations, boycotts or other tactics. The new approach has worked at Las Vegas hotels and Levi Strauss.
But most managers exert too much control over the current balloting process to accede to voluntary recognition. Sensible reforms could make elections fairer. The secret ballots could be conducted in a timely fashion without waiting to resolve all legal challenges by management. Speedy injunctions could reinstate union organizers who have been inappropriately fired, and binding arbitration could be used to break an impasse over the initial contract. But Republican leaders, still smarting from organized labor's campaign to boot them out of office, are hardly inclined to reshape the system to give labor a fair shake.
Labor leaders complain that their right to organize is being thwarted by fear and economic intimidation. Management complains that labor laws often impose irrational restrictions, preventing them from creating productivity teams at work or compensating workers, if they prefer, with time off instead of extra pay for overtime. In a less partisan time, Congress would pass evenhanded reforms. That will not happen soon, leaving labor unions on their own. Their shift toward voluntary recognition does no one harm. After all, it is voluntary. But more will be needed to right the grievous imbalance in some of the nation's workplaces.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Limited Faith in the Nation's Productivity

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
For weeks, Alan Greenspan has been saying that the nation's productivity is greater than the statistics acknowledge. American workers, the Federal Reserve chairman suggested, were managing to produce ever greater amounts of goods and services, thus avoiding the shortages and inflation that so often come with a strong expansion. Just last Thursday, Mr. Greenspan told Congress that Fed policy makers would have to decide whether the expansion "will continue to be met by solid productivity growth."
Mr. Greenspan had given plenty of hints that he and his fellow policy makers would raise interest rates. But he had also spoken optimistically about productivity, and that had left open the possibility that he just might let a strong economy run. Rather than raise rates to discourage spending and cut back economic growth, the Fed would count instead on rising productivity to keep the economy safely supplied and free of inflation. Yesterday's decision dashed that hope. Mr. Greenspan, who dominates policy-making at the Fed, announced, in effect, that his faith in productivity had its limits. 
 "He is not willing to bet on productivity," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street firm. "Whatever the productivity story, when demand is strong, and inflation a possibility, Mr. Greenspan goes back to his old instincts, which are hawkish."
Mr. Greenspan had opened the door to a rate increase by arguing recently that temporary factors had played a role in staving off inflation, but these temporary factors seemed likely to disappear. He cited, for example, falling health care costs, job insecurity and a strong dollar that made imports inexpensive. He also drew a distinction between gains in productivity over the last year or so, and gains still to come. Going forward, productivity might fall short, he suggested, particularly at a moment when consumer demand is so strong.
If this strong demand "does not seem likely to be matched by productivity improvement," Mr. Greenspan told Congress last week, then he and his colleagues might have to act. They did, yesterday.
Still, Mr. Greenspan's optimism about productivity, set forth in recent speeches and testimony, is likely to reappear. It helped to explain why the Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady for more than a year. "He is not walking away from the notion that productivity has improved," said Chris Varvares of Macroeconomic Advisers, an economic consulting firm.
But he did flinch yesterday, in the view of many corporate executives, who insist that their downsizings, their reorganizations, their computerization and their other efficiencies have bolstered productivity. Productivity has risen, the National Association of Manufacturers said in a statement yesterday critical of the Fed's rate increase, because of "technological advances and increases in efficiency from new production processes."
Productivity is key to prosperity, which has two main ingredients. One is the labor force. When it grows, because of population growth and immigration, then there are more workers to produce the goods and services that Americans demand. But labor force growth has been a meager 1 percent a year.
The other main ingredient is productivity, or output per worker in a given hour. Circumstances and equipment play a big role here. Given the right mix, output has risen more quickly in some decades than others. Since 1973, however, the rise in output has also been meager, averaging just more than 1 percent a year, according to Government statistics. The total of labor force and output growth -- averaging a bit over 2 percent a year since 1973, and less in recent years -- is considered to be the ceiling at which the economy can expand. If the economy grows more quickly, then shortages develop and prices are driven up.
The economy's growth in the current six-year-old expansion, however, has averaged 2.6 percent annually, and higher in recent months. But no shortages have appeared, and inflation has remained subdued, despite the weak productivity growth registered in Government statistics.
Mr. Greenspan, however, rejects the statistics as inaccurate, offering several arguments. One involves the Consumer Price Index, which is used to calculate productivity. If a "faulty" C.P.I. overstates inflation, as Mr. Greenspan argues, then the published productivity rate understates productivity. The math leaves no other choice, he says.
Then there is technology, and the stories the corporate executives tell. "Certainly, the judgment that aggregate productivity has been growing faster than indicated by the official statistics seems reasonable," Mr. Greenspan said, "in light of the significant business restructurings and extraordinary improvements in technology in recent years."
Manufacturing productivity has indeed been rising handsomely, the Government data show. But that means productivity in the much harder to measure service sector must be shrinking. Mr. Greenspan rejects this conclusion. How can that be, he says, when service companies have been so profitable. Two Fed economists produced a study last fall that said as much -- a study Mr. Greenspan cites, ignoring another study by Fed economists that raises doubts about improvements in the nation's productivity.
Still, for all his emerging convictions about productivity, he did not insist on them yesterday. "I don't know why he makes these productivity arguments," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm. "He has argued against what he wants to do."

HEADLINE: Backers of Rival Health Tests Fight to Get Medicare Dollars

SERIES: SPECIAL PLEADERS: A look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Legislation to expand Medicare coverage of preventive health services is all the rage on Capitol Hill as Republicans and Democrats trumpet the value of tests to detect breast cancer, prostate cancer, diabetes and other diseases.
But behind the scenes, lobbyists are waging a shadowy, fierce battle to win the Government's imprimatur for some tests while denying coverage for others. At stake are millions of patients' lives and billions of dollars in revenues for doctors and medical-supply companies. 
 The debate over testing for one particularly deadly disease, colorectal cancer, illustrates how Congress grapples with such issues, which raise complex questions of science, economics and politics.
Gastroenterologists say they can best detect cancers, and the benign polyps that can turn malignant, by inspecting the colon with a fiber-optic instrument in a procedure known as a colonoscopy.
Radiologists say they can spot the abnormalities just as well by taking X-rays of the large intestine filled with a barium solution that shows up on film. The largest maker of barium products used in the X-ray procedure, E-Z-EM, says that test is cheaper and safer than the colonoscopy but just as effective.
Each side has lined up a politically well-connected law firm to argue the case, knowing that private insurers and health plans often follow the example set by Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled.
The American College of Gastroenterology has hired the law firm of Patton Boggs here to obtain Medicare coverage of colonoscopy as a screening procedure.
E-Z-EM, of Westbury, L.I., has hired the law firm of Manatt Phelps Phillips, which has a large office here, to obtain coverage of barium X-rays for screening.
A Congressional aide who spoke on the condition of anonymity said, "You'd think barium was gold, the way they've lobbied on this."
Daniel R. Martin, president of E-Z-EM, said: "Barium is not gold. It's a product that happens to be opaque and inert and exceedingly safe, much safer than colonoscopy. I won't allow anyone in my family to have a colonoscopy if they can get a barium examination."
Mr. Martin wants Medicare to cover barium exams and colonoscopies "on an equal footing" so doctors and patients can choose whichever they prefer.
But Dr. Seymour Katz of Great Neck, L.I., a former president of the American College of Gastroenterology, said: "We have overwhelming evidence to show that colonoscopy is the best screening device for high-risk patients. The barium lobby, the companies that sell products used in barium X-ray procedures, have, in my view, placed their own commercial interests ahead of the best interests of patients."
Colorectal cancer is the second-leading cause of death from cancer in the United States, killing 55,000 people a year. It strikes men and women in roughly equal numbers. Doctors say it is largely preventable because most colorectal cancers develop slowly over many years from benign polyps. Finding and removing these polyps radically reduces the risk of such cancer.
David M. Klaus, a lawyer at Manatt Phelps who lobbies for E-Z-EM, said: "There is some pretty tough politics going on here. I've never seen a medical specialty group campaign so vigorously to knock out a competitor."
Mr. Martin of E-Z-EM said: "Colonoscopies account for a very significant part of gastroenterologists' income. The gastroenterologists have made a very determined effort on Capitol Hill to exclude barium procedures. And they have misrepresented the effectiveness of these procedures."
The College of Gastroenterology and Patton Boggs insist that colonoscopy is the preferred method of screening, especially among blacks, who are much more likely than whites to die of colon cancer. And they say the fight over barium may confuse Congress and jeopardize the passage of legislation providing colorectal screening for the 38 million people covered by Medicare.
But Dr. C. Daniel Johnson, a radiologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said the barium examination was "the most cost-effective way of screening for colorectal cancer" and should at least be available to Medicare patients as an option.
Medicare now covers these procedures for treatment but not screening. The Medicare fee schedule for 1995 shows that the Government paid $131 for an X-ray examination and $434 for a colonoscopy with removal of tumors or polyps.
Dr. Johnson, the chairman of the colon cancer committee of the American College of Radiology, said: "I hope this legislation doesn't get bogged down because of disputes over these techniques. Let's hope the patient doesn't lose in the end."
Each side has inundated Congressional offices with articles from medical journals to support the use of its preferred technique.
President Clinton; Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California, and Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, have all proposed wider Medicare coverage of preventive services, including colon cancer tests, and their proposals have broad bipartisan support. But the proposals differ on details.
Representative Norman Sisisky, Democrat of Virginia, has an intense interest in the issue because his own colon cancer was detected in a routine screening two years ago. He praised Mr. Thomas's efforts, but faulted his bill on the ground that it would not immediately cover barium X-ray tests, which Mr. Sisisky described as "one of the most cost-effective screening procedures currently available."
Mr. Sisisky's cancer was found by colonoscopy in August 1995. He had surgery, and doctors then performed barium X-ray tests to confirm that the operation had been successful.
On the other hand, Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., a professor of surgery at the Howard University College of Medicine, said colonoscopy was "the best means presently available for detecting and preventing colorectal cancer." With that test, Dr. Leffall said, a physician can remove cancerous and precancerous growths as they are identified, with no need for separate surgery later. But "barium X-ray has not been well established for colorectal cancer screening in either the average-risk or high-risk populations," he said.
In a newsletter summarizing the issue, the College of Gastroenterology said it was resisting a compromise with "the barium lobby," fearing that private health plans would cite Medicare to justify "selection of lower-cost barium enema instead of colonoscopy for high-risk patients."

HEADLINE: Toyota to Sell Hybrid-Power Car in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 25

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would become the first company to sell a low-polluting hybrid vehicle, with both an electric motor and a gasoline engine, to a mass market.
The company, the largest Japanese auto maker, said it would begin selling a compact hybrid car with a 1.5-liter engine in Japan this year. Executives said they had no immediate plans to sell the vehicles in the United States, though that is a possibility later. "We are very confident about what this offers," said Akihiro Wada, an executive vice president of Toyota, "but we would like to get reaction and criticism by testing it in the Japanese market first." 
 Hybrid vehicles significantly reduce emissions compared with gasoline-powered cars but are far more practical than fully electric cars. They cannot achieve the zero-emission level of the fully electric car, which California regulators have been seeking. But many auto engineers believe that the hybrid approach represents a reasonable compromise.
Toyota estimates that its hybrid car will get 66 miles a gallon of gasoline in Japanese fuel-economy tests, twice the efficiency of a similar-size Corolla. Emissions of carbon dioxide would be cut in half, and those of carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides reduced 90 percent.
Many other companies are working on hybrid vehicles. Detroit's Big Three -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- are pursuing them, in an effort partly financed by the Department of Energy, to develop a high-efficiency supercar. Audi, a division of Volkswagen, is said to have a hybrid car using a diesel engine ready for sale later this year, and Renault has also announced hybrid technology.
Until recently, much of the emphasis in cutting automotive air pollution had focused on fully electric vehicles, because California was requiring that 2 percent of the cars sold there beginning in the 1998 model year have zero-emission levels.
But last year, with auto makers insisting that it would be a long time until it was possible to make an electric vehicle that would satisfy consumers, California dropped that deadline, though it is still aiming for 10 percent of vehicles sold in 2003 to have no emissions.
Takehisa Yaegashi, chief engineer for Toyota's hybrid system, said the company hoped that California might further relax its requirements and accept hybrid vehicles instead of electric ones.
General Motors in December began offering an electric vehicle in California and Arizona, but has sold only a few dozen a month. The Honda Motor Company, Toyota and possibly others are expected to begin sales of electric vehicles in California this year.
The hybrid vehicles could avoid a major shortcoming of fully electric ones -- the limited range of the batteries. G.M.'s electric vehicle goes only about 90 miles before the battery must be recharged, a process that takes about three hours.
But the hybrid vehicle can also travel farther because it uses gasoline. And energy from the gasoline engine can recharge the battery while the car is in motion, so that no external recharging is needed.
Hybrids can achieve high efficiency and low pollution because of the way they combine dissimilar propulsion systems. Gasoline systems are good for quick refueling, but get zero miles a gallon when the car is idling; in a hybrid, that energy can be converted to current for the batteries. And if the engine runs at a constant speed, the antipollution system can operate at most efficient levels for that speed.
Electric systems are clean and powerful but rely on slow recharging, which is cumbersome if the car has to stand still. And the gasoline engines used in hybrids can be small and light, because they do not have to be big enough to meet peak demand -- acceleration to highway speeds; for that, they can get help from the electric motor.
Because hybrid cars can get by with smaller batteries, they also should cost significantly less than fully electric cars, Toyota executives said. They would not disclose the price of their new car, but said they aimed to keep it no more than about $4,000 more expensive than a similar-size conventional car, implying a price of less than $20,000 for a compact model. By contrast, the G.M. electric vehicle, which seats only two people, has a price of $34,000.
Toyota officials suggested that they expected to sell significantly more hybrid vehicles than the several hundred a year electric cars that most makers expect to sell. But they would not announce a sales target and conceded that the hybrid car's higher price compared with conventional cars would limit sales.
In Toyota's hybrid vehicle, power from the gasoline engine is split into two paths -- one directly turning the wheels and the other operating an electric generator. The generator's electricity output can be used to turn a motor that drives the wheels, or to charge the battery. The proportion of power allocated to each path is automatically adjusted to achieve maximum efficiency.
When the car is started and moving slowly, only the electric motor is used because gasoline engines operate inefficiently at such low speeds. In normal driving the gasoline engine is used, perhaps assisted by the electric motor during acceleration. When the car is slowed, the gasoline engine is shut off and the momentum of revolving wheels helps recharge the nickel-metal hydride battery.
Toyota is not banking solely on hybrids but is pursuing many different technologies for increasing fuel efficiency and lowering emissions, such as lean-burning gasoline engines, electric vehicles and cars that use other kinds of fuel.

HEADLINE: Mobutu Offers to Share Rule; Some See Ploy to Keep It

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 25

 BODY:
In the first public admission that Mobutu Sese Seko is losing his hold on a country ripped by civil war, his spokesmen said that the longtime dictator is willing to negotiate an end to the fighting and share power with the rebels.
Speaking on national television tonight, Mr. Mobutu's spokesman, Kabuya Lumuna Sando, said that Mr. Mobutu has formed a negotiating team with full power to represent him and has called on the Parliament to nominate a Prime Minister and form a transitional government. And the second-ranking official in Mr. Mobutu's party, Banza Mukalay, also said tonight, "We have decided to share power, including with the rebellion, during a transition period." 
 But political specialists here said that Mr. Mobutu, who has managed to outmaneuver his opponents since his supreme rule was challenged in 1991, may be simply trying to buy himself more time in what looks like an increasingly doomed effort to cling to power.
"This is clearly a preparatory step," said a Western diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Mobutu knows that his days are numbered, and he is trying to prolong them."
The rebel alliance, which already controls the eastern third of the country and is poised to take Lubumbashi, Zaire's second-largest city, rejected Mr. Mobutu's overture and warned that it would treat as an enemy anyone who accepted the post of Prime Minister in a Mobutu Government.. On Sunday, Mr. Mobutu made his first public appearance and promised that in the next 48 hours he would have a plan to stop the rebels' attempt to overthrow his government. The rebels, known as the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo, have rejected international pressure for a cease-fire and confidently proclaimed that they will win the war by marching into this sprawling capital city by June.
The rebels are said to be about 100 miles from Lubumbashi.
While, it is clear to almost everyone that the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, will win the war, he faces a greater political fight whenever he invades this capital city. Mr. Kabila has announced that he would not let any existing political party participate in a transitional government.
Mr. Kabila's move to exclude opposition leaders, particularly Etienne Tshisekedi, from the Government, does not sit well with people here. While Mr. Tshisekedi enjoys strong backing, many here in recent days have come to view Mr. Kabila suspiciously as a potential second incarnation of Mr. Mobutu.
"We've been fighting for democracy for years," said Alphonse Lupumba Kamanda, president of the Republican Front, which supports Mr. Tshisekedi. "If Kabila can put an end to dictatorship, then we say yes. But if he comes with his guns, we will say no. We can't chase one dictator only to end up with another."
But Western officials here said that Mr. Tshisekedi's moment to lead Zaire is well behind him. "I don't think Tshisekedi is a player," said a senior Western diplomat. "You see his press saying it has to be settled by sitting Mobutu, Tshisekedi and Kabila around a table. But I don't think Kabila sees any reason to deal Tshisekedi into the game."
Zaire's war began last October, when Zairian ethnic Tutsi began an uprising in the eastern border region. The rebel movement was widely believed to have had the backing of Rwanda, Uganda, and Angola, all countries with scores to settle with Mr. Mobutu for having supported uprisings in their own country.
After weeks of empty declarations from the Government, Mr. Mobutu could have seized the occasion to name a Prime Minister today, particularly Mr. Tshisekedi, who led the Government twice during 1993, Zairian leaders and people on the street interviewed here said.
The crisis is being hotly debated today in the streets of Kinshasa, the capital. Throughout most of the day, the residents were anticipating a bolder move from the dictator, who is suffering from advanced prostate cancer. Many people said they had been expecting him to announce his resignation, or at least to name a Prime Minister.
So tonight when Mr. Mobutu failed to appear in person, there was deep disappointment.
In bars in the working class neighborhood of Matonga, at the university and on the streets, people said they had been expecting Mr. Mobutu to announce his resignation.
"I want Mobutu to go," said Paul Tsimva, 40, an unemployed civil servant. "He has done nothing for the country except to enrich his friends and his cronies."
Such talk, which never would have been heard here during the years when Mr. Mobutu was the unquestioned ruler, was echoed over and over.
The stage was set for a challenge to Mr. Mobutu in 1991 after Zaire's economy nearly collapsed, forcing Western donors to intervene politically here. Mr. Mobutu reluctantly agreed to share power then, but by manipulating divisions in the opposition, he managed to avoid actually doing so until the civil war erupted in the eastern region.
"Mr. Mobutu must exit the political stage gracefully," said an African diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "But that is difficult in our continent. After 30 years in power it is difficult to accept defeat."

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE LIFTS A KEY RATE; FIRST RISE SINCE '95

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to raise interest rates for the first time in more than two years, firing a warning shot at an inflationary threat that remained hidden over the horizon.
The central bank took one of the smallest steps it could, nudging up the more important of the two short-term rates it controls -- the Federal funds target rate for overnight loans between banks -- by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. In doing so, it was trying to keep the economy from growing so fast that it generates wage and price pressures strong enough to threaten the nation's six-year economic expansion. 
 Because banks tie their benchmark loan rates to the Federal funds rate, today's action will ripple through the economy, probably curbing investment and consumption somewhat by increasing the rates charged for many business and personal loans and for credit cards.
The move was applauded as tempered but appropriate by a number of Wall Street and academic economists, many of whom say the current combination of strong growth and low unemployment will ultimately lead to a resurgence of inflation unless action is taken to slow the economy. They said the Federal Reserve was likely to keep trying to fine-tune the economy by raising rates at least once or twice more this year.
"What the Fed did today is about right," said Paul A. McCulley, an economist at UBS Securities.
But with few signs that rising prices are actually infecting the economy, the move drew criticism from a significant minority of economists as well as from labor unions, business groups and politicians who say that economic statistics overstate the threats to steady growth and that such factors as global competition and fear of layoffs have permanently damped inflationary forces.
"By increasing short-term interest rates even though there is no evidence of accelerating inflation in the actual data," said John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., "the Federal Reserve has sacrificed the economic interests of America's working families on the basis of a hunch that's about as scientific as reading tea leaves."
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, had dropped broad hints about the central bank's intentions last week, taking some of the sting out of today's move for the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 6,876.17, down 29.08 points. It rose more than 40 points immediately after the Fed's announcement at 2:15 P.M, but then plunged a few minutes later. Bond prices fell, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 6.96 percent, and the dollar increased in value against other major currencies.
Big lenders like Citibank and the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis immediately followed the Federal Reserve's action by raising their prime rates to 8.5 percent from 8.25 percent. The longer-term rates set by the financial markets -- such as those that govern mortgage rates and auto loans -- had already moved up in recent months as investors anticipated today's action.
The Federal Reserve's other monetary policy tool, the little-used and largely symbolic discount rate for loans from the Federal Reserve system to banks, was left unchanged today at 5 percent.
In his nine and a half years as the chairman, Mr. Greenspan has built a reputation as an uncompromising inflation fighter. But over the last year he has surprised many analysts by patiently watching the economy to determine whether it can accommodate strong growth despite an unemployment rate, currently 5.3 percent, that is well below the past levels at which workers began receiving the kind of hefty wage increases that can lead to higher prices.
In raising rates today, Mr. Greenspan not only signaled that his patience with that experiment had run out, but also that he was concerned that growth might be so strong that it could require further rate increases this year, analysts said.
In a statement explaining its action, the Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee said its action "was taken in light of persisting strength in demand, which is progressively increasing the risk of inflationary imbalances developing in the economy that would eventually undermine the long expansion."
The central bank last started a series of rate increases on Feb. 4, 1994, when it made the first of seven moves that pushed the Federal funds rate to 6 percent from 3 percent over the span of a year. In that case, Mr. Greenspan succeeded in squelching any inflationary pressures without choking off growth completely.
Although the situation now is different -- most notably, interest rates relative to inflation are much higher than they were three years ago -- analysts said 1994 had clearly become a model for pre-emptive action at the Federal Reserve.
Economists said Mr. Greenspan had also learned another lesson in 1994, when he sent the financial markets into a tailspin as soon as he started raising rates. This time, Mr. Greenspan has been explicitly warning investors for months that interest rates would have to rise eventually, and he has tried to impose a reality check on investors with his comments about the "irrational exuberance" of the stock market.
Whether Mr. Greenspan will be forced to keep raising rates, economists said, will largely be determined by whether the economy slows substantially from its 3.9 percent growth rate in the fourth quarter of 1996.
Given the economy's record last year of strong growth without serious signs of inflation, critics of Mr. Greenspan's take-no-prisoners approach to inflation spoke out today.
"The Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates was simply wrong," said Paul Huard, senior vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "It will impede economic growth and make life tougher on consumers and job-creating businesses."
But in its statement, the Fed defended its action as "a prudent step that affords greater assurance of prolonging the current economic expansion" because low inflation "is essential to realizing the economy's fullest growth potential."

GRAPHIC: Graphs: The Federal Reserve raised its short-term interest rate -- the Federal funds rate -- for the first time since Feb. 1, 1995. The Federal funds rate is raised to slow economic growth when the Fed wants to restrain inflation. Graph tracks the Federal funds rate, since the third quarter of 1994. (Source: Associated Press) (pg. A1)
 
"Ripple Effects of the Fed's Rate Move"
The Federal Reserve, for the first time in more than two years, increased its short-term interest rate target, lifting it a quarter of a percentage point to 5.5 percent. To some extent, the move had already been anticipated in the markets, where long-term bonds, mortgage rates and bank deposit rates have moved up slightly in recent weeks. But consumer and auto loan rates tend to be much stickier and they have barely budged. The Fed is counting on higher interest rates to help slow the economy enough to keep a lid on inflation. Graphs track bond yields, bank deposits, mortgages and consumer loan rates, since the beginning of 1995. (Sources: Bank Rate Monitor; Datastream; Associated Press) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Judge Orders Assessments For Workfare Recipients

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A State Supreme Court justice has told the city to stop assigning welfare recipients to workfare programs unless it first does a full assessment of recipients' needs and skills to determine whether they should be put into educational programs instead.
In a setback to the Giuliani administration, Acting Justice Jane S. Solomon of State Supreme Court in Manhattan issued an injunction on Monday after making a preliminary finding that the administration was violating state law by assigning many welfare recipients to its Work Experience Program without doing proper individual assessments. 
 The injunction was in response to a lawsuit brought by six welfare recipients who say that the city -- which calls in more than 3,000 welfare recipients for possible workfare assignments each month -- is undermining their prospects for jobs and economic advancement by not assessing their needs and by steering them away from education. Workfare does not, they say, provide them with valuable training or experience.
"The judge wants to see a genuine process in which an honest attempt is made to determine what an individual needs and to improve his or her chances of becoming employed," said Christopher Lamb, a senior attorney with the Center on Social Welfare Policy and Law and a lawyer for the plaintiffs. "The injunction rejects the city's current one-size-fits-all approach, that every single person should be placed into workfare."
City officials say that placing welfare recipients into workfare jobs, which often involve cleaning parks or streets, is the best route to permanent employment.
The city had steered the six plaintiffs into its 35,000-person workfare program, by far the largest such program in the country. City officials say they plan to expand the program to between 50,000 and 60,000 recipients by the end of the year.
One of the plaintiffs, a mother of three, had a 3.72 grade point average as she pursued an associate's degree at the College of Staten Island, with the goal of becoming a teacher. She said she was told she had to drop out of school immediately to take a workfare assignment. She refused and had her public assistance cut.
Another plaintiff had her welfare grant cut by 20 percent because she continued with her high school diploma equivalency, or G.E.D., program rather than reporting to her workfare assignment.
Acting Justice Solomon has asked the plaintiffs' lawyers to draft an order that would tell the city exactly what it must do to satisfy the requirements on individual assessments called for by state law. The city would then respond to that proposed order, and the justice would issue the formal order, probably sometime next month.
Paul Crotty, the Corporation Counsel, said it was highly unlikely that the city would appeal the order. However, his office says that the city is in compliance with the law.
"We have to insure that for each client who comes in, the information is properly recorded and all the questions that should be asked are asked," said Muriel Goode-Trufant, the Corporation Counsel lawyer handling the case.
The plaintiffs disagreed, saying that the city largely stopped doing individual assessments a year ago, and Acting Justice Solomon agreed that the city was falling short of what the New York State social services law requires.
Ms. Goode-Trufant, however, said that the judge, in a series of oral decisions from the bench, rejected one of the plaintiffs' arguments: that welfare recipients should be free to choose whether they want to go into an education program or workfare.
Acting Justice Solomon did grant the plaintiffs' motion to expand the lawsuit into a class action that includes not just the six plaintiffs, but all current and future welfare recipients considered for workfare.

HEADLINE: Roberto Sanchez Vilella, 84, Puerto Rican Governor, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Roberto Sanchez Vilella, the somber, efficient, bespectacled technocrat who in 1964 became Puerto Rico's second elected Governor and then shocked the Commonwealth with an unlikely love affair that left his marriage, party and political career a shambles, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in San Juan. He was 84 and had cancer.
When Luis Munoz Marin, the charismatic figure who had ruled Puerto Rico by virtual fiat, decided to step down after 16 years as Governor, there was no doubt about who would succeed him. 
 Mr. Munoz, a revered figure who is regarded as the father of modern Puerto Rico, had seen to that simply by letting it be known that his choice was Mr. Sanchez, the brilliant administrator who had been his right-hand man for much of his political career.
As a young man, Mr. Sanchez, a native of Mayaguez whose father had been Speaker of the Puerto Rican House of Representatives, had turned his back on politics and on Puerto Rico, obtaining a degree in civil engineering from Ohio State University and accepting a job with the new Tennessee Valley Authority. But Mr. Munoz persuaded him to return to Puerto Rico and devote his talents to the social and economic development of his homeland.
Mr. Sanchez proved so adept at his work and so indispensable to his mentor that when Mr. Munoz organized the Popular Democratic Party and became president of the Puerto Rican Senate in 1940, Mr. Sanchez resigned as city manager of San Juan to become his chief legislative assistant.
Over the next few years, Mr. Sanchez was deeply involved in every Munoz strategy and initiative, from his vaunted Operation Bootstrap, which transformed Puerto Rico from a near feudal agricultural society into a modern industrial state, to his campaign for increased autonomy from the United States.
When Mr. Munoz became the first elected Governor, in 1948, Mr. Sanchez became his chief of staff. It was a measure of his value to the Munoz administration that after Puerto Rico gained full commonwealth status in 1952, Mr. Sanchez served simultaneously as Secretary of State and Secretary of Public Works.
After Mr. Munoz anointed him as his successor, the voters obligingly swept Mr. Sanchez into office with 60 percent of the ballots.
As Governor, Mr. Sanchez continued and expanded the Munoz economic and social programs and promoted younger politicians to the party leadership, stepping on some toes along the way.
But while Mr. Munoz was a gregarious, emotional man who had ruled by the force of his personality, effectively suppressing factionalism within the party, Mr. Sanchez was a colorless administrator in black horn-rimmed glasses who puffed contemplatively on his pipe, gave up his lifelong fascination with horse racing upon taking office and had virtually no political base of his own.
As a result, dissident politicians soon found they were able to form viable factions, which bickered among themselves and undermined Mr. Sanchez's authority, creating some doubts that he could win re-election.
Whatever his chances, Mr. Sanchez, then a 55-year-old grandfather, effectively took himself out of the running in 1967 when he stunned all of Puerto Rico and his largely Roman Catholic constituency by announcing that he was divorcing his wife of 30 years to marry his 35-year-old staff assistant, Jeannette Ramos.
The move was so shattering that although Mr. Sanchez said he would not seek re-election -- a decision that drew swift approval from Mr. Munoz -- his announcement produced a wave of demands that he resign immediately.
Mr. Sanchez not only clung to his office as Mr. Munoz and other party leaders scrambled to find a replacement candidate, he also stunned the nation and his mentor all over again the next year when he announced that he would in fact seek re-election under the banner of a new People's Party, a decision that caused a break with Mr. Munoz that lasted until shortly before his death in 1980.
Mr. Sanchez was swamped in the 1968 election but polled enough votes to sink the Popular Democratic Party candidate as well, handing that party its first defeat for governor. After an abortive race for the legislature in 1972, Mr. Sanchez retired from politics, taught at the University of Puerto Rico, resumed his trips to the track, played dominoes and became a panelist on a television program of political commentary.
Like his first marriage, his second ended in divorce. His survivors include a daughter, Evelyn, from his first marriage, two children from his second, Olga Elizabeth Ramos and Roberto Jose Sanchez, a sister, Olga Sanchez Vilella, and several grandchildren, all of San Juan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Moves to Increase A Key Interest Rate
The Federal Reserve voted to raise interest rates for the first time in more than two years, firing a warning shot at an inflationary threat that remains hidden over the horizon. 
 The central bank raised the Federal funds target rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.50 percent. A number of economists applauded the move, saying that without such action, the economy's growth could eventually lead to price rises. But others said the Fed had acted prematurely, saying there were few signs of inflation and that changes in economic fundamentals had shifted since the last time price increases were a problem. [Page A1.]
 
The last time the Fed began raising rates, bond prices, which had been driven up by speculation, went into a slump. This year, the Fed move will probably have less effect on the financial markets, largely because speculation has been fostered less here than it has been half a world away, by the Japanese central bank. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [A1.]
 
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has been saying that productivity is greater than data show, and that it has prevented the inflation that so often accompanies a strong expansion. But with the rate increase, he announced, in effect, that his faith in productivity had its limits. News analysis. [D5.]
 
Dow Falls 29.08 After Fed Move
Stocks slumped after the Fed moved to raise rates. The Dow industrials fell 29.08 points, to 6,876.17, though they had initially risen after the announcement. [D6.]
 
Bond prices also fell, with the 30-year Treasury's yield rising to 6.96 percent from 6.92 percent. [D16.]
 
Short-sellers, who often intend to profit from declines in stock prices, became more active in recent weeks as the Nasdaq stock market declined sharply. [D18.]
 
A Warning From T.W.A.
Trans World Airlines said that its auditors had included a qualification in the carrier's annual report regarding its "ability to continue as a going concern." The timing of the statement, which came as the company said it wanted to raise $50 million in a private offering, suggested that T.W.A. was simply trying to disclose all risks, but analysts saw another sign of a questionable future. [D4.]
 
$2.8 Billion British Insurance Deal
Prudential of Britain, outbidding two other companies, said that it would buy Scottish Amicable Life Assurance for $2.8 billion. The purchase would make Prudential, which is Britain's largest life insurance company, a more powerful force in selling policies through an independent sales force. [D2.]
 
Consumer Confidence Down a Bit
Americans' confidence in the economy has slipped a bit, though it remains high. The Conference Board said that its index of consumer confidence fell to 118.5 in March from a revised 118.9 in February, which was the highest reading in eight years. [D5.]
 
VF to Buy Maidenform
VF agreed to acquire Maidenform Worldwide for an undisclosed amount, shoring up its position as a leading manufacturer of women's intimate apparel. [D18.]
 
It's Gotta Be the (Old) Shoes
Converse, a former All-Star among sneaker makers that has more recently been consigned to the second team, is turning to the past for its latest marketing effort. In hopes of recapturing a bit of former glory, Converse has developed a line of retro sneakers, recasting classics like the Chuck Taylor canvas high-top as new performance shoes. Advertising. [D3.]
 
Strike Deadline Is Extended
American Airlines said that it and the Allied Pilots Association had agreed to a new timetable in their contract talks that extends the deadline for any possible strike beyond the current date of April 28. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Toasted In China

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
The Vice President stood as still as a terra cotta warrior, facing the cameras in the Great Hall of the People with a fixed smile as the Chinese tossed him bouquets of Buicks and Boeing jet deals worth $2 billion.
But his eyes were darting back and forth. And there, on the periphery of his vision, was a terrifying sight: two women beneath the glistening chandeliers, coming toward him bearing glasses of champagne. 
 He got a Gore-in-the-headlights look, a look that this Vice President, unlike the last, more easily rattled one, rarely gets.
Mr. Gore was outfoxed, maneuvered into a cozy champagne toast at a morning business deal signing ceremony with Li Peng, the man who choreographed the Tiananmen Square massacre. It was the sort of cozy toast that got Brent Scowcroft into trouble when he snuck over not long after the momentous atrocity; the sort of cozy toast that Richard Gephardt is panting to use in a campaign ad in 2000, to suggest that the Clinton Administration's China policy prefers money to morality.
The frazzled Gore crowd clearly underestimated the complexity of this trip and have been caught up in an ever-escalating series of clarifications on diplomatic issues. Yesterday they spent the evening explaining how they got Shanghaied on the toast.
"You rent the room, you get the glasses," Ginny Terzano, Mr. Gore's press secretary, said. But even Leon Fuerth, the Vice President's relentlessly uninformative national security adviser, conceded surprise.
During the marathon negotiations for the trip, the Gore team tried to control every detail and put a news blackout on anything that could seem embarrassing, even American Chamber of Commerce meetings that might include corporate donors. The toasts at Tuesday night's dinner with Mr. Li were cut out, and an Administration official lamely explained that highly unusual action by saying: "This wasn't a banquet. It was just a large social dinner." But it is unthinkable that the Chinese, whose culture is so drenched in protocol, would not have wanted to toast such an honored guest at a formal dinner -- and perhaps leak the pictures, as they did with Mr. Scowcroft.
Besides, Mr. Gore's relationship with Mr. Li is anything but social. Even though the Prime Minister is anxious that the visit go well, so the post-Deng leadership can show it can still get American technology and market share while doing little in return, he could not resist a public jab. He admonished Mr. Gore that the U.S. "should play a more positive role in international affairs."
China resents America for holding up its admission to the World Trade Organization. Many Chinese are also fuming over the assertion in "The Coming Conflict With China," by Richard Bernstein and Ross H. Munro, that China threatens world peace.
Picnicking with the tiger is never easy. But this time it was folly. The Chinese may have tried to buy our Government. They may have tried to use espionage to penetrate the White House through the Democratic fund-raising operation. They may be engaged in a ruthless attempt to transform themselves into a military and economic superpower.
And here is Al Gore reassuring his hosts that, while the Feds are investigating whether the Chinese tried to corrupt Democrats, or whether the Democrats wanted to be corrupted, this will in no way deflect the Clinton Administration from pursuing its policy of engagement with China.
But Mr. Gore wanted it known that he had told the Chinese the Administration was taking the inquiry "seriously" -- to avoid an unfortunate echo of Mr. Scowcroft's secret reassurances that Tiananmen would not derail engagement with China.
When Mr. Fuerth was asked about complaints that the U.S. has little to show on human rights in China, he dismissed the idea "that it's got to be an on-the-barrelhead exchange."
Mr. Gore raised the issue of human rights in a way he considered "vigorous." But he talked more to his hosts about the environment, whipping out his carbon dioxide emission charts for the Prime Minister. ("No, as a matter of fact they were all fascinated," insisted Ms. Terzano.) He opined about the start of civilization, recalling the last ice age, "when humankind moved from hunting and gathering to agriculture" and then to technology.
He might also have pointed out that, at least in other parts of the world, it moved from hunting and gathering to agriculture to technology to human rights.

HEADLINE: Metro News Briefs: NEW YORK STATE;
Proposal to Exempt Home Improvements

 BODY:
Saying that homeowners should not be penalized for improving their houses, the Nassau County Executive yesterday proposed a state law to exempt additions and other improvements from tax assessments.
"Home improvements should stimulate the economy, create jobs and increase sales tax revenues but not increase property taxes," the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said. 
 Mr. Gulotta, who is running for re-election this fall, said his proposal was being introduced in Albany by Senator Norman J. Levy, a Republican, and Assemblyman Harvey Weisenberg, a Democrat.
Under legislation approved by Albany two years ago, the assessment for home improvements is phased in over eight years, making for a more gradual rise in taxes on the property.
Mitchell Pally, vice president for legislative and economic affairs at the Long Island Association, the area's largest business organization, said such a change would have a strong trickle-down impact on the region's economy. "We believe that any potential loss in property tax revenue," he said, "would be more than offset by the economic shot in the arm this change would have, including a boost in sales tax revenues from new home furnishings and appliances."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Racing From Wrenching Calamity to a Clean Slate

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE BIG PICTURE
By Douglas Kennedy
374 pages. Hyperion. $23.95.
 Here's a thriller that will carry you far away for the weekend: "The Big Picture" by Douglas Kennedy.
 Ben and Beth Bradford seem to have the perfect yuppie life together, with their two adorable children and their half-million-dollar New England Colonial on the Connecticut Gold Coast. He's a rising young lawyer specializing in trusts and estates for a Wall Street firm. She's an antiques collector, favoring items with a historical pedigree. Saturday mornings they mellow out by shopping "in that elegant economic fortress called Greenwich." Ben, the narrator, adds: "Natural habitat of the WASP. Impossible on less than $250,000 a year. And, ergo, free of aspiring middle-class mobs. Especially on Saturdays." 
 But all is not well with Ben and Beth these days. Ben actually wanted to be a photographer and became a lawyer only because his father bullied him into achieving. Now Ben's only outlet is collecting expensive photographic equipment. Beth tried to be a novelist, wrote three books, but couldn't get them published. Now she feels trapped by the compromises she and Ben have made.
As the novel opens, she's barely speaking to Ben. And when she does, she frequently lies, about where she's been all day, about where she got this amazing New Zealand sauvignon blanc called Cloudy Bay that she served at dinner. Ben can't bring himself to ask Beth about a fresh scratch on her back. When Ben tries to buy some Cloudy Bay at the local liquor store, the proprietor has never heard of it.
At a neighbors' party on Saturday night, Ben runs into Gary Summers, a man he loathes, in part because Gary lives on a trust fund and works at photography pretentiously if unsuccessfully. Ben sees Gary presenting the host with a bottle of this great new wine he has discovered. Cloudy Bay sauvignon blanc. Many stiff drinks later, Ben sees Beth and Gary touching hands and smiling.
The next evening, recovered from his hangover, Ben drops by Gary's house with the excuse of talking photography. Gary breaks out a bottle of Cloudy Bay. They begin arguing and putting each other down. Gary brazenly admits he's sleeping with Beth. He tells Ben that Beth hates him and ridicules Ben for his sexual failings. Ben takes the bottle of Cloudy Bay and smashes it against Gary's head. Then he stabs the jagged stem into the back of Gary's neck. Geysering blood, Gary falls dead.
Yet believe it or not, "The Big Picture" is not about crime and punishment. It's about second chances and the fantasy so many pressured people entertain of starting over with a clean slate. So instead of going "Dostoevskian," as Ben warns himself not to do, the author takes a plot wrinkle from Patricia Highsmith ("Strangers on a Train," "The Talented Mr. Ripley," among many others) and contrives an elaborate way for Ben to exchange identities.
On the verge of committing suicide out of guilt, Ben happens to see a televangelist exhorting his audience to be born again by accepting Jesus. Ben reflects: "Yes, I must die. For there is no other way out. But after I am dead, why can't I live anew? Why can't I have that second chance? Why shouldn't I be born again?
"The more I considered it, the more clearly I realized: You don't need Jesus to be reborn. You need a lot of careful planning."
The planning is done with great precision and is carried out so that each of its elements sticks in the reader's mind like that bottle of Cloudy Bay. It involves an I.B.M. Thinkpad, a jeweler's hammer, a cookbook recipe, a pair of surgical gloves and sundry other equipment.
Yet what happens is handled with surprising sensitivity, too, particularly considering Mr. Kennedy's punchy prose and his brutal, edge-of-the-seat plot. For instance, a day before the murder, Ben discovers that he has actually taken a worthwhile photograph, of "a hefty middle-aged man -- treble-chinned, his suit crumpled -- emerging from the doors of the New York Stock Exchange, his eyes as wide and fearful as those of a deer blinking into the headlights of an oncoming truck."
Yet on closer examination of "this image of bloated midlife crisis," Ben notices "a flaw in the print: the broker appeared to be shadowed by a second image." That "lurking phantom" will figuratively take on flesh on Mr. Kennedy's plot.
His story is not perfect. As hateful as Beth is, one finds it hard to believe that a woman claiming such integrity would so willingly tear her family apart. The plot teases you several times with threats that turn out to be completely beside the point. The dialogue is sometimes so breezy that small-craft warnings go up. And the ending strains credibility almost to the point of breaking the narrative's spell.
Still, so much of "The Big Picture" is done so well that you ignore its flaws and race through it, hoping it will never end. Mr. Kennedy is an American (born in New York City in 1955) who has lived in Ireland and Britain for the last 20 years, writing radio plays and books. "The Big Picture" is his first novel to be published in the United States. When you finish it, you reflect that while a picture may be worth a thousand words, the author has taken the whole subject of pictures and made them worth an entire transfixing novel.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Douglas Kennedy. (Sigrid Estrada/Hyperion)
